column2: PARIS, Oct. 25--The North Atlantic Treaty Organization's group of 14--all members except France--decided today on moving the alliance's political headquarters to Brussels.

BONN, Oct. 25--The trial of 16 former Nazi officials charged with murdering or complicity in the murders of thousands of Jews in the forced labor camp at Lvov began today in Stuttgart, West Germany. Lvov was part of Poland but now is in the Soviet Union.
MANILA, Oct. 25--The Allies' offer today to withdraw troops from south Vietnam if North Vietnam does the same seems to be based on a premise that observers have found open to serious question.
Miss Carole F. Schwartz, daughtgr of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Schwartz of Kings Point, L.I., was married yesterday morning to S. Gordon Hyatt, son of Mr. and Mrs. S.G. Hyatt of Lee, Mass.
POMONA, N.J., Oct. 25-- The Federal Aviation Agency today began the first tests in its investigation of wake turbulence--the trail of swirling air made by an airplane.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 25--Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. sought maximum exposure today before the state's undecided voters, who he believes are greater in number this year than in any other race for Governor.
Voters in midtown Manhattan are fortunate to have a choice between two good candidates for the City Council in the coming election.

The Wheeling Steel Corporation has announced the appointment of Robert E. Wright as vice president of engineering, effective next Tuesday. At the same time, Earl V. Akerlow, who has been director of engineering, will be promoted to the post of technical assistant to the president.

Bill Steinkraus, with Snowbound and Kathy Kusner, with Aberali, scored triumphs yes-, terday that stamped the United States as the team to beat in the international jumping events of the National Horse Show, which opened at Madison Square Garden for eight days of competition.

WHEN Sidney Harth plays the violin, one never wonders about the possibility of mishaps. There is something about the way the man works with the instrument that makes you know everything is going to be played perfectly, or at least about as perfectly as any human being could do it.

SUMMIT, N.J., Oct. 25-- Carl H. Fister of 103 Beekman Road, former vice president of the Chesebrough Building Company of New York, died yesterday at his home after a short illness. He was 74 years old and retired in 1959.

"We're sitting on the edge of our seats until the end of the year because of the possibility of numerous bankruptcies in the apparel industry," Charles L. Harding, president of the Meinhard-Commercial Corporation, asserted yesterday.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., Oct. 25 (AP)--Underfed body cells, in urgent need of special nutrients not contained in ordinary diets, may be the cause of all apparently noninfectious diseases such as muscular dystrophy, a University of Texas scientist said today.
ABERFAN, Wales, Oct. 25 (AP)--A tiny coffin with a single spray of red roses was cairied through the rubblestrewn streets of Aberfan today. Miners stood with bowed heads. Some wept.
Reports that more sugar was available in Britain and elsewhere in Europe at low prices depressed world sugar futures here.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 (AP)--The unbeaten Philadelphia 76ers routed the victoryless Baltimore Bullets, 130-110, in a National Basketball Association game tonight, with Hal Greer and Wilt Chamberlain leading the victors' barrage.
Two men were arrested last night on extortion charges involving eight textile salesmen who had allegedly bought stolen merchandise.
The Norfolk Western Railway announced yesterday improved third-quarter earnings and record nine-month profits.

LONDON, Oct. 25--When Emrys Hughes stalked out of the House of Commons today, he carried the sympathies of other Laborites who feel that the Labor Government's economic policies hit the working man unduly hard.
Dan Curtis, an independent producer, has acquired the television rights to 32 plays by Eugene O'Neill.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Political and Security Com mittee--Heard statements on halting spread of nuclear weapons by Togo, Britain, United Arab Republic, Rwanda and Czechoslovakia.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 25 (UPI) --Norman R. Klug, president of the Miller Brewing Company, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.
GUATEMALA, Oct. 25--Six persons identified by the police as guerrillas were captured by the police last night after a wild chase through downtown streets in this city.
SINGAPORE, Oct. 25--Prime Minister Abdul Rahman of Malays warned today against picketing and demonstrations during the visit of President Johnson on Sunday.
NOW that it is legal to bag a deer in the Northern Zone of New York, at least some hunters will wind up an otherwise good hunt by losing their venison in one way or another.

His voice teacher, Seth Riggs, was at the piano and Tim Brown, the star halfback of the Philadelphia Eagles, was singing. His voice, which he describes as "somewhere beteen baritone and tenor," was booming through the room. Suddenly, he winced and stopped.
A 9-year-old girl has won a $275,000 malpractice verdict against the city more than four years after a penicillin injection she received in a municipal hospital partly crippled her.
The City University, which announced Monday night that it would establish a new senior college, hopes to name a president of the institution "very soon."
TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 25 (AP) --The Newspaper Guild joined printer today in a strike that shut down The Toledo Blade and The Morning Times.

Meadow Lenco, a 15-1, shot, drew post position No. 1 yesterday for the $169,885.24 Messenger Stakes, a pace for 3year-olds with the largest purse in harness racing history. The race will be held Saturday night at Roosevelt Raceway.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 25--Charles Howard Levitt, a lawyer who formerly had an office at 274 Madison Avenue, New York, died here last night in his home at 27 Claremont Avenue. His age was 82.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 25 (Reuters)--Dr. Ahdullah Yaffi, Premier and Finance Minister of Lebanon, inaugurated today the Trans Orient Bank here. This is a joint ventur a between the International Sank of Washington and a number of Lebanese and other Arab investors. (The International Bank is a private American banking corporation operating largely overseas and is not to be confused with the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
The Department of Parks halted the care of 500,000 trees on city streets yesterday and ordered its 245 tree surgeons to work only on the two million trees within parks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--The National Republican Congressional Committee, responding to charges of unfair campaign tactics, has advised Republican candidates for the House to stop using an altered tape recording that it sent to them last month.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 25 --The head of the nation's leading medical research complex today cited what he called mistakes in developing a polio vaccine to show that research must march hand-in-hand with basic scientific knowledge.
GIBRALTAR, Oct. 25--Spain shut the iron gates at the neck of the Gibraltar isthmus at midnight to complete the isolation of the British colony of Gibraltar from the mainland.

MERIDIAN, Miss., Oct. 25 (UPI)--A multimillion-dollar libel suit stemming from arti cles dealing with the slaying of three civil rights workers near Philadelphia, Miss., in 1964 has been settled for $3,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25 (AP)--A $31-million damage suit charging James J. Saxon, Controller. of the currency, with fraud and deceit in the closing of the San Francisco National Bank was filed today in United States District Court.

Almost all of the 113 decisions of the new Civilian Complaint Review Board in its first three months have been unanimous; and in the handful of disagreements the board has never split on the basis of its divided civilian and police membership.

WARSAW, Oct. 25--Informed Polish sources reported today that nine Communist nations at their conference in Moscow last week were in general agreement on the need to soften North Vietnam's stand on peace terms.

William S. Wesson, manager of the Scott Paper Company's special product division, declared yesterday that about 80 per cent of the effort on new products was being applied to projects doomed to failure.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 25--Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Osgood have announced the engagement of them daughter, Miss Pamela Osgood of New York, to Charles Francis Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Adams of Mobile, Ala.
A new trend of public opinion toward further peace efforts in Vietnam favors Democratic rather than Republican Congressional candidacies, a Louis Harris poll in The Near York Post reported yesterday.

"Never mind, Jimmy," a friend shouted to the man who led Alhambra Pal into the winner's circle after the second race at Aqueduct yesterday. "He win it, and that's the main thing." It seemed unusual that a winner should have to be consoled. But then, it's unusual when an owner wins a race but loses his entire stable.
The American Stock Exchange closed with slight losses yesterday after a late rally failed to wipe out most of the earlier losses.
A wave of favorable earnings reports and dividend actions by major corporations carried the stock market to another advance yesterday.
The City Council voted yesterday to increase the maximum fine for Httering from $25 to $100 and the maximum jail sentence from 10 to 30 days. Both a fine and a jail term may be imposed.

A two-day strike for back pay and better working conditions by 600 Welfare Department investigators ended yesterday after the city pledged to provide the professional-level workers with new office space, desks, chairs and an "acceptable ratio of telephones per worker."
LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 25 (UPI)--Jim Ryun, the 19-yearold holder of the world record in the mile run, has a sore back that hurts when he runs downhill.

MOSCOW, Oct. 25 (Reuters) --The Soviet press agency Tass said tonight that the countries participating in the Manila conference could not hide the fact that their real aim was to continue and broaden "the aggression" in Vietnam.
New York City had to pay an interest rate of 4.759 per cent yesterday to borrow $123,330,000--the highest rate it has been charged in 34 years.

PARIS--Greece's imaginative genius has been limitless since the days when it raised the Parthenon an a forbidding outcrop and sponsored Pericles, Phydias and Plato. Now once again it displays a capacity to manufacture Olympian fantasies. I refer to the current political crisis deriving from a column I wrote Oct. 5.
The W.T. Grant Company, a large general merchandise chain, announced here yesterday the election of Harry E. Pierson to the new post of vice president for store expansion.

A rosy aspect was visible yesterday in dividend actions as R.H. Macy Co. announced an increase in its quarterly dividend and a number of concerns in other industries took similar action. Stock dividends were also declared by several companies.
City plans for a "showcase" containership terminal on the eastern shore of Staten Island were announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.
SILVER SPRING, Md., Oct. 25 (AP)--Brig. Gen. Charles Dr. Roberts, retired, winner of the Medal of Honor for bravery during the Spanish-American War, died here yesterday. He was 93 years old.
At Lincoln Center today: Gounod's "Faust," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Puccini's "La Boheme," New York City Opera, New York State Theater, 8:15; Andre Watts, pianist, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.
PLILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 (UPI)--Eugene Ormandy, conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, made a personal appeal to his musicians today to end their six-week strike.
At the sales promotion agency where Suzanne Reynolds worked as a secretary, she was known as a punctual and pleasant girl who never mentioned her part-time modeling career.

MOSCOW, Oct. 25--Soviet Communists portrayed today new heights of anti-Soviet fervor among Communist China's Red Guards Moscow gave prominence to charges that the Soviet Union was preparing an armed attack on Chinese territory.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Oct. 25--After a morning of speeches and electing new officers at the Broadmoor, the members of the Association of National Advertisers had the afternoon off.

Many United States military officers believe that the proposed withdrawal of allied troops from South Vietnam within six months after North Vietnam recalled its forces would result in a wasteful exodus.
The Transit Authority, anxious to protect its own image, is doing nothing ,to, help Mayor Lindsay's campaign, to promote New York as a fun city for filmmakers.

WHEELING, W. Va., Oct. 25--The chief accuser of the Right Rev. James A. Pike has been described as the only member of the Episcopal House of Bishops who is as restless and energetic as the controversial retired Bishop of California.
"The Bible" at Loew's State Theater. "Romeo and Juliet" (Royal Ballet) at the Lincoln Art Theater and the Fifth Avenue Cinema.

Dr. Nahum I. Stone, a retired Consulting economist, former Government official and one time executive of the HickeyGreeman Company, died Monday night in Beekman-Downtown Hospital. He was 93 years old and lived at 535 West 111th Street.

To see the crowd that filled those former bastions of conservatism--the box seats--at the opening of the 83d National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden last night, one would almost think that John Butler had been speaking in a vacuum.
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced last night that a council of priests would soon be established to advise Cardinal Spellman.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 25 --Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood, a six-time New Jerscy State champion who likes math play, led the field today into the semi-final round of the 44th state women's match-play golf championship at the Spring Brook Golf Club.
President Johnson declared last night that "the shadows of bigotry and hatred are fading in the sunshine of human compassion and brotherhood."

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 25 --Dr. Subandrio, Foreign Minister of Indonesia for nearly nine years until his arrest last March, was sentenced to death tonight by the Extraordinary Military Tribunal here. The onetime intimate of President Sukarno stood quietly and calmly in the crowded courtroom while Lieut. Col. Ali Said read the decision of the five military judges.
In continuing to play its waiting game on taxes, the Johnson Administration is lessening the prospect that it will request a hefty increase in corporate and individual tax rates in 1967.
Pumpkins and squash belong to the same family. Each has its special traits. But the countryman contends that a pumpkin pie has a certain flavor and texture that elevate it slightly above its cousin.
The management of the Belmont Iron Works, Philadelphia, said yesterday it would fight an anonymous bidder seeking at least 35,000 Belmont shares at $22 a share.

ALGIERS, Oct. 25--Algeria's oil and distribution company, Sonatrach, announced tonight it had signed an agreement in New York yesterday for a $15million loan with two United States banks to finance the construction of six new pumping stations on its third TransSaharan pipeline.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP)--The House Government Operations Committee called day for a study of ways to preserve the value of foreign currencies owned by the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25-- Yields on the new monthly issues of nine-month and oneyear Treasury bills were substantially lower than those on the similar issues auctioned on sept. 27, the Treasury Departnent announced tonight.
A minor modification of terms involved in the proposed acquisition of the Hertz Corporation by the Radio Corporation of America was announced yesterday.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 25 (AP) --Boycotts by housewives will not bring lasting relies from high prices, a spokesman for American supermarkets said today.
Fourteen parking areas where only operators of motorcycles and motor scooters may angle park will be established soon in Manhattan, Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes said last night.
MORGAN CITY, La., Oct. 25 (AP)--The 527-foot tanker Gulfstag, aflame for nearly two days, capsized tonight and floated bottom up in the Gulf of Mexico. The fire was quenched.
Burlington Industries, Inc., the largest domestic producer of textile products, achieved record sales and earnings in fiscal 1966 for the fifth consecutive year, the annual report stated yesterday.
Fiction CHRISTMAS IS EVERYWHERE, INCLUD ING ASIA MINOR, by Morton Fineman (Norton, $3.50). Short novel about a Jewish boy's desire for a Christmas tree.
Students of oceanography and the literature of the Pacific will have an opportunity next year to combine luxury sea travel and scholarship.

PASADENA, Calif.,--Man's prospects for mastering his immediate environment were viewed with modest optimism at a scientific convocation here today, but his chances of ever confronting extraterrestrial life were regarded with the utmost skepticism

Governor Rockefeiler and Mayor Lindsay were urged by a builders' group yesterday to intervene personally in the 94day-old construction plumbers strike, which has seriously curtailed or stopped work on $500million in public and private construction here.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 25 --Barry Goldwater, on a "thank you" tour of states where he ran well in the 1964 Presidential election, told an enthusiastic Alabama audience today that a third-party movement to elect a President "will not work in the United 'States."
BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Oct. 25--Refuse collectors today walked off the job, leaving this city of 56,000 without service.
TOKYO, Oct. 25--A test that may prove useful as a mass screening device to detect cancer was described here today at a meeting of the ninth International Cancer Conrgress.
A new report card, intended to give parents a better picture of their children's performance, will be issued next month by the city's elementary schools.
Follawing is the remainder of the itinerary of President Johnson's trip to the Far East:
ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 25--A break in diplomatic relations between Peking and Accra is "imminent," according to diplomatic observers here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--The Federal Trade Commission said today that retailers and processors were responsible for most of the recent increase in bread prices and nearly half of the increase in milk prices.

THE audience response to the increased dose of pro football programming on television this season has been good in the case of the National Football League, not so good with the American. Nielsen ratings across the nation for the first six weeks of the campaign, through Oct. 9, show N.F.L. games going into an average of 7,980,000 homes on Sunday after-...
Roman Catholic bishops in the United States may soon vote to end meatless Fridays as the hierarchies have already done in Canada and France.

NOEL PAUL STOOKEY pointed to a decaying factory on Bedford Street in Greenwich Village. "What do you think of that?" he asked his fiancee. "I think someone should tear it down," she replied, blissfully unaware that he had just bought it.
CAFE SAHBRA, Hotel Westover, West End Avenue and 72 Street. Menashe Ba harav, instrumentalist-singer; Line Monty, vocalist; the Negev Dancers; Itamar, Yemenite Singer.

Of all the Congressional districts in the city, the Seventeenth in Manhattan has the closest and most sharply contested race. Representative Theodore R. Kupferman, Republican, who won the seat formerly held by Mayor Lindsay in a special election last February, is opposed by State Senator Jerome L. Wilson, Democrat-Liberal, and Richard J. Callahan, Conservative.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Oct. 125 (AP)--Woodruff Randolph, former president of the International Typographical Union, died of a heart ailment yesterday at the Union Printers Home Hospital here. He was 74 years old.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 25-- Court records showed today that a New Jersey official had admitted knowing of a statement purported to have been made by the wife of a man allegedly murdered by Dr. Carl A. Coppolino.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Oct. 25--The next two Surveyor unmanned spaceships scheduled to land softly on the moon will carry "surface simplers" to dig a furrow, allowing television cameras to take a look beneath the lunar surface.

MORGANTON, N.C., Oct. 25--Even to the practiced eye it is becoming increasingly difficult to see what furniture is made of. Molded plastic appliques are replacing machine carvings, rotogravure printing simulates fine wood grains, and vinyl film is used as a substitute for veneer. Several manufacturers have introduced furniture incorporating these innovations at the eightday Southern Fall Furniture Market, which ends Friday.
The credit markets flexed their muscles yesterday in an effort to find out just how strong they really are.

HONG KONG, Oct. 25--The peace formula in the Manila communique does little to narrow the wide gap between the United States and North Vietnam on terms for a settlement of the Vietnam war, observers of Southeastern Asian affairs said today.
YONKERS, Oct. 25--The Old Glory Sales got under way today with 210 standardbreds sold at auction for a total of $291,000, an average of $1,309.

The account of the first voyage around the world by one of Magellan's companions, Antonio Pigafetta, a Venetian nobleman, whose book was published in Paris about 1525, was sold for $56,000 last night at the Park-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (AP)-- A set of guidelines for news coverage of the prosecution of Richard Speck was drawn up today by the state's attorney and counsel for the man accused of murdering eight student nurses.

Arthur Bowie, a former Assistant Superintendent of City Schools, died yesterday in Methodist Hospital, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived at 35 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.
Frank D. O'Connor declared yesterday that there was "a tremendous split" in the Liberal party because of its decision to back Franklin D. Rooseveit Jr for Governor

Consolidated net income of The New York Times Company in the nine months ended Sept. 30 rose to $5,579,000, or $12.62 a share, from the year-earlier $3,192,000; or $6.85 a share, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, chairman, and Arthur Oehs Sulz-, berger, president and publisher,, reported yesterday.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell was found guilty for the third time yesterday of civil contempt of court for what the state's second highest court called his "long and ugly/record" in flouting court orders.
Dr. David D. Denker, a social scientist who is not a physician, was appointed yesterday to the post of president of New York Medical College--Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25-- The maximum permissible dividend rate on savings accounts at mutual savings banks in New York City may well be rolled back from 5 per cent to 4 per cent by the end of this year, key Federal Government officials said here today.
The Minerals Chemicals Philipp Corporation, which has offices in 28 countries, mill move its headquarters three blocks south on Park Avenue late next year.

UNITED STATES STEEL surprised Wall Street yes terday when it increased its quarterly dividend 10 cents a share, to 60 cents. The move immediately caused speculation that Bethlehem Steel would raise its dividend today.

The United States Steel Corporation raised its quarterly dividend yesterday in a move that caught Wall Street by surprise, while the General Motors Corporation issued a report of disappointingly lower earnings for the third quarter.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 25. (AP)--The American Lutheran Church convention cautioned its youth magazine One today against publishing articles offensive to members of the church body.
The American Heart Association installed Dr. Lewis E. January, professor of medicine at the State University of Iowa in Iowa City, yesterday, as president.

Marking his return to university life. Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. defended the role of men of ideas in the affairs of state as he delivered his first public lecture as Albert Schweitzer Professor of Humanities at the City University yesterday.

THE Ideal Lady of Europe of 1966, who happens to be Miss Grace O'Shaughnessy of Dublin, crossed her long slim legs, showing only her kneecaps even while sitting, and drew on a Rothmans cigarette as she told how she won her title from 13 other contestants, each representing a European country.
Esquire magazine will sponsor an award competition designed to spur business support of the arts.
A breakthrough in a "promotion logjam," which since June, 1964, has prevented the naming of permanent police captains will be sought in State Supreme Court early next week.
Because San. 1, 1967, is a Sunday, the Cotton Bowi football game at Dallas and the Gator Bowl game at Jacksonville, Fia., will be played on Saturday, Dec. 31.
City Council President Frank D. O'Connor began an effort yesterday to drive down the price of milk by at least 2 to 3 cents a quart.

HARRISON, N.Y., Oct. 25-- A car swerved onto the upward tilting center mall of the Cross-Westchester Expressway today, soared into the air and sheared off the roof of another car going in the opposite direction. The driver of the second car was killed.
The "People's Choice" and the "Old Master" were added yesterday to the line-up for Old-Timers Day at Aqueduct on Nov. 5.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 25 --W. Michael Rummel, a cofounder and the president of the Mineola Plumbing Supply Company, Inc., died Sunday night at Nassau Community Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at the Garden City Hotel.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 25 (UPI)--A two-day school boycott reached its climax today as 66.3 per cent of Duval County's Negro pupils stayed home.

ACAPULCO, Mexico, Oct. 25--Now that the For mula One racing season has ended, the international driving set is relaxing and looking forward to the 1967 season opening Jan. 2 in Johannesburg, South Africa.

WHEELING, W. Va., Oct. 25--The Episcopal House of Bishops overwhelmingly approved tonight a report recommending that threatened heresy charges against the Right Rev. James A. Pike be dropped but charging him with "irresponsibility" and "vulgarization of great expressions of faith."

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 24 --A Wallace Democrat from an Arkansas mill town and a Republican from one of America's wealthiest families are waging a bruising contest to become Governor of Arkansas in the Nov. 8 general election.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Oct. 25--Julius S. Loewenthal, a real-estate investor and a leader in the American Jewish Committee, died yesterday in Broward General Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 120 East 81st Street in New York. He had a winter home in Fort Lauderdale.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25-- Mike Mansfield, the Senate Democratic Leader, proposed today that the Manila conference be followed without delay by a peace conference on Vietnam that would include the Communist side.

"I haven't any worry about winning," said Representative Edna F. Kelly, a Democrat with Liberal party backing, who is seeking her 10th term in office in the 12th Congressional District race in Brooklyn. She added: "I expect and hope to win. The problem is by how much."
The Friends of the Philharmonic opened their campaign yesterday for $300,000 to help maintain the New York Philharmonic in the 1966-67 season.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 25--An American wig company signed a multimillion-dollar agreement today with the Indian Government to buy hair shaved from the heads of pilgrims at South Indian temples.

WHEELING, W. Va., Oct. 25 --Following is the text of a statement by a special ,committee adopted by the Episcopal House of Bishops regarding possible heresy charges against the Right Rev. James A. Pike:
MANILA, Oct. 25--The United States and five other nations said today that their troops would be out of South Vietnam within six months after North Vietnam had disengaged itself from the war.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 25-- Molly Brook Dean, the 9-to-5 favorite in tonight's $35,814.10 New York Sire Stakes, a onemile race for 2-year-old pacing fillies, rallied in the stretch to score by a head over Adios Treat.

There will be no quarrel in the Western world with the aims and aspirations of the communique issued after the Manila conference. They are admirable. But the answer to the burning question of whether they are likely to contribute greatly to peace in Vietnam and Southeast Asia would have to be: "No."
MANILA, Oct. 25--Old hands in the lively social life ef Manila averred that there had never been such a "barrio fiesta."

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 25 (UPI) --A new date for a world lightweight championship bout between Carlos Ortiz and Ultiminio (Sugar) Ramos--Jan. 29 --was announced today after the World Boxing Council began voting on a motion to declare the title vacant. A site for the fight was not announced.
The spot rate on the British pound advanced slightly in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. The final quotation of $2.7911 was up 4 points over Monday's level.

Paperboard production rose 4.3 per cent with 469,000 tons in the week ended Oct. 29 from 448,800 tons in the corresponding 1865 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 25 (AP)-- The chairman of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association warned today that the "bootleg drug" market could become a major policing problem for the Food and Drug Administration.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 25-- Robert Kennedy is rising and changing faster than any other political figure in the nation today. He is turning the legend he inherited from his brother into a powerful political movement, and he is coming out of the 1966 elections a winner, regardless of what happens to the Democratic or Republican party.
STOCKHOLM, Oct. 25 (Reuters)--Schoolchildren marched through the streets of Swedish towns today to protest the absence of 20,000 teachers from the nation's classrooms, in a labor dispute.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 25 (UPI) Four more temporary jurors were seated in the Sheppard murder trial today alter the defense contended anew that the defendant could not get a fair trial in Cleveland.
SINGAPORE, Oct. 25-- Japan agreed today to give Singapore $16,510,000, half in grants and the remainder as reparation for atrocities committed during World War II.

Attorney General Katzenbach's ruling that Federal "participation certificates" are backed by the credit of the United States Treasury is obviously designed to broaden their appeal to investors. Sales of these certificates, which--represent loans to the Government, were temporarily halted by the Administration because of the squeeze in the nation's money markets. But Mr. Katzenbach's decision enhancing the attractiveness of the certificates indicates that the Administration intends to resume sales when market conditions improve.
Several major oil companies reported record earnings yesterday.

ALBANY, Oct. 25--The engagement of Miss Betsy Ellen North, daughter of Mr, and Mrs. George A. North of Delmar, to Roger Winston Robinson, son of Mrs. Foneta Setz Robinson of Omaha, and the late Gilbert W. Robinson, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.
If all avant-garde concerts were as much fun as the one Cathy Berberian put on last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, a public might develop. This was not the childish kind of...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--Organized labor has become fearful that white backlash to Negro pressure for civil rights may lead to votes against liberal candidates who support prolabor legislation.
The Columbia Pictures Corporation rejected yesterday the request of two stockholder groups--who together own more than half the common stock --for major representation on its board of directors.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 25 (AP)--Cliff Richey of Dallas and Arthur Ashe of Richmond won their quarter-final matches in the South American lawn tennis championships today, but Allen Fox of Los Angeles was eliminated.

SAIGON, South Vietnam-- Around the swimming pool, young French housewives sunned themselves in bikinis while their children splashed in the water. Next to the stucco clubhouse, under the shade trees, a French family sat down to a picnic table, garnished with bottles of Algerian wine, and began their lunch.

Net income of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., fell to $64,752,492, or $1.74 a share in the nine months ended Sept. 30, from $70,236,514, or $1.89 a share, in the 1965 period, the giant utility announced yesterday.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 25 --John D. Rockefeller 3d today praised the manner in which the Colombian presidential guard and other troops resisted an attack with rocks, bricks and vegetables by extremist university students on President Carlos Lleras Restrepo and Mr.Rockefeller last night.

Inventories of steel users at the end of 1966 will decline to 24 million tons from 25.5 million tons a year earlier, and the entire drop will occur in the fourth quarter, Roger M. Blough, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, estimated yesterday.
Two new award activities by Topps Chewing Gum were announced yesterday at the eighth annual award luncheon for the Topps Rookie All-Star team selections, held at the Americana Hotel.

TUXEDO, N.Y., Oct. 26-- Amid the sylvan setting of Sterling Forest, a research, residential and recreational community here, some 200 stockholders of the City Investing Company gathered for its annual meeting.
PARIS, Oct. 26--France endorsed today a decision by her allies to move the civilian headquarters of the North Atlantic alliance from Paris to Brussels.
BOSTON, Oct. 26 (AP)-- The State Board of Education says Chinese are Chinese and not members of the white race.

MANILA, Thursday, Oct. 27 (AP)--President Johnson left the Philippines at 11:22 A.M. (11:22 P.M. Wednesday, Eastern daylight time, for the threehour flight to Sattahip Air Base, 75 miles southeast of Bangkok, the capital of Thailand.
Johnny Carson will not appear on "The David Susskind Show" because the National Broadcasting Company believes he should not compete with himself.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 26--Flames swept through the blunt gray nose of the United States aircraft carrier Oriskany today in the worst naval accident of the war in Vietnam. At least 43 men were reported to have died and 16 to have been injured in the fire.
BERLIN, Oct. 26--The East German Communists sought today to raise their asking price for wall-crossing permits for West Berliners to virtual recognition by the West.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 26 --Efforts to identify the causes of the common cold were likened here today to "uncoordinated' guerrilla warfare" by Dr. Albert B. Sabin of the University of Cincinnati.

The Congressional delegation from Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island continues to present a picture of almost unrelieved mediocrity. Ten of the eleven seats are held by organization Democrats. Since the Reform movement--which has upgraded the quality of the Representatives from Manhattan and the Bronx in recent years--has not affected these areas, the Democratic nominations still go mainly to party hacks who are unqualified to serve in the modern Congress.
CAMRANH BAY, South Vietnam, Oct. 26 (AP)-- Wounded men in an Air Force hospital joked with President Johnson today as he pinned Purple Hearts on their pajamas.

WHEELING, W. Va. Oct 26 --The Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church said today that he would allow a coolingoff period before appointing a committee to investigate "rumors, reports and allegations" about the Right Rev. James A. Pike, the Retired Bishop of California.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 26 (Reuters)--The new chairman of the Intra Bank said tonight the bank's assets exceeded its liabilities by 80 million Lebanese pounds ($25-million).
HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Oct. 26 --The Suffolk County police arrested 20 persons this morning --11 men and nine women--on charges that they were numbers runners for three policy banks.

The Citizens Union, which has been influential for 70 years in civic affairs, urged Mayor Lindsay yesterday "to discontinue entirely the long-standing practice of soliciting or accepting private contributions for official city functions not open to the general public."

CLEVELAND, Oct. 26 (UPI) --A temporary jury panel was completed today in the murder trial of Samuel H. Sheppard. The defense indicated three times it would try to prove by circumstantial evidence that someone else killed Sheppard's first wife.
A $185-billion "freedom budget for all Americans" designed to end poverty in the United States in the next 10 years was proposed yesterday by a coalition of civil rights, religious and labor leaders.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 26, (AP)--Dennis Ralston and Cliff Richey advanced today to the semifinals of the men's singles in the international lawn tennis championships of Argentina.
The British Advertising Association has prepared its answer to the Government's request that household detergent manufacturers cut down on advertising so the saving can be passed on to the housewife.

Joseph O'Hanlon, former assistant chief of the Fire Department and one of the last of the tough generation of fire fighters known in the department as "the iron men," died Sunday at the Madonna Residence, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. He was 83 years old.
CONCORD, N. H., Oct. 26-- Two men who are not running for office have emerged as factors in the closing days of the lackluster campaign in New Hampshire.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 26 (UPI)--The International Typographical Union asked today for a Federal mediator to help settle a two-day strike against the city's two daily newspapers.
BUFFALO--At Kitty Lou's Bar on Grant Street the patrons appeared surprised when somebody tried to start a conversation about the campaign for Governor.
OMAHA, Oct. 26 (AP)--Directors of the Omaha Public Power District awarded contracts totaling more than $73million today for a nuclear power plant and a seven-year supply of enriched uranium fuel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP)--Hans V. Tofte, a Central Intelligence Agency agent whose contract was terminated recently, filed a damage suit today in Federal Court against the agency's director, Richard Helms, and three other persons.
The consumer boycott movement that has been developing around the country reached New York yesterday.

CORREGIDOR, the Philippines, Oct. 26 (UPI)--After a quarter of a century the jungle still could not cover the scars and Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson looked pensively down a rocky valley at the crumbling stone and rusted metal around her.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 26--When C. W. Post meets Upsala here Saturday, Coach Joe Scannella of Post will be communicating with his pressbox spotters on a telephone system designed, manufactured and sold by John Hooper, his Upsala counterpart.

"Let's Sing Yiddish" will' come to the Brooks Atkinson Theater on Nov. 9. It will be the first Yiddish musical on Broadway since Maurice Schwartz starred in "If I Were Rothschild" at the Jolson Theater, now demolished, in 1940.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported yesterday record third-quarter earnings of $1.01 a share, compared with 70 cents a year earlier.
MOSCOW, Oct. 26 (UPI)-- The Soviet Union's Luna 12 spacecraft sent a stream of information from its moon orbit today but sent no photographs back to earth.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 26--The Government has released nine political prisoners associated with the late President Ngo Dinh Diem and is considering freeing more than 40 others on National Day, Nov. 1, informed sources said today.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 26 --After several weeks, of delicate negotiations on details, Premier Thanom Kittikachorn's military-civilian coalition prepared today to give President Johnson a traditional Thai welcome with some modern touches.
KANKAKEE, Ill., Oct. 26 (UPI)--Richard M. Nixon said today the 89th Congress had set a "dangerous and deplorable" record as a "rubber stamp" for the programs of President Johnson.

Chief S. O. Adebo, Nigeria's permanent delegate to the United Nations, told the annual meeting of the Franklin Book Programs yesterday at the Harvard Club that the organization showed wisdom in not "spoon-feeding" developing countries, but sticking to a policy of "helping people to help themselves."

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Oct. 26 (AP)--Ferrari, which lost the world road-racing championship last year to Ford, announced today it would send a factory-backed team to the Daytona 24-hour Continental in February.
Two 3-year-olds, Indian Sunlite, running in the silks of George M. Humphrey, and Swinging Mood of the Harbor View Farm, divided the honors yesterday in the feature activity at Aqueduct.
The syndicate of investment bankers that bought the $123.33-million offering of New York City bonds Tuesday morning was terminated late that night with the securities all sold.
HAVANA, Oct. 26--The opening ceremony and grouping of the 52 nations in the 17th Chess Olympics took place at the Havana, Libre Hotel here last night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26-- Camranh Bay, where President Johnson visited American fighting troops today, is one of the two major United States logistic complexes in South Vietnam. The other is at Saigon.
The three major candidates for Governor intensified their attacks on one another yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI)--Some Republican leaders said today that President Johnson's dramatic visit to Vietnam was a political gimmick that would backfire against Democrats in the coming elections.

CAMRANH BAY, South Vietnam, Oct. 26--President Johnson flew to South Vietnam today to salute his troops, to thank them, to decorate them, to eat with them, to joke with them, to be photographed with them.

GREENFIELD, Mass., Oct. 26--H. Judd Payne, a retired vice president in charge of the magazine and book division of the F.W. Dodge Corporation, now a division of McGraw-Hill, Inc., died here last night. He was 66 years old and had been ill for several months.
MOSCOW, Oct. 26--Chinese Communist students and Russian bystanders argued politics and ideology for nearly three hours today in Red Square as Soviet policemen milled around in confusion.
SEATTLE, Oct. 26 (AP)-- Jennifer Johnson, a 21-yearold blonde, wants to be a combat soldier in Vietnam. "I'm willing to die," she says.

The projected subway tunnel under the East River will connect in Manhattan with the Sixth Avenue IND line at 58th Street and possibly tear up, at least temporarily, the southeast corner of Central Park.
WHITEY HERZOG, who was reappointed as third base coach for the New York Mets only a couple of weeks ago, was promoted to a special scouting position yesterday.

JIM CALLAHAN of Temple is in a slump. The soph omore split end made his 11th reception of the year last Saturday against Connecticut, but for the first time he failed to turn the completion into a touchdown. The Owls aren't worried, though.

Christmas came early in Brooklyn yesterday. At the Towers Hotel there was a tremendous assortment of toys. But they were all of the canine variety, with 176 competing at the Progressive Dog Club's 34th annual fixture.

GENEVA, Oct. 26--The World Health Organization warned today that man faces a "growing menace of explosive outbreaks of human plague"-- the dreaded "Black Death" that killed millions of Europeans during the great epidemics of the Middle Ages.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 26 --Robert Bruce Dempster, an industrialist, died today at a Knoxville hospital. He was 75 years old.
The National Broadcasting Company released the results of a statewide poll last night that showed Governor Rockefeler with a commanding lead over his Democratic opponent, Frank D. O'Connor.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 26 --Miss Georgian Blair Hurley and Edward William Ryan plan to marry here on Dec. 17.
TOKYO, Oct. 26 (AP)--Antismoking campaigns are making only small gains, two cancer experts said today.
The spot rate on the British pound was higher in moderately active trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.
MESCALERO, N. M., Oct. 26 (AP)--Robert Geronimo, a son of the famous Apache Indian chief who for 10 years defied the Federal Government, died yesterday. He was 77 years old.
The rate of growth of New York State's labor force is expected to decline substantially in the years ahead on the basis of current projections by the United States Department of Labor.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26-- In Bob Odell's first year as head football coach at his alma mater last fall, Pennsylvania had its best season since it won the Ivy League championship in 1959.

PHILADELPHIA, Thursday, Oct. 27 (AP)--Some 11,000 mechanical and auditing employes of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania went on strike shortly after midnight today with the expiration of a threeyear labor contract.
I came here today for one good reason: simply because I could not come to this part of the world and not come to see you.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26--Mrs. Peterson, who is special assistant to President Johnson for consumer affairs, denied tonight that she was fomenting the housewives boycotts, or that they were led by left-wing groups.
BONN, Oct. 26--West Germany's coalition government avoided in a dramatic showdown tonight a split over what had appeared to be irreconcilable positions on budgetary problems.
Off the Irish coast and off Cape Cod, 250,000 blue plastic envelopes have been cast adrift in a "message" campaign against pollution of the seas.
A junior committee has been formed for the Daiquiri Ball, to be given on Tuesday at the Plaza as a benefit for the Girls Club of New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP)--Frank R. Valeo, the Secretary of the Senate, reported today that 805 of President Johnson's nominations failed to win Senate" confirmation this year and that 160 others were withdrawn.

Contributions ranging from 20 cents and three trading Stamps, mailed in by an unemployed Connecticut man, to $30,000, a gift from the Continental Insurance Company, have raised to $136,000 the fund for families of 12 firemen killed in a Madison Square blaze here Oct. 17.

ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 26 Reuters)--Horst Schumann, a former Nazi doctor, said in Ghana's Court of Appeals today that he supervised the World War II killing of 80,000 to 120,000 insane people in order to make room in hospitals for wounded German soldiers.
OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 26--A November wedding is planned by Miss Stephanie Lenox Stouffer and Lawrence Alan Kahn, who received degrees in sculpture in June from the Rhode Island School of Design.

BAINBRIDGE, N.Y.--Upstate fear that New York City may acquire tyrannical power over the state has become an important force for the re-election of Governor Rockefeller that may outweigh bitterness over taxes imposed during his administration.
Radio Corporation of America announced its plans yesterday to increase monthly rentals to reduce purchase prices for most models in its computer line.
Bonn, Oct. 26--The West German Government pledged itself today to a serious consideration of the nuclear-controls offer made by Poland and Czechoslovakia.
Spurred by a flood of favorable earnings reports, most issues on the American Stock Exchange made good gains yesterday in moderate trading.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 26, (AP)--The owners of Tom Rolfe and Assagai have accepted invitations to race their colts in the Washington, D. C. International as this country's entries.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 (UPI)--The New York Knicks handed the Los Angeles Lakers their fourth consecutive defeat, 133-122, tonight at the Sports Arena.

The American Tobacco Company, with the aid of Sunshine Biscuits, Inc., acquired earlier this year, turned in record sales and earnings yesterday for the three-month and six-month periods ended Sept. 30.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 (AP) --Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower has endorsed Ronald Reagan, the Republican candidate for Governor of California, and the entire Republican state ticket.

Mortimer Berkowitz, a retired publishing and advertising executive who was general manager of two Hearst supplements, the old American Weekly and the Comic Weekly-Puck, died yesterday at the Frank Pavilion of the Jewish Home and Hospital, 140 West 106th Street. He was 79 years old and lived at the Westchester Country Club in Rye.
A Manhattan furrier was indicted by a Bronx County grand jury yesterday for allegedly pawning fur coats left with him for storage. One of the purported victims was his sister.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26-- The Federal Trade Commission warned coffee processors today that they were violating the law if they put "cents off" bargain labels on their coffee over any extended period of time.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26--The faces that launched a thousand ships met here today.
The Taft Broadcasting Company confirmed yesterday in Cincinnati that it would acquite Hanna-Barbers Productions, Inc., for about $12-million in cash and stock.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP)--The National Community Christmas Tree this year will be a red fir from California, the National Park Service said today.
LAWRENCE, L. I., Oct. 26-- Mr. and Mrs. Sam Robert Chernow have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elva Ann Chernow, to Howard S. Berger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Berger of Brooklyn.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Oct. 26 (AP)--A powerful AtlasCentaur rocket achieved America's first double ignition of high-energy hydrogen-fueled engines in space today, thereby providing the United States with the ability to send heavy payloads to the moon and planets.
MOSCOW, Oct. 26--Soviet commentators scorned the communique from the Manila conference today, calling it hypocritical and empty.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26--Diplomatic sources reported today that France was resisting a move begun by Communist countries to extend international nuclear controls into Western and Eastern Europe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26-- The Chicago North Western Railway and its merger partner, the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad, notified the Interstate Commerce Commission today that they no longer were opposed to a merger of the Great Northern, the Northern Pacific and the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroads.
Mostly small gains predominated at the close of trading on the London Stock Exhange yesterday despite late profit taking.
ATHENS, Oct. 26--It is no laughing matter, if you are a tourist, to be confronted with the Acropolis.
MONTREAL, Oct. 26 (AP) --Bobby Hull and his brother Dennis paced the unbeaten Chicago Black Hawks to their fourth National Hockey League victory tonight, a 5-3 decision over the Montreal Canadiens.

Paced by an unusally strong steel group, stock prices rallied in active trading yesterday. Prices shaded off late in the session, but advances topped declines by almost three to one at the close. At the peak of the advance around 2 o'clock, the upside margin was almost four to one.
THE sentimentalist, Jessamyn West tells us early in this hauntingly symphonic novel, looks toward the future; the romanticist looks toward the past.
Long-smoldering resentment felt by five Borough Presidents over the asserted bypassing of their offices by Mayor Lindsay came into the open yesterday.

TORONTO, Oct. 26--The Canadian Government is investigating the tax aspects of an unusual deal under the United States-Canadian auto-trade agreement, whereby the Studebaker Corporation made special profits by acting as an importer for Volkswagen in Canada.

LONDON, Oct. 26 (Reuters) --The director of a thoroughly panned "Macbeth" today warned the London critics against pushing the British theater into the plight of Broadway, where he said critics' deadlines and "commercial pressure" strangled creativity.

The 68 mutual savings banks in the New York metropolitan area would welcome a rollback from 5 to 4 per cent in the interest paid on savings deposits--if interest rates on marketable securities were to decline as well. Key Government officials hinted this week that such a rollback might be ordered before the end of the year.
Jacob Glatstein, a 70-year-old poet and essayist, has won the H. Leivick Yiddish literary award of $1,000 of the Congress for Jewish Culture.
DENVER, Oct. 26 (AP)-- Associate Justice Tom C. Clark said today no Supreme Court decision placed a gag on law officers in discussing with newsmen details of a crime before arrests had been made.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26 --The American Bankers Association closed its 92d annual convention today by accusing the Johnson Administration of mismanaging its fiscal policy and the Federal Reserve of mismanaging its monetary policy.

A picture of weakening Jewish cultural and religious life in the Soviet Union despite the desire of many Jews to preserve it was drawn yesterday by the head of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America.
The employes of a small candy-making concern, who were formerly represented by a union with underworld connections, have voted against being represented by any union.

Russell Inslee Clark, a partner in Spencer Trask Co., stockbrokers of 60 Broad Street, died, Tuesday night of a heart attack at a performance of "Dinner at Eight" at the Alvin Theater. He was 63 years old and was a resident of Garden City, L.I.
WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 26-- Arrangements for a $100-million complex of office buildings and stores in the deteriorated core of White Plains were announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) --Supreme Court Justice Hugo L. Black refused today to stay a Nevada Supreme Court decision that bars from next month's election ballot a petition to start the first official lottery in the state's history.
KINSHASA, the Congo, Oct. 26--President Joseph D. Mobutu abolished the post of premier today and took over as president of the Cabinet.
MANILA, Oct. 26--The final decision on President Johnson's trip to South Vietnam was made less than a day before his plane landed at Camranh Bay.
A "sound car" with a loudspeaker on the roof squawks its brief, repetitious message into the mild autumn afternoon long pleasant, shady streets of neat brick homes--and then is gone.

PARIS, Oct. 26 (Reuters)-- A Paris theater was ordered today to delete all references to the Marquis de Sade from the title and publicity for its production of the play. "MaratSade," on a complaint by the marquis's descendants that the title was "likely to damage the family's good name."

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 26--Mr. and Mrs. Leon Sondik have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Sondik, to Louis Perlmutter, son of Mrs. Kermit Perlmutter of Longmeadow, Mass., and Boston, and the late Mr. Perlmutter.

JOSEPH TANKOOS, who owns Delmonico's Hotel won't wear them in Palm Beach. Warren Avis (of the No. 2 car-rental clan) does without them in Acapulco. Bill Blass, the designer, thinks they're superfluous in Southampton, and Mr. John, the hatter, doesn't wear them even in New York.

Elisabeth Carron, soprano, who made her local recital debut last night at Town Hall, is an uncommonly shipshape musician. Her phrasing is worked out to the last shimmer, her enunciation is crisp and she makes a polished production out of each song and aria.
PARIS, Oct. 26--The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization decided here today to retain Taiwan as a member instead of Communist China.
UPLAND, Calif., Oct. 26 (AP)--For the last time, an Upland College official pronounced a prayer in the school's small wooden chapel.

The student government at Queens College will sponsor a protest demonstration tomorrow at 1:30 P.M. on the corner where two Queens College faculty members were killed as they left the college in an automobile last Friday.

NOW that Milos Forman's Czechoslovak film, "Loves of a Blonde," has attained a lively reputation and a considerable audience want-tosee by virtue of its explosive premiere showing at the recent New York Film Festival, the beginning of its regular engagemeht at the Sutton yesterday is almost an anticlimax in the trajectory of its interesting career.
BILOXI, Miss., Oct. 26--At three-judge Federal panel ordered today that three Negro independent candidates of the Mississippi Freedom Democratic party be placed on the state's election ballot Nov. 8.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26--African and Asian sponsors of a resolution to have the United Nations supplant South Africa as the administering power in South-West Africa agreed to a series of amendments today to broaden its appeal.
Directors of the Douglas Aircraft Company voted yesterdays in Santa Monica, Calif., to omit the company's quarterly dividend of 25 cents on its capital shares due at this time.

Demolition of the old New York Tribune building on Nassau Street near City Hall continued yesterday despite a Buildings Department order to hold up the work because the resulting dust was polluting the air.

Working with the juice of fresh-cut spinach, two California scientists are believed to have taken mankind a big step closer to the use of sunlight for the production of nourishing foods out of such waste plants as jungle leaves and grass.
Walter E. Washington, director of public housing in Washington, is almost certain to become the new chairman of the city Housing Authority, reliable sources said yesterday.

The former business agent of a racket-ridden laborers' union local was being sought yesterday by District Attorney Nat H. Hentel of Queens for questioning by a Queens grand jury that is investigating organized crime.
PARIS, Oct. 26--French commentators of almost all political persuasions today dismissed the main proposals of the Manila conference as either a futile gesture or deliberate double-talk.
LONDON, Oct. 26--All Britain's convicted spies have been moved to top-security jails in hte last few days in an effort to avert more escapes such as that of George Blake.

Tonight at 8 the Metropolitan Opera is presenting its new version of Verdi's "La Traviata" at Lincoln Center. Tonight at 8:15 the New York City Opera is presenting its new version of Verdi's "La Traviata" at Lincoln Center.

A thorough review of all college guidance and admission tests with a view to giving lower income groups a better chance of qualifying was announced yesterday by the College Entrance Examination Board.
CAMRANH BAY, South Vietnam, Oct. 26--President Johnson was about the flashiest figure on the reviewing platform during his visit to the huge American base here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26--For the last two months, the Federal Government has been making emergency payments to some hospitals in the interim between the treatment of Medicare patients and receipt of payment.
A "shadow cabinet" created yesterday will give City College students a voice in administrative decision-making.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Oct. 26 --This is the New York Giants' first week off in seven years. Coach Allie Sherman's team is reeling from a 1-5-1 won-losttied record. What better place for the coach to recover than Gainesville, where hope is just four (maybe five) college games away?

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Oct. 26 (AP)--A satellite of the Communications Satellite Corporation swept into orbit today as a major step toward establishing a commercial communications link across the Pacific Ocean.

CAIRO, Oct. 26--First indications of popular unrest over the latest round of economic belttightening by the Government of the United Arab Republic came to light today with a reliable report that 3,000 dockworkers at Port Said went on a protest strike earlier this month against wage cuts.
SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 27 --Australia may have to commit more troops to the war in Vietnam, Prime Minister Harold Holt said last night on his return from the Manila Conference.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26--The Federal Trade Commission is studying several proposals that would label certain retail credit practices as unfair or deceptive a commission spokesman said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26--The Senate ethics committee announced today that it would conduct hearings on "certain financial affairs and other activities" of Senator Thomas J. Dodd, including his use of campaign funds raised on his behalf between 1961 and 1965.

Cliff Grant, a Negro factory worker in Cleveland, was angry at the Republicans two years ago for nominating Barry Goldwater for President, and he showed it by voting a Democratic ticket from "top to bottom."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI)--The Government urged the nation's cities today to create special welfare units to protect an estimated total of 165,000 elderly Americans who are so senile "they seriously endanger themselves and their neighbors."
NEW beauty products available at cosmetics counters run the gamut from a portable mirror, with lights attached, to make-up in the latest violet shades.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith announced yesterday that it had begun a cooperative program with the Bell Telephone System to end what it described as the system's "under-utilization of Jews" on its executive and managerial levels.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 26 --The Intra Bank, which closed its doors Oct. 14 because of a lack of cash to meet withdrawals, owes or is responsible for obligations to the United States Commodity Credit Corporation totaling about $21-million.

Petroleum companies continued to show the best earnings performances of any industrial group in third-quarter and ninemonth reports issued yesterday.
TIRANA, Albania, Oct. 26-- Albania appears to have adopted an attitude of wait and see toward Communist China's cultural revolution.

WASHINGTON, Oct.26--New offerings of corporate securities in the three months ended Sept. 30 totaled $4.3-billion, off seasonally from the preceding quarter but the highest third-quarter figure on record, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 26-- A Foreign Ministry spokesman declined to comment on the Manila communique today, saying that the Government had not yet received the text.

The Realty Equities Company has leased the eleventh floor of the Seagram Building in a brief game of musical chairs that is characteristic of much of the office leasing now going on in mid-Manhattan prestige buildings.

ALFRED SISLEY was the quietest of the impressionists, and one day his landscapes may end as the best loved. YONKERS, Oct. 26--Specials Dream, one of 10 standardbreds of racing age that were sold in today's stock dispersal of the C. and M. Stable of Archbold, Ohio, brought the highest price $26,000, during the second day of the Old Glory Horse Sale under the tent at Yonkers Raceway.
Ingrid Bjoner sang her first Empress in the Metropolitan Opera's "Die Frau ohne Schatten" Tuesday night, and the occasion was a vocal triumph but a casting mistake.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 26 --Romeo Hanover, the 3-yearold pacer who is the 4-5 favorite to capture the rich Messenger Stakes at Roosevelt Raceway Saturday night, has, in addition to speed and stamina, a number of idiosyncracies. One is a streak of stubbornness that shows itself at the most inopportune times.

BERLIN, Oct. 26--About 1,200 churchmen under the leadership of the Rev. Dr. Billy Graham, the Rev. Dr. Carl Henry, editor of the American fortnightly review, Christianity Today, and other leading evangelical-minded clergymen have gathered here for the First World Congress on Evangelism.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26-- Senator George Murphy, California Republican, was asked at a news conference here today whether he was "put out" because California's senior Republican Senator, Thomas H. Kuchel, was not campaigning for Ronald Reagan, the party's gubernatorial nominee.

LODI, N. J., Oct. 26--Michael Cavallo, four-time mayor of this borough and a founder of the Democratic organization in Bergen County, died of a heart attack in Hackensack Hospital today. He was 70 years old.

The chairman of the state's Joint Legislative Committee on Public Health and Medicare said yesterday that "the medically indigent in New York City have been the victims of a hospital system that for more than two decades has viewed its patients with cynicism and cruelty."

Gerald Tsai Jr., president of the Manhattan Fund, Inc., said yesterday that his mutual fund continued a "somewhat cautious" position during the third quarter, a period when stock prices generally were declining.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Oct. 26--Mrs. Michael Burke of Deal and Mrs. Percy Pyne 3d of Somerset Hills gained the final of the New Jersey women's match-play golf championship today at the Spring Brook Golf Club.

A wealthy German businessman, indicted here 24 years ago in a wartime international plot to sell millions of dollars worth of diamonds stolen by the Nazis, was held in $15,000 bail yesterday in Federal Court.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26--Exports exceeded imports by slightly less than $300-million in September, the Department of Commerce reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26-- The President's chief economic adviser said today that the Government should not attempt to reduce unemployment below its current level by its tax and spending policies.

Americana of universal appeal and significance, starring such names as Magellan and Columbus at the opening on Tuesday of the auction of the Thomas Winthrop Streeter collection, remained the great performers as the sale closed last night, bringing $618,115.

Canada had the best in Tom Gayford and Gail Ross in the international jumping competition of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night as they finished first and second respectively in the Frederick D. Mackay Memorial Challenge Trophy.

HIGH POINT, N. C.--A list of the major furniture styles shown at the Southern Fall Furniture Market, which ends tomorrow, reads like an anthology of the decorative arts from the Renaissance to the mid-1960's.
The New York Telephone Company announced yesterday the election of Francis J. Moses as vice president for the operating staff. He succeeds Emil M. Pastore, who has retired.

LONDON, Oct. 26--While speaking softly on the ultimate issue of British sovereignty over Gibraltar, the British Government has gone ahead with preparations for immediate economic defense of Gibraltarians, British officials said today.

The Most Rev. Fulton J. Sheen, Auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and national director of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, was named Bishop of the Rochester, N. Y., Diocese yesterday by Pope Paul VI.
EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., Oct. 26 --Senator Robert F. Kennedy made a strong plea today to Illinois voters to send Paul H. Douglas back to Washington for another Senate term.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Oct. 26 (AP)--A California biochemist reported, today that a laboratory-produced compound closely resembling one in the human body had brought about an "apparent improvement" in mice genetically afflicted with muscular dystrophy.

HARRISON, N. Y., Oct. 26-- Abraham N. Davis, a lawyer who retired two months ago after four years of service as New York State's Executive Deputy Secretary of State, died today in his home here at 365 West Street after a long illness. He was 74 years old.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 26 (UPI)--Two adults who called a two-day school boycott by Negro pupils in Duval County were arrested early today on charges of contributing to the delinquency of minors.
