OBI'S of Hong Kong Ltd. has specialized in cutom made clothes at ready-to-wear prices for 30 years.
About 150 deteriorated dwellings have been repaired under an experimental program in which landlords avoid prosecution for housing code violations by agreeing to make their property safe and clean.
STOCKHOLM. Oct. 26--The newest Soviet liner, the Alexandr Pushkin, which entered trans-Atlantic service only this year, is going to be a Swedish cruise ship this winter.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26-- The First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company, Philadelphia's largest bank, is actively looking for Jewish applicants who might eventually qualify for top executive positions.

Floyd M. Davis, a magazine illustrator who portrayed England at war during World War II, died Tuesday at the Veterans Administration Hospital, First Avenue at 24th Street. He was 70 years old and lived at 1 West 67th Street.

An end of United States bombing of North Vietnam would open the way to ending the Vietnam war by reconvening the Geneva conference or enabling talks in some other forum, Gus Hall, general secretary of the Communist party, U.S.A., asserted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) --Mrs. Sadie Overton Davis, wife of Brig. Gen. Benjamin O. Davis, died last night at Walter Reed Army Hospital.
It may be somewhat jarring to think about Federal income-taxes this far in advance of the April 15 deadline, but doing so can mean substantial tax savings.
Record sales and earnings were announced yesterday by the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation for the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30.
ALBANY, Oct. 26--The Court of Appeals ruled today that one question on the New York Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board--not two--would face the voters in the Nov. 8 referendum.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 27 (AP)--In its first reaction to the Manila conference, North Vietnam said today that President Johnson had used the meeting to lay bare his intention "to embark on a greater adventure by stepping up the war of aggression."

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Oct. 26 (AP)--A Spanish-American group abandoned a New Mexico forest area today after a Federal judge in Albuquerque issued a temporary restraining order to prevent possible bloodshed.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 26 (AP)--Alabama disclosed today a freedom-of-choice plan under which pupils could change teachers in order to have a teacher of their own race.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 102.7 on Tuesday from 102.6 on Monday.
The Presbyterian Progress Foundation has arranged a dinner for next Thursday in the Pierre's Cotillion Room and a theater party for later that evening at "Dinner at Eight" at the Alvin Theater.

National Airlines, which has not operated from La Guardia Airport since September, 1948, will begin service there on Dec. 14, according to L. B. Maytag Jr., its president. Eight scheduled airlines now fly from La Guardia.

PRELATE extraordinary, television idol and the new Bishop of Rochester, N. Y., the Most Rev. Fulton John Sheen is probably the Roman Catholic Church's bestknown preacher and evangelist. The Bishop's penetrating blue eyes and persuasive personality are his trade mark.
Physical misfortune has kept both candidates for Congress in the 14th District of Brooklyn from active campaigning--but the outcome of the race will almost certainly not be af fected.
FRANKLIN TOWNSHIP, N. J., Oct. 26 (AP)--Two girls died and their three sisters were injured when fire burned their two-story brick and frame home here early today.
LONDON, Oct. 26 (AP)-- Alma Cogan, one of Britain's highest paid singers, died in a hospital today at the age of 34. A friend said the cause of death was leukemia.
GRAND MASTER PAL BENKO of New York, scoring six straight victories, won the recent Quaker City Open in Philadelphia from a strong 32-man field of mixed masters and experts in a sixround Swiss system.

The New York chapter of the Arthritis Foundation will benefit from a cocktail party and candlelight dinner, to be held on Wednesday in the Grand Ballroom of Delmonico's Hotel, and from a theater party afterward at the first preview of "Cabaret."
RECENT stock market strength may not suggest that the bulls are back but rather that the smart money is searching for safe havens in the event of a recession.

LISBON, Oct. 26--Ministers from the European Free Trade Association are gathering in Portugal to celebrate and to take stock of the future. The celebration concerns the freeing of the bloc's area of all internal tariffs. The last 20 per cent of the tariffs will be dropped Dec. 31.
Ideas for a major sports center in Flushing Meadow Park were outlined for the City Planning Commission yesterday by Parks Commissioner Thomas P. F. Hoving.

LONDON, Oct. 26--The British Council of Churches, the body most widely representative of Britain's major Protestant groups, today reached a compromise stand on a controversial report on sex and morality.

At Lincoln Center today: Verdi's "La Traviata," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M., and New York City Opera, New York State Theater, 8:15; Wheeler Beckett Orchestra, young people's concert, Philharmonic Hall, 2; New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30; David Anton, cellist, and Anna Anton, pianist. Library and Museum of the Performing Arts, 6.
How do you concoct whodunits that have rolled up world sales of 300-million copies? Ask Agatha Christie.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26--Canada urged today that Communist China be brought into "active participation' in international disarmament negotiations.
Robert A. (Skipper) Deacon of Paignton, England, is a bottler of ships--a skill that allows only fractional deviations from infinite precision and patience.
Doubt exists over the treatment the City Council will give the Lindsay administration's bill consolidating city departments and agencies in a bid for greater efficiency and economy in government.

ALMOST all the hotel schools or general cooking schools in Europe offer instruction, to one degree or another, on pleasing the palates of foreigners. There is a Swiss school, for example, whose manual speaks of "les produits Heinz avec 57 variations" as well as of "Lea and Perrins de Worcestershire, England."
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 26-- The Art Museum of Princeton University will open its new $2-million home Saturday.
BOWDOINHAM, Me., Oct. 26--There are about 195 million Americans who do not go gunning for ducks. At least they don't pay the $3 for a Federal hunting license if they do.
SENDAI, Japan, Oct. 26 (AP)--The Los Angeles Dodgers, on an 18-game barnstorming tour of Japan, were whipped, 13-6, by the Yomiuri Giants of Tokyo today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26--The Post Office Department said today that it had been forced to borrow $30-million to underwrite an emergency effort to move an "unprecedented deluge" of early Christmas mail.
On the race track, his name was Pensioner, and bettors who lost money on him complained he ran like one.
The nation's electric power production rose 9 per cent in the week ended Oct. 22, from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.

Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation-March of Dimes, said yesterday that the president of the National Institutes of Health was "talking through his hat" at Oklahoma City on Tuesday when he charged that the foundation was guilty of secrecy and mistakes in dealing with polio vaccine development.
Something happened on the way to the opening of trading in futures of frozen orangejuice concentrate yesterday.

Columbia University is adopting Benjamin Franklin High School to improve the education of students at the East Harlem school, where almost half the freshmen have reading skills below fourth-grade level.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26-- The Southern California Trojans, known in the past for their explosive offense, are flattening football foes with their defense this season.

United States cargo vessels carried only 10.8 per cent of this season's record-breaking grain shipments in the Great Lakes, according to Oliver T. Burnham, vice president of the Lake Carriers' Association.
MIAMI, Oct. 26 (UPI)--The nation's supermarket operators ended their annual convention today with a promise to housewives that they would wage war on rising food prices.

The graduation of officers from Federal and state merchant marine academies will be advanced by two to six months next year to meet the need for licensed deck and engine-room personnel for ships carrying supplies to Vietnam.
Notre Dame's unbeaten football team is the result of "a happy combination of circumstances," according to the Rev. Edmund P. Joyce, executive vice president of the university in South Bend, Ind.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 There is a curious air of theatrical unreality about this election. It is going on all over the country in a series of unrelated sideshows, but it is mainly a clash of personalities and debating points rather than a serious referendum on national policies.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 27 Walter S. Frisbee, treasurer of the Disbrow Manufacturing Company of East Orange, died yesterday of a heart attack while waiting for a train at the Grove Street station of the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad here. He lived at 228 Fairmount Avenue, Chatham.

HONG KONG, Oct. 27--Peking joined Hanoi today in rejecting the Manila Conference formula for ending the war in Vietnam. Both made scathing comments that indicated there was little hope for an early settlement.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 27 Miss Ethel Berman and Dr. Michael R. Siegal plan to marry in December.
BONN, Oct. 27 West Germany's government coalition disintegrated today.
The Lindsay administration's first program of coordinated transportation construction, totaling more than $400-million, was outlined yesterday to the City Planning Commission.

A faint touch of irony lingers over the debate on the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board. When civil rights and liberal groups began demanding a board four years ago, there were cries of "police brutality" and 'whitewash."

THE National Collegiate Athletic Association out- lawed the use of electronic quarterbacking this season. The association ruled out use of a device with which an edgy coach could call the plays for his quarterback through a receiver in the player's helmet.

MOSCOW, Oct. 27 One of the few remaining fraternal links between Soviet and Chinese Communism was broken today, and a chilly Soviet Government protest set the new tone of official animosity between the neighboring Communist powers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 A new test for immunity to rubella infections was announced today by a unit of the National Institutes of Health. The test was described as simple, rapid and reliable.

Brentano's will open a new book store tomorrow on the northwest corner of University Place and Eighth Street in the Brevoort East apartment building. It will be the 18th store in the country run by Brentano's, a company begun by August Brentano with a newsstand on Broadway near Third Street in 1853.

THE chances are that at least one doll under the Christmas tree this year will have been bought by request and ordered by name under the influence of television. This is the consensus of seasoned observers on the doll scene, some of whom deplore it, few of whom can afford to ignore it.

MOSCOW, Oct. 27 (UPI) Luna 12, the Soviet Union's latest craft orbiting the moon, has fallen silent and Western space experts speculated today that it was shut down temporarily to conserve battery power.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 27 The United States and Britain asked the Security Council today to call on both Israel and Syria fo cooperate fully with all United Nations bodies concerned to end tensions that are threatening to cause new fighting along their border.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 27 (UPI)--Fire destroyed half the city of Quibdo causing property damage estimated at more than 10-million, the Government reported today.
Herbert K. Buskin, vicepresident in charge of the Bankers Trust Company office at 1107 Broadway, near 24th Street since 1961, died yesterday at his home at 36 East 36th Street. His age was 58.
PEKING, Oct. 27 Icy winds out of the northwest swept through the streets of Communist China's capital Friday as a mass exodus of visiting Red Guards got under way.
LISBON, Oct. 27 The British told their European Free Trade Association partners today that France clearly still had "considerable reservations" about a British application to join the Common Market.
OTTAWA, Oct. 27 A prominent Canadian broadcaster has asked the Government to approve plans to set up a national all-color television network fed by an "all-Canadian" satellite.
PARIS, Oct. 27 The Marquis de Sade became Monsieur de X tonight.

LIMA, Peru, Oct. 27 (AP) Latin-American governments face a top-priority task in encouraging domestic and foreign private investment, David Rockefeller told members of the Inter-American Press Association today.

A NUMBER of courageous and budget-minded young women have in recent months been scouting lingerie departments for party dresses. The woman who owns a Body Stocking or other appropriate underwear can find a variety...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 A House subcommittee called today for a broad attack on environmental pollution-including a 10-fold increase in Federal financial aid in the next five years.

LONDON, Oct. 27 The Burmah Oil Company, Ltd., one of the great British oil producing companies, moved today to take over Castrol, Ltd., a specialist in the manufacture of high-grade lubricants for the equivalent of about $103.6-million.

Jim Day, a 20-year-old member of the Canadian Equestrian Team, rode the young chestnut gelding. Canadian Club, high and handsome to win the International Puissance jumping competition at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.

TORONTO, Oct. 27 (Canadian Press)--Michael Langham, artistic director of the Stratford Shakespearean Festival, said today that two artistic directors, Jean Gascon and John Hirsch will succeed him when he leaves the festival at the end of its 1967 season.
The Dependents Fund for the families of 12 firemen killed Oct. 17 received $32,000 yesterday from members of the New York Stock Exchange.

The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation made it three of a kind in the automobile industry by their announcement yesterday of a decline in earnings for the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30.
Passers-by in Queens gaped yesterday as four men in business suits gave a statuesque couple their first bath in 25 years.
HAVANA, Oct. 27 The United States chess team scored a 3 - victory over Ecuador in Group III in the opening qualifying round of the 17th Chess Olympics at the Havana Libre Hotel here last night.

ROME, Oct. 27 Italain socialism, divided since 1947, began today a series of meetings that will end Sunday with the formation of a new unified Socialist party, rivaling both the Christian Democrats and Communists.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UPI) The first regular telecommunication link between America and Asia by commercial satellite is expected to begin operations Monday, the Communications Satellite Corporation, (Comsat) announced today.

GOSHEN, Vt., Oct., 27 (AP) Mrs. Elsie Masterton, an author and the operator of the well-known Blueberry Hill Restaurant and Blueberry Hill Farm, died yesterday at Mary Fletcher Hospital in Burlington after a long illness. She was 52 years old.

A panel of three Federal judges has been named to decide the validity of the Liberal party's complaint that New York State's Congressional district lines violate the Supreme Court's one-man one-vote ruling.
Sales and earnings of the Procter Gamble Company in the three months ended Sept. 30 rose to the highest levels for any quarter in the concern's 129-year history, it was reported yesterday.

WORLD WAR II is a misnomer; it should be World War I. Fought on three continents and across the two largest oceans, World War II was the first war truly to span the globe. Twenty-one years separated the armistice of 1918 from the Wermacht's invasion of Poland on Sept. 1, 1939; and now, since the surrender of Japan, another 21 years has passed.
A hairdresser who is fearful that he will lose his technique among his short-haired fellow convicts was denied his freedom yesterday by a Federal judge.
Construction contracts in September reversed the downward drift of the last several months.

PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 27 A December wedding is planned by Miss Mary Ellen Robinson and James Fredrick Miller. Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Anthony Robinson have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Miller of Montrose, Colo.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 27 (AP) The Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the independent United Electrical Workers reached agreement on a new contract today, leaving one major union yet to come to terms.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP) Alan S. Boyd, Under Secretary of Commerce for Transportation, said today that there was no evidence that driving training did any good.

RENO, Oct. 27 The director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Governor of Nevada exchanged hostile statements today over the interlock- ing subjects of electronic eavesdropping and hoodlum involvement in Las Vegas gambling casinos.
LONDON, Oct. 27 The Egyptian Army in Yemen has arrested about 2,000 people in Sana and about 1,000 in Taiz, British sources reported today. More than 300 people had been arrested previously.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 27 South Vietnam's troops suffered their highest combat casualties of the year during the week ended Oct. 22, a spokesman said tonight.
"THIS bull market won't top out," some of the wise men on Wall Street were saying last winter, "until the steel stocks make their move."
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 (UPI) Wilt Chamberlain of the Philadelphia 76ers was ordered today to wear a brace temporarily because of a knee injury.

BERLIN, Oct. 27 Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin, chairman of the West German Social Democrats, said here today that his party was not prepared to agree to a temporary solution to the government crisis or to "tolerate continuation of the present confusion." The party, he added, "reserves its full freedom of action."
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 102.4 on Wednesday from 102.9 on Tuesday.
Grants totaling $3.75-million have been made by the William R. Kenan Jr. Charitable Trust to five universities in New York State to assist in the improvement of undergraduate instruction.
A leading maritime union official has asked the Federal Government to bar the use of a former American-flag liner in cruises out of Nassau, event though she will not come to a port in this country.

LONDON, Oct. 27 A new literary trial that may rival that of D.H. Lawrence's "Lady Chatterley's Lover" opened in London today with the prosecution of the American novel "Last Exit to Brooklyn" for alleged obscenity.
The nation's powerful manufacturing and service industries showed signs of strain in the third quarter as profit margins narrowed the gains of earnings in this year's first nine months.

KARLSRUHE, Germany, Oct. 27 (AP) The West German Supreme Court ordered the dismissal today of treason charges against a suspended Bundeswehr general staff officer who was a central figure in the socalled Spiegel affair four years ago.
Augustus A. Beekman, a 43year-old veteran of 19 years in the Fire Department, yesterday achieved the highest uniformed rank ever held by a Negro in the department deputy chief.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 United States officials suggested today that the latest Chinese Communist nuclear test might increase worldwide pressure for the early signing of a treaty banning the spread of nuclear weapons.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP) The Chicago Linen Supply Association was found guilty last Monday of conspiracy to violate Federal antitrust laws and fined $15,000 by Judge Julius J. Hoffman in United States District Court.
WHEELING, W. Va., Oct. 27 The Episcopal House of Bishops voted today to form a council of laymen and clergymen to "help rethink, restructure and renew the church for life in the world today."

It probably took ten years of work by the best Chinese scientists and engineers to make possible the Peking Government's test yesterday of a missile with a nuclear warhead, according to a leading American rocket designer.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 27 Former United States Senator H. Alexander Smith, an early internationalist and influential Republican foreign-policy adviser, died of a stroke today at the Princeton Hospital. He was 86 years old.
The board of directors of the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, elected Frederick S. Moseley Jr. yesterday as president of the association for a year, effective immediately.

MONTREAL, Oct. 27 (Canadian Press) Directors of two of Canada's largest paper companies, the Consolidated Paper Corporation, Ltd., and Bathurst Paper, Ltd., have agreed to a merger of their companies, it was announced here today.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 27 President Johnson resumed his tour of Asia today by starting a state visit to Thailand, but his only public comment was devoted to a dramatization of his visit to the American supply base at Camranh Bay in South Vietnam.

FOR the final program of his current session with the New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein put together a felicitous and neatly balanced program, which he offered in Philharmonic Hall last night. It began with Mozart and ended with Beethoven; beween came the works of two Massachusetts composers with whom the conductor has been closely associated.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 27 (AP) Warrants were issued against two persons today in connection with a $2,000 political contribution made to the campaigns of Gov. Karl F. Rolvaag and Senator Walter F. Mondale, leaders of the Democratic-Farmer-Labor party in Minnesota.
A 675,000-share offering of common stock of Springs Mills, Inc., was sold yesterday at $17 a share by an underwriting group headed by Morgan Stanley Co. and R.S. Dickson Co., Inc.
Mayor Lindsay, reacting to the first major scandal in his administration, dismissed Vincent A. Starace yesterday from his $17,500 post as First Deputy Commissioner of Sanitation.
DETROIT, Oct. 27 (UPI) Paul Henderson scored four goals and assisted on the fifth as he paced th Detroit Red wings to a 5-3 victory over the New York Rangers tonight in a National Hockey League game.

The Carolina Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday it was giving shareholders rights to subscribe for 716,868 shares of common stock at $14.25 a shares at a rate of one new share for each 10 held of record Oct. 27.
TEL AVIV, Oct. 27 A Jerusalem art teacher was in trouble today for having sent Jewish students to Christian missions for free copies of the Gospel in preparation for an examination.
ALBANY, Oct. 27 (AP) The Rev. Donald S. Harrington, Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.'s running mate, disagreed today with Mr. Roosevelt on the state Iottery proposal.
Olivetti Underwood Corpora tion announced its entry yesterday into the copying-machine field.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 27 Communist China's entry into the field of nuclear missile delivery was seen by many United Nations delegates as strengthening the case for Peking's admission to the organization and for acceptance of nuclear disarmament by all nuclear powers.

The dubious practices that have prevailed in price quotations of stocks sold in the nation's vast overthe-counter market are slowly being eliminated. Frank D. O'Connor charged yesterday that the Rockefeller administration had shown no interest in the plight of the housewife faced with rising food prices.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UPI) Lynda Bird Johnson is back in Washington recuperating from a virus after a week on her new job with McCall's Magazine.

BAYONNE, N. J., Oct. 27 Norman Lazarus, a land developer, died here yesterday at his home, 127 West 42d Street. He was president of the Mercury Construction Company in Bay one and of Pocono Peak Lake Estates in Pennsylvania.

WARNING! Don't be misled by the "marionette" show at the Billy Rose Theater that is billed as the WeillBrecht-Blitzstein version of "The Threepenny Opera." Last night's two-act production by the Stockholm Marionette Theater of Fantasy has about as much relation to the masterpiece that ran for six years at the Theater de Lys (1955-61) as a children's pop-up version of Hamlet would have to the original. And it is just as coy an idea.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 27 (UPI) Heavyweight champion Cassius Clay toyed with 10thranked Doug Jones, hitting him at will with a quick left hand, in an exhibition that ended in a chorus of boos tonight.
TOKYO, Oct. 27 (AP) North Vietnam charged today that President Johnson's visit to South Vietnam yesterday was illegal.

LONDON, Oct. 27 (Reuters) Britain has opened her big nuclear power station at Bradwell in Essex to international inspection as a step toward preventing the spread of nuclear weapons, it was disclosed today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 (AP)--A South African Negro leader said today that the United States had produced the closest thing to the apartheid, or racial separation, of his native land.
The Staten Island Zoo has acquired a two-headed turtle. The two heads compete with each other for food, and they also disagree on where they want to go.

DUBLIN, N.H. 27 Mr. and Mrs. Beekman Hoppin Pool of Dublin and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sylvia Fleetwood Pool, to Peter Ridley Sperling of Brookline, Mass. He is the son of Mrs. Ridley Sperling of Hamden, Conn., and Jerome Sperling of Arlington, Va.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 27 (UPI) Fixed opinions on the part of prospective jurors bogged down the Samuel H. Sheppard murder trial today in the face of continued defense requests that the trial be moved to another county.
BERLIN, Oct. 27 The Rev. Billy Graham said here today that he intended to go to Vietnam soon at the invitation of Gen. William C. Westmoreland, commander of United States forces there.
ATLANTA, Oct. 27 (AP) Dr. Paul Louis Schroeder, one of the 10 psychiatric consultants at the Nuremberg war crime trials, died yesterday in a local hospital.

ALBANY, Oct. 27 Frederick Pavlicek, director of the building codes bureau of the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, died yesterday at Albany Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived in South Egremont, Mass.
A State Supreme Court justice yesterday upheld a jury verdict holding Representative Adam Clayton Powell in criminal contempt of court.
LONDON, Oct. 27 Prime Minister Wilson announced today a reform of Britain's honors system to make it less political. Skeptics denounced the plan as a tepid quarter measure.
PEKING, Oct. 28 Special editions of Jenmin Jih Pao, the party paper, carrying news of the launching of Communist China's nuclear missile appeared today when most people were at home.

The Union Pacific Railroad Company announced yesterday that its net income in the third quarter, calculated in conformity with Interstate Commerce Commission requirements, rose to $31,493,975, or $1.37 a share from $24,944,767, or $1.07 a share, the year before. Revenues climbed to $157,726,933 from $141,481,362.

WARSAW, Oct. 27 The Soviet Union and its allies agreed at the conference of their leaders in Moscow last week to grant North Vietnam assistance in materiel and money amounting to about $1-billion, informed Polish sources said today.
Senator Jacob K. Javits contended yesterday that Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.'s third-party candidacy was "jeopardizing Governor Rockefeller's chances" of re-election.

WHITEY FORD, the Yankees' most distinguished convalescent, is back home on Long Island after a sojourn of a couple of weeks in Florida. Besides basking in the sunshine, the artful left-hander paid daily visits to Hollywood, Fla., where classes are being held by the Bombers in their instructional school, an institution of higher learning that the mangled syntax of Casey Stengel described as "the instructural school."

Investment in negotiable certificates of deposit a major source of funds for commercial banks continued to shrink in the week ended Wednesday, but the pace of the decline slowed substantially, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

CARLISLE, Pa., Oct. 21 Representative N. Neiman Craley Jr. stood in his tiny storefront campaign office here in this politically uncertain district today and assessed the lift he is getting from organized labor.
BONN, Oct. 28 The West German Government published today a 13-page statement denying that Dr. Heinrich Lubke, President of the Federal Republic, had committed crimes under the Nazi regime.
INDPENDENCE, Mo., Oct. 27 (UP) An extension of the Harry S. Truman Library building will be constructed soon, Dr. Philip C. Brooks, director of the library, announced today.

Governor Rockefeller led a Truman-style campaign for reelection through Suffolk, Sullivan and Richmond Counties yesterday, running hard and scared and lambasting the opposition. In wealthy Eastern Long Island, he addressed himself to commuters' fears of crime and taxes.
President Johnson's special assistant for consumer affairs urged 19 Queens housewives yesterday to "vote with the dollar" by using boycotts and selective buying to reduce food prices.

Many suburban and upstate districts that once were as safely Republican as Brooklyn is still safely Democratic have now become "swing districts" where both parties compete on even terms. This is all to the good. The quality of candidates is rising, and controversial issues are now more adequately debated than in the past.

THE diagramed deal, played last week at the Mayfair House of Bridge, presents a defensive problem that can be solved in two different ways. Readers who wish to test their own ability should cover the South and West hands.

PARIS, Oct. 27--The French Government said today that Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin would visit France during the first half of December. However, the two other principal Soviet leaders will not come until next year.
The Christopher D. Smithers Foundation announced yesterday that it had made a $1million grant to help with the rehabilitation of 300,000 alcoholics here.

HONOLULU, Oct. 27 (AP) Ted Makalena, born and reared about a brassie shot away from the first tee, and two golf tour pros, Doug Sanders and Miller Barber, had six-under-par 66's on the Waialae course today and shared the first-round lead in the $57,000 Hawaiian open.
The Columbia Pictures Corporation filed suit yesterday in New York Federal District Court against two groups who jointly claim ownership of more than 50 per cent of its common stock.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Oct. 27 Harry Toscano, of New Castle, Pa., a 24-yearold former Pennsylvania amateur golf champion, topped the 32 freshman pros who were graduated from the Professional Golfers' Association school tonight.
ROCHESTER, Oct. 27 Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. said tonight he would not promise the voters of New York that their taxes would not be raised in the next four years if he were elected Governor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 Freight traffic generated by carloadings on U.S. railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Oct. 22 were both considerably ahead of the volume in the corresponding week of last year.
Alfrd J. McGinness of Akron, Ohio, manager of national advertising for the Firestone Tire Rubber Company, died yesterday of a heart ailment at New York Hospital. He was 63 years old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 George Hamilton, the actor who frequently escorts Lynda Bird Johnson and who is a principal target of those disgruntled with the draft system, has been summoned by his Selective Service board for a physical examination.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 27 (AP) Senator Edward M. Kennedy sparred with antiwar hecklers at the University of Wisconsin today and won a standing ovation from a crowd of 4,000.
WARSAW, Oct. 27 A violent attack against Stefan Cardinals Wyszynski as a sworn enemy of Communist Poland has been published here.

Natan Schwartzman, a 36year-old Brazilian violinist who studied here in the late nineteen-forties, returned last night for his debut at Carnegie Recital Hall, Mr. Schwartzman's concert is part of a tour sponsored by the Brazilian Government.
THE National Basketball Association season is less than two weeks old, but trends are already discernible.

BONN, Oct. 27 A West German Social Democratic leader in the Bundestag (lower house of Parliament) today asked if reports that West German scientists were negotiating contracts to help Communist China develop its missile capacity were true.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Oct. 27 (UPI) The Douglas Aircraft Company said today it had been awarded a $149-million Army contract to develop and test an advanced version of the Zeus missile in the Nike-X missile defense system. WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 President Johnson signed a $5billion supplementary appropri- ations bill today that included more than $2-billion for school and Library aid.

At Lincoln Center: Strauss's "Elektra," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Offenbach's "The Tales of Hoffmann," New York City Opera, New York State Theater, 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Philharmonic Hall, 2:15.

Five homes here known for their art collections will be open to visitors next Thursday afternoon in behalf of the joint campaign committee of Planned Parenthood-World Population and Planned Parenthood of Manhattan and the Bronx.
How much drawing power does Lincoln Center have? Enough for about 60 persons to fly in from San Francisco for two programs tomorrow. The cost? Three-hundred dollars each.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 27 The Albuquerque Symphony Orchestra last night celebrated its 35th anniversary by opening a new season in its new home, the new University Concert Hall. The occasion, without meaning to do so, underlined a moral for our nation and our time.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 27 Bill Elias Was saying today that Navy will be is its best physical condition since the opening game of the season for its 40th football meeting with Notre Dame in Philadelphia Saturday when the telephone rang.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 27 The decision by the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. not to endorse any candidate for Governor this year was made today although some of the 1,500 delegates vowed last night on their arrival to make a floor fight for their favorite candidate.

The effectiveness of President Johnson's Columbus Day visit to the city may well be determined when the votes are counted in the 16th Congressional District, where the incumbent, Representative John M. Murphy, is engaged in a tough campaign for re-election.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration asserted today that a drug company had issued misleading advertising of the antibiotic Lincocin.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 27 W. Averell Harriman received a somewhat remote welcome this afternoon when he arrived to report to Indonesian officials on the outcome of the Manila conference on Vietnam.
The State Health Department pledged yesterday to help the city "overhaul" its municipal hospital system and find longrange solutions to long-standing problems.
The Tahse Corporation, organized by Martin Tahse to produce touring musicals, yesterday filed a voluntary petition in bankruptcy in Federal District Court here.

The 15th Congressional District is a 12-mile long gerrymander that has its head under the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge and its tail at the Brooklyn Bridge.

BOISE, Idaho, Oct. 26 When conservative Republicans helped to defeat Gov. Robert E. Smylie in the August primary they unleashed furies that will not go back into the bottle, it has become apparent in the last days of the Idaho campaign.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 27 Howard C. Pauly, an electrical engineer with the Bell Telephone Laboratories for 37 years, died Tuesday at the Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 123 Gordonhurst Avenue.

Mr. and Mrs. William Parks of Eltingville, S.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ann Parks, to John Joseph Carty Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carty of Brooklyn. A January wedding is planned.

Miss Lorraine Greenberg's engagement to Alex Weinberger has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Greenberg of Jamaica, Estates, Queens. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmond Weinberger of Montreal.
Stephen Moore, a 19-year-old Lightning Class skipper from Plandome, L. I., took the major prize last night at the annual awards dinner of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.

Seventy down, more to come, That's the number of countries that have agreed to participate in Montreal's Expo '67 next year. Pierre Dupuy, the diminutive diplomat who is running the show in his home town, hastens to add that the figure is 70 "at least."
One of the leading builders of middle-income housing in this country said yesterday that strikes, tight-money policies and high taxes were serious threats to construction enterprises.
The Boys' Club of New York will receive the proceeds from a preview next Wednesday evening of a show of 31 flower paintings by Henri Fantin-Lasour at the Acquavella Galleries, 119 East 57th Street.

A folk music show starring Bob Dylan, singer and songs writer, has been postponed by the American Broadcasting Company network. It was to have been televised on Wednesday, Nov. 16, from 10 to 11 P.M. on "ABC Stage 67."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 27 The General Assembly adopted a resolution tonight to terminate South Africa's mandate from the League of Nations to administer the neighboring territory of South-West Africa. The vote was 114 to 2, with 3 abstentions.
GRENADA, Miss., Oct. 27 (UPI)--Sixteen Negroes, mostly teen-agers, were arrested today when they attempted to march on two newly integrated schools to protest alleged harassment of Negro students.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 27 (AP) Kelvin Hartley, 32-yearold Melbourne engineer, fired a four-under-par 68 today and led Australia to a six-stroke lead over South Africa, in the first round of the Eisenhower Trophy's golf tournament.

ABERFAN, Wales, Oct. 27 (AP) Eighty-one child victims of the Aberfan disaster were buried in a mass funeral today at a bleak mountainside cemetery half a mile from the spot where their school was crushed in a slag head avalanche last Friday.
A STUDY the Coast Guard describes as "revealing" has confirmed what a lot of people have suspected for years: young boat operators are more dangerous than their elders.
The American Guild of Authors and Composers celebrated its 35th year last night with an anniversary ball at the plaza's Grand Ballroom.

A.G. Becker Co., a member of the New York Stock Exchange, was charged yesterday with "maintaining a false or fictitious market" in the stock of the Westec Corporation. The accusation was made by a Westec stockholder in a suit filed in Cook County, Ill., Circuit Court.
BRECKENRIDGE, Tex., Oct. 27 (AP) A female former convict eluded Texas Rangers yesterday, slipped her 95-yearold millionaire patient into Oklahoma and married him.
Frozen orange juice concentrate futures had a surprising day for a brand new contract. They jumped the 2-cents-apound permissible limit yesterday.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange rose by a fraction yesterday but below their best levels because of profit taking.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Oct. 27 City refuse collectors began today to empty trash cans that have been lining residential streets since Tuesday when the workers abandoned their trucks and began picketing.
BOWDOINHAM, Me., Oct. 27 The duck shooting on Merrymeeting Bay has not been of the best in recent days, although the daily limit of three ducks usually can be obtained.

Senators Jacob K. Javits and Robert F. Kennedy charged yesterday that the ultra-right John Birch Society was pouring its "full resources" into the fight against the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board.
The Deputy Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said last night that "this is no time to be complacent" in the race for space.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 27 (UPI)--Three small boys were found dead in their apartment home here at 425 Rosehill Road today about an hour after the police said their mother threw herself under the wheels of a truck.

Bequests totaling $11-million have been left to relatives, friends and employes by Mrs. Elizabeth N. Graham (Elizabeth Arden), according to a will filed for probate yesterday in Manhattan's Surrogate's Court.
The appointment of John C. Kenefick as vice president for operations was announced yesterday by the New York Central Railroad.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 27 Chile wants to reach a specific arms limitation agreement with her Latin-American neighbors, Foreign Minister Gabriel Valdez said today.

HONG KONG, Friday, Oct. 28 Analysts here ascribed Communist China's successful detonation of an atomic missile to the skills of Western-trained scientists, although the Chinese Communist press agency called it "a great victory for Mao Tse Tung's thought."

PARIS Having sat for months beside it with their diplomatic fishing poles, the NATO allies decided this week to cross their Rubicon, in this case called the Seine. With a unanimity that was unusual because it included France, the fifteen partners resolved to move their headquarters to Brussels.

Robert W. Howison of Bronx- ville, N.Y., and Quogue, L.I., who retired in April as vice president in charge of sales of the Alexander Smith Carpets division of Mohasco Industries, Inc., died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 67 years old.
The police yesterday seized a two-foot-long machete, a hooked linoleum knife and a switchblade knife from a group of youths moving toward the Lafayette High School in Brook- lyn.

WESTBURY, L.I, Oct. 27 Twenty-two-year-old John Patterson Jr. received a phone call that made him the happiest young man in Nassau County today. Calling from Dalton, Ga., was John Patterson Sr., his father.

The American Stock Exchange advanced for the second consecutive session yesterday as the market continued to respond to improved earnings reports.

Five young women will be presented at the annual dinner dance of the Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York next Friday at the Plaza. The debutantes are members of the society or daughters of members.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 The Treasury announced today a cash refunding of $4.1-billion worth of securities maturing Nov. 15.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 27--E. Kenneth Smith of the Hempstead Golf Club was reelected tonight for a second one-year term as president of the Long Island Golf Association at its annual meeting at the Hempstead Golf Club.

The late President Theodore Roosevelt was honored yesterday, the 108th anniversary of his birth, as the sportsman of the century.

PARIS, Oct. 27 The successful Chinese nuclear test is regarded by French officials as further proof of the soundness of the French argument that Communist China can no longer be ignored as a world power.
HONG KONG, Friday, Oct. 28 Communist China announced today that it had exploded on target a nuclear weapon carried by a guided missile.

WESTBURY, L.I, Oct. 27 Ferdie Catropa of Peninsula and Frank Cardi of Rockaway Hunt Club shot a 32, 31 63 today for the best round in a Metropolitan Professional Golf Association senior-junior pro championship at the Salisbury Park course.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 27 (AP) The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation announced plans today to build another atomic generating plant upstate.
The tonnage of world shipbuilding rose to a new record during the third quarter of this year, it was reported yesterday by Lloyd's Register of Shipping.

The license of New York Airways to operate helicopters between the Pan American Building and John F. Kennedy International Airport will "most probably" be extended for one month, to Nov. 30, Leo Brown, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 Officials here reacted today with a mixture of skepticism and sympathy to a proposed $185-billion "freedom budget" to eliminate poverty in America over the next 10 years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 Representative William B. Widnall of New Jersey, the ranking Republican on the House Banking Committee, called today for a full investigation of possible American losses in connection with the closing of Lebanon's Intra Bank.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 The reorganization plan of the trus- tees of the New Haven Railroad, providing for the ultimate sale of the bankrupt carrier to a merged New York Central and Pennsylvania Railroad, was formally filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today.

ALBANY, Oct. 27 The Court of Appeals ruled 5-to-2 today that new restrictions on confessions did not apply retroactively to cases decided by state courts before the United States Supreme Court laid down the limitations last June 13.

The spot rate on the British pound moved higher in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. The closing quotation of $2.7921 was 3 points above Wednesday's level.

"We're fighters and we're going to fight" the control bid of the Allied Products Corporation, A.L. Freedlander, chairman of the Dayco Corporation, declared yesterday.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), Oct. 27 An Israeli freight train was derailed tonight several miles southwest of Jerusalem after setting off an explosive charge on the track believed to have been laid by Syrian-backed infiltrators.
PARIS, Oct. 27 France stopped buying United States gold this month. For the first time in more than one and a half years, the French Government is not making its regular monthly purchase.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 27 Carlos Lacerda, former Governor of the state of Guanabara, who took a leading part in the downfall of the last three Presidents, called today for a "people's union" against the present Government which he asserted was ruling Brazil by proxy for the United States Central Intelligence Agency.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) Americans for Democratic Action described the second session of the 89th Congress tonight as disappointing and said President Johnson must bear the responsibility "for many of the failures."

The directors of the Monsanto Company elected John L. Christian a senior vice president yesterday. The office is a new one within Monsanto's management structure.

CANTERBURY, England, Oct. 27 (AP) Soviet and British Communists formed part of the congregation that filled the nave of Canterbury Cathedral today for the funeral of Dr. Hewlett Johnson, who was called the Red Dean of Canterbury. He died Saturday at the age of 92.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 The United States has preliminary indications that the Chinese Communists fired a missile about 400 miles and that it carried an atomic war- head of the size dropped on Hiroshima during World War II.
The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company reported gains yesterday in operating revenues and net income for the three months ended Sept. 30.

Milton Ritzenberg's Spooky Joe flashed past James Melton's My Chap in the final strides to win the $18,550 New York Turf Writers Cup at Aqueduct yesterday. With Doug Small in the saddle, Spooky Joe scored by a nose in the 2 -mile hurdle race that attracted 10 starters.

Directors of the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation voted here yesterday to raise the quarterly dividend to 45 cents a common share from 40 cents.

The Manhattan chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution will celebrate its 66th anniversary with a Charter Day Tea next Thursday at Mrs. John Welchel Finger's home at 860 Park Avenue. The guest of honor and speaker will be Mrs. William H. Sullivan, president general of the D.A.R.

YONKERS, Oct. 27 The total of 592 standardbred yearlings, colts, fillies, stallions, mares and broodmares sold at auction during the seventh annual revival of the three-day Old Glory horse sale, which was concluded today at Yonkers Raceway, brought $1,267,850, for an average of $2,142. Mayor Lindsay stepped into the plumbers' strike yesterday in an effort to hasten a settlement of the 96-day dispute.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Oct. 28 --Woe to the politician who must sponsor a tax increase. Gov. William H. Avery needed a $45-million package last year. The former Republican Congressman, serving his first term as chief executive of Kansas, sought and got tax increases on liquor, cigarettes, sales and income to provide the needed funds.
A $75-a-week kitchen worker at Bellevue Hospital won a $135,000 malpractice verdict against the city Thursday on his claim that the hospital had wrongfully diagnosed an illness.

Dr. Louis L. Shapiro, a former medical officer in the United States Public Health Service, died of a heart attack last Saturday in Istanbul, Turkey, while on a world tour. He was 72 years old and lived at 34 Wentworth Street in Bridgeport, Conn.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28--Arthur J. Goldberg called on the Security Council today to act urgently to avoid "a showdown" in the Middle East.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Oct. 28--Vice President Humphrey came to Florida tonight to play peacemaker in the Democratic intraparty battle and found that the way of the peacemaker is hard.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 28--Carl H. Ruprecht, who retired in 1958 as director of advertising, sales promotion and public relations for the Underwood Corporation (now Olivetti Underwood), typewriter manufacturers, died today at Mountainside Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 21 Norwood Avenue.

HOUSTON, Oct. 28 (AP)-- The United States attempt to launch its first manned Apollo moonship into orbit around the earth has been delayed until at least January, the space agency announced today.

The F.W. Woolworth Company incurred slightly reduced profits in the third quarter and first nine months despite a sharp increase in sales, the interim report disclosed yesterday.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 28 --Gerald F. Pace, head of Pace Associates, 141 Parkway Road, real-estate consultants and appraisers, died Wednesday at Lawrence Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 250 Bronxville Road.
A handbag containing a roseshaped diamond and platinum pin valued at $150,000 was stolen early yesterday from a woman supervising the decorations for last night's April in Paris Ball.
GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 28 --Miss Margaret Fernald Kohler and Dr. Charles Everett Nicholson Jr. have made plans to be married in December.

A common theory about solo instrumentalists is that they are happiest when they can get together with each other and submerge their individual egos in selfless performances of chamber music. All goes comfortably and beautifully because they understand music and each other so well, etc. etc. etc. It is a lovely theory that occasionally works out in practice.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 28-- President Osvaldo Lopez Arellano of Honduras ended an official visit to Mexico today. The visit was viewed as another step toward closer relations between Mexico and Central America.
Kathy Kusner, the 27-year-old Arlington, Va., Miss America of the horse show circuit, gave a convincing demonstration of her prowess at the national event in Madison Square Garden last night.

By noon on the day after each of the previous 14 April in Paris Balls, virtually everyone has sworn either to herself, her best friend or her hairdresser that she would never, never ever get caught in that huge crush again, cross her heart and hope to die.

ALBUQUERQUE, Oct. 28-- The problems of a city like Albuquerque in raising the level of its cultural activities are manifold, but they differ only in degree, not kind, from those of other communities in the United States. There is a desire in many quarters for lifting standards.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 28 (AP) --The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit ordered the Federal District Court in Louisville today to reconsider a $2-million libel suit brought by Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker, retired, against The Louisville Courier-Journal and Times and WHAS, Inc.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 28--Doug Hardin, Harvard sophomore, set a course record in leading his team to victories over Princeton and Yale in the Big Three cross-country championship over the Yale golf course today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UPI) --The Civil Aeronautics Board blamed today a pilot's decision to continue his flight in bad weather, despite lack of instrument training, for the crash of a light plane in which two lives were lost.
A group of 17 officers and directors of the Glen Alden Corporation have been named in a complaint brought by a stockholder in Supreme Court here. The complainant is Samuel C. Wolfensohn.

HAVANA, Oct. 28.--Most of the favorite teams retained the lead in their sections of the seven-group 52-nation 17th Chess Olympics after completion of the second round of the preliminaries at the Havana Libre Hotel last night.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 28 --Edward M. Keating, publisher of Ramparts magazine, said today that "we are going to invade North Vietnam" not long after the November election.

William S. Cashel, a vice president of the Cross Brown Company, real-estate brokerage and management concern at 532 Fifth Avenue, died of a heart attack Thursday in his home at 2 Fifth Avenue. He was 79 years old.
MEMPHIS, Oct. 28 (AP)-- The throbbing beat of the blues curled out across Beale Street again today, a Beale Street much changed from the time when W.C. Handy made it the home of the blues.

Delta Air Lines said yesterday that it recently had exercised options on 12 DC-9 and seven DC-8 aircraft--all of the "stretched" type--to be delivered in 1968 and 1969 by the Douglas Aircraft Company.
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 20.8 per cent in production for the week ended Oct. 22, compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28-- The McGraw-Edison com- pany will receive a patent next week for its talking typewriter, which has taught hundreds of children to read, spell, typewrite and take dictation.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 28-- The first "happening in Buenos Aires happened in a small theater a little more than two years ago, when people on stage threw spaghetti at the audience and the audience, naturally, threw it back.

By PHILIP SHABECOFF Special to The New York Times BONN, Oct. 28--Chancellor Ludwig Erhard's minority Government suffered a rebuff today as the Bundesrat, the upper house of Parliament, unanimously rejected its proposed 1967 federal budget.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28--The President of the General Assembly, Abdul Rahman Pazhwak of Afghanistan, is consulting with members on the selection of a commission of 14 to study the problems of United Nations supervision of South-West Africa.
The increased stock transfer tax is producing more revenue for the city than expected.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed a little firmer yesterday after being lower most of the day. However, losses still outnumbered gains.
METUCHEN, N.J., Oct. 28-- A former Rutgers football star who lost an arm fighting in World War II died early today while trying to rescue his father-in-law from their burning home.

Nearly 100 employes--mostly kitchen help--walked off their jobs Metropolitan Hospital yesterday and joined a Teamsters Union picket line that stopped the flow of food and drugs into the 1,000-bed municipal institution.
Continental Airlines, Inc., reported yesterday a record net income of $12,576,000, or $3.86 a share, for the first nine months of 1966.
O. Rudolph Johnson, an economist and a founder, director and former vice president of C-E-I-R, Inc., died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 860 United Nations Plaza.

THE season's first big sale of Americana, held at Parke-Bernet last Saturday, showed that interest in the field continues to be strong and that the term has been broadened to include material from the beginning of this century.

Michael Davis, an English violinist now on the faculty of Wooster College in Ohio, and Robert Woitach, the pianist who accompanied him in two previous New York recitals, were heard again yesterday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall. Their program was a romanticist's delight--Schumann's A Minor Sonata, Op. 105, Brahms's "Rain" Sonata and the Sonata in A by Cesar Franck.
TOMS RIVER, N.J., Oct. 29 --James M. Maltbie, a former assistant secretary of the Irving Trust Company, died yesterday in his home at 175 Edgewood Drive. His age was 68.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange moved in a narrow range yesterday but the market managed to close slightly higher in quiet trading.

BRISBANE, Australia, Oct. 28 (AP)--Arnold Palmer shot a four-under-par 70 for a total of 137 today and took a onestroke lead over Peter Thomson of Australia at the halfway mark of the Australian open golf championship.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 28 (UPI) --A permanent jury of eight men and four women was seated today to decide whether Samuel H. Sheppard is guilty of murdering his first wife, a crime for which he has spent nearly 10 years in prison.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP)--Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon, urged today that a decision on the proposed merger of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the American Broadcasting Company be delayed until after Congress returns in January.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 28--Indian officials declined to comment publicly today on Communist China's missile test. In private, some expressed concern over Peking's "remarkable speed" in developing its nuclear capacity.

One of the largest textile companies in Great Britain, the Calico Printers Association Ltd., of Manchester, has formed an American subsidiary, to sell a variety of its own products in the men's, women's and children's wear field, as well as fabrics and textile machinery.

The New York City Opera revived its production of Offenbach's "Les Contes d'Hoffmann" last night at the New York State Theater. The combination of the fanciful sets (borrowed from the Cincinnati Summer Opera), the singing of the City Opera regulars, and the conducting of Julius Rudel made the opera a delight to see and hear.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct.28 --General Suharto, chairman of the Cabinet Presidium, declared tonight that the Vietnam problem" should be solved by Asia, in an Asian way and by Asian people."

The appointment of John H. Wiles as president and chiefexecutive officer of the Wallerstein division of Baxter Laboratories, Inc., was an nounced yesterday in Morton Grove, Ill.

The principal of Lafayette High School in Brooklyn said yesterday that alarming rumors chat brought racial tensions close to a crisis pitch at the school appeared to have been deliberately inspired.

Brigadier of Bloomingdale, N.J., and Provincetown, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Harris Brigadier, to John Seymour Howland, son of Mrs. William Merrill of Amherst, Mass., and the late Richard M. Howland of Riverside, Conn. A December wedding is planned.

ROME, Oct. 30--With evangelical fervor, 17,000 Italian Socialists today hailed the unification of their two parties as an advance toward the democratic conquest of power and leadership of the Italian working class.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 30 (AP) George P. Mahoney said today he did not want the Ku Klux Klan and the national States Rights party to support his Democratic candidacy for Governor of Maryland.

A $1-million fund campaign will be opened by the Young Men's Christian Association of Greater New York on Nov. 14 with a dinner in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton. The fund will support the organization's youth programs for the coming year.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 30 The biggest wedding reception Lebanon has ever seen was held last spring at the Phoenicia Hotel in Beirut. The local press reported that the wedding cake weighed three tons and cost $10,000.
The International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots will set up a new union training school to train mariners who do not have officer licenses.

YONKERS, Oct. 31--A man and woman held up a branch of the First National Bank in Yonkers this morning, wounding the bank manager and a customer, and escaping with an estimated total of $12,160.
Mayor Lindsay has the right to delegate to aides his duties to preside at meetings of the Board of Estimate, State Supreme Court Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff ruled yesterday.
The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago told stockholders yesterday that business during the first nine months "showed significant improvements over the same period of 1965."

A pleasing recital of songs and arias was given at Carnegie Recital Hall last night by Evelyn Reynolds, a mezzo-contralto who has done considerable work in the Chicago area but who had not appeared here previously.

Louis Harris, the pollster, in an article in yesterday's New York Post, said the Democrats had risen from 52 to 54 per cent in the national vote for Representative in late October from September. They slipped from 47 to 46 per cent in the contests for governor. The Democratic vote for Senator remained at 52 per cent.

BUFFALO, Oct. 31 (AP)-- Five children, from 2 to 4 years old, died today in a fire that heavily damaged a home on the East Side here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) --W.E. Reynolds, former Commissioner of the Public Building Service, died of cancer today at his home. He was 79 years old.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31--Representatives of Ghana and Guinea today met separately at their requests with Secretary General Thant to discuss their dispute.

Miss Ann Elizabeth Neely of 20 Brook Manor, Pleasantville, N. Y., who retired in 1964 as program consultant for the Council on Social Work Education, 245 East 46th Street, died yesterday at the Cleveland Clinic in Cleveland after heart survery. She was 70 years old.

GREENWICH VILLAGE mothers have been com plaining that their children are being pushed out of Washington Square by beatniks. Yesterday afternoon, the kids pushed back. They turned the park into a huge Halloween party--and the beats, rather than fight, joined them.

Governor Rockefeller recently announced that he intends to use operations research techniques and personnel for improving the efficiency of the state government. With the state budget now running in the neighborhood of four billion dollars annually, there should be abundant opportunity for creative employment of this management science to get maximum returns from these huge expenditures. This is true no matter who wins the gubernatorial election.

Kathy Kusner, cast in a make-or-break role for the United States Equestrian Team for the Nations Cup in the international jumping of the National Horse Show last night, came through handsomely with an aged chestnut gelding, Untouchable.
BONN, Oct. 31--Leaders of the West German air force have decided that the Luftwaffe's crash-plagued Starfighter jets will not have to be replaced until 1970, Defense Ministry sources reported today.
The appointment of Richard I. Fricke as senior vice president was announced yesterday by the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York.

The president of the Board of Education pleaded yesterday for approval of a $284-million school capital budget, saying that 33 of the 60 academic high schools are now on special sessions that hinder giving children a good education.
The Allied Products Corporation conceded defeat yesterday in its week-old bid to acquire a majority interest in the Dayco Corporation.
TOKYO, Oct. 31--Trade circles here have expressed concern over the effects that Communist China's development of a nuclear guided missile may have on Japan's expanding trade with that country.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. (UPI)--The United States Education Office moved today to cut off Federal funds for 14 Southern school districts for failing to comply with desegregation guidelines.
FARMER CITY, Ill., Oct. 30 --Fences are coming down all over the Midwest prairies.

The fund for the families of the 12 firemen killed in a Madison Square fire two weeks ago reached $230,000 yesterday.

BERLIN, Oct. 31--On the 449th anniversary of the establishment of Protestantism, 1,200 leaders of the Evangelical wing of the church, meeting in West Berlin, discussed today obstacles to the preaching of the Gospel and the basic teachings of Martin Luther throughout the world.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31-- It has been much like 1960 all over again, traveling the campaign routes this year with Richard M. Nixon and Senator Robert Kennedy of New York. It is richly nostalgic, a little saddening; Lyndon Johnson has been out of it all these past few weeks, just as he was in 1960, and one cannot help thinking that we have only been marking time, waiting for an old battle to be rejoined.
Trading was dull yesterday on the London Stock Exchange, and prices dipped.

Gerry Swinehart, chairman of the executive committee of Carl Byoir Associates, Inc., a public relations organization, died yesterday in Carlsbad, Calif. He was 63 years old.

Stock prices backed and filled yesterday and closed with an almost even balance of advances and declines.

In a talk last week before the Catholic Poetry Society of America Robert Moses came out for Chaucer, Shelley, Byron and Tennyson. LONDON, Oct. 31--Monopoly conditions operating against the public interest prevail in the British film industry, a Government antitrust commission found today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 1--Vietcong terrorists disrupted South Vietnam's National Day celebration today, firing recoilless-rifle shells into downtown Saigon for the first time.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31-- Yields on new issues of Treasury bills continued to ease somewhat in this week's auction.
The men from Bossy should have been delighted yesterday --but they weren't.
BEN PRESERVE Us, by Chaim Bermant (Holt, Rinehart Winston, $3.95). Humorous novel about a rabbi in a small Scottish provincial town.

Four candidates are vying for election in Manhattan's 19th Congressional District, but the campaign is only a mild anticlimax to a bitter Democratic fight that has probably already settled the election.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Oct. 31 --Mrs. Arthur Lester Middleton Worthey has announced the engagement of her stepdaughter, Miss Mary Worthey, to Samuel Cook Edsall 2d of Hartford, son of the Rev. Samuel Harmon Edsall and Mrs. Edsall of Geneva, N.Y. A fall wedding is planned.

HILLSIDE, N. J., Oct. 31-- Mr. and Mrs. J. Carroll Dolan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sueanne Kathleen Dolan, to Peter Lawrence Korn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard E. Korn of Elizabeth. A summer wedding is planned.
Important roles in forthcoming productions have been allotted to a number of players.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 31-- Depositors with accounts of 5,000 Lebanese pounds ($1,660) or less in Intra Bank, which suspended payments Oct. 14, will be paid off by the Lebanese Government under a draft bill approved tonight by the Finance Committee of Parliament.
Frank D. O'Connor predicted his own victory in the race for Governor for the first time yesterday and said that the "witching hour" had struck for Governor Rockefeller's administration.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31--India demanded today that all nuclear nations be obliged to halt the production of atomic arms under a proposed treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.

PARIS, Oct. 31--It takes very little time in Paris to discover that the quarrel between France and the United States runs deeper than a mere political squabble. In fact, France and America disagree about practically everything.
One of the six mental patients who escaped from a Bellevue Hospital psychiatric ward Sunday night was still at large yesterday.
DETROIT, Oct. 31 (AP)-- Communications workers rejected a proposed contract with the Michigan Bell Telephone Company by a vote of 7,018 to 4,825, a ballot count showed today.
At a formal White House reception in January of 1948, President Harry S. Truman noticed that the crystal chandelier in the Blue Room was making a tinkling sound.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 31--W. Averell Harriman, President Johnson's roving Ambassador, met with Indian leaders today and explained to them the American position at the Manila conference on Vietnam.

DEARBORN, Mich., Oct. 31 (UPI)--A Federal judge refused today to ban from the election ballot Nov. 8 a question asking voters in this city of 112,000 population whether they think the United States should pull out of Vietnam.

The Marathon Oil Company reported yesterday record earnings for both the third quarter and first nine months of 1966. The company's crude oil production and refined products sales also were at new highs for these periods.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) --The State Department said today that Guinean militiamen were posted outside the American Embassy in Conakry, the United States Information Service and Peace Corps headquarters.

When Secretary General Thant announced General von Horn's resignation as acting chief of the United Nations mission in Yemen in 1963, he said the general's reasons were "largely personal in nature." But some informed sources felt the resignation reflected a sharp disagreement over what the mission was supposed to do in Yemen.

The New York Times and The Associated Press will receive the National Broadcasting Company's electronic vote analysis data on election night next Tuesday, William R. McAndrew, president of N.B.C. News, announced yesterday.

Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation, announced yesterday the appointment of Herbert L. Barnet of New York City as the national chairman of the March of Dimes, the fundraising arm of the organization.
MAISONETTE, St. RegisSheraton, Fifth Avenue and 55th Street, Carol Bruce, singer.
Waterfront management and labor were asked yesterday by a high-ranking Federal official to find new and imaginative answers to waterfront labor relations problems in the years ahead.

A group of 114 scholars, intellectuals and others, who on Sunday urged opposition to Communist China's membership in the United Nations and to her recognition by the United States "at this time," was organized by Dr. Frank N. Trager, professor of international affairs at New York University.

WARSAW, Oct. 31--Leszek Kolakowski, professor of philosophy at the University of Warsaw, was reported today to have been expelled from the Communist party after a speech he made at a university meeting last week.
The Zenith Radio Corporation is headed for its sixth successive year of record sales and earnings, based on results issued yesterday for the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30.
SUPERIOR, Wis., Oct. 31 (AP)--"Oh, my God," said the mother of Sergeant Boeckenhaupt when told tonight of his arrest.
BONN, Oct. 31--Bavaria's Minister President, Alfons Goppel, a leader of the Bavarian wing of Chancellor Ludwig Erhard's Christian Democratic party, called on Dr. Erhard today to resign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--The Air Force announced today the award of a $235.8-million contract to the Boeing Company for the development and production of a nuclear-tipped air-toground missile for use by United States strategic bombers.
Mrs. Hilda Bull Perrin, the widow of Lee J. Perrin, a lawyer, died last night in her apartment at 116 East 63d Street. She was 78 years old.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. yesterday accused his Democratic gubernatorial opponent, Frank D. O'Connor, of "appeasing the backlash vote" by predicting city voters would abolish the police department Civilian Complaint Review Board.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 29-- Arizona has two kinds of Democrats--genuine ones and "pinto" (multi-colored) Democrats who vote Republican. The prevalence of the latter this season threatens to cost the party a governorship and perhaps a House seat as well.
Frank O'Connor was assailed from three sides yesterday as the result of his prediction that the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board would be defeated.
Eleven constitutional amendments and one statewide proposition will be on the ballot next Tuesday. We urge negative votes on Amendments Seven, Ten and Eleven. The others all deserve support.

GILBERT BECAUD, the French singer who made his Broadway debut in a oneman show last night, has an electric quality about him. He darts about the stage in quick, whippetlike movements. He pivots and turns...
Sigurd J. Arnesen, former publisher of the Norwegian weekly newspaper Nordisk Tidende (Norwegian News) in Brooklyn, died Sunday in Sarasota, Fla. His age was 79.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31-- Three unidentified satellites are in orbit about the earth.
Domenico Cimarosa's comic opera "The Ladies' Game" was given at Town Hall last night in an English translation by Anna Russell that sounded just like an Anna Russell monologue.
Columbia University opened a three-year campaign last night to raise $200-million for a dramatic expansion and to provide the funds to maintain a firstrate faculty and student body.
Steel production fell slightly for the fourth successive week in the seven days ended Saturday, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
BRISBANE, Australia, Oct. 31 (AP)--Minutes after he arrived from a 36-hour trip from Argentina, Allen Fox of Los Angeles was involved today in a marathon doubles tennis match.
The State Liquor Authority opened hearings yesterday into the ownership of a Long Island discotheque where a murdered go-go girl had worked.

The United States Tobacco Company purchased yesterday B.A. Bernard Co., Inc., of Camden, N.J., a manufacturer of all-meat dog and cat foods. This is the third tobacco company to diversify into the pet food business recently.

ROMA, Tex., Oct. 31 (AP)-- Mexican officials arrested three Texas farm worker sympathizers today after they blocked the International Bridge for an hour between Roma and Miguel Aleman, Mexico, by shoving a gate across the span.

LONDON, Oct. 31--Roy Jenkins, the Labor Government's Home Secretary, vigorously defended himself tonight against a conservative motion of censure following the recent prison escape of George Blake, the former British diplomat who had spied for the Soviet Union.
Marine and Aviation Commissioner Leo Brown yesterday extended until Nov. 30 the permit for helicopter operations at the Pan Am Building. The permit was to have expired at midnight.
PITTSBURGH, Tuesday, Nov. 1--The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers went on a nationwide strike against the Westinghouse Electric Corporation just after midnight today.

Nineteen men were held yesterday in $1,000 to $7,500 bail each--a total of $81,000 --in an alleged conspiracy by an anti-Communist Minutemen group to commit arson with firebombs. A hearing in Queens Criminal Court was set for Nov. 22.

The appointment of Arthur C. Novacek as executive vice president and general manager of Transamerican Trailer Ferry, Inc., has been announced by Eric Holzer, president of the company and of American Union Transport, Inc., its affiliate.
ATLANTA, Oct. 31 (UPI)-- Stokely Carmichael said tonight that President Johnson and his family could go to Vietnam if they wanted to but, as for him, "Hell, no!"

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 31 (UPI)--Mrs. Helen Sims, whose husband and daughter were slain 10 days ago, died tonight without regaining con- sciousness and ending police hopes that she might give them a lead.
At least one judge and several other persons were involved in a plot last July to shake down a liquor license applicant for $5,000, Queens District Attorney Nat Hentel said yesterday.

The quiet revolution that has transformed working conditions on the docks in the last decade was highlighted by the opening in Brooklyn yesterday of a glistening new Waterfront Commission employment center.

Henry Miller's Theater, 124 West 43d Street, between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas, will be acquired for $500,000 in cash by Detroit's Nederlander family, which controls the Palace Theater here and owns a growing chain of road theaters. The Broadway landmark is being sold by Mrs. Gilbert Miller, wife of the 82-year old international producer.

N. Harvey Collisson, chairman of the board of directors of the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation since 1964, died today in his office at 460 Park Avenue apparently of a heart attack. He was 66 years old and lived at 136 East 56th Street and in Hendersonville, N. C.

TORONTO, Oct. 31 (Canadian Press)--A claim for $450million, one of the largest sums ever sought in a Canadian court action, was presented today against the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company before Chief Justice G.A. Gale of the Ontario Supreme Court.

MANY experts make a habit of signaling their length in any suit which is led by the declaring side. A high spot card is played whenever an even number of cards is held. This can be a considerable help to careful defenders who count all suits in order to build a picture of the distribution, but it can be carried too far.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Oct. 31--Warren W. Wilentz, the Democratic candidate for Senator, campaigned hard in northern New Jersey today.

Mr. and Mrs. Paul Gordon Evans have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Serena Evans, to Robert Rose Carson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carson of Clinton and Geneva, N. Y. A June wedding is planned.
LONDON, Oct. 31 (AP)--Detectives in the hunt are now in little doubt that Blake received his final instructions for the escape by short-wave radio.

A slight cutback in the number of night games, an end to successive series with the Los Angeles Dodgers and the San Francisco Giants, and an earlier date for the annual old-timers' game are features of the 1967 Shea Stadium schedule of the New York Mets. The schedule was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) --An attempt to establish commercial communications via satellite over a vast Pacific Ocean area has failed.
UCHINOURA, Japan, Oct. 31 (AP)--The first MU rocket, designed to orbit Japan's first scientific satellite by 1968, was launched here today.

Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner and Mrs. Wagner, hosts at a benefit dinner dance at the Plaza last night, left before any of the guests did to go to another benefit dinner dance, the "Comeback to Mexico Fiesta" in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 31 (AP) --General Ankrah said today that if Guinea had notified Ghana that her diplomats would be passing through the country, "We probably would not bother them and allow them to pass."

Seven private collections of art will be visited in the 14th annual tour for contributing members of the American Federation of Arts on the afternoon of Nov. 12. Mrs. Linn Biron Turecamo and Mrs. Lawrence Copley Thaw are chairmen of the tour, assisted on arrangements by Donald M. Oenslager, a Federation trustee.

VIENNA, Oct. 31--Archduke Otto of Habsburg, claimant to the Austrian throne and son of the last Emperor of Austria-Hungary, today made his first visit to the Austrian republic since 1919, when his father was expelled after the collapse of the monarchy.
Carl L. Kempner was admitted yesterday as a general partner of Hamershlag, Borg Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange.

NEEDHAM, Mass., Oct. 31-- Dr. and Mrs. Samuel B. Burgess have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Peace Burgess, to Anthony Samuel Kroch. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Kroch. A July wedding is planned.
BUFFALO, Oct. 31--Governor Rockefeller campaigned today upstate for the last time, attacking "the New York City machine" and the "splinter parties."
