GAINESVILLE, Fla., Oct. 31 --Steve Spurrier, the quarterback Allie Sherman flew 2,000 miles to meet last week, is the 21-year-old son of a Presbyterian minister who may hit the biggest jackpot in pro football.

ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 31-- Lieut. Gen. Joseph Ankrah, leader of Ghana's military Government, today ridiculed the statement of President Toure that the United States played a part in the arrest of the Guinean officials.

THE New York Television Theater tried a change of pace last night on Channel 13 with two one-act plays by Bernard Shaw. On the first occasion it scored delightfully; on the second it struck out dutifully and inevitably.
The United States Military Academy will retain Tom Cahill as head football coach for at least another season and is expected to announce his new contract prior to the Army-Navy game on Nov. 26.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) --Interest rates for conventional home mortgages continued to climb to records during September on both new and existing homes, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.
India's Ambassador to the United States warned more than 1,000 business leaders here yesterday that the gap between the well-to-do and the poor nations of the world was widening.
MYTHO, South Vietnam, Nov. 1 United States Navy patrol boats intercepted a Vietcong battalion attempting to cross the Mekong River last night and sank 35 sampans and junks in a two-hour battle.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 1 Richard M. Nixon said today that a Republican victory in next Tuesday's election in Minnesota would be a "serious blow" to the chances of Vice President Humphrey's staying on the Democratic national ticket in 1968.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Getting arrested in Africa is not unusual for Robinson McIlvaine, the debonair, pipe-smoking American Ambassador to Guinea.

DURING the lunch hour yesterday more than 200 persons including secretaries, importers and workers from City Hall discovered a bistro-style restaurant that serves only cheeses and cheese dishes. They were at the opening of the International Cheese Club Restaurant on... the second floor of the Cheese of All Nations emporium, 153 Chambers Street (between Hudson and Greenwich Streets).

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Nov. 1 (UPI) Billy Casber, of San Diego, who pared his weight and beefed up his golf game, was named the 1966 player of the year at the annual meeting of the Professional Golfers' Association tonight.

"Harold Nicolson: Diaries and Letters, 1930-1939," edited by Nigel Nicolson, will be published by Atheneum on Nov. 14. The book is the first of three volumes edited by the younger son of the English writer, scholar, diplomat and parliamentarian.

The Defense Department's new and still controversial system of ocean cargo procurement through competitive bidding appears to have run afoul of the realities of commercial shipping life in its second major test.

Opposition is beginning to be heard against the "Christmas Tree Bill," which owes its nickname to the extraneous riders attached to some excellent legislation revising the tax treatment of foreign investors in the United States. The bill, passed by Congress on the final day of the session, has just been criticized by a group of professors of tax law, representing seven universities, who urge President Johnson to veto it.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1 (AP) The will of Roy A. Hunt, former president of the Aluminum Company of America, was filed for probate on Monday. It listed $1,722,000 in bequests.

UTICA, N. Y., Nov. 1 Dr. Paul L. Adams, the Conservative party candidate for Governor, charged today that by the Liberal party's own admission, Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. was using the race for Governor as a lever to seize control of the Democratic party.

The honors that the United States Equestrian Team gained at the National Horse Show during its eight-day run in Madison Square Garden were wrapped up neatly last night by Mrs. Frank D. Chapot of Wallpack, N. J., riding her chestnut mare, Tomboy.

SEOUL, SouthKorea, Wednesday, Nov. 2 (AP) Following are a transcript of President Johnson's remarks yesterday to American and Korean servicemen at Camp Stanley, South Korea, and the prepared text of his speech today to the Korean National Assembly:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) Nearly 250,000 veterans have gone to college this fall with the aid of the new G.I. bill, officials reported today.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 Better days lie ahead if builders, brokers and the men who arrange finances for them can weather the next few months, an economist told mortgage bankers here today.

Earnings of the Beaunit Corporation in the three months ended Sept. 30 fell sharply to $8,141 from $1,980,045, or 50 cents a share, a year earlier although sales climbed to $43,502,667 from $41,351,819, the company disclosed yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 1 The leadership of Argentina's powerful General Confederation of Labor met today for two hours with President Juan Carlos Ongania. The session has been billed as a prime indicator of Peronist intentions toward the four-month-old military Government "war or peace," as the analysts put it.

Paperboard production rose 3.8 per cent with 459,000 tons in the week ended Oct. 29, from 442,200 tons in the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.
Donations to the fund for the families of 12 firemen who died in a Madison Square fire Oct. 17 grew yesterday to $278,000 and included the entire monthly pension check of a retired Bronx fireman.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 1 Fifteen public health nurses employed by the city picketed briefly this morning outside City Hall and apparently won their point as the City Council tabled an ordinance to raise their salaries.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 1 (AP) Harvey Sterkel pitched a onehitter as Aurora, Ill., beat Mexico, 6-0, today and won the first world softball championship in the final game of the tournament.
LONDON, Nov. 1 (AP) The Soviet Embassy threw a lavish farewell party last night for its military attache Maj. Gen. Sergei Edemsky, the man once accused by the United States of being a spy.

The current national bulletin of the Minutemen calls upon member bands to identify "leading Communists and Communist sympathizers," and "determine the best manner for eliminating or controlling these individuals."
MIAMI, Nov. 1 (UPI) The police scoured Miami last night for youngsters who were accidentally given potentially deadly barbiturate tablets during their trick-or-treat rounds on Halloween night.
ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 1 The furor over the 19 Guinean hostages being detained comfortably in Ghanaian Army camps threatens to split Africa.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 1 New Orleans was awarded its long-sought franchise in the National Football League today. Pete Rozelle, the N.F.L. commissioner, announced the award at a ceremony at the Hotel Pontchartain that was attended by Senator Russell Long, Representative Hale Boggs and Gov. John McKeithen.

EXPERIENCED players are instinctively aware that certain defensive holdings are quite worthless and can safely be discarded. Sometimes the instinct proves faulty, as in the diagramed deal, which was played in the open team event in the recent Metropolitan Championships.
The spot rate on the British pound was practically unchanged in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. The closing quotation of $2.7913 was one point over Monday's final level.
The Boeing Company announced yesterday the election of Harold W. Haynes to the new 14th place on its board and of T.A. Wilson to a new executive vice presidency.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 (AP) A strike of 3,400 members of the United Auto Workers shut down the Buick-Oldsmobile-Pontiac plant of the General Motors Corporation in suburban South Gate today.

HARRINGTON PARK, N.J., Nov. 1 Mr. and Mrs. John A. Dawson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Penelope Ayres Dawson, to Robert Brooks Eufer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Eufer of Ossining, N. Y.

The Democratic-Liberal candidate for re-election in the 21st Congressional District has entered the last week of the campaign with the comforting knowledge that even his Republican opponent feels "he has done a very fine job."
An urban development program, costing approximately $200-million is already under way to make Grenoble, France, a perfect host city for the 1968 Winter Olympic games, its mayor said yesterday.
The American Stock Exchange turned in its best performance in two weeks yesterday as the list moved higher on stepped-up buying.
NOW in its fourth season, the International Festival of Visiting Orchestras, sponsored by the Carnegie Hall Corporation, has developed into one of New York's most valuable series.
Frank J. Hammel, former vice president and controller of the Western Electric Company, died yesterday in his home, 197 Hillside Terrace, Great Kills, S. I. His age was 69.

The Democratic incumbent representing the 22d Congressional District in the Bronx and his two opponents agree on one point that voters in the sprawling South Bronx area are particularly interested in "breadand-butter issues."
Sometimes wheat, corn and soybean futures prices move together in sympathy. Yesterday they all declined, but for different reasons.
Despite a heavy load of new bond issues, most interest rates continued yesterday the downward trend that has developed over the last two months.
MOSCOW, Nov. 1 Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, paid tribute to Stalin today as one of the Georgians who had distinguished himself "in the course of the revolutionary struggle."

A race-track encounter, a death threat and payoff dickering in a Brooklyn used car lot were described yesterday as components of an alleged plot to extort $5,000 from three partners seeking a liquor license for a bar in Queens.
A force of 26 detectives quietly mingled with guests and employes at the Plaza Hotel yesterday to investigate a burglary and attempted rape of a guest in her suite on the 13th floor Monday night.

Dr. Henry Alsop Riley, former president of the American Neurological Association and an authority on the anatomy of the nervous system, died yesterday in his home at 340 East 72d Street. He was 79 years old.
SYRACUSE, Nov. 1 Senator Robert F. Kennedy called today for a "fundamental" overhaul of the State Constitution in "as nonpartisan a way as possible."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--The Labor Department is asking for, and probably will receive, control of three new programs in the Antipoverty Law of 1966.

A settlement of the suit brought by two minority stockholders of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., following the ouster in early 1965 of James T. Aubrey Jr., as president of its television network, has been recommended by a court-appointed referee.
Selections of William S. Hart Western movies at the Museum of Modern Art, starting tomorrow, CI 5-8900.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday gave first priority in the allocation of funds in next year's capital budget to the improvement of the city's hospital system.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (UPI) Pit Martin's disputed goal in the first period put the Boston Bruins in front to stay as they scored a 3-2 victory tonight over the Chicago Black Hawks. The Hawks, leading the National Hockey League, had a fourgame winning streak snapped.
Merger negotiations of Gristede Bros., Inc., and the King Kullen Grocery Company, announced last month, have been terminated by the two food chains.
Simon E. Osserman, a retired real-estate man, died Monday in the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged, 140 West 106th Street. He was 93 years old.

Fashion apparel is becoming a mass production industry in Paris, much like it is on New York's Seventh Avenue. So says Zyga Pianko, managing director of Pierre d'Alby, one of the major women's apparel producers in Paris.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 1 (AP) Strikers against newspapers in Toledo and Dayton now have made idle about 2,000 newspaper workers in Ohio.
More than 300 guests dined and danced last night at the Paddle-Wheel Ball, a benefit for the Travelers Aid Society of New York, held in the Riverboat restaurant.
Livingston L. Wingate, the controversial executive director of Haryou-Act, announced his resignation from the Harlem antipoverty program yesterday.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 1 Ambassador Ralph A. Dungan of the United States rolled up his sleeves and applied 195 pounds of leverage to the movable arm of a building-block machine.
The Affiliated Distillers Brands Corporation, the marketing subsidiary of Schenley Industries, Inc., announced here yesterday the election of Harry Jay Greenwald as executive vice president.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 1 (AP) Samuel H. Sheppard's defense offered the theory today that his first wife, Marilyn, was beaten to death by someone left-handed with "strength compatible to that of a woman."

HAVANA, Nov. 1 (Reuters)--Cuba and North Korea have called on all socialist countries to send an international force of troops to help North Vietnam and the Vietcong fight against "Yankee imperialism."

OSSINING, N. Y., Nov. 1 Halloween pranks developed into a riot here last night as 400 Negro teen-agers rampaged through the downtown streets, smashing two store windows, stomping a policeman unconscious and injuring six other patrolmen.
The Ford Foundation has granted $1.5-million to the Congress for Cultural Freedom, the international organization of intellectuals and artists in Paris.
BROWN University football players take note: Yesterday's report from the Cornell correspondent said, "Cornell faces its second consecutive easy foe Saturday when it plays Brown in Providence."

NORTHAMPTON, L. I., Nov. 1 Larry Laoretti of Pine Hollow posted a 33, 38 71 and won the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association assistant pro championship at the 6,815-yard par 36, 36 72 Northampton Golf Club today. It was the first tournament played on the new course.
Theodore G. Bergmann named vice president for programing at Ted Bates Co., Inc.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1 The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that no key defense plants had immediately been affected by the strike begun at midnight by the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.
OXFORD, Md., Nov. 1 "Speak no more of bluebird weather," said Smiley Cole, the leading commercial goose field entrepreneur of the area, as he peered into his favorite beverage, black coffee.
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. accused Governor Rockefeller yesterday of resorting to fiscal trickery to mislead the public and evade his constitutional obligation to balance the budget.
A winner who ran second in a race for nonwinners and a fog-out that brought shouts of "C'mon Somebody!" added a bizarre flavor to yesterday's action at Aqueduct.

DOVER, N.J., Nov. 1 A runaway two-engine diesel locomotive 236 tons in all slammed head on into an ErieLackawanna passenger train just a few blocks short of the train's final stop here today, killing the engineer and injuring the eight other persons on the train.

SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 1 Traveling by train, helicopter and jeep, President Johnson made a broad sweep outside South Korea's capital today to see something of the country and people and to meet some of the American and Korean soldiers guarding the republic against a repetition of the Communist attack 16 years ago.
A 16-year-old Brooklyn youth has complained to the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board that policemen harassed him because he was carrying literature that supports the board.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Communist China again used enriched uranium as the weapons material for its fourth atomic test last week, according to a preliminary analysis by the United States.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 102.2 on Monday from 102 on Friday.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 The Los Angeles Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra canceled its season today after failing to reach agreement with the musician's union.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 2 (AP) Troops of the United States First Cavalry Division (Airmobile) fought a day-long battle yesterday with an enemy force near South Vietnam's central coast, the United States command announced today.

The Douglas Aircraft Company, hit by mounting losses, labor shortages and an inability to meet delivery schedules on its jet transports, is negotiating with a group of eight banks for a line of credit near $100million.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 1 Sixty-seven concerns that run vital sections of Ceylon's trade were closed today by a strike. The Ceylon Mercantile Union said 11,000 of its members had responded to the strike call after a breakdown of pay negotiations with employers. The employers put the number of strikers at 8,000. The tea and rubber trades have been affected.

The Continental Insurance Companies ended the first nine months of this year with an adjusted operating income of $51.6-million, or $4.44 a share, compared with $40.9-million, or $2.48 a share, it was reported yesterday by J. Victor Herd, chairman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 The State Department described today as a serious situation the confinement of United States citizens in Conakry, and the continuing official broadcasts blaming the United States for Ghana's detention of 19 Guineans.
HAVANA, Nov. 1 The United States team swept all boards, 4-0, in the sixth and penultimate round of the preliminaries vs. Bolivia in the 17th Chess Olympics at the Havana Libre Hotel here last night.
LONDON, Nov. 1 The Government sought today to soften the impact of its tough deflationary policies on the business man and the unemployed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Senior members of the International Monetary Fund have significantly changed their attitudes toward the admission of Eastern European nations in the last year or so, an official of the Fund said today.

CONCORDIA, Kan., Nov. 1 Mrs. Charles B. Swope has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Julia Delafield Swope, to Herbert Robinson McIlvaine Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McIlvaine of Philadelphia.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 1, (AP) Argentina rallied after failing to score in the first two chukkers today and defeated a British military polo team, 8-7, for the Capt. John Young Cup.
WQXR, the radio station of The New York Times, has announced the beginning of its 1966-67 "Young Artists Competion."

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Nov. 1 A $100,000 bond issue to expand village park facilities was defeated today by a vote of 786 to 116. The expansion was to have been done in Memorial Park, the largest civic recreational area in any Rockland County village.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 1 (AP) John Miller, reprimanded last Saturday for not having ridden Galilee out in a race, guided the New Zealand-bred gelding to victory in the two-mile $67,200 Melbourne Cup today before 80,000 people at the Flemington course.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) A Presidential emergency board recommended today a settlement of a Pan American World Airways contract dispute, calling for a scale of wage increases and fringe benefits previously termed inflationary by the Administration.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1 Secretary General Thant postponed today his final decision on remaining in office, citing the "outlook for peace in Asia" as a major factor in his eventual choice.

The International Council of Shopping Centers has appointed Gordon D. MacDonald as its director of research. Dr. MacDonald will supervise the activities of the trade association's two-year-old ICSC Research Foundation. The council has 2,100 members.
The fifth annual Daiquiri Ball drew more than 400 persons to the Plaza last evening for dining and dancing in a Grand Ballroom decorated with foliage and birds typical of Puerto Rico.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--Chicago's Commissioner of Aviation urged today creation of a national aviation planning commission to meet the explosive growth of air travel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Measles, until now an almost universal childhood sickness in this country could be eradicated in the United States next year, according to Dr. William H. Stewart, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service.

PARIS Europe's biggest question is the German question and West Europe's biggest question is the West German question. The balance of world power may well be settled by ultimate solution of the first and the existence of NATO by the second. Therefore, now that political rumblings reverberate inside the Bonn Republic, the whole issue of Germany is coming again to the fore.
Revlon, Inc., achieved record sales and earnings in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30, Charles Revson, chairman, reported yesterday.
The fifth annual dinner dance in behalf of The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, will be held on Nov. 15 at the Plaza. Proceeds will go toward a fund of $1,149,000.
A concert that rewarded keen anticipation with bleak disappointment was given at Carnegie Recital Hall last night by Frank Baker, tenor, and Henry Brant, pianist.

SASARAM, India, Oct. 31 For centuries, Hindus in this devout town have celebrated the annual Dussehra festival by dunking a statue of Durga, the goddess of power, in a muddy pool on the town's outskirts.

Martin Weldon, director of news and public affairs for radio station WCBS, died Monday night after suffering a heart attack while driving to New York. He was 53 years old and lived at 161 West 54th Street.

TORONTO, Nov. 1--The price of nickel was increased 9.6 per cent today to 85 cents a pound by the International Nickel Company of Canada Ltd., producer of about two-thirds of the Western world's nickel supply.

Gulton Industries, Inc., announced yesterday the acquisition of Southern States, Inc., in exchange for 50,000 shares of Gulton common. Based upon trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, the acquisition price would be $1.8million.
American Airlines has placed an order for 10 giant Boeing 747 jetliners.

The leader of the so-called young Turk faction of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People predicted yesterday that a major battle was shaping up in the organization's 1,600 branches between his group and what he called "the old guard" over six contested board of director seats.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 1 Outwardly unshaken by the first Vietcong shelling of the center of Saigon, the South Vietnamese Government staged an elaborate reception and dinner for its own dignitaries and foreign guests tonight.

Two international transactions in wheat were reported yesterday in the grain trade. One involved the sale of 600,000 tons, about 22 million bushels, by Australia to Red China. The other involved the sale of 200,000 tons, about 7.35 million bushels, to Algeria by the Soviet Union.

The American National Theater and Academy will this season give Monday night performances in addition to the Tuesday matinees in its series of experimental plays at the Theater de Lys, according to Lucille Lortel, artistic director.

Floyd Little of Syracuse scampered 91, 69 and 25 yards on three touchdown runs against Penn State last year. Had it not been for these runs by the bow-legged star, the Nittany Lions would probably have won, since they gained 387 yards from scrimmage to 193 for Syracuse.
The appointment of William D. Randolph to the new post of corporate vice president was announced yesterday by Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc.

About 30 latecomers were refused seating last night for the entire performance of the oneact opera "Elektra" at the Metropolitan Opera House. Despite the shortness of the opera and the protests of the late arrivals, the Met management declined to breach its new policy of not admitting latecomers.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 1 Representative Prentiss Walker, who came off a Smith County chicken farm in 1964 to become Mississippi's first Republican Congressman in 80 years, is trying to unseat Senator James O. Eastland, the crusty old Dixiecrat who has been entrenched for a quarter of a century.
The city's Commissioner of Public Works warned yesterday that the 101-day-old plumbers' strike was crippling construction at five new city hospital and health buildings.

City officials said yesterday that a grocery inspector, whose job was to protect consumers against short weights and long prices, recently emerged from a Bronx supermarket carrying a box of groceries for himself that had the opposite fault long weight and short price.
PORTSMOUTH, Va., Nov. 1 (UPI) Three men were killed and 12 injured today when a helicopter tipped over on takeoff and hurled broken parts across the decks of the assault aircraft carrier Guadalcanal.

ONE of the more effective services of Channel 13 is its local town meetings on subjects of community interest, and last night's topic, a study of lysergic acid diethylamide, was a representative example. The program, rather awkwardly and a shade sensationally entitled "LSD for Parents," was consistently interesting as six specialists fielded questions from both viewers and members of the studio audience.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company achieved the highest sales and earnings in its 68year history for the third quarter and first nine months, Russell DeYoung, chairman, and Victor Holt Jr., president, reported yesterday.
Led by an upsurge in the glamour stocks, the stock market advanced on a broad front yesterday.
Richard E. Osmer, director of operational planning for Burlington Industries, Inc., was elected yesterday as a vice president of the textile producer.

WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 1 Three fillies sired by Sharpshooter stayed close together tonight, behaved themselves, and finished one, two, three in the $34,023,40 New York Sire Stakes for 2-year-old trotting fillies at Roosevelt Raceway.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 1 (AP) A new state came into being in India today with the division of the Punjab into Punjabi Subha and Hariana.
SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Nov. 2 Six American soldiers and one South Korean Army man were killed early today when they were attacked by North Koreans south of the demilitarized zone.

ALBANY, Nov, 1 (AP) State income tax collections are pouring in at a pace that promises to exceed Governor Rockefeller's latest estimates for the current fiscal year by about at least $45-million, State Controller Arthur Levitt said today.
The Navy's unique river patrol craft in Vietnam are beginning to interrupt the Vietcong lines of communication and supply in the Mekong delta's maze of waterways.

MOSCOW, Nov. 1 Leonid I. Brezhnev today defended the Soviet Union's interest in finding ways to cooperate with Western governments, thus defying Chinese criticism that such efforts amount to collusion with enemies of Communism.

THE PROFESSIONALS, a drama written for the screen and directed by Richard Brooks for Columbia Pictures with Burt Lancaster, Lee Marvin, Claudia Cardinale, Robert Ryan, Jack Palance and Ralph Bellamy, is the attraction at the Victoria Theater, Broadway and 46th Street, and the Festival Theater, 57th Street, west of Fifth Avenue.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 Dr. Alexander Langmuir, an epidemiologist, predicted here today a substantial rise in the number of measles cases in the coming months of the campaign to eradicate it in the United States.
The Philadelphia Orchestra members yesterday unanimously rejected the latest offer of the Philadelphia Orchestra Association to end the musicians 47-day walkout.

Distress conveyances of Manhattan real estate in the first nine months of 1966--foreclosures by mortgagees and surrenders of deed in lieu of foreclosure--were slightly higher in number than in the comparable period of 1965. The dollar value of the conveyances was lower than the year-ago total.
Five resolutions and six bills aimed at lowering the retail price of milk in New York City were introduced yesterday in the City Council.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (UPI) The San Francisco Warriors moved into a tie for first place in the Western Division of the National Basketball Association tonight by downing the Chicago Bulls, 137-121.

THE HAGUE, Nov. 1 (Reuters) Guests invited to the wedding of Princess Margriet to Pieter van Vollenhoven, a commoner, have been asked to bring their skates. Weather permitting, the wedding festivities on January 10 will include an iceskating party on the big lake behind Soestdijk Palace, the residence of Queen Juliana and Prince Bernhard. About 150 guests were invited.

At Lincoln Center: "Die Frau ohne Schatten," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; "Don Giovanni," New York City Opera, New York State Theater, 8:15; Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli, pianist, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.

Increased shipments and generally better profit margins of fabricated metal products contributed to the record consolidated earnings of the Cerro Corporation in the third quarter and first nine months. The profit mark was achieved despite an eight-week strike that ended Aug. 29 at the Maspeth, Queens, plant of the Cerro Wire and Cable Company division.

BERLIN, Nov. 1 Methods to evangelize the entire world, according to a Washington Presbyterian pastor who addressed the World Congress on Evangelism here today, are as numerous and diverse as the people yet to be Christianized and the missionaries who can reach them.

HOUSTON, Nov. 1 John W. Mecom Jr., the young Texas sportsman, disclosed today that he has three new Lola chassis on order for the 1967 Indianapolis 500-mile race. He said the cars would be shipped from Eric Broadley's shops in England before the first of the year.

TOKYO, Nov. 1 Japan's rice crop for 1966 is estimated to total 12,863,000 tons, or the second largest in this country's history, the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry announced today. The current crop was surpassed only by the 13,000,000 tons for 1962 and represents an increase of 450,000 tons over the 1965 figure.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Nov. 1 In the ring, Joey Archer, wearing blue trunks and a white T-shirt, was swinging his arms and skipping as he warmed up today for his four-round workout. Nearby, Lou Goldstein, the social director at Grossinger's, was entertaining the 250 spectators.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Ecuador asked the United States today to "exhaust every effort" to prevent an arms race in the Western Hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 President Johnson's mission to Asia is over and the outlook now is not only for a more savage fight for victory in Vietnam, but for a larger and longer United States commitment to secure the freedom of South Vietnam and the rest of free Asia.
The Public Development Corporation sponsored by the Lind say administration struck a new snag yesterday when the City Council declined to act on funds for it pending further study.
One betting and one nonbetting race, both Sire Stakes contests will occupy the spotlight a Roosevelt Wednesday night.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 1 (AP) A 612-foot, sulphurladen tanker sliced into a railroad bridge over the Savannah River last night, severing the structure and sending tons of steel and cross ties into the water.
WARSAW, Nov. 1 Hundreds of candles were flickering tonight on the monumental tomb that occupies the place of honor in this city's Powazki Cemetery.
WCBS-TV urged the re-election of Governor Rockefeller in an editorial last night as a candidate of "proven skills" and "a record of achievement."

The New York Giants, in trouble everywhere they look, shifted Freeman White, a rookie pass receiver, to second-string right linebacker yesterday. White, a Nebraska pass catcher, never got into action except as a member of the kick-off team this season.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 1 (AP) The United States Naval Academy initiated a new "academic forum" today designed to give its civilian and military faculty more of a voice in academy affairs.

The appointment of Lewis Lusardi to the recently-created post of administrative director of the-Lincoln Center Fund has been announced by William Schuman, president of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. The fund provides support for the capital projects and annual programing of Lincoln Center. Mr. Lusardi began his work there early in the summer.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov.1 Secretary General Thant told the Security Council today that the inability of the IsraeliSyrian Mixed Armistice Commission to function tended to throw minor border incidents into the political context of the Security Council.
Forbes, Inc., publisher of Forbes magazine, is getting ready to move next year into the building on lower Fifth Avenue it bought nearly five years ago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--Two national groups of liberal Republicans conspicuously snubbed Ronald Reagan, the party's candidate for Governor of California, as they issued endorsement lists today.
HONG KONG, Nov. 1 The ruling Chinese hierarchy headed by Mao Tse-tung and his chief aide, Lin Piao, is showing signs of strain in face of activities by a purported opposition.
The Board of Education's preschool summer program was severely criticized yesterday for having offered the wrong kind of instruction to the wrong group of children.

Soviet party chief Brezhnev's remarks about the Vietnam war yesterday were brief and relatively moderate and for this very reason are receiving special attention. He did not place the usual emphasis on Soviet support of Hanoi's conditions for opening negotiations with the United States. Mr. Brezhnev centered much of his oratorical fire on Peking.

ANDREW GOODMAN, president of Bergdorf Good- man, believes that some of his happiest days were spent in 1928 when he was 21 years old, and carried a mouthwash bottle filled with gin to New York debutante parties.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission, in a 3-2 decision, ruled today that the defunct R. F. Collier Son Corporation, former publisher of Collier's Encyclopedia, used "lengthy and blatant use of deception" to sell its books.
HONG KONG, Nov. 1 The Chinese Foreign Ministry rejected today a Soviet protest against Red Guard demonstra- tions outside the Soviet Embassy in Peking.
Unanimously extended term of Secretary General until end of 21st session.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Dr. and Mrs. Howard B. Slavin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Slavin, to Robert E. McHugh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. McHugh of Arlington, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) John M. Bailey, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, charged today that a movie produced for the Republican Congressional campaign Committee attempts to "mix sleazy and lurid visual material into disjointed scenes which are necessarily shown out of context."

MURFREESBORO, Tenn., Nov. 1 (AP) Gen. Ben Lear, who stirred a national controversy before World War II by ordering a regiment of citizensoldiers on a disciplinary march between Memphis and Little Rock, Ark., died today in the Veterans Administration hospital where he had been a patient since August, 1964. He was 87 years old.

New Jersey's trade caravan touring Mexico and Central America is doing standing-room-only business, with $1-million in sales so far, Gov. Richard J. Hughes said yesterday. "And this is only the beginning," he said.
The nation's automobile manufacturers built 832,247 cars in October, off slightly from the 849,577 units built a year before.
Prices dropped again yesterday on the London Stock Exchange but most of the losses were slight.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Nov. 1 Mr. and Mrs. M. Jay Chaikin have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joyce Daryl Chaikin, to Burton Joel Ahrens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton S. Ahrens of White Plains.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 1 (AP) A total of 47 domestic and international flights were canceled today by the Mexican Airline Mexicana de Aviacion after about 3,000 of its workers struck at midnight. Mexicana is Mexico's second largest airline, behind Aeronaves.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 1 Disquiet among smaller airlines about their ability to compete with the big ones has emerged from the first sessions of the current meeting here of the International Air Transport Association.

MOSCOW, Nov. 1 (UPI) The Soviet Union gave praise today to a book charging that Lee Harvey Oswald, the assassin of President Kennedy, was a "discredited agent" for the Central Intelligence Agency in the pay of ultra-right-wing Texans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 A Soviet-United States agreement establishing direct air service between Moscow and New York is scheduled to be signed Friday at the State Department, Administration officials said today.

Mrs. Darlington Sands of Mexico City has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Teresa Sands, to Robert Haigh Leonard, son of Mrs. Ruth Marsden Leonard of West Woodstock, Vt., and Dr. Richard Lewis Leonard of Greenfield, Mass.
RIALTO, Calif., Nov. 1. (AP) When Mrs. Roger Lee Williams opened her door to two young girls last night a woman asked if she knew them.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) The Defense Department announced today that retired military pay will be increased 3.7 per cent, effective Dec. 1, to match a rise in the cost of living.

BONN, Nov. 1 West Germany took in a little more money from abroad than it paid out during the quarter ended Sept. 30. The Federal bank announced that according to estimates now available, the quarter showed a positive balance of payments of $1.75-million.
Prints by 25 American artists, to be exhibited in the United States embassies in West Africa, were shown yesterday to United Nations delegates at the Museum of Modern Art.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) The Norfolk Western Railway asked the Interstate Commerce Commisson today to refuse "death benefits" for three small lines affected by the world's largest rail merger and keep them alive through consolidation in another system.
HILLSBORO, Ohio, Nov. 1 Dr. and Mrs. John R. McBride have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss B. Kathleen McBride, to James S. Ogsbury Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ogsbury of Brewster, N.Y.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1--Mayor Richard J. Daley said today the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was seeking to stir up a backlash vote here to hurt Democrats at the polls next Tuesday.

Mrs. Esther Rosenblatt Kaplan, former president of the AmHill Chapter of Hadassah, and the widow of Louis Kaplan, a clothing and jewelry merchant, died yesterday in the Home and Hospital of the Daughters of Jacob, the Bronx. Her age was 91.
St. Francis Hospital, which won a reprieve when Cardinal Spellman pledged his coin collection toward a new hospital last year, has been ordered to close by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

BONN, Nov. 1 West Germany's extreme right-wing National Democratic party accepted today the resignation of its vice chairman, who quit saying he could not with a clear conscience ask voters in the Nov. 20 Bavarian state election to choose his party.
The city is trying to shut off the easy market that vandals find for the plumbing and other fixtures they steal from buildings.
THE most active stock in the nation yesterday didn't even make the New York Stock Exchange's list of the 15 most active stocks.
Malcolm S. Forbes, president of Forbes, Inc., announced the appointment of James J. Dunn as publisher of Forbes magazine.

The Columbia Broadcasting System was reported last night to have made a new contract offer to the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, which represents engineers, technicians and cameramen employed by company owned television and radio stations throughout the country. Negotiators for both sides ended a series of meetings that began in Washington last Friday.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 1 The Republican candidate for United States Senator from Oregon in 1962 urged members of his party today to vote for the Democratic candidate in the present race for that office.
Long before final taps were sounded signifying the end of the National Horse Show last night, a long equine caravan was heading toward Washington where the Washington International Show starts today.

THE operas of the Czechoslovak composer Leos Janacek have made little headway in this country. A couple have been produced by various companies at widely separated intervals. "The Makropoulos Affairs," dating from 1924, will be given its American premiere in San Francisco this month. Some have never been done here at all.

RAHWAY, N. J., Nov. 1 The Rev. Hedding Bishop Leech, former pastor of Trinity Methodist Church here and the Epworth Methodist Church in Elizabeth, died yesterday at his home at 372 West Scott Avenue. He was 94 years old.

CONGRATULATIONS and condolences are due How ard Otway this morning. Congratulations for the attractive little theater he opened last night in the East Village. Condolences for the exasperating play he wrote for the opening.
All eight members of a local school board in Harlem resigned yesterday to protest the Board of Education's failure to resume negotiations on Intermediate School 201.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 1 (AP) Dr. Norman R. Gay, dean of the Engineering School at the University of Notre Dame, was found dead at his home yesterday. He was 47 years old.

A collection of artists' views in water-color of scenes from City Island to Santa Barbara, Calif., was donated yesterday to Fairleigh Dickinson University by the Ford Motor Company's New York-New Jersey Community Relations Committee.
Sandy Koufax, for the second straight year and for the third time in his career, won baseball's Cy Young Award yesterday as the outstanding pitcher in the major leagues.
After 10 years together, the Mennen Company and Warwick Legier, Inc., are parting over "a basic disagreement on creative philosophy."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Photographs and X-rays taken of President Kennedy's body at the autopsy were turned over to the National Archives yesterday by the Kennedy family.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 The Intelsat 2 communications satellite, nicknamed Lani Bird, may be usable four to eight hours a day, even though it is not in the desired orbit, the Communications Satellite Corporation (Comsat) said today.

New York City department stores had an average gain of 4 per cent in October over last year, but a number of merchants expressed disappointment. They said the results should have been better considering the number of favorable factors during the month.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) Mrs. Aaron Leifer of Brooklyn, N. Y., was elected president of the Mizrachi Women's Organization of America today at the religious-Zionist group's 41st annual convention.
In 1948, Mr. Packard went on a Marshall Plan mission to Greece, where he was chief of the land reclamation unit of the Economic Cooperation Administration for six years.
Economic policy-making is always difficult but formulating policy for the coming year looms as an especially difficult task for the Johnson Administration.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 New orders received by manufacturers of durable goods made an unusually large advance in September, revised Commerce Department figures showed today.
Governor Rockefeller charged yesterday that "crime virtually doubled in Queens County" while his Democratic opponent, Frank D. O'Connor, was District Attorney there.
MADRID, Nov. 1 Spain's dispute with Britain over Gibraltar the Rock and the Town is being increasingly overshadowed by the dispute over the adjacent neutral zone.
DETROIT, Nov. 1 (AP) The resignation of Joseph L. Rauh Jr. as general counsel of the United Automobile Workers was announced today by Walter P. Reuther, president.
A formal agreement was signed yesterday providing for the delivery of coal from the Navajo mine in New Mexico to two new 755,000-kilowatt generating units to be constructed at the mine site.

The Very Rev. John Vernon Butler accepted a small brown bag containing some large brass keys yesterday and thereby became the 14th rector of Trinity Parish, the most prestigious Episcopal church in this country.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1--Eleven fire fighters were killed and a score of others injured late today as 50-mile-an-hour winds whipped flames across several square miles of brushland in the San Gabriel Mountains on the outskirts of Los Angeles.
The team standings, with points figured on a 10-9-8-7-65-4-3-2-1 basis for first through 10th places (first-place votes in parentheses):

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Edward Drozniak, Polish Ambassador to the United States for the last five years, died today in the Washington Hospital Center. He suffered a heart attack two weeks ago. He was 64 years old.
William D. Morrison has been elected a group vice president of the Hooker Chemical Corporation. He was formerly a corporate vice president.

COAT and suit designers are a resourceful lot. Instead of crying in their cof- fee or looking around for another line of work because suits are reportedly out of fashion and spring coats have been supplanted by jackets or raincoats, they have simply come up with a new bag of tricks:...

Israel Schawartzberg better known to associates as Mizo, Irving Ace, Irving Ticket, the Fat Tiger or Mr. Israel strolled into his favorite eatery, Lou G. Segal's Kosher Restaurant, in the garment center yesterday for barley soup and stuffed peppers.

The football season is on, and nowhere is the game being played with more intensity than down at City Hall. In a remarkable display of Board of Estimate teamwork last week, the five Borough Presidents kicked the city's planning programs right off the field.
ESCANABA, Mich., Nov. 1 (UPI) An ambulance operator said today he had refused to take an elderly stroke victim to a hospital because of the difficulty in collecting fees under Medicare.

"A Countess from Hong Kong," written and directed by Charlie Chaplin and co-starring Sophia Loren and Marlon Brando, will have its world premiere on Jan. 5 at the Carlton Theatre in London. The charity performance of the Universal production will benefit the Institute of Ophthalmology's "Light for Sight" campaign.

TEL AVIV, Nov. 1 (Reuters) An Israeli newspaper today said that the memoirs of Maj. Gen. Carl von Horn, former commander of United Nations peace keeping forces, showed he had a talent for writing cheap novels.

The lawyer for Representative Adam Clayton Powell promised a Court of Appeals judge yesterday that the Manhattan Democrat would appear in court here Dec. 9 for a financial examination if the top state court upheld a lower court ruling.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 1 Secretary General Thant, a spokesman disclosed today, has intervened in the dispute between Ghana and Guinea.
TOKYO, Nov. 1 Research into the causes and control of cancer during the last half century has been something like a very long horse race.

HALF essay, half picture album, "Martha Graham" should be a welcome memento to everyone who knows her work. What it will mean to those who do not is anyone's guess. It will be a little like describing Schoenberg's "Moses and Aaron" to an opera lover whose musical education was halted at "The Barber of...

The Texam Oil Corporation said yesterday that its directors had "recently learned" that three top officers had siphoned about $900,000 out of the company over the last seven years by supplying it with equipment and services from behind a screen of dummy concerns at substantial mark-ups.
PARK RIDGE, N. J., Nov. 1 (AP) Warren W. Wilentz, Democratic senatorial candidate, was endorsed today by Mrs. Bernice Alexander, a Republican freeholder in Bergen County.
Frank D. O'Connor charged yesterday that Governor Rockefeller was resorting to "Goldwater Republicanism" in his charge that crime rates soared in Queens when Mr. O'Connor was District Attorney there.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 1 The Netherlands proposed today a broad expansion of the safeguards system of the International Atomic Energy Agency to seek to prevent the diversion of nuclear materials from peaceful to military uses.

The Henry Street Settlement will benefit from a theater party at the Nov. 10 performance of "Don Giovanni" at the New York State Theater. The evening will start with a dinner at La Comedie restaurant.

The highest judicial office in New York State, Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals, will be filled at this election because of the compulsory retirement, due to age, of the incumbent, Charles S. Desmond. We are pleased that Stanley H. Fuld, who has demonstrated great talent in twenty years' service as an associate judge of the court, has been nominated by all four parties for the post and will be Judge Desmond's successor.

A former security officer at Yonkers Raceway was indicted yesterday for having permitted so-called 10 per centers to pose as twin-double ticket-holders so that the actual recipients could evade paying Federal income taxes on their winnings.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Many Republican candidates have become worried that the spreading supermarket boycotts will damage their efforts to use inflation as a ma- jor national election issue.

SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Nov. 2 President Johnson completed his whirlwind tour of seven Pacific nations today with a vigorous reassertion of United States interests in Asia and a pledge to defend them overseas before any challenger can reach American soil.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 1 Statements last night in Canberra by Bruce White, Secretary of the Army Department, pointing to difficulties in the relations of the Australian forces in Vietnam with United States and South Vietnamese troops and questioning the American bombing of North Vietnam caused wide repercussions in the capital today.

ROME, Nov. 2 W. Averell Harriman, the United States Ambassador at Large, visited the Italian leaders and Pope Paul VI today to brief them on the results of President Johnson's Manila meeting with allies in the Vietnam war.
Leaders of the Congress of Racial Equality are scheduled to meet this morning in Harlem with creditors to seek a settlement on debts that have been conceded to total "less than $200,000."
GRENADA, Miss., Nov. 2 (AP) A Negro boycott of public schools here ended today under pressures from a Federal judge.
Government and corporate bond prices dropped sharply yesterday in the steepest decline in a month.

Savings and loan authorities in California have quietly combined one of the most serious "problem cases" in their industry, the Gardena Savings and Loan Association, with the larger and stronger Union Federal Savings and Loan Association of Los Angeles.

FOR the first time in its 18year history, the Greater New York Bridge Association has elected a woman to its highest office, Mrs. Lee Goldberg began a one-year term as president at the recent Metropolitan Tournament, succeeding Sol Seidman.

The Donald E. Axinn Company, Long Island real estate development concern, reports it has leased 460 feet of frontage along Jericho Turnpike, in Jericho, L.I, to complete the assemblage of a three-acre site on which the company will erect two five-story office buildings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 Price increases by the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., the world's largest producer, were described today by the President's Council of Economic Advisers as "very large" and "regrettable."

COMMACK, L.I., Nov. 2 Governor Rockefeller, buoyed by his own poll showing for the first time that he is winning, toured Long Island today, blasting away at his Democratic opponent as a man who lacks "foresight imagination and independence."

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that four New York City Democrats a judge and three members of the State Legislature had been involved in the reported attempt to shake down partners who sought a liquor license for their Queens tavern.
The scholarship fund of the Mount Holyoke Club of New York will benefit from the annual "Art Lover's Sunday Afternoon," a tour of private art collections on Nov. 13.
Copper futures prices rose sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange here as uncertainty continued over supplies of the metal from Zambia.

Dr. Henry Neumann, a leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture and former leader of the Brooklyn society, died Tuesday in his home at 24 Willow Street, Brooklyn. He was 84 years old and had been recuperating from an operation.
Wes Westrum touched down from Florida yesterday with a glowing suntan and a glowing winter book on his 1967 New York Mets.
Leonard Bernstein will not return as music director of the New York Philharmonic when his current contract expires in the spring of 1969. The conductor intends to concentrate on composing.

BOSTON, Nov. 2 (AP) Edward Jay Epstein, author of "Inquest," which challenged the Warren Commission's investigation of the assassination, says the possibility of a second assassin "will probably be reduced to nil" by the pictures.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 2 "As a lefty I have an advantage," asserted Dave Davis, before he began his defense of the Professional Bowlers Association national championship today.

BRISBANE, Australia, Nov. 2 (AP) Francoise Durr, the French star, strained a tendon in her right wrist today and lost to Joan Gibson of Australia in the quarter-final of the Queensland lawn tennis championship. The scores were 6-3, 6-3.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Nov. 3 (AP) A former United States aid official, convicted of killing a Vietnamese woman in what the police said was a crime of passion, has been granted amnesty and ordered freed from prison, Vietnamese police sources said today.

The election of William J. Casey as chairman of the executive committee of the International Rescue Committee was announced yesterday by Leo Cherne, chairman of the committee's board. He succeeds Francis L. Kellogg, who has become vice president of the committee.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 Cigarette smoking decreased markedly in a group of more than 500,000 now middle-aged to elderly men and women during a six-year study of the American Cancer Society.

Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Allen of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Jean Allen, to J. Roger Guilfoyle, son of Mrs. John F. Guilfoyle of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Mr. Guilfoyle.
BOSTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) The situation in Pontiac recalled the Boston police strike of 1919, the last such walkout in the nation.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 2 Dr. Nureddin Attassi, the Syrian chief of state, attacked the United States and the United Nations today, threatened Jordan and accused King Faisal of Saudi Arabia and President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia of betraying the Arab cause in Palestine.

A call for tightening New York State's weapons laws and achieving a regional compact for interstate control of arms and ammunition here was made public yesterday by the Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 2 (UPI) Oscar Robertson clicked off five points in a row to break a 120-120 tie and lead the Cincinnati Royals to a 131-129 victory over the New York Knickerbockers tonight.
Dick Bass of the Los Angeles Rams continues to show the way in the race for the National Football League rushing title vacated by Jim Brown, the retired Cleveland fullback.

A poll for the American Broadcasting Company completed early yesterday shows a marked increase in public approval for President Johnson's handling of the Vietnam war, apparently as a result of the President's trip to Asia.

A series of 10 performances for children at the Hunter College Playhouse was announced yesterday by the Hunter College Concert Bureau. The series is being sponsored by Mrs. S.I. Newhouse, wife of the publisher. Two performing groups, the Paper Bag Players and Mara and her company, will present the shows.
Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, said early today he would scrap plans to build a controversial parking lot on a lawn at 133d Street and Convent Avenue.
The Borden Food Company said yesterday that it did not know the source of the Salmonella organism that had been found in samples of Starlac, its nonfat, dry milk product.
THE New York Giants and New York Jets lost regular linebackers yesterday because of leg injuries. Their probable replacements on the roster will have little to do with defense.
MOSCOW, Nov. 2 (AP) Tass described today the placing of X-rays and photographs in the Archives as an "attempt to hide clues to the mystery" of his assassination.

New York voters have no more important assignment this year than the election of the 186 delegates who will meet next April in the state's ninth constitutional convention. Their deliberations are likely to have far greater effect in shaping the state's future than the choice of either the Governor or the Legislature.

The 24th Congressional District, which sprawls across some 20 square miles of the north and east Bronx, is one of New York City's political paradoxes. More than 60 per cent of the voters registered are Democrats but the Congressman for seven terms has been Paul A. Fino, the Republican leader of Bronx County.
The Curtiss-Wright Corporation reported yesterday that net profit for the third quarter fell to $1,889,000 from $2,142,000 a year earlier.
Mr. Vice President and Mrs. Humphrey, Mr. Chief Justice, members of the Supreme Court, members of the Cabinet, your excellencies the Ambassadors, ladies and gentlemen, boys and girls:...

WITH THE UNITED STATES SECOND INFANTRY DIVISION, DEMILITARIZED ZONE, Korea, Thursday, Nov. 3 (AP) Maj. Gen. George Pickett Jr., Commander of the United States Second Division, said at a news conference today that one of the six Americans killed in a North Korean attack yesterday passed up a chance to get away and stayed to help the others.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 2 Mrs. Patricia Brown Delate and Thomas Edward Delate of Caracas, Venezuela, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Drucilla Delate, to John Andrew Mantle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Junius Dow Mantle of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 Lewis Graham slipped a nickel in the slot and all of a sudden it was like two Jack Bennys playing except that the tune wasn't "Love in Bloom." It was "Always."

Senators Robert F. Kennedy and Jacob K. Javits teamed up yesterday to campaign for the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board, but promptly broke apart and engaged in a brief, unscheduled and utterly amicable debate over the race for Governor.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 2 (UPI) The Rev. Edmund P. Joyce, chairman of the faculty board in control of athletics at Notre Dame, said yesterday that it was very doubtful that the University would change its policy against participating in postseason games.
Murray M. Wise, vice president of the American Bank Note Company in charge of foreign sales, died Tuesday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 58-years old and lived at 20 Fifth Avenue.

W. LAWRENCE ELDRIDGE of Portland, Me., topped a field of 54 players from seven states to win the Hartford Amateur Open. His score, 6-1, was equaled by Lucien Kraszewski of Dartmouth College and 14-year-old Marc Lonoff of New York City, but he was awarded the title after a tiebreak.
THE announcement that Leonard Bernstein will become "laureate conductor" of the New York Philharmonic in 1969 came as a surprise because his decision had been kept so secret.
SYRACUSE, Nov. 2 (AP) Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that despite personal differences with Governor Rockefeller he would support him for re-election.

ICE shows all operate under an inescapable handicap: When you've seen one, you've seen them all. Not even the most creative performers can transcend the form's basic limitations and, in time, you're left only with changes in sets and costumes.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 2 The strike against the Westinghouse Electric Corporation by the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers was expanded today as more workers walked out or refused to cross picket lines.

Continuing a pattern set earlier in the week, industrial shares drifted back on the London Stock Exchange yesterday on lack of support while fixedinterest issues continued to be in demand for investment.

THERE is something supremely assuring about television; the worst is always yet to come. Last night the ill-starred "Stage '67" undertook what was called a musical suggested by Oscar Wilde's, "The Canterville Ghost." Local 802 of the Musicians Union should adopt a bylaw covering unfair ectoplasm.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 (AP) A United States District judge, Joseph S. Lord 3d, made permanent today an injunction prohibiting Girard College from denying admission to any orphaned boy solely because he is a Negro.
ATLANTA, Nov. 2--If Southern voters saw a gubernatorial candidate on a campaign train in past elections, they could safely bet that a Presidential or Vice-Presidential nominee was somewhere around.

CHERRY HILL, N.J., Nov. 2 (UPI) Jack of All Trades, a 2-year-old colt that displayed front-running form in winning his last start, came from off the pace today to take the $10,000 Garden State Trial by a nose.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 2--The Cabinet of President Mohammed Ayub Khan approved today the introduction of a consitutional amendment bill to give more legislative powers to the National Assembly.
A group of leading electricutility executives agreed here yesterday that by 1980 roughly 20 per cent of this nation's generating capacity will be nuclear-fueled.
The election of Robert F. Flood as vice president in charge of purchasing and distribution was announced here yesterday by the Union Carbide Corporation.

President Johnson has returned safe and sound to the United States, for which all Americans will be thankful. The results of his trip, however, leave little cause for thankfulness. Peace in Vietnam is certainly no nearer than before he left the country. The prospects are for a long and escalating war.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 President Johnson returned home this evening from his seven-nation Pacific tour "more confident" and "more hopeful" that peace, security and prosperity could be achieved in Asia. The "road ahead may be a long and difficult one," he told a crowd that had assembled on a rainy fall evening to greet him at Dulles International Airport.

The Pioneer Finance Company of Detroit, which moved to the brink of bankruptcy last Friday apparently is going to get a new lease on life. The brink was reached when the holders of its 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock rejected a proposed acquisition of the company by the General Acceptance Corporation of Allentown, Pa.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 The Federal Government will almost double expenditures in the fiscal year 1967 for birth control and family planning, according to a survey by the Bureau of the Budget.
LONDON, Nov. 2 "All business is a gamble," says Sir Basil Smallpeice, chairman of the Cunard Steam-Ship Company, Ltd., adding quickly that "one tries to insure as small a gamble as possible."
ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 2 The cold war between Ghana and Guinea appears headed for a quick thaw.
FALL RIVER, Mass., Nov. 2 Democrats were hopeful this week before election of closing the gap that has kept them from control of the 10th Congressional District seat for 42 years.
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. charged yesterday that Frank D. O'Connor was insincere in promising to appoint Negroes to top state positions if he is elected Governor.
City antipoverty officials, worried over the effect of Federal cutbacks, have begun a drive to get the state to contribute funds to their programs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 Richard A. Graham, a former Peace Corps director in Tunisia and a member of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, was sworn in today as the first director of the National Teacher Corps.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 2 Premier Jens Otto Krag submitted his Government's resignation today and called for a general election Nov. 22.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2 Secretary General Thant asked Ghana today to release 19 members of a Guinean diplomatic party detained in Accra.
SYRACUSE, Nov. 2 Richard M. Nixon called tonight for an immediate "economic offensive" to help end the war in Vietnam.
BONN, Nov. 2 Chancellor Ludwig Erhard offered today to resign if that would solve West Germany's political crisis. His remarks, however, were not regarded as an offer to step down immediately.

The Bank of New York, the oldest bank in the city and a specialist in investment management, opened its biennial investment seminar at the New York Hilton Hotel yesterday with the airing of some mixed views on the business outlook.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 The 145,000-member Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen accepted today a 1967 contract with the nation's railroads that provides a 5 per cent increase in wages and benefits.
"MOTHER was a snob," the Baron Roy Andries de Groot said this week in his Greenwich Village apartment.
The American Stock Exchange closed higher yesterday although some of its earlier gains evaporated on profit taking in the late afternoon.

The Rockwell-Standard Corporation announced yesterday the election of two bankers to its board. They are John J. Balles, vice president of the Mellon National Bank and Trust Company in Pittsburgh and Roy L. Reierson, senior vice president of the Bankers Trust Company of New York.

PARIS, Nov. 2 The Chase Manhattan Bank took over the Paris Hilton ballroom today to tell 150 European bankers that the United States economy may rise more slowly next year, the stock market will do better, and "You have a friend at the Chase."
SYLMAR, Calif., Nov. 2 (AP) Four marines died while fight- ing a brush fire in the hill country of Southern California today, bringing the number of men killed in fires to 14.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 The State Department announced today that it was "seriously concerned" over the recent series of attacks by North Korean forces around the military demarcation line in Korea.
The Board of Elections here cautioned voters yesterday to do as much homework as possible before going to the polls next Tuesday.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 2 (AP) Buyers spent $1,117,150, a record, for 258 horses today at the annual standardbred horse sale.

The Department of Agriculture has estimated that cigarette sales this year will increase about 2 per cent over the 515.5 billion units sold last year. Consumption in 1965 was 3.5 per cent ahead of 1964.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Nov. 3 United States Navy sources disclosed today that Navy ships have bombarded the coast of North Vietnam for the first time.
Stock prices churned erratically yesterday as the market slogged through an active session marked by alternating periods of rally and retreat.
If you want to vote to retain the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board, vote "No" on Question 1 in the Nov. 8 election; if you oppose the board, vote "Yes."

Edwin E. Bond, executive director of the United Service Organizations for 15 years, died yesterday at his home in Groton, Mass. He was 63 years old and had suffered from a heart ailment for three years.

Rabbi and Mrs. Avigdor Cyperstein of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, hare announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nechama Cyperstein, to Rabbi Noam Gordon, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Judah Gordon of Brooklyn.

The engagement of Miss Ines Martins, daughter of Alex A. Martins of 315 Eighth Avenue and Mohegan Lake, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Martins, to Eugene Clifford Scharmann of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Scharmann of Fair Lawn, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's father.
BERLIN, Nov. 2 "Billy Graham is the theologian-evaneglist of the Baptist movement," the Rev. Dr. Carl F.H. Henry said in an interview today between sessions of the World Congress on Evangelism.

TOKYO, Nov. 2 The Johnson jet was barely off the ground at Seoul this morning when the hundreds of lovely girls chanting a sweet farewell were suddenly displaced by grunting men with brooms and bins shuffling away the debris.

ALBANY, Nov. 2 The Malverne, L.I., school board and lawyers for Negro parents clashed over a conference table today as State Education Commissioner James E. Allen Jr. heard arguments on the board's proposed "freedom of choice" plan for pupil transfers.
A two-hour meeting in City Hall yesterday brought no solution to the plumbers' strike that has stopped $500-million worth of building construction in Manhattan and the Bronx since last July.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 2 A Democratic fund-raiser went on trial today on charges of having accepted an illegal campaign contribution. The case has rocked the Democrats in their fight to retain control of the state.

"RELAXED" was the word for dog shows in Eng land, said Mrs. Pat Spear at the Dog Fanciers Club meeting at the Overseas Press Club yesterday. Mrs. Spear, who came from Yorkshire, now lives in Locust Valley, L.I., and airs her canine opinions regularly on the radio.
Sales of new cars fell behind last year's pace in the month and final 10 days of October, according to reports received yesterday from Detroit.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) The Justice Department said today it was looking into the legal significance of Stokely Carmichael's comments that he would refuse to be drafted into the Army.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 2 The skies cleared over North Vietnam yesterday and United States pilots flew 122 bombing missions, each involving two planes or more. It was one of the heaviest attacks on the North in four weeks.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 The United States went to the Organization of African Unity today to criticize both Guinea and Ghana for their conduct in their current dispute.

LONDON, Nov. 2 A new security case erupted in Britain today with the appearance in a magistrates court of Cecil William Mulvena, a 47-year-old busnessman of dual British and French nationality. He faced what his lawyer described as "serious charges" under the Official Secrets Act.

Bobby Cassidy of Levittown, L.I., knocked down Argentine Cele (The Cat) Lema twice in the first and second rounds and went on to score a unanimous eight-round decision at Sunnyside Gardens in Queens last night.

Almars Elksnis, who was freed from state prison last July where he had been serving a term of up to 35 years for the knife-slaying of his commonlaw wife, was found guilty yesterday by a Federal Court jury of possessing and passing two counterfeit $10 bills.
The spot rate on the British pound eased yesterday on foreign exchange markets here. The pound moved down a point to $2.7912 from $2.7913 on Tuesday.
Mayor Lindsay reported yesterday a measurable improvement in the city's economy this year over last year.

PARIS, Nov. 2 It is hard for an American to be himself in Paris. Strolling the St. Germain with his wife, he pauses at a cafe, orders coffee, calls for writing paper and ink and is suddenly Ernest Hemingway.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2 An urgent appeal for completion of a treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons was approved today by 100 to 1 in the General Assembly's Political Committee.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov 2 Dick Colman would not go so far as to say that the Harvard football team that comes into Palmer Stadium Saurday with a perfect record and designs on the Ivy championship and Lambert Trophy is the best that John Yovicsin has sent out in his 10 years at the Crimson's boss man.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 2 (UPI) Preminer, an Irish 4-year-old colt, was withdrawn today from the $150,000 Washington D.C. International Nov. 11 because he had not been training well.

A Congressman who calls the skies over Manhattan an "aerial cesspool" and a Federal air pollution expert who agrees with him charged yesterday that New York and New Jersey were procrastinating on efforts to halt air pollution.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 2 (AP)--The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. advocated today an overhaul of Selective Service exemption procedures to correct "the disproportionate number of Negroes in Vietnam."
VIENNA, Nov. 2 A noted investigator of Nazi war crimes against the Jews said today that Austrian Nazis had killed about half the six million Jews who perished during World War II.
The directors of The New York Times Company have proposed a 5-for-1 split of the company's Class A and Class B common shares.
A 4 per cent increase in 1967 apparel production was forecast here yesterday at a meeting of about 300 industry executives and security analysts.

The Columbia Broadcasting System's television network announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Royal Shakespeare Theater of England for the production of three plays, each to be at least two hours. They are "King Lear," "Macbeth" and "A Midsummer Night's Dream."

Two metals makers the Phelps Dodge Corporation and the United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company joined yesterday the bandwagon of record profits for the third quarter and first nine months of this year.
GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 2 Miss Ines Hinckeldeyn and John M. Kingsley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kingsley, plan to marry in January.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 2 (UPI) A former mayor of suburban Bay Village, a close friend in 1954 of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard and his wife, testified today that he felt Dr. Sheppard had tried to point the finger of suspicion at him for the murder of his wife.
Anthony Brenninkmeyer, formerly vice president, has been named president of Ohrbach's, the New York-based specialtystore chain, succeeding his cousin, Elmar Brenninkmeyer.

George S. Moore, president of the First National City Bank, New York, offered cautious optimism last night that the United States might have a surplus in international payments "in the not-so-distant future." In a brief address to the National Foreign Trade Convention that awarded him with this year's Captain Robert Dollar Memorial Award, the banker said:

OXFORD, Md., Nov. 2 Xavier Toocate, a duck and goose calling guide from Quebec charmed a flight of geese off their intended course the other morning and brought them in over the pit blind and decoys to the gunners.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy announced yesterday that John R. Strachan, a career post office employe, would be sworn in tomorrow morning as the first Negro acting Postmaster for Manhattan.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2 The Security Council and the General Assembly filled three of the five vacancies on the International Court of Justice today. The votes were secret and concurrent.

ARTURO BENEDETTI MICHELANGELI gave a piano recital last night in Philharmonic Hall, and the first half of the evening was as beautiful as the second half was perplexing. But that is Mr. Michelangeli's way. He is a perplexing pianist who can play one piece of music directly and clearly, then turn around with powder and paint, and toy around with a composition until one could scream.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 There is not much left of the national election campaign except what might be its major event the swing around the circuit upon which President Johnson will embark Friday, with twenty or so stops planned in fifteen states. Advance reports say it will be a "Boston to Austin" junket, opening in Massachusetts and winding up Election Day with several appearances in Texas.
A VETERAN observer of marketing trends, who has his hand on the pulsebeat of small business, has come to the conclusion that a recession is on the way.
The City Planning Commission took the first steps yesterday toward carrying out Mayor Lindsay's policy of concentrating urban renewal in the "areas of greatest need."
JEAN DUPUY placed his cube-based table next to a cube seat inside a cubeshaped room and talked about cubes.

The Holland Society of New York will present its gold medal for distinguished achievement on Monday to Dr. Mason W. Gross, president of Rutgers University. The society's president, Walter E. Hooper Jr. will bestow the medal, at the Pierre.
Carnegie Hall's Festival of Visiting Orchestras welcomed its second visitor last night as William Steinberg led the Pittsburgh Symphony in a program- of Beethoven, Mahler and Debussy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara has won an argument over whether the United States should become physically involved in putting down a Communist rising in northeast Thailand.
UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 2 Syracuse, with its All-American tailback, Floyd Little, is favored to beat Penn State here Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 Scientists at the National Institutes of Health have found a way of tricking hidden cancer viruses into revealing themselves.
General Assembly and Security Council elected three of five new judges.
In seeming defiance of the Superintendent of Schools, DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx has barred a 17-yearold senior from class until he gets a haircut.

The Beatrice Foods Company is further diversifying its nonfood activities through the proposed acquisition of Melnor Industries, Inc., Moonachie, N.J. makers of garden equipment. The transaction involves between $10.5-million and $11million in stock.
Meets at 11 A.M. on Israel's complaint against Syria; meets after General Assembly to complete World Court election.

A former lieutenant of the security forces at Yonkers Raceway and a daytime chestnut vendor were arrested yesterday by Federal agents in the continuing investigation of tax frauds involving the twin double at the harness track. The number of persons under arrest reached 41.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 2 A wedding on Nov. 26 is planned by Miss Freya Elizabeth Lund and Burton Sonenstein, Mr. and Mrs. Geoffrey V. Lund have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Sonenstein of Waterbury.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 2 (AP)--Harland Sanders, finance chairman for the Democratic campaign in Kentucky, was listed today as the largest contributor to a Republican's Congressional campaign.

LITTLE ROCK, Nov. 2 (AP) Two financial documents "of a very personal nature" to Winthrop Rockefeller, the multimillionaire who is the Republican candidate for Governor of Arkansas, were reported missing today from the office of Mr. Rockefeller's accountants.

Peter Joseph William Debye was born in Maastricht, the Netherlands, on March 24, 1884. He studied electrical engineering at the Technische Hochschule in Aachen, Germany, from which he graduated in 1906.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 Opening tonight with a gala and tomorrow to the public, the Manet exhibition at the Philadelphia Museum of Art is certainly one of the very important shows of the year.

Staging a rousing rush in the closing phase of the 1 1-16-mile feature on the turf at Aqueduct yesterday, Sabemar carried the colors of James E. Clay to a thrilling victory over Blue Thor and Fatal Step. Only a nose and then a neck separated the first three in the field of nine fillies and mares, and the one that the crowd of 22,817 regarded as least likely to succeed, of this trio, was Sabemar.

SAIGON, Thursday, Nov. 3 (AP) United States Air Force pilots said today they devastated a missile site in Communist North Vietnam in strikes that began in daylight Wednesday and continued into the night.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Sharkey of Brooklyn and Lake Mohawk, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Therese Sharkey, to Joseph Michael Pedersen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Pedersen of Lake Mohawk.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 2 (AP) Paul McCoy, who patented and sold the first vitamin tablets 43 years ago, died in a hospital today. He was 92 years old. He founded McCoy's Laboratories in 1923. The company's principal product was cod liver oil tablets.

The final race was run in a thick fog, and the track announcer Bill Johnson, a sharpeyed ex-Marine, was unable to identify the horses on the backstretch, and neither could anyone else. When the field came into sight, Nashaweena had a big lead on Sir Sanford, whom he beat by 3 lengths, with Barbagris third in the field of seven. Nashaweena, ridden by Ernie Cardone, paid $7 for $2.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 2 Election Day will settle most political races in the country, but not necessarily those in Bullock County, Ala.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 Secretary Robert C. Weaver of the Department of Housing and Urban Development disclosed here today a step toward alleviating the present housing crisis and a study aimed at dramatic changes in home financing to prevent future convulsions.
