IF the impression has been growing on you that more and more field goals are being kicked this season by the professionals and the collegians, there is no need to wonder whether your judgment is inaccurate. You are correct. The field goal booters are connecting at a record rate.
John H. Forbes, a retired lawyer, died yesterday in the Lynwood Nursing Home, 306 West 102d Street. He was 61 years old and lived at 1295 Madison Avenue.

TORONTO, Nov. 2 The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., settled for a smaller price increase than it has originally intended following discussions with Canadian Finance Minister Mitchell Sharp, Government sources in Ottawa said tonight.
Jeanne Stark, pianist, who made her local debut in 1960 as Jeanne Sartanaer and has continued her concert career under her married name, played at Town Hall last night.
A young woman recently reported for an employment interview at a company where she had been sent by an employment agency. She was told she was overqualified for the job.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 All stocks of Borden's Starlac, a leading powdered milk product, are being recalled because some of it has been found to be contaminated with disease-causing Salmonella bacteria.

The Government of Colombia has decided to begin construction of an interoceanic seaway. It will run for 260 miles from the Gulf of Uraba on the Caribbean through the jungled valley of Choco Province in the northwestern part of the country to the Bay of Malaga on the Pacific Ocean.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 2 (AP) Blaming apathy among housewives, the women who organized the first protest movement against rising prices resigned today.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Nov. 2 (AP) A bill establishing a five-year research program for the production of fish protein concentrate for human consumption was signed by President Johnson here today.

Representative Jonathan B. Bingham is campaigning for re-election in a red-white-and-blue converted school bus that has a rear platform from which he can expound his views to constituents in the Bronx's 23d Congressional District.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell's Republican opponent in next Tuesday's election charged in court yesterday that the Harlem Democrat was not a bona fide New Yorker and therefore was ineligible to hold office.
Seventy-six persons slid safely down plastic emergency chutes last night from a Boeing 727 jet when the landing gear collapsed and the plane skidded to a stop at La Guardia Airport.

Leonard J. Oppenheimer of 86 Woodmere Boulevard, Woodmere, L.I., senior vice president and secretary of West Chemical Products, Inc., died on Tuesday at St. Joseph's Hospital, Far Rockaway, Queens. His age was 58.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 Consumer installment credit recorded its smallest rise of the year in September, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Outstanding installment credit increased by $475-million to a total of $72.8-billion during the month.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) This year for the first time, Roman Catholic bishops of the United States will elect a president and a vice president of their group. They will also elect an administrative board of 40 members.
The recently founded Center for Maritime Research now being organized at Webb Institute of Naval Architecture, Glen Cove, L.I., yesterday announced plans for three research projects.
Senator Kennedy said yesterday that the number of narcotics addicts in New York State had doubled during the tenure of Governor Rockefeller.
The National Foreign Trade Council wound up its annual convention yesterday by issuing a call for a broad reappraisal of United States trade and shipping policies.
Dr. Paul L. Adams, the Conservative party candidate for Governor, ventured into Democratic Brooklyn yesterday urging voters to join in a "tax rebellion."
Abraham Straus, a division of Federated Department Stores, Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of Kenneth Kolker as vice president and general merchandise manager.
VIENNA, Nov. 2 (Reuters) Mao Tse-tung has accused the Soviet Union, Yugoslavia and their allies of working to restore capitalism and of crawling before the imperialists.
WILLIAMS' undefeated and untied football team is fully backed, at least for one more game, by the Amherst team.

Frank D. O'Connor and Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. pledged to the state's mayors yesterday that if elected Governor they would insist that local governments be reimbursed for expenditures mandated on them by the state.

City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., Queens Democrat, is seeking to enlist the support of the nation's housewives for a one-day countrywide boycott of all chain food stores some day during the week of Nov. 20 Thanksgiving Week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) An Administration recommendation of a large increase in Federal income taxes, possibly up to 10 per cent, was forecast, today by Senator George D. Aiken of Vermont.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 2 (AP) Smith College awarded the Smith Medal today to three alumnae who "exemplify in their lives the true purpose of liberal arts education."

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 2 Stanley Dancer, who triumphed with See Lucky in the $40,762 colt division, and Levi Harner, who won with Avon Girl in the $40,462 filly division of the two sections of the New York Sire Stakes at Roosevelt Raceway tonight enjoyed easy journeys over the sloppy Nassau County track.

THE bedeviled characters in Francoise Sagan's new novel, "La Chamade," seem to have been reading too many stories by Francoise Sagan. Is this guilt by association? Yes, in a way. In fact, it is appropriate.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 2 For the second consecutive year, India is facing a critical food shortage and a threat of famine.

The strike called by the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers at some large Westinghouse plants points up the need for fresh thought by both management and labor on the adequacy of traditional bargaining structures.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Nov. 2 Federal mediation in a wage dispute between Local 1911 of the International Longshoremen's Association and Cargo Handlers Inc. at the big port here was sought today by the International union's vice president, William Haile of Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2--Private persons will not receive permission to see the autopsy photographs and X-rays of President Kennedy's body for the next five years, a representative of the Kennedy family disclosed today.
MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 2 (UPI) The police said today they had recovered all but two packets of dangerous prescription pills given by mistake to trick-or-treat youngsters on Halloween night.
LONDON, Nov. 2 A deal to airlift copper from Land-locked Zambia and bring in gasoline was announced here today by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and Zambian Air Cargoes, a Zambian company.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 2 (UPI) Mob violence spread throughout southeast India today and the police opened fire in at least three cities to quell left-wing riots that have claimed at least 17 lives.
Earnings of the IngersollRand Company rose 20.6 per cent for the first nine months of this year while sales gained 11.2 per cent both records
LONDON, Nov. 2 Britain's reserves of gold and convertible currencies showed a significant gain in October, the second rise in a row after five straight declines.
The nation's electric power production rose 7.7 per cent in the week ended Oct. 29 from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Elteric Institute.
What do the sea lanes carrying American ships across the Pacific Ocean to Vietnam have to do with the Kings Point- Hofstra University football game this Saturday in Hemp- stead, L.I.?

The immediate tasks of the United States Equestrian Team which won the top awards in international jumping at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden are the Washington International and the Royal Winter Fair in Toronto. The Washington show started yesterday and the other opens Nov. 11.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) Representative Emanuel Celler urged the Federal Communications Commission today to prohibit radio and television stations from endorsing political candidates.
MOSCOW, Nov. 2 Marshall D. Shulman, an American expert in Soviet studies, left here today at the end of a one-month visit after the Soviet press had branded him an intelligence operative.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) An early snow storm brought wintry-like weather to sections of the Midwest and Southeast today as temperatures dipped to freezing as far south as the Gulf Coast and central Texas.

Pope Paul's decision to defer once again a modification of the stand of the Catholic Church on birth control is disappointing, particularly to Catholic leaders who have been pressing for and anticipating decisive change. Worse still, his strong affirmation of traditional doctrine is likely to check some of the campaigns that prominent Catholics, both lay and clerical, have undertaken to acquaint their coreligionists with the importance of "responsible family planning."
The Federal Aviation Agency is studying the possibility of shifting all international flights from Kennedy International Airport to a lesscongested airport.
Marvels, a little-known cigarette that ranked second in the latest Reader's Digest tar and nicotine study, has reached New York and is on the verge of being widely promoted here.

Britain's National Theater, headed by Sir Laurence Olivier, will not be seen here in repertory during the 1967-68 season as planned. The troupe was to have been here for eight weeks after completing a Canadian trip as one of the features of that country's centennial celebration.
Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation said yesterday that it had earned $763,000, or 34 cents a share in the nine months ended Sept. 30.

TIJUANA, Mexico, Nov. 2 (UPI) A fast-moving fire broke out in a densely populated residential area of this border city tonight engulfing an estimated 250 flimsy homes and forcing several thousand residents to flee into the night.
The American merchant marine at midyear was losing ground in its efforts to increase its participation in the nation's growing waterborne foreign trade.
The appointment of Donald R. Hibbert as vice president and treasurer of the Wyandotte Chemicals Corporation was announced yesterday in Wyandotte, Mich.

TORONTO, Nov. 2 (UPI) J.C. Tremblay, a defenseman scored on a bouncing shot from center ice in the first minute or the third period to enable the Montreal Canadiens to tie the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2-2, tonight in a National Hockey League game.
The U.S. Option Corporation affiliated with the Fidelity Management and Research Company of Boston, has applied for membership in the Put and Call Brokers and Dealers Association, Inc., New York.

A third-party campaign by Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama for the Presidency in 1968 "would cripple Republican chances for victory and all but insure the re-election of President Johnson," Louis Harris reported in yesterday's New York Post.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP)--Dr. James L. Goddard, commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, called on the pharmaceutical industry today to develop better control over clinical investigators of new drugs.

SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 2 Three hours after North Korean soldiers attacked a United Nations command patrol just south of the demilitarized zone, infiltrators clashed with South Korean forces today along the zone, allied military authorities reported.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) John M. Bailey, Democratic National Chairman, charged today that House Republican leaders had ordered a quick "scrubbing up job" on a $50,000 campaign film after news reports described its contents.

PONTIAC, Mich., Nov. 2 (UPI)--The entire night crew of the Pontiac Police Department called in "sick" in a wage dispute today in what could be the beginning of the nation's first police strike since 1919.

Dana W. Grant has been appointed managing director of the Ajax, Ont., holdings of Duffins Creek Estates, Ltd., a division of the Perini Land Development Company of Framingham, Mass. Mr. Grant was formerly assistant vice president of real estate and finance for the D.H. Overmyer Company in this city.
THE EAGLE AND THE IRON CROSS, by Glendon Swarthout (New American Library, $4.95), Novel about two Germans who escaped from an Arizona prisoner-of-war camp.

Professor Shulman once worked as a reporter for The Detroit News and later as a writer for the National Safety Council. In World War II, he rose from private to captain in the Air Force as a glider pilot and psychological warfare officer.

PEKING, Nov. 2--The heroes' welcome accorded 65 Chinese students who returned to Peking today after expulsion from the Soviet Union tended to over shadow a sweeping new measure aimed at minimizing dislocations caused by millions of teen-age Red Guards traveling around the country to "exchange revolutionary experiences."
ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 2 When Martin Liquori was younger, he frittered away his spare time plucking a banjo or a guitar in a combo.

CEDARHURST, L.I., ,Nov. 3 Mr. and Mrs. G. Philip Lynch of Cedarhurst and Bridgehampton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Madelaine Low Lynch, to Peter Arnold Karthaus Reese, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lee Reese Jr. of Wilmington, Del.

It is regrettable that Controller Mario A. Procaccino's report on New York City's finances was not made public prior to the latest sale of the city's obligations. If the market had been made aware that the city was in such good shape, the prospect is that the city--and its taxpayers--would have achieved a substantial saving instead of being forced to pay the highest interest costs in more than a generation.
FOR most working Americans, 1913 was a black year. That was the year that Congress passed the 16th Amendment to the Constitution empowering the Federal Government to levy income taxes.
DETROIT, Nov. 3 (UPI) A goal by Murray Hall, a rookie, with six minutes remaining to play enabled the Detroit Red Wings to achieve a 2-2 tie tonight with the Toronto Maple Leafs.

Dr. Robert D. Cross, the 42-year-old chairman of the history department at Columbia University, was named president of Hunter College yesterday by the Board of Higher Education, effective next August.

LEATHER is too good a fashion to leave down on the farm or in the hands of the motorcycle brigade. Designers have brought it to town, imbued with color gentle, feminine shades like dove gray or screaming fashionable ones like chrome yellow paired it with silk, linen or tweed and endowed it with contemporary shapes.

Frederick E. Weeks Jr., an assistant state attorney general and former chief assistant district attorney of Westchester County, died of a heart attack ofter an operation Wednesday night at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 59 years old and lived at 50 North Broadway in White Plains.
WESTBURY, L.I. Nov. 3 Looking at him struggling to get into a pair of baggy blue trousers, Frank Ervin did not look like an athlete who could control a 1,000-pound horse for a mile.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission, apparently seeking to head off a new tar competition among tobacco companies, announced today it would try to establish common standards for measuring the nicotine and tar content of cigarettes.

The Deltona Corporation which now has two huge home communities Deltona and Marco Island under development in Florida, is making plans for a third. The new development in west central Florida will house 50,000 persons.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 On a sunny afternoon early last June, 10 unhappy Government officials gathered around an oval table in the White House office of Joseph A. Califano Jr., a Presidential assistant.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 3 Capt. Townsend Clarke probably will miss the final home game of his Army football career when the cadets play George Washington Saturday before a near-capacity crowd at Michie Stadium.

THE NEW YORK GIANTS rehearsed indoors and out- doors yesterday at Yankee Stadium for Sunday's game here against the St. Louis Cardinals, the Eastern Conference leaders of the National Football League.

The Hanna Mining Company announced yesterday it was increasing the price of its ferronickel by 7 cents a pound effective immediately. The Cleveland-based producer said it was "following the pattern" set earlier by other nickel industry leaders.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy announced yesterday the appointment of a 30-year-postal employe, Frank Viola, as Acting Postmaster for the Bronx.

LONDON, Nov. 3 The negotiable certificate of deposit, that modern instrument of capitalist finance that has captivated Wall Street, will soon be on sale at the Moscow Norodny Bank in London for dollars.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 President Johnson and Vice President Humphrey have an agreement that could make Mr. Humphrey "acting President" if the President wished during Mr. Johnson's hospitalization.
Mrs. Flora Ginsburg Chudson, a lawyer and a Democratic candidate for Congress in Westchester County in 1952, died Wednesday. She was 47 years old and lived at 11 Pryer Lane in Larchmont, N.Y.
A 17-year-old Bronx high school senior was reinstated in his class yesterday after an assistant superintendent of schools decided that his hair was not too long.

In one significant respect the President's visit to Manila has served a useful purpose. It has helped to unite our Asian allies and to give Asians a visible demonstration that America remains behind her commitment to a free Pacific.
Despite going very wide in the stretch, Ornamento of the Saddle Rock Farm won the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday.

No matter how the review board referendum fares next week, the idea of civilian control is firmly planted, and it is doubtful that it can be bypassed in the future. But because the new Civilian Complaint Review Board has been the center of such controversy, and perhaps overstated as a symbol, its abolition might also assume inflated importance to minority groups.

The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation has called for redemption Dec. 31 all outstanding shares of the company's 4.75 per cent convertible preferred stock at $50.50 a share and all its 4.25 convertible preferred stock at $51 a share.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 Following are the texts of statements made at the White House this afternoon by President Johnson and the President's physician, Dr. George Burkley:

A faculty committee's report advocating that City College's Bernard M. Baruch School of Business and Public Administration become a separate college within the City University will be presented to the Baruch School faculty today.

Directors of the Polaroid Corporation voted yesterday in Cambridge, Mass., to double the quarterly dividend to 10 cents a common share. The 5-cent rate had been in effect since the fourth quarter of 1965.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 3 (UPI) Led by Chet Walker's 36 points and 21 rebounds, the unbeaten Philadelphia 76ers tied a National Basketball Association record by winning their 17th consecutive regular-season game tonight as they downed the St. Louis Hawks, 120-108.

The appointment of J. Ward Wright to head the research program of the Temporary State Commission on the Constitutional Convention was announced yesterday by Robert S. Herman, the executive director of the commission.
Milton Herder, the Socialist Labor Party's candidate for Governor, termed his opponents yesterday "singularly ordinary men armed with, at best, a pot of money and a few glib phrases."
IT was really inconsiderate of Shakespeare not to have written a play about Queen Elizabeth. If only he had, he'd have closed the door and kept everybody else from trying so hard.
Drastic reforms in building procedures to speed municipal construction projects and cut red tape were urged yesterday by Public Works Commissioner William C. Mattison.

Edward Bartsch, who retired in 1950 as board chairman of Rayonier, Inc., producers of purified wool cellulose and lumber, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at Melvin Village, N.H., and Lake Wales, Fla.

John Ferdinand Hickey, a stockbroker with W.E. Hutton Co. and a former banker and national treasurer of the United Service Organizations, died yesterday in his home at 360 Central Park West. His age was 73.

HAVANA, Nov. 3 The United States team, by tying Norway, 1-1, with two games adjourned, in the seventh and final round of the preliminaries, virtually assured itself of first place in Group III of the 17th Chess Olympics at the Havana Libre Hotel here last night.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 3 (AP) Wayne Zahn of Atlanta rocked the pins for a 230 average in his final six games tonight and the big set moved him to the top with a 5,270 total for 24 games in the $65,000 Professional Bowlers Association Championship at the Garden City Bowl.

BRISBANE, Australia, Nov. 3 (Reuters) Owen Davidson, who is ranked No. 6 in Australia, defeated his fourth-ranked compatriot, Tony Roche, 6-2, 6-3, 6-4, in the quarter-finals of the Queensland lawn tennis championships today.

TREASURE ISLAND, Calif., Nov. 3 A much-decorated Navy captain was accused today at a general court-martial of having run a black market operation while commanding a military supply network in Vietnam.
With the help of some new Litton ads, the water cooler may be replaced by the Royfax 7 copier as the office social center.
The appointments of Paul W. Douglas and Thomas G. Ferguson as vice presidents was announced here yesterday by the Freeport Sulphur Company.
Richard M. Nixon said yesterday that the recent Manila Conference accomplished nothing toward achieving peace in Vietnam.
Dr. Paul L. Adams, Conservative candidate for Governor, went to Wall Street yesterday in his campaign to pull "true Republicans" away from Governor Rockefeller.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) A convention of Negro clergymen spoke out today against the quest for "black power" and against violence and hate in the civil rights movement.
The New York Metropolitan Committee of the United World Federalists has given its annual Publius Award to The New York Times.
The New York State Athletic Commission said yesterday it would recognize the Nov. 28 Carlos Ortiz-Flash Elorde fight at Madison Square Garden as a world lightweight championship contest.

Young men with the muscles, instant reflexes and sailing talent required to be crew members on America's Cup defense candidates, who also are willing to work long and hard at sea without pay, never seem to be in short supply.

Contradictory polls, rampant unenthusiasm among voters and the complication of two splinter parties have left political experts thoroughly confused about the likely outcome of next week's election for Governor.
In Hollywood, where rumor is news, there have recently been circulating reports of impending changes in the studio operations of Paramount Pictures and Columbia Pictures.

Steve Spurrier, the quarterback with the biggest scrapbook in college football, will face his biggest challenge tomorrow when undefeated Florida meets once-defeated Georgia before 62,000 at Jacksonville, Fla.

For five years, a power struggle in amateur sports has disrupted America's Olympic effort, decimated track meets and other competition, harassed athletes for competing and sometimes for not competing, encouraged sanctions and countersanctions, embittered participants and grass-roots volunteer officials and focused attention on administrators rather than athletes.
New-car sales of the American Motors Corporation fell 25 per cent, to 8,181 units, in the final third of October from 10,937 units in the comparable period last year.
The men of The Yale Daily News are planning their 10th, biggest and best career guide magazine The Word Business '67.

The spot rate on the British pound rose in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The closing quotation was $2.7924, up 12 points from Wednesday. The increase largely reflected temporary money market maneuvers. Pound sterling for delivery Monday was quoted at $2.7915.

The trial of Eugene Rodriguez, a Bronx Democratic candidate for the State Senate, who has been accused of perjury and attempted grand larceny in a narcotics case, was adjourned until Nov. 14 when his lawyer failed to turn up in court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 Attorneys for James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters' Union, asserted today that two convictions against him must fall if the Supreme, Court strikes down one now before it.

YONKERS, Nov. 3 Frank D. O'Connor stood late this afternoon on an abandoned ferry slip over a major sewer outlet, sniffed cautiously and said that Governor Rockefeller "obviously has been dragging his heels" in cleaning up the Hudson River.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 Eyebrows rose at a Tariff Commission hearing today when a group of United States importers suggested a move that might raise duties on certain classes of imports.
MADRID, Nov. 3 Spain was reported today to be considering a request by Tass, the Soviet press agency, to open an office in Madrid.

The American Society of Civil Engineers has elected Earle T. Andrews as president. At the same time, the 58,000member organization has named Richard H. Tatlow 3d as president-elect to succeed Mr. Andrews when his term expires at the end of October, 1967.

The Attorney General of New York State is its chief legal officer, though his powers and responsibilities are far less than those of his Federal counterpart. The post has been filled effectively for the past nine years by Louis J. Lefkowitz. He has shown great energy in protecting consumers and investors against fraud. He organized a civil rights bureau to combat discrimination, and has worked hard to improve election procedures. He deserves re-election.

JOHN V. LINDSAY Jr., who is 6 years old, was ready yesterday to chuck his perfectly nice workroom at home in Gracie Mansion when he saw the one that had been done for him at the National Design Center.

Tickets for a theater party on Nov. 16 in behalf of Volunteer Service Photographers are still available, although the buffet dinner at Sardi's that will start the evening is sold out. The party will see "Is Paris Burning?" at the Criterion Theater.

Twin inquiries were started yesterday by the State Investigation Commission and the Appellate Division into an alleged extortion attempt in connection with a liquor license application for a Queens tavern.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 The Securities and Exchange Commission split 3-2 today on an issue that has increasingly divided it in recent months the fairness of penalties imposed on violators of the securities laws.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 3 Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. John F. Grady of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Grady, to Lieut. Frederick W. Keith Jr., U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Keith of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

ATLANTA, Nov. 3 (AP) A Latvian immigrant who developed a one-man rat-killing business into a nationwide multimillion dollar pest control enterprise has been certified as needy and is allowed to pick up free Government surplus food.

PARIS, Nov. 3 Francois Mitterrand, leader of the nonCommunist left-wing opposition to President de Gaulle, opened France's latest electoral campaign today with a broadside attack on the general's policy of "national independence."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 A hernia such as President Johnson has developed is one of the standard risks of abdominal surgery.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 3 A merger of the white and Negro teachers' associations in Virginia was approved here today. The unification is scheduled for Jan. 1.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 Alumni of Girard College will move to have the institution closed and its funds turned over to the state under the donor's will if the United States Supreme Court orders the admission of Negroes to the home and school for white orphans, according to Dr. H. Todd Williamson, president of the association.
Stock prices and trading volume moved in tandem yesterday. They went down.
SPOKANE, Wash., Nov. 3 (AP) The whereabouts of the Los Angeles Dodgers shortstop, Maury Wills, remained a mystery today, although his wife said here she believed he was in Hawaii.

PROVIDENCE, R.I. Nov 3 (UPI) A scheduled four-day walkout by 1,500 state employes, the first such work stoppage in the state's history, ended tonight after one day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 Franklyn A. Johnson has resigned as director of the antipoverty program's Job Corps, effective upon acceptance of the resignation by the President.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 The American Public Health Association called today for the overhauling of Federal laws on "over-the-counter" drugs to require that all ingredients be listed.
SAN DIEGO, Nov. 3 (AP) A Federal judge ruled today that the Navy could retain an officer on active duty against his will because the Vietnam War had created an emergency.

John Thomas Cahill, senior partner in the New York, Washington and Paris law firm of Cahill, Gordon, Reindel Ohl, died of cancer yesterday at the King Edward VII's Hospital for Officers in London. He would have been 63 years old on Nov. 17.

GRENADA, Miss., Nov. 3 Mississippi John Hurt, the country blues singer who was twice "discovered" by recording companies but who spent most of his life in poverty, died yesterday in a hospital here after a short illness. He was 74 years old.
The research that won Dr. Alfred Kastler a Nobel Prize has been basic to the development of the laser.

Francis Heilbut's debut piano recital last night at Carnegie Recital Hall showed him to be far from the usual conservatory pianist stamped with conformity. The Burgtheater of Vienna will visit New York for the first time in March, 1968. It will play, a three-week engagement, March 18 through April 7, at the City Center.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 3 Governor Rockefeller told Westchester audiences today that the election of Frank D. O'Connor as Governor would leave narcotics addicts "on the streets for purse snatching, mugging and murder."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 3 With the election of two more judges of the International Court of Justice, the General Assembly and the Security Council finished the task today of filling five vacancies on the bench.

WARSAW, Nov. 3 Twelve people gathered at the Israeli Embassy the other night. They were men and women of ordinary appearance and ordinary biographies except for one period of their lives.

The small trader loomed large in the first study ever made by the American Stock Exchange of investors who buy and sell securities there.

An employe of a Lower East Side junkyard was arrested yesterday on a charge that he had given a $200 bribe to the counsel of the City License Department to get information on accusations against his company.

The Home and Hospital of the Daughters of Jacob in the Bronx will receive the proceeds of a luncheon Nov. 15 in the Waldorf-Astoria's Empire Room. The event has been arranged by the Mother's Day Group as its 33d annual benefit.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. President Johnson's occasional illnesses always startle but seldom surprise the capital. The restless pace of his life and his unrelieved concentration on his work are such a source of wonder to his aides that they are constantly afraid he will go beyond the point of human endurance.

ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 3 (AP) Ghana and Communist China agreed today to release each other's diplomatic missions following suspension of diplomatic relations between the two countries. The diplomats are to return to their countries Saturday.

Reporting on operations of the National Dairy Products Corporation yesterday, Gordon Edwards, president, noted that sales and earnings were the highest in the company's history for the three months and nine months ended Sept. 30. Increased volume and greater efficency of its worldwide operating facilities helped earnings despite sharply rising raw material costs, the officer said.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 Defense Department planners are drafting blueprints for an intensification of the bombing of North Vietnam.
The New York City Opera gave Marguerite Willauer her first chance at the title role of the company's new "Tosca" last night at the New York State Theater.

FUKUYAMA, Japan Japan's leading steel maker, Nippon Kokan, has embarked on the second construction stage at its new integrated steel works here. The move is designed to increase capacity from 1.5 million tons to 4 million tons a year.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 3 New York City will help the United National Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization mark its 20th anniversary tomorrow.
Prices of industrial shares dropped to a low point of the year on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

Manufacturers of fashion merchandise have long neglected the women's rainwear industry because most are convinced that the occasions on which a welldressed woman goes out in the rain are too few to warrant presenting a full line. But things are changing.

The Curtis Publishing Company announced yesterday that, "because of the customary summer lull in the publishing business," it had a net loss in the three months ended Sept. 30 of $1,830,000. But the company said it expected to report a profit for the full year.
Spectacular raids and investigations conducted in recent weeks by Queens District Attorney Nat H. Hentel have tightened the election race for that office and created doubt as to its outcome.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 Walter W. Heller, former chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, called again today for an anti-inflationary tax increase. But he said he was less positive now that it was needed than he had been eight weeks ago.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Nov. 4 (Reuters)--Vietcong terrorists killed 13 South Vietnamese civilians and wounded seven in two attacks yesterday, according to official reports today.
HONG KONG, Nov. 3 (Reuters) North Vietnam and Cuba today condemned any attempt to bring the United Nations into the Vietnam problem and again denounced United States peace proposals.

The "C.B.S. Playhouse," a series of original television dramas, will make its debut in February, the Columbia Broadcasting System announced yesterday. The date has not been set, but the network is considering a Sunday evening.

Creditors looking for payment of close to $200,000 from the Congress of Racial Equality reserved comment yesterday on a proposal by the financially weakened civil rights group that they settle for 25 cents on the dollar.
HONG KONG, Nov. 3 (Reuters) It was just an old abandoned locomotive, lying rusting on a siding.

DENVER, Nov. 3 (AP) Archie Matsos, a linebacker for the Denver Broncos of the American Football League, was put on the reserve list today for walking off the practice field yesterday before drills had ended.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 In her first opportunity as a member of the United States Equestrian team, in the indoor circuit, Carol Hofmann raced Salem to his first international jumping victory at the opening of the six-day WashingtonInternational Horse Show tonight.

BONN, Nov. 3 Human error was probably the cause of the sinking of the West German training submarine Hai, a committee of specialists investigating the disaster reported today.

Prices for wheat futures rose sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday following reports that India was facing a critical food shortage for the second consecutive year and the sale of 3.7 million bushels of wheat to Morocco.

Len Hunt Chandler Jr., a folk singer, was found guilty of contempt of court yesterday by Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy for refusing to testify at a recent trial of three draft card burners.

The New York State Veterinary College at Cornell University announced plans yesterday for construction of a $550,000 laboratory to combat a disease threatening the state's horse population and tax revenues.
DETROIT, Nov. 3 (AP) A snowstorm whirled southeastward from Michigan and Ohio tonight with icy roads, power failures and drifts that contributed to at least 23 deaths in five states.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 3 North Vietnam has protested to the International Control Commission that United States warships shelled its coast on the morning of Oct. 25.

BONN, Nov. 3 Amid the storm of words unleashed by the collapse of West Germany's Government coalition and the efforts to find a new majority, one major political figure in Bonn has remained silent former Chancellor Konrad Adenauer.

CHATHAM, N.J., Nov. 3 Mr. and Mrs. H. John Rowland have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan M. Rowland, to John Howard Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Williams of Racine, Wis.

SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 3--United States and South Korean officials said today they saw no indication that North Korea was preparing for major hostilities along the demilitarized zone. North Korean forays in the last 18 days have resulted in the death of 25 South Korean soldiers and six American soldiers.
ROME, Nov. 3 (AP) The Vatican Secretariat for Christian Unity announced today that a joint Roman CatholicAnglican commission will hold its first ecumenical talks on Jan. 9 to 13.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 President Johnson announced today that he would undergo surgery later this month for repair of a ventral hernia a defect in the scar from his gall bladder operation a year ago.
LONDON, Nov. 3--The architectural plans for the Royal Shakespeare Company's new $3.6-million home were unveiled here today.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of Boyd P. Doty Jr. to the new post of sales vice president for the central area. The new district embraces Michigan, Indiana, Ohio and Kentucky.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 3 (AP) Harvard University announced today a $240 increase in tuition for several of its schools.
DETROIT, Nov. 3 Telephone appeals from union officials appeared today to have ended a two-day work stoppage over pay rise demands by the bulk of policemen in the Detroit suburb of Pontiac.

RICHMOND, Ind., Nov. 3 Mr. and Mrs. John P. Lontz have announced the engagement of Mrs. Lontz's daughter, Miss Suzanne Shiveley Bridge, to Frederic Barstow Moriarty, son of Mrs. John C. Hauck of Butte, Mont., and the late Frederic B. Moriarty.

A city official expressed concern yesterday over the possibility that the Federal Aviation Agency might shift international flights from Kennedy International Airport to some less congested airport away from the city.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 3 (UPI) A suit seeking $6-million in damages was filed today against the National Basketball Association charging the league had violated antitrust laws by refusing to sign Connie Hawkins.

THE limitation on duplication of the same programs by AM and FM stations in large cities, which becomes effective on Jan. 1, is leading to depressing results that are not consistent with the hopes of the Federal Communications Commission to diversify radio.
IN Paris plastic dresses are finished and very short hemlines are coming down, according to Anne Marie Gournay, a French ready-towear manufacturer.

The city's upstate reservoirs received an average of 1.21 inches of rain in the 24hour period up to 8 A.M. yesterday. This raised the supply to 284 billion gallons, or 59.6 per cent of capacity. The reading was 400 million gallons higher than 24 hours earlier.

Mayor Lindsay swore in Louis A. Cardona yesterday as Deputy Commissioner for Career Development and Ira Aldridge as Deputy Commissioner for Management and Finance in the new Human Resources Administration.

The operating companies in the Royal Dutch-Shell Group reported yesterday for the third quarter combined net earnings of $172,567,000, on sales and other income of $1,940,434,000. Prices on the American Stock Exchange moved in a narrow range yesterday, with declines outpacing advances by a small margin.

President Charles de Gaulle used to threaten to resign and let France go back to chaos if the voters did not support his policies at the polls. It was his most potent electoral argument.

CAIRO, Nov. 3 Syria and the United Arab Republic have agreed to exchange ambassadors and enter into a defense agreement, the Egyptian Foreign Minister, Mahmoud Riad, said tonight.

GUATEMALA, Nov. 3 The Guatemalan Government declared a state of siege today to cope with violence by extremists of both left and right. Radio and television broadcasts were interrupted to make the announcement this morning.
BOSTON, Nov. 3 (UPI) Harry Howell, a defenseman, scored two goals tonight to lead the Rangers into a threeway tie fox fourth place on a 7-1 rout of the Boston Bruins.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 3 Brad Hanover, a handsome yearling colt, brought $100,000, the year's top auction price and the third highest in harness racing history, as the 28th annual Harrisburg Standardbred Horse Sales ended today.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 3--India, where rioting has broken out in recent months over the Punjabi language, bar examinations and the slaughter of cows, is facing one of the most bizarre agitations of a violent year.

Prices have been increased $90 on three of the models in the 1967 Volvo line introduced yesterday by the company. A few weeks ago the French tested a train that ran on an air cushion instead of wheels. It reached about 170 miles an hour. The French are building a larger model to run 250 miles an hour.

THE strength of the German pictorial tradition, unlike that of its French counterpart, has always been essentially graphic. Though German art contains relatively little of what is regarded as pure painting, it abounds in virtuoso draftsmanship. The great German painters of the past had always been draftsmen first and painters second, and this tradition has continued into modern times, producing a rich legacy of graphic achievement.

Governor Rockefeller yesterday described Frank D. O'Connor, with heavy irony, as "the most misquoted and misunderstood candidate in history."

BRECKENRIDGE, Tex., Nov. 4 (AP)--A county grand jury refused to indict Mrs. Pearl Choate Birch today for kidnapping. The jury heard three hours of testimony.
Welfare clients on the Lower East Side began receiving chits for winter overcoats yesterday after demonstrating since Wednesday at four of the Welfare Department's centers.
CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (UPI) The backlash of a violent autumn storm stacked heavy snows in western New York today, and record cold brought winter miseries to the Deep South.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 Miss Susan Stone and Lieut. William Vail Woodward, U.S.A.F., plan to be married Nov. 19 in the chapel at Bolling Air Force Base here. Their engagement has been announced by Gen. William Sebastian Stone of the Air Force, Air Deputy to the Supreme Allied Commander at SHAPE headquarters in Paris, and Mrs. Stone.
ST. PAUL, Nov. 4 A pivotal figure in Minnesota's insurance scandal declined today to tell what he knew about a $2,000 political contribution that weighs heavily in next Tuesday's state elections.
Wheat and corn futures prices continued to rise yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, but other grains and soybeans dipped slightly or closed mixed.
CAIRO, Nov 4 Syria and the United Arab Republic signed today a mutual defense agreement establishing a joint command over their armed forces.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 4 The International Air Transport Association, representing 90 per cent of the world's air traffic, decided today to make a further effort to close the gaps in standardizing airline fares.

TRENTON, Nov. 4 (AP) Two officers of a camp for the blind have been ordered to appear before a hearing of the State Division on Civil Rights Nov. 22 to answer charges that the camp discriminated against a Negro.
STRING-QUARTET playing of a kind quite different from that usually encountered these days took place last night in Town Hall, where the Beaux-Arts Quartet played Ives, Beethoven and Debussy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 President Johnson cautioned North Vietnam today against interpreting next week's Congressional elections as a test of the Administration's policy on Vietnam, Mr. Johnson said at a news conference that he hoped the Communist side would be "very careful not to make any mistakes of judgment about this election."

Policemen will visit schools and pupils will visit the police in a new program designed to help the two groups understand each other.
OTTAWA, Nov. 4 (Canadian Press) The Dominion Bureau of Statistics today raised the estimated size of the 1966 wheat crop to 844,444,000 bushels, a 4-million-bushel increase from its Oct. 5 forecast.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 President Johnson defended the Warren Commission today, declaring that the evidence supports its conclusions about the assassination of President Kennedy.

BONN, Nov. 4 Britain's Foreign Secretary, George Brown, indicated today that London would no longer insist on revision of the Treaty of Rome, the charter of the European Economic Community, if it decided to reapply for admission to the Common Market.

James E. LoPiccolo, a judge of the Queens County branch of the Civil Court, died on Thursday of a heart ailment at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 23-15 29th Street, Long Island City, Queens.
Pippin and Young Sam were the star performers at Aqueduct yesterday. The winners of the first and second races, they made up the winning daily double combination that paid $1,091.60.

In the performance of "Faust" given by the Metropolitan Opera last night, there were two newcomers in the cast that has been performing the work this season. Nicolai Ghiaurov made his first appearance of the season as Mephistopheles, and Carlotta Ordassy sang the part of Marthe for the first time with the company. Miss Ordassy was replacing Shirley Love, who was indisposed.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell was sentenced to 30 days in jail and fined $500 yesterday for criminal contempt of court for breaking two pledges to appear in court on a $164,000 judgment he owes.

SARASOTA, Fla. A hurricane in June, followed by the 43-day airline strike, brought tremors and some discomfort, but little damage, to this Gulf Coast city. However, had Alma, the earliest hurricane ever to hit the state, lived up to her advance billing, her storm tides might well have ruined the beach resorts and the summer tourist season as well. Hence the tremors up and down the coast.

Many efforts have been made and will continue to be to help schizophrenic patients on a psychological basis. CHARLOTTE AMALIE, St. Thomas, V.I. Is history repeating itself in the Virgin Islands? A few centuries ago, the islands were inhabited by Arawak Indians, who spent most of their time swinging in hammocks and enjoying life. Holding sway today is a new tribe of swingers, known as tourists, who spend a lot of time in hammocks and a lot of money besides.

"LETTERS of Wallace Stevens" makes a rich and unforgettable mailbag. There are nearly a thousand here in his daughter's finelyedited selection. Three times the number were available to choose from (Stevens died in 1955 at 75); we are given enough but hardly too many. Few poets in their letters have talked so freely about their art and their intentions and scruples. Even fewer have talked so well. The result is a treasury.

LANCHASTER, Pa., Nov. 5 The engagement of Miss Abby Virginia L'Hommedieu, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Arnold L'Hommedieu, to Gilbert H. Dunham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Durham of Highland Park, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 5 (AP) Georgia's relentless defensive unit harassed Steve Spurrier all afternoon today as the Bulldogs handed the seventh-ranked Florida Gators their first loss of the season, 27-10.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 5 (UPI) Harold Deters field goal and three scores set up by the defense carried North Carolina State to a 24-21 triumph over Maryland today despite a three-touchdown rampage by the Terrapins' Alan Pastrana within two minutes during the fourth period.

DENTON, Tex., Nov. 5 (UPI) Corkey Boland, a secondstring quarterback, got off the bench when Vidal Carlin's tosses began to fall into enemy hands and fired the North Texas Eagles to a 35-13 Missouri Valley Conference victory over Cincinnati today

IN "Science and Survival," Barry Commoner has written a social tract dealing with the impact that science and technology exert on our daily lives. It is an enlightening and important work, so much so that its chances of reaching as wide an audience as it deserves are probably slim...
MONTREAL, Nov. 5--Canada took a step this week to attack pollution of water, soil and air for the first time on a national scale.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (UPI) The Westmount Golf Club of Kitchener-Waterloo, Ont., won the Canadian-American mixedbonspiel championship today for the second straight year. This was the first consecutive victory in the six-year history, of the event.

It appears that the building boom that has transformed the upper part of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) will be given further impetus by a partnership of the Rockefeller Center interests and Time, Inc.
St. Luke's Home of Morning- side House, 2914 Broadway at 114th Street, will hold its preChristmas bazaar on Wednesday.

IT is possible that the very power of John Steinbeck's "The Grapes of Wrath" has worked harm as well as good in the generation since it appeared. It was such an epic depiction of the migrant Okies' tragically squalid travail in California's lush farm belt during the Depression that there is a natural tendency to classify the subject as a period-piece.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Nov. 5 (UPI) The United States AllStars defeated Japan, 5-4, today on Jack Hiatt's 10th-inning homer in the opening of the TriNation tourney marking the 50th anniversary of the introduction of baseball to Brazil.
A second North Texas company has landed an aircraft contract with the Government.

YONKERS, Nov. 5 Miss Lorraine Mary Sachar was married this morning to Robert F. Travia, son of Anthony J. Travia, Speaker of the State Assembly, and Mrs. Travis. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Sachar.
Queens authorities said yesterday that for two years a state policeman had stolen heavy weapons for the rightwing Minutemen and had tipped them off on state and Federal investigations.

Traces of a prehistoric Indian village that may have existed 4,000 years ago were churned up by a developer's bulldozer one day last summer as a site was graded for a new home community on Northport Harbor in Suffolk County.

The two-day "sick", strike of policemen in the Detroit suburb of Pontiac last week affords urgent new evidence of the need for improved legal machinery to prevent work stoppages by public employee. The extent to which existing prohibitions against civil service strikes are breaking down already has been reflected in brief walkouts in various parts of the country by firemen and other groups whose uninterrupted presence on the job is indisputably imperative to community safety.
SYDNEY, Nov. 5 (UPI) Bob Stanton and Daryl Welch both shot two-over-par 74's today on the blustery Kensington course-to take the third-round lead of the Dunlop golf tournament with 221 totals.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 5 Mr. and Mrs. Louis David Mallet have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rita Naomi Mallet, to Peter Mitchell Rothman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lester D. Rothman of New York.

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, B.W.I. At midnight on Tuesday, Nov. 29, floodlights will go on at the Savanna, a large open area at the edge of this capital city. A display of fireworks will light the sky, and church bells will ring. The beat of drums and the sound of music will be heard, here and throughout the island.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 5 (UPI) A court reporter for The Springfield Union was found guilty yesterday on a contempt charge for allegedly having written an article a judge told her not to write.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 5 Secretary General Thant is expected by qualified sources in the Secretariat definitely to announce his retirement effective at the end of this General Assembly unless there is a clear move toward peace in Vietnam.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 5 (A.P) A three-judge Federal appellate court has ruled that a lower court was wrong in ruling that two Negro candidates for Greene County offices had been improperly nominated. It has ordered an indefinite delay in a portion of the gendral election in the county.
Conquering the Alps by pipeline has been one of the most difficult construction jobs even undertaken by the oil industry.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Nov. 5 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today that the American troop commitment in Vietnam would continue to grow, but at a substantially lower rate than in 1966.
STOCKHOLM, Nov. 5 The Swedish school crisis, in which teen-age students have had to take over as teachers, ended today.
Not surprisingly after its steep three-week run-up, the stock market has crawled back into a cocoon of caution. Is this a pause for refreshment or retrenchment?
BUFFALO, Nov. 5 The University of Buffalo Bulls scored a 36-6 victory over the University of Delaware football team before 5,434 spectators on snowswept Rotary Field.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Nov. 5 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Savage Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Doyle Savage, to Alexander D. van Eyck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bogdan D. van Eyck of Larchmont, N.Y.
Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan said yesterday that teachers should pay "minuscule attention" to miniskirts.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Nov. 5 This country's copper mines produced 43,000 tons last month, 78 per cent of normal output and a little more than they had expected would be possible.
BERLIN, Nov. 5 Of 68 million Protestants in the United States, about half can be classified as Evangelical in the sense of which the word was used by the World. Congress on Evangelism here.
THE PRESIDENT Good morning, ladies and gentlemen.

The American Bible Society has arranged a party for Nov. 15 at Philharmonic Hall, when the New York Philharmonic, conducted by Sir Malcolm Sargent, will perform Handel's "Messiah" with the Westminster Choir.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 5 Members of the Harvard football team showed the poise of champions yesterday when the Eastern Constellation plane bringing them from Cambridge, Mass., to Newark ran into trouble.

"Gee, but I'd give the world to see that old gang of mine," could have been the musical motif yesterday at Aqueduct, where an old-timers' day celebration served as a popular diversion for the 45,295 betting-minded customers.
FIERY RUN, Va., Nov. 5 Nobody can follow an American election for long without being both appalled by all the noise and nonsense and yet impressed that the system works as well as it does.
Jack B. Collins has been appointed associate director of the Center for Inter-American Relations here.

DALLAS, Nov. 5 (AP)--Black-haired Sandra Lee Roberts, 17 years old, who wants to be an electrical engineer, was crowned Miss Teen-age America of 1967 tonight. was crowned Miss Teen-age America, of 1967 tonight.
An industrial development concern has spent "in excess of $100,000" for a 92-foot steel sculpture to advertise its property.
About 10,000 antiwar demonstrators assailed the Johnson Administration, disrupted traffic from Greenwich Village to Times Square and bewildered pedestrians during a three-hour march yesterday.

TRENTON, Nov. 5 (AP) Room and building shortages at New Jersey public and private colleges have resulted in requests for $131-million worth of construction funds from the new State Educational Facilities Authority.

GATLINBURG, Tenn., Nov. 2--A device invented only five years ago to take advantage of superconductivity in metals at very low temperatures is to receive its first application on a multimillion-dollar scale.

The DuMont Apartment Hotel was on top of the world when it was completed in Morristown, N.J., 42 years ago. From there, it had no way to go but down. And that is the general direction it took, though not before it had enjoyed a period of eminence.

Three flat slabs of white concrete, starkly modern, stand out against the piney Connecticut woods to frame the new senior dormitory of the Ethel Walker School in the town of Simsbury, a few miles north of Hartford.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 Almost all the political experts in Maryland agree: if the election were two weeks off, Spiro T. Agnew, the Republican candidate, would be elected Governor.

CHERRY ALL, N.J., Nov. 5 (AP) The Bohemia Stable's Politely closed with a burst of speed in the stretch and beat the favorite, Native Street, by a neck at the fire to capture the $28,400 Princeton Handicap at Garden State Park today.
WHILE "Tchaikovksy" is still an unfinished symphony of SovietAmerican film rela- tions, a few more happy notes have been added to this prospective biography of the composer.

BARRANQUITAS, P.R. On a recent driveit-yourself automobile tour of the mountainous hinterlands of Puerto Rico, my wife and I stopped at a small resort hotel for the night. The next morning, I discovered that my electric razor could not be plugged into the lighting circuit, and so I summoned a chambermaid and asked for an adapter. Knowing only Spanish, she stared at me in wonderment.

FORTY-EIGHT superstars have been selected by Zander Hollander as the greatest American athletes of this century. He has also called upon an impressive list of fellow sportswriters to contribute chronicles of the athletes' careers and achievements. The selections, drawn from all major and a few minor sports, are remarkably sound and not...
NEWTON, Mass., Nov. 5 (AP) Brendan McCarthy ands Larry Marzetti, a sophomore, rallied a sputtering attack for two long touchdown strikes today as Boston College defeated William and Mary, 15-13.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) Pentagon officials are happi ly tallying up the first month's deposits made by servicemen overseas under a new savings program that pays 10 per cent interest.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 Evidence is accumulating that more money has started to flow back into homebuilding and home buying, signalling a time of easier credit for the housing field.

CEDARVILLE, N.J. Nov. 5 (AP)--A fiery cross blazed over the flatlands of southern New Jersey tonight. The cross, as feet high and drenched with kerosene was ignited by Frank W. Rotella Jr., former head of the New Jersey Ku Klux Klan. He now leads a group called The White Crusaders of The North.

Executives and buyers for the giant mass-housing and feeding industry, who will purchase equipment, food, beverages and supplies in excess of $3.6-billion this year, are getting ready for another big year.

Thomas G. Ayers, president of the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry, has warned that increasing pressures for industrial land in the coming years could threaten the city's potential in employment growth.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 5 Pushing over the game's only touchdown in the fourth period, Trenton State College completed its football season on a winning note by downing Montclair State last night, 7-0, before 4,300 fans at Sprague Field.

Take an eight-year-old company with a rather vague name. Lloyd (Sonny) Dove, an allAmerican selection last season as a junior, has been named captain of the 1966-67 St. John's University basketball team.

TO rank Presidents, living or dead, is tricky business. To cornpare Presidents, one still superactive and the other an overnight legend, is risky business. But now that Lyadon B. Johnson has passed the test of his first thousand days we may hazard some kind of comparison with his predecessor of the original thousand days.
The New York Stock Exchange will open for business as usual at 10 A.M. tomorrow, but it will leave the door to the trading floor at 11 Wall Street slightly ajar under a newly amended rule.
The Maritime Administration has awarded a $47,000 research contract to George G. Sharp, Inc., naval architects, to study "one-way containerization."

NORTH WOODSTOCK, Conn., Nov. 5 Roscoe E. McGowen, for 30 years a sportswriter for The New York Times, died of lung cancer today at the home of his granddaughter, Mrs. James Danielson. Mr. McGowen, who moved to North Woodstock shortly after his retirement from The Times in 1959, was 80 years old.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 5 Apparently beaten by the fabulous passing of Gary Marshall, Rutgers drove for two touchdowns at 6:47 and 10:14 of the fourth quarter today to score a 32-28 victory over Lafayette before 10,500 fans in Rutgers Stadium.
Intent on an afternoon of writing or research, a professor at City College is likely to find his desk occupied, his telephone in use, and his secretary too busy to talk to him.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Nov. 5 Stanley N. Kinney, director of the Colgate University placement service, has been elected president of the Eastern College Placement Association. He succeeds Dr. Alva Cooper, director of counseling and placement at Hunter College.

OUT in Kansas, the state school system has set up the equivalent of a circuit-riding com- poser. He spends a week or two in each of the school districts, so that students can get acquainted with a "live" composer. And in Eugene, Ore. (1960 pop.: 51,000), the citizens have voted to engage a composer solely to write music for its public schools.
A 35-foot memorial to Jews killed in the Nazi period will be constructed on a hill at the entrance of Jerusalem by B'nai B'rith.
TRENTON, Nov. 5 (AP) The State Board of Education appointed this week a 19-member committee to study possible regionalization and consolidation of New Jersey school districts.

The St. Louis Cardinals, leaders in the Eastern Conference of the National Football League, at a favored by two touchdowns in today's game against the wounded New York Giants at Yankee Stadium. The kickoff is at 1:30 P.M. and the usual capacity crowd of 63,000 is expected at the park where the Giants have won once in three tries this season.

EVERY year, according to the power mower industry, many millions of mowers are purchased as replacements. Conceivably, the number that will have to be discarded as inefficient next spring will be appreciably reduced if owners give their mowers better winterizing care this fall.
A Family Court judge has ruled that parents of an infant with suspicious injuries are presumed guilty of neglect or abuse and must prove otherwise, at the risk of losing custody of the child.
A mathematician has divined Broadway's future and has come up with pleasant predictions for those whose fortunes depend uuon the theater's health.

AMATEUR photographers in 17 states have contributed practically all of the 1,200 color photographs reproduced in "Wild Flowers of the United States: The Northeastern States" (New York: New York Botanical Garden and McGraw-Hill Book Company. 559 pp. in two parts. In slip case. $39.50).

FOR a people with a short history, Americans are curiously rich in legends; for a people with so re cent a history, many of the legends stay stubbornly unverifiable. And American historians even more than the historians of other countries are not only tellers of tales and hard diggers into the past, but still more the keepers of the legends.

The Police Department is investigating complaints growing out of a 16-year-old Brooklyn youth's campaign for retention of the Civilian, Complaint Review Board, Chief Inspector Sanford D. Garelik said last night.

THE preservation of our national landmarks, which once looked like an innocent enough objective, has now become a cause, and like certain other causes is trying the tempers of businessmen and enlisting the leisure hours of dedicated citizens from coast to coast. Perhaps the time has come to pay some attention to the men who started the argument, to the regional architectural historians whose seemingly antiquarian researches have ended in a crusade.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 5--Gov, James A. Rhodes and his fellow Republicans appear to be riding a wave that could produce major gains for the party in Ohio this year.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 5 The headquarters staffs of Republican Senator John G. Tower and his Democratic challenger, State Attorney General Waggoner Carr, were exuding confidence here today. But only a slight trickle.

Several hundred small Soviet-t. supplied power plants are helping to keep North Vietnam's factories humming despite the repeated bombing of key power stations, according to the Nov. 7 issue of Electrical World.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. Vacationists driving southward into Florida, and weary of the concrete-and-automobile scenery offered by superhighways, may find State Route 13 a welcome change without unduly delaying their progress.
Two new trustees of the Museum of Modern Art were announced yesterday by David Rockefeller, chairman of the board. They are Robert R. Barker of New Canaan, Corm., and Gifford Phillips of Los Angeles.
A synagogue founded by Polish immigrants at the turn of the century stands in peril of extinction on the edge of a Lower East Side housing project.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) The women have formed a "waiting wives" club while the men are away. They take turns babysitting for one another. Town and a hairdresser are nearby. Elementary school is just around the corner.
MADRID, Nov. 5 Six Opposition candidates will run for seats on the Madrid City Council in elections on Nov. 24, in the first direct test of policies aimed at liberalizing Spain's political life.

SADDLE RIVER, N.J., Nov. 5 The Old Stone Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss. Elisabeth Woodman Hull, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Prentiss Hull of Upper Saddle River and Millbury, Mass., to Russell Stuart Hume Jr. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Hume of Brooklyn and Sea Island, Ga. The Rev. Robert Minnik performed the Protestant ceremony.
ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 5 (Reuters) Communist China's eight diplomats here left for Paris and home today following the decision of Ghana and Peking to close their embassies in each other's capital.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) A study of graduates coming from the antipoverty agency's Job Corps indicates the youths are being placed in jobs paying a national average of $1.71 an hour.
LEHIGH, Pa., Nov. 5 Davidson College scored three touchdowns in the first half today and went on to defeat Lehigh University, 34-27, before 7,500 spectators.

NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 5 Rippowam extended its winning streak to 18 today with an 18-0 victory over Norwalk as John Baran tossed two touchdown passes to Tom McCrocklin. Intercepted passes set up the first two touchdowns for Rippowam which boosted its season's record to 8-0.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. What's new in Florida for the millions of visitors who are expected to arrive here during the coming months? For one thing, there are many more lodging accommodations than a year ago, and more are being built.
PARIS, Nov. 5 Premier Georges Pompidou is thinking of running for election to the National Assembly.
An award-winning painting by Winslow Homer has come home for exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, on loan from the Museum of Modern Art in Paris.

ANSHEL BRUSILOW had spent a year picking the 36 musicians he wanted from the 408 who had auditioned for the new Chamber Symphony of Philadelphia. Now, three weeks before their first concert in Kingston, Ont., it was time to see how they sounded together. The confident young conductor made a small welcome-aboard speech, smiled a large I-believe-in-you smile and gave the chosen ones the downbeat for the first movement of Mendelssohn's "Italian" Symphony.

FLAWS have been found on two of the recently issued British stamps commemorating the 900th anniversary of the Battle of Hastings, and a New Jersey collector has reported the discovery of eight Fiji stamps that apparently were never issued.
Dr. Frank L. Karp, a specialist in internal medicine and a police surgeon, died of a heart attack Friday in his home, at 921 Avenue P, Brooklyn. His age was 55.

BANGKOK, Thailand In recent years, this lovely, languorous capital has become a big, bustling city that is a market place for Asian businessmen and a stopping place for international travelers and vacationists. One example of the increased stature of Thailand and Bangkok in international affairs was the recent three-day visit by President Johnson, as part of his tour of the nations that participated in the Manila conference on Vietnam.

Sales of replacement tires will show a greater increase in 1967 than in any previous year, P.W. Perdriau, president of the B.F. Goodrich Tire Company predicted last week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. (AP) The Navy gave a glowing report today on a new com-. bat-support ship-the Sacramento, a kind of floating supermarket that has revolutionized supply operations in Vietnam waters.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 Dan Begel's 29-yard field goal in the last 21-seconds enabled Yale to beat Penn, 17 to 14, at Franklin Field today.

THE ancient art of telling stories to children has been well cultivated during the 20th century. In THE BLUE ROSE (Harcourt Brace World, $3.50) Eulalie Ross brings together an anthology of "13 romantic stories" for girls 10 and up. These are chiefly original fantasies, or reworkings of folk tales by distinguished modern writers.
A man was charged yesterday with stealing his own car. He took it from a pier where the police had towed it after finding it illegally parked.

The State Commissioner of Welfare yesterday directed the Ulster County Welfare Commissioner to submit a full report "without delay" on his decision to deny adoption of a blond blue-eyed child by the brunet, Italian-American couple who have taxed for her since she was five days old.

The prickly issue of the right of the Federal Maritime Commission to subpoena the records of foreign shipping lines has been placed before the Supreme Court, with a request that it review a decision by two lower courts.

KUSADASI, Turkey The Aegean coast of Turkey is one of the few remaining corners of Europe little known by tourists. Although the tract is contiguous to Pitcairn Park it is in the adjoining community of North Caldwell.

A GROUP of recent books and/or toys was submitted to the Woods Structural Soundness and Long-Term Amusement Testing Laboratory, an average group of consumer children, more or less. These book-toys are what is referred to in the trade as merchandise hybrid, gimmicky items with some toy, amusement or learning device attached. Generally, they make no pretension at being literature but are promoted right along with legitimate books and even compete with them.

Miss Christine Shier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Arthur Shier of white Plains, was married yesterday afternoon to William Leonard Shaw, son of Mrs. J. Gilmore Fletcher of Manchester, Vt. The Rev. Dr. Bryant M. Kirkland performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

SOME recent editions of traditional poetry, directed largely to young er audiences, outdo one another for sheer handsomeness. Sales of used machine tools in the third quarter, measured in dollar volume, were the highest ever recorded for any third quarter since 1953, the Machinery Dealers National Association reported over the weekend.
