THE advantages of color television were strikingly illustrated last night in the National Broadcasting Company's opulent production of "Alice Through the Looking Glass." The variety of eyecatching color made for a delightful musical spectacle that accented the spirit of the Lewis Carroll classic and helped compensate for the considerable weaknesses of the score.

MADRID, Nov. 6--The rebellion of the "new church" in Spain has reached a milestone with the delivery here of a resounding protest from the rebellious priests to the conservative Roman Catholic hierarchy.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 6 There was intense speculation here yesterday that the Government of Lieut. Gen. Juan Carlos Ongania will order either a massive devaluation of the Argentine peso or a "free peso" within 48 hours.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 6 Demand for steel showed some new firmness last week.
The following dispatch is by David Oancia of The Globe and Mail, Toronto. 1966 by The Globe and Mail.

A new 360-page book that leads prospective sponsors through each stage in the processing of loans for multifamily housing under Section 221 (d) (3) of the National Housing Act, has been announced by Urban America, Inc.

A one-hour television program about the theater of the deaf, designed to be intelligible to the deaf and those who can hear and speak, will be produced by the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Foundation and the National Broadcasting Company.

The Getty Oil Company reported yesterday for the nine months ended Sept. 30 that net income rose to $7,603,761, or 48 cents each on 15,984,228 shares. This is exclusive of the company's share of earnings retained by subsidiaries not consolidated that amount to $48,115,000, or $3.01 a share.
ROME, Nov. 6 The known deaths in Italy's floods rose to 123 today as new rains sent streams over their banks in the north.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6 Gov. Edmund G. Brown accused his Republican opponent, Ronald Reagan, today of deliberately exploiting "white backlash" sentiment.
United States Senator Clifford P. Case of New Jersey sharply criticized President Johnson and former Vice President Richard M. Nixon yesterday as mixing partisan politics into the war in Vietnam.
LONDON, Nov. 6 (AP) Henry Charles Dickens, who had been the last surviving grandson of Charles Dickens, died at his home last night. He was 88 years old.

VERBANK, N.Y., Nov. 6 Jazz Nonstop, a 2-year-old dog owned by Brackenbriar Kennels of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., won the English springer amateur allage stake of the 33d annual Connecticut spaniel field trial today at the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club.
WARSAW, Nov. 6 John F. Kennedy was the choice of a great majority of students at the Cracow Metallurgy and Mining Academy, an advanced technical college, when asked recently to name their "hero."

A MAN WITH A LOAD OF MISCHIEF" is a costume musical about a Lord who makes love to a Maid and a Servant who makes love to a Lady. It is based on a play by Ashley Dukes that lasted 16 performances here in 1925.

AN afternoon of uncommon musical satisfaction was provided at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon when the American Symphony Orchestra played a concert under the direction of Karl Bohm, the distinguished Austrian conductor of the Metropolitan Opera.

TORONTO, Nov. 6 Canada's sales finance companies continue to be plagued by problems of retrenchment brought about by tight money and by the confidence-shattering collapse of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation 17 months ago.
VIENNA, Nov. 6 At least 23 Austrians were killed over the weekend by torrential rainstorms, high winds and snow and mud and rock slides.

The so-called "white backlash" has taken many aberrational forms, but none quite so weird as the refusal of an upstate welfare commissioner to let a brunet couple adopt a blond four-year-old girl they have brought up almost from birth.
Firemen found two persons dead and one seriously injured last night when they responded to a call at 555 West 174th Street.

Marks Spencer, Ltd., of Britain, the world's largest apparel chain, which also exports to stores in other countries, is "disappointed" by its inability to penetrate the American market except with "pennypacket" amounts.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Nov. 6 President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic is reported to have persuaded President Sekou Toure of Guinea to come to Addis Ababa for the meeting of the Organization of African Unity.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 6 Wayne Zahn won the Professional Bowlers Association $65,000 national championship here tonight and set a record in yearly prize money on the tournament tour.
The Soviet Union's latest cultural ambassador, Yevgeny Yevtushenko, opened a six-week tour of the United States last night with a recital of his poetry at Queens College.
MOSCOW, Nov. 6 (Reuters)--President Johnson has told Soviet Chief of State...

LONDON, Nov. 6 In an attempt to force the international oil consortium in Iran to make a dramatic 17 per cent increase in production, the Government of Iran is threatening to deprive the Western companies making up the group of all or part of their exploration area.
The C.I.T. Financial Corporation over the weekend reported gains in earnings for both the third quarter and the first nine months of 1966.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 6 (Reuters) Prime Minister, Ian D. Smith was quoted today as having said that Rhodesia had made firm and definite proposals to Britain to settle the crisis between them and that the next move was up to Britain.

BOSTON, Nov. 6 (UPI) Dennis Hull had a hand in scoring three Chicago goals tonight as he led the Black Hawks to a 4-2 victory over the Boston Bruins. The triumph, combined with the Montreal Canadiens' loss to the Detroit Red Wings, put Chicago back in first place in the National Hockey League standings.

YONKERS, Nov. 6 Daniel Ellison, sales manager of the Seymour Mittelmark Organization, Inc., New York, publishers of trade periodicals in the women's fashion field, died of a heart attack yesterday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville. He was 50 years old and lived at 24 Cresthill Road.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 6 Claytan Gengras, the Republican candidate for Governor, charged today that "the entire machinery of state government was cranked up and directed at me because my candidacy threatens the continuation of the machine."

Kathy McIntyre of the Long Island Mercurettes posted a convincing victory yesterday in the first Senior Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union women's cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 6 (AP) The body of a 42-year-old woman, who had apparently been raped and beaten to death, was found today near Severance Hall at University Circle, a cultural center on the East Side.

A drive for reorganization of the Liberal party "immediately after the election" was urged yesterday by a founding member who was outraged by the selection of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. as the party's candidate for Governor.
Bud Wilkinson, whose Oklahoma team set a record for consecutive victories, wrote in his syndicated column after seeing his first Ivy League game, between Harvard and Dartmouth Oct. 29:

MOSCOW, Nov. 6 (UPI) The North Vietnamese capital of Hanoi was described today as "a fortress" bristling with antiaircraft missiles but afflicted by food shortages, rationing and a steady evacuation of residents. Hanoi Again Spurns U.S. Offers

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6 (AP) John Brodie ran for two touchdowns and passed for a third today in leading the San Francisco 49ers to a 21-13 victory over the Los Angeles Rams on muddy Kezar Stadium field.

When President Johnson was ticking off signs of "a very healthy movement toward price stability" at his news conference the other day, he didn't bother to note that his Administration has accommodated itself to a strategic retreat on the wage front in its flickering war against inflation. It has moved away from the magic number of 3.2 per cent for the last four...

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 6 (UPI) Bob Stanton, a 20-yearold Australian, cooled off a late charge by Arnold Palmer today to beat the American on the second hole of a sudden-death playoff and win the $8,000 Dunlop golf tournament.

Mayor Lindsay urged voters yesterday to approve Amendments 1 and 2 on the election ballot to "attract more industry here, help existing industry and vastly increase the number of factory and service jobs in the city."

GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 6 (UPI)?A 10-point fourth-quarter by the Minnesota Vikings upset the Green Bay Packers today, 20-17, and cut the Packers' National Football League Western Division lead to half a game.
LONDON, Nov. 6 Lord Fraser of Allander, a leading London merchant, died tonight of a heart attack at his home at Mugdock, near Glasgow. He was 63 years old.
The New York Giants were searching today for a quarterback, preferably a quarterback who, as Coach Allie Sherman says, "has heard the music before" in the National Football League.
MONTEVIDEO, Minn., Nov. 6 Running at full verbal speed, Vice President Humphrey streaked through farm country today to woo farmers and try to save a Democratic House seat.
The American Institute of Architects is seeking to have removed the Federal limitation of 6 per cent on architectural and engineering fees for Government construction projects.
George H. Boyce a former Municipal Court justice, died yesterday in his home, at 62 Greenway Terrace in Forest Hills, Queens. His age was 84.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 6 --Economic jitters, impassioned political controversies and a social awakening among the poor are the fitful highlights of the Chilean scene after two years under Latin America's first Christian Democratic government.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Nov 6 (AP) President Johnson paid today a surprise visit to two Medicare patients, both of whom said they had known the President all his life.

Maria Moors Cabot Prizes will be awarded at Columbia University on Wednesday morning to three men "for distinguished journalistic contributions to the advancement of international friendship and understanding in the Americas."
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 6 The policemen moved in quickly from different directions on the small cluster of adolescents gathered on Nassau Street under the light of a bowling alley sign.

ROSCOE, N.Y., Nov. 6 The Rev. Ida Lucy van Dyck, minister of the Roscoe Presbyterian Church, was married this afternoon in the church to John Hordines of New York, a widower. The Rev. S. Read Chatterton, minister of the Federated Church of Edgartown, Mass., performed the ceremony.

The intimation that the Federal Aviation Agency might move all international flights from Kennedy Airport to an unspecified location to the east may be more dramatic than definite, but it ought to rekindle action on a fourth jetport.

"India and the Future of Asia," by Patwant Singh, will come from Knopf next Monday. Mr. Singh contends that Chinese expansionism is a threat to the Soviet Union and the United States as well as to India and that India may serve to keep... the balance of power in Asia. He is critical of Indian nonalignment and of American policy toward India. Mr. Singh is the founder and editor of the Indian magazine Design.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 Alan Stephenson Boyd, named today by President Johnson to be the first Secretary of the new Department of Transportation, is known as one of the most outspoken public servants in the upper level of the Administration.
It seemed odd that Paul C. Harper Jr., president of Needham, Harper Steers, Inc., should travel from Chicago to have a press conference in Keen's English Chop House here.

The Torch of Hope award dinner Nov. 15 at the New York Hilton will honor William M. Fine, publisher of Harper's Bazaar. Proceeds will establish the Richard Deems Jr. research fellowship at the City of Hope in Duarte, Calif. The medical center treats and carries on research in diseases of the heart, chest and blood.
FREDERICKSBURG, Tex., Nov. 6 President Johnson today selected Alan S. Boyd, Under Secretary of Commerce, to head the new Cabinet-level Department of Transportation.

The entertainment industry has responded most generously to the United Service Organ izations' call for more shows for Vietnam. These shows, arranged by the Hollywood Overseas Com mittee, go to U.S.O. Centers all over the world.

GRAND MASTER Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia, Who won the recent European Zone I tournament at the Hague, the Netherlands, displayed his glittering best there, strategically and tactically, against Honfi of Hungary.
BRIGHTON, England, Nov. 6 (Reuters) A chugging 1902 Mercedes led 250 gasoline and steam-driven old-time automobiles over the finish line here today to win Britain's annual veteran car rally.

William Doppmann, who is pianist-in-residence at the University of Iowa, played a brilliant recital Saturday night at Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Mr. Doppmann's playing is unusual for its finesse and sense of understating.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 5 The Australian Government has halted further investment at least for the time being in the big, uncompleted Ord River irrigation and hydroelectric project.

FREDERICKSBURG, Tex., Nov. 6 The White House released today a report from the Council of Economic Advisers declaring that the long upward trend in interest rates was now "past history" and predicting further declines in food prices.
More than 100 winners of the Irish Feis, or cultural festival, held in June at Hunter College appeared last night in concert at Carnegie Recital Hall.

Gavin Jones of the New York Athletic Club, a 25-year-old Australian, captured first place yesterday in the Junior Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union four-mile cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

A rally Thursday at 11:45 A.M., in the Rockefeller Plaza Skating Rink, will open the United Hospital Fund's Hospital Week. The Coty cosmetics company is sponsoring the rally, which will be opened by Meredith C. Hough, president of Coty, with Mrs. Lewis Schachne, chairman of Hospital Week, and Mrs. James O. McClellan, vice chairman.
The election of Samuel H. Wolcott Jr. as a director of the Ruberoid Company was announced over the weekend by the asphalt and asbestos materials producer.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 Looking about as strong as a bad high school team when running plays from scrimmage, the Philadelphia Eagles upset the Dallas Cowboys, 24-23, today. The Eagles scored touchdowns on 93 and 90-yard kickoff returns by Timmy Brown and a 67-yard punt return by Aaron Martin. Sam Baker got the winning margin ...
ALL the favored teams survived the first round of the Greater New York Bridge Association's Double Knockout, but Waldemar von Zedtwitz, donor of the new trophy for the event, had a narrow escape.

RKO General, Inc., announced yesterday that it had established a subsidiary company named the RKO Pictures Company for entertainment projects. The president of the new company is Robert J. Leder, former executive vice president of RKO General Broadcasting, another subsidiary.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Nov. 6 Willard J. Graham, former president of the American Accounting Association, died at his home here yesterday. He was 69 years old.

THE decision of the Kennedy family to turn over to the National Archives, though for severely restricted use, the autopsy photographs and X-rays of President Kennedy's body brings up once again the question of the political effect of books.

An alert and well-informed taxi driver walked into a voting booth and took a test to see how long it would take him to vote on the candidates and issues tomorrow.

Richie Szaro, New York's leading football scorer, tallied 25 points as undefeated St. Francis Prep routed Chaminade, 37-8, yesterday at Boys High field in Brooklyn. The victory was the sixth for the highscoring Little Terriers.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 6 While the band of the 50th Armored Division blared a march, as it practiced in the basement of the National Guard Armory today, the top-winning dog in the United States shuffled across the drillshed floor and was pronounced best in show at the 28th annual fixture of the Union County Kennel Club. He was Ch. Fezziwig Raggedy Andy, an Old English...
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 6 (Reuters) A New South Wales farmer is trying to grow bigger and better bananas by "serenading" them.
DAR EL SALAAM, Tanzania, Nov. 6 (AP) United States money and technology will help build the world's first meat processing plant using gamma radiation as a preservative, it was announced today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 6 Crystal stemware, a cham pagne bucket and silver flatware were set out yesterday on a fringed green and white checked tablecloth on the tailgate of the Warren H. Millers' station wagon.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 6 The marriage of Miss Lynda Frances Siegel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton M. Siegel of Brewster, to Lieut. Joseph Charles Zengerle, U.S.A., took place this evening. He is the son of Mrs. Anthony Coletta of Pitman, N. J., and Joseph Zengerle of Washington.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 6 When Maj. Guy S. Meloy 3d of the United States Army walked into the jungle northwest of Saigon three days ago with two companies of 400 riflemen, "all hell broke loose."
TOKYO, Nov. 6 The Los Angeles Dodgers have been upstaging Lyndon Johnson in Japan for two weeks now.
Fire destroyed the interior of the abandoned Spring Street Presbyterian Church yesterday afternoon.

The Civilian Complaint Review Board on which New Yorkers will vote tomorrow is a pledge to all citizens that their voices will be heard, officially and responsibly. Such reassurance is as significant for white citizens as it is for minority groups.

Governor Rockefeller accused Frank D. O'Connor yesterday of neglecting his duties as City Council President because he was too busy running for Governor. Mr. O'Connor retorted that the Governor's statement showed "gall that Mr. Rockefeller had been running for President ever since he was first elected Governor in 1958.

BOSTON, Nov. 6 (AP) Max Choboian, a rookie quarterback, hit Al Denson on a 64-yard touchdown pass play with two seconds remaining today and gave the Denver Broncos a 17-10 victory over the Boston Patriots in a rain-swept American Football League game.
FREDERICKSBURG, Tex., Nov. 6 President Johnson said today that he hoped, subject to his doctors' approval, to undergo surgery much sooner than expected and that it would probably take place in Texas.

MOSCOW, Nov. 6 Communist China's representatives walked out of a Kremlin rally today as the Soviet leadership commemorated the 49th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution with a sweeping denunciation of Chinese policy.
Republican hopes of recoupsuffered in 1964 and thus laying the basis for a strong campaign in 1968 are riding to a large extent on state legislative races in tomorrow's election.

An interesting program of lesser-known songs by Brahms, Dvorak, Grieg, Mahler and Strauss was sung in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon by Helen Laird, a soprano who returned to this country last year after working for a decade in the smaller opera houses of Germany.
The first Music from Marlboro concert of the season took place last night at Town Hall before an audience bristling with musicians and their wives.

A concert of solid musical values was given at Carnegie Hall last night for the benefit of the Shaare Zedek Hospital in Jerusalem. In the first half, Joseph, Rosenstock conducted an excellent orchestra of freelance instrumentalists in a Beethoven overture, Haydn's Symphony No. 102 in B flat and Kodaly's "Marosszek Dances."

PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, Nov. 6 (AP) The United States took a 2-1 lead today over Brazil in the Davis Cup interzone semi-finals as Dennis Ralston and Arthur Ashe defeated Tomas Koch and Jose Edison Mandarino in the doubles match, 7-5, 6-4, 4-6, 6-2.

An Army sergeant and a friend who allegedly struck and robbed a 73-year-old Greenwich Village gasoline station attendant were held yesterday by Criminal Court Judge Joseph Martinis in $5,000 bail each for a hearing Nov. 15.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the defeat of the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board would be a step towards "totalitarianism" and "the destruction of basic principles of democratic government."
The Presbyterian Home for Aged Women, at 49 East 73d Street, will receive the proceeds of a theater party Thursday at the Morosco Theater, where "Don't Drink the Water" will be seen.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 6 William H. Boshart, former president of Owens-Illinois, Inc., major manufacturer of glass products, died last night. He was 95 years old.
Investment bankers will take a mid-autumn rest this week as the calendar of new securities issues is shortened by Election Day tomorrow and Veterans Day Friday.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 6 (UPI) Johnny Unitas passed for 344 yards and three touchdowns today to guide the Baltimore Colts to a 37-10 victory over the Washington Redskins.
The nonchalance with which the Soviet Union casts its veto to block even the mildest Security Council action remains one of the most depressing aspects of the United Nations.
DETROIT, Nov. 6 The stock market looks "just fine" to Robert E. Fletcher of the Detroit Super Dupers.

On an afternoon when their chief competitors, Cleveland and Dallas, were enduring defeat, the St. Louis Cardinals played poorly enough against the New York Giants yesterday at Yankee Stadium to lose, too. But the Giants did not play quite well enough to win and so the Cardinals triumphed, 20-17, enabling them to open their lead in the Eastern Conference of the National Football League to 1 games, with six to play.
Coverage of important election races in New York and throughout the country will be provided direct from the news room of The New York Times beginning election night at 8 P.M. by WQXR.
Arthur J. Goldberg upheld last night the right of dissent from the Government's foreign policy and said such dissent "can only benefit" that policy.
LISBON, Nov. 6 The Portuguese are concerned about the news from their West African possession, Angola, where nationalist guerrilla activity is spreading.

Secretary of Defense McNamara no doubt meant to be reassuring when he talked about the Vietnamese war at the Johnson ranch this weekend. Instead, he simply added to the confusion created by two weeks of Administration war-and-peace statements calculated to provide something for everybody just before the nation goes to the polls.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 6 (UPI) Ron Smith's 8-yard scoring pass in the fourth period to Gary Ballman and Mike Clark's third field goal, with 36 seconds left, enabled the Pittsburgh Steelers to upset the Cleveland Browns, 16-6, today in a National Football League game.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 6 (UPI) Len Dawson of the Kansas City Chiefs blended two touchtown passes with the power running of Curtis McClinton, a fullback, for a bruising 24-14 victory today over the San Diego Chargers. The triumph gave the Chiefs a commanding lead in the Western Division of the American Football League.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 6 (UPI) Clem Daniels ran for three touchdowns and Tom Flores passed for two today in leading the Oakland Raiders to a 38-23 victory over the Houston Oilers on a field soaked by rain.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 6 The Aluminum Company of America has purchased 75 abstract paintings and several sculptures, the last unsold portion of the collection of the late G. David Thompson, Pittsburgh industrialist and art collector.

Marion Harper Jr. is stepping out of his roles as president and chairman of Interpublic, Inc., but will remain president, chairman and chief executive officer of the parent company, the Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., which has 91 offices in 47 countries and 8,500 employes.

A spontaneity rare for folk singers, and several additions to their repertory, were the dominating impressions of the concert given by the Clancy Brothers and Tommy Makem Saturday night at Carnegie Hall.

FREDERICKSBURG, Tex., Nov. 6 The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, John Gardner, announced today is proposals for a major reorganization of his department, which has long suffered from giantism and bureaucratic sprawl.

THE witches' caldron that has been concocting all sorts of unpalatable potions for the New York Giants this season bubbled up more trouble yesterday. This one was harder to take than most of the others because it was jammed down unprepared throats without any warning.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 6 Egyptian bombers operating from Yemen bombed Najran, a Saudi oasis near the Yemeni border, on Oct. 14, killing 4 persons and wounding 10, according to reports reaching here today from Yemen.

Eighty-six young men and women were arrested early yesterday morning in a raid on a West Side party, held by the police for 15 hours on disorderly conduct and narcotics charges, and then released for lack of evidence.
The First National City Bank of New York, which has been taking a cautious view of business prospects for some time, published yesterday an analysis of the economy that had a distinctly bearish cast.

The Bankers Trust Company, which last Spring surprised the banking community by selling a $20-million convertible bond issue in Europe, announced yesterday that it had found a way to put about $5-million of these funds to work.
Richard M. Nixon charged yesterday that Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara had stooped to "political fakery" with his pre-election announcement of a slowdown in the flow of troops to Vietnam.

If the politicans had deliberately sought to mystify and intimidate New York's voters, they could scarcely have done more than will be accomplished in normal course by the ordeal of facing the voting machine tomorrow. Many entering the polling place and confronting the infinitely involved ballot can be forgiven if they experience a regressive yearning for the simplicities of a paper ballot and a stub pencil.
A truck carrying blankets and antibiotics was picked up by a helicopter at Kennedy Airport yesterday and airlifted to a Manhattan pier.
Two stores in the Bronx were targets of firebomb attacks last night, which set off small blazes that were doused before any damage occurred.
BASILE, La., Nov. 6 (AP) Half of this town's 2,000 citizens were evacuated today after a toxic liquid gas began leaking from derailed railroad tank cars.
ATLANTA, Nov. 6 (AP)--Jim Hylton of Inman, S.C., won the Atlanta Cracker 250-mile stock-car race today after having led most of the way.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 6 Karl August Berger, who retired a year ago after 40 years as a violin maker, died here yesterday. He was 72 years old.

In a brisk, biting wind that ruffled the robes of the clergy and set worshipers' teeth chattering, the Roman Catholic Chapel of Our Lady of the Skies was blessed and dedicated yesterday at Kennedy International Airport.
CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor said today "a tax increase is certainly going to get serious consideration" early next year.

AMARILLO, Tex., Nov. 6 (UPI) Kathy Whitworth sank a 20-foot birdie putt on the first hole of a playoff today to beat Mickey Wright and win first prize of $1,500 in the $10,000 Amarillo women's open golf tournament. Miss Wright had chipped in a shot on the 18th hole for an eagle 3 to send the tournament into the playoff.
MINNEAPOLIS, Kan., Nov. 6 (AP) E. Barry Faris, former editor in chief of the International News Service, died of a coronary attack today at Ottawa County Hospital. He was 78 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 A few days ago conservatives across the country received in the mail a letter signed by Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen soliciting funds for the Senatorial campaign of Robert P. Griffin, Republcan of Michigan.
Yevgeny Yevtushenko took over a Russian language and literature class at Queens College yesterday and chatted with students for an hour in Russian about his ideas on life and writing.
Mrs. Harriet Fox Whicher, associate professor of English at Mount Holyoke College from 1918 to 1944, died yesterday in her home, 63 East Ninth Street. She was 76 years old.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 Dr. Arthur Lindo Patterson, internationally known crystallog rapher, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage at Jeanes Hospital. He was 64 years old.
Several large orders for equipment and supplies helped the 51st annual National Hotel and Motel Exposition get off to a fast start yesterday at the New York Coliseum.
Two men and a woman were arrested yesterday after abandoning an auto in which they were allegedly carrying 225 pounds of marijuana and a bottle of liquid believed by the police to be LSD.

Part evangelist and part Yankee trader is the way many people described the tall, rangy Murray Danforth Lincoln. Born, reared and educated in Massachusetts, he was driven by a basically simple, but relatively new idea.
Higher prices for potash, farm equipment and high-speed steels were, announced yesterday by a number of companies in the United States and Canada.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 7 A small new party of businessmen and intellectuals called the Liberal Reform Group has injected an uncertain element into the elections for the new Australian Parliament.

In the trial of Jack L. Ruby for the murder of Lee Harvey Oswald, accused assassin of President Kennedy, Dr. Guttmacher was called as a principal witness for the defense. He testified that in his opinion Ruby was legally insane when he shot Oswald.

"THREE HAND REEL" is too gay a title for the trio of one-act plays about Irish life that opened last night off Broadway at the Renata Theater. Laughter is heard during the evening, but pathos is the predominant note. And it is struck so often that it finally becomes monotonous.
LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP) A Royal Commission recommended today that Britain's special government tribunals keep their "exceptional inquisitorial powers" but not act in secret.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 7 An Italian-American couple today challenged as arbitrary and capricious a ruling that they cannot adopt a blond 4 -yearold girl who has been in their care since she was 5 days old.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Tuesday, Nov. 8--The on-again, off-again trip by S kou Tour , President of Guinea, to the conference of African chiefs of state appears to have been canceled for good.

Brooks Hays, the nonpareil storyteller who used to represent Arkansas in Congress before the racists got rid of him, likes to recall the little old lady he once encountered near a polling place on Election Day.
ANDERSON, Ind., Nov. 7 Richard M. Nixon ended an intensive two-month campaign for Republican candidates today with a hoarse get-out-thevote plea at a lively rally here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) President Johnson has sent a letter to all members of Congress reporting on the Manila conference and stressing commitments by South Vietnam's rulers for elections, land reform, and steps toward peace and a working economy.

Steel production in the week ended Saturday declined for the fourth successive week, but the drop at 0.2 per cent was the smallest of the series, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The four-way campaign for Governor of New York State ended yesterday with Governor Rockefeller and Frank D. O'Connor running so close that few politicians would predict the outcome of today's voting with any confidence.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 7 Vice President Humphrey, who has a personal stake in tomorrow's Minnesota election, stood in the aisle of a DC-3 airplane today and expressed disappointment.
Activity on the London Stock Exchange was slow yesterday, with prices generally declining in light trading.

Mayor Lindsay's staff proposed today that the women's and children's apparel industry use portions of several of the city's industrial parks. The proposal was made at the first fullscale liaison meeting between the industry and the city administration.

The American Express Company, after two and a half years of the toughest kind of bargaining, is apparently convinced that it is very close to wrapping up a proposed settlement with creditors of its warehousing subsidiary.

YALE UNIVERSITY deserves three cheers for helping produce a campus documentary without a single cheer or cheerleader. An unhappy tradition seems to make it virtually impossible for a camera to view higher education without depicting the collegiate life as a succession of beer and circuses.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission proposed tonight a trade regulation designed to prevent unlawful discriminatory advertising or promotional allowances, services or facilities in the men's and boys' wholesale tailored-clothing industry.

Today is Election Day. Following is a list of voting hours and of facilities and services that are or are not affected by the holiday:
Directors of the Ruberoid Company proposed yesterday a two-for-one stock split to be distributed Dec. 29 to stockholders of record Dec. 23.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7--A last-minute poll indicates that Lieut. Gov. Raymond P. Shafer, a Republican, may hold a substantial lead over his Democratic opponent for Governor, Milton J. Shapp.

The chairman of City College's W.E.B. DuBois Club, one of 87 youths arrested early Sunday morning at a fund-raising party for the leftist group, charged yesterday that the arrested youths had been "brutalized" and "subject to abuse" by the police.

After three weeks of unexpected idleness Jim Ryun, the 19-year-old possessor of the world records for the mile and half-mile run, hopes to start working out again today in the University of Kansas swimming pool.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 8 A battalion of about 500 United States infantrymen was reported engaged in renewed fighting this morning in the jungle northwest of Saigon.

The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday a year-end dividend of $1.50 a share, off sharply from last year's rate of $2.25 a share but still a little higher than most observers on Wall Street had expected.

Northwest Airlines has asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to approve fare reductions in the Pacific that would cut $57 off the round-trip economy fare from the United States to Tokyo for all but the four peak summer months.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) Western Union asked the Federal Communications Commission today for permission to build an earth satellite system to carry its telegrams from coast to coast.
Fischbach Moore, Inc., electrical contractors, announced here yesterday the election of Allen D. Fischbach as vice chairman, chief executive officer and chairman of the executive committee.
For those who consider Davis Cup elimination an affront to the national pride, yesterday's defeat by Brazil was another slap in the face for American tennis.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Nov. 7 A January wedding is planned by Dr. Jacqueline Gail Parthemore and Dr. Alan M. Blank. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. P. Mark Parthemore, parents of the...
The Bank of New York and the Empire Trust Company cleared one of the last hurdles yesterday in the path of their proposed merger.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 7 After last February's Honolulu conferences between President Johnson and Premier Nguyen Cao Ky, the nonmilitary aspects of the war in Vietnam became increasingly prominent.

KARLSRUHE, Germany, Nov. 7 (Reuters)--A young American told a West German Supreme Court today of a murder plot by which he and two others hoped to stop trials of Nazi war criminals and restore Nazi rule in Germany.

CAIRO, Nov. 7 The premiers of Syria and the United Arab Republic agreed today to take preliminary steps toward possible reunification of their countries to "defeat the offensive being launched by reaction in cooperation with imperialism and Zionism."
A Federal judge said yesterday it would be "anarchy" if every draft evader demanded and received a jury trial in an attempt to avoid service in the armed forces.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 7 President Juan Carlos Ongania announced tonight a sweeping series of economic reforms, including an end of official exchange rates for Argentina's currency in effect, a devaluation of the peso.
The bitter referendum campaign on the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board ended last night on the same note on which it began anger and disagreement.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 Two green performers won the President of the United States Cup at the Washington International horse show tonight.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 7 President Johnson will probably undergo surgery next Friday in the Brooke Army Medical Center here.

An amended rule that permits members of the New York Stock Exchange to deal directly with firms of the "third market" in Big Board-listed stocks got off to a slow start in its first session yesterday. The third market consists of overthe-counter trading in exchange listed stocks.
The Police Department will require department store patrolmen to take suspected shoplifters to station houses for booking to reduce the time spent by city police in handling such cases.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7 (AP) Pounding rains flooded southern California today, blocking two main highways in and out of Los Angeles, sending families to evacuation centers and spawning a minor tornado while up to a foot of snow fell in the mountains.

BONN, Nov. 7 Despite renewed demands for a prompt solution of West Germany's governmental crisis, the surprisingly heavy vote yesterday for the rightist National Democratic party is expected to delay the formation of a new coalition.

A post-election investigation of privately owned hospitals was pledged yesterday by State Senator Seymour R. Thaler, ranking Democrat on a legislative committee that has investigated the municipal hospital system.
The election of David M. Corcoran as vice president and a director was announced here yesterday by Sterling Drug, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) The Supreme Court affirmed today a decision that the Jos Schlitz Brewing Company violated the Clayton Antitrust Act by acquiring control of two other brewing companies.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 7 (UPI) Dr. Paul L. Adams, Conservative party candidate for Governor, said today that he could win tomorrow's election "if the 2,200,000 New Yorkers who supported Barry Goldwater in 1964" voted for him.

CHEVY CHASE, Md., Nov. 7 Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Fischer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beth-Ann Fischer, to Carmen L. Gentile. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Gentile of Boston.
Frank D. O'Connor flew across the state yesterday in a hastily planned tour, warning upstaters and downstaters that Governor Rockefeller was planning to raise their taxes.
September contracts for future construction in New York
The El Paso Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for three and nine months ended Sept. 30.

THE explosive growth of the airline industry and the mounting congestion at airports were covered last night in a documentary called "The Aviation Revolution." It was a visual feature story of interest to every air traveler, and also a vivid reminder that greater speed in the sky may be thwarted by increased delays on the ground.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 7 A 25story office building hard by Brussels' most fashionable shops and bars has become the most likely new headquarters of the Atlantic Alliance.
The city is investigating alleged payoffs to supervisory personnel for employe transfers in the Sanitation Department.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 John W. Gardner said here today that the proposed reorganization of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare had been under discussion for months.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) --The Supreme Court let stand today an award of $265,000 plus interest against the Kemper Insurance Companies in favor of the American Broadcasting Company in a dispute over sponsorship of a network news program.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) A commission of the Methodist Church voted 22-2 today to recommend that the church eliminate its separate Negro Jurisdiction within the church "and get it done by 1972."
A. Edward Archibald was elected yesterday to the presidency of the Investors Syndicate Life Insurance and Annuity Company, a subsidiary of Investors Diversified Services, Inc.

DETROIT, Nov. 7 (UPI) The Internal Revenue Service settled its $106,226 income tax claim against James R. Hoffa today for $24,371 because of recent Supreme Court decisions making attorney's fees for criminal proceedings tax deductible.
RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 7 King Faisal of Saudi Arabia believes Britain must make greater efforts to get a strong and stable government in the Federation of South Arabia.
SELMA, Ala., Nov. 7 (AP) Stokely Carmichael, head of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, was released on bond today after being charged with inciting a riot Saturday.
At 9:05 A.M. yesterday, Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, strode into the executive suite on the 10th floor of the American Stock Exchange.

JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Nov. 7 (AP) President Johnson, trying to clean up legislation passed by Congress, has signed bills dealing with job retraining, governmental financing and waterway control projects, the White House announced today.
The latest effort on the part of advertising to tell the public how the industry aids the economy is an ad prepared by the Campbell-Ewald Company in Chicago.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 7 The two sides in one of the nation's most important House races accused each other today of inflaming racial tensions as the race moved toward a tight finish in tomorrow's election.
PARIS, Nov. 7 Robert Edouard Gauthier, one of the founders of the authoritative Paris afternoon paper Le Monde, died here last night. He was 64 years old.

GENEVA, Ill., Nov. 7 Mr. and Mrs. S. James Stanfield, formerly of Madison, Conn., and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Chapin Stanfield, to Marshall Haywood 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Haywood Jr. of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara has just received a new Air Force proposal for a strategic bomber that would boast approximately five times the nuclear punch and twice the range of the most advanced bomber now being developed, the FB-111.
Although bond prices did no change much yesterday, because the day was isolated between the weekend and Election Day the buildup in new issues of corporate securities was pronounced.
Mrs. Alan G. Trebach of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elaine Trebach, to Lionel Marshall Nelson, son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Nelson of Flushing, Queens.

HARTFORD, Nov. 7 Clayton Gengras, the Republican candidate for Governor, filed a complaint today with the Fair Campaign Practices Committee and announced that he was suing "the whole Democratic machine" for libel.

LONDON, Nov. 7 An American missionary in Rhodesia is to stand trial there in two weeks for having described in a church sermon an alleged instance of police brutality against a black member of his congregation.

THE casualty rate among pro football quarterbacks continues to grow. Charlie Johnson, the quarterback of the St. Louis Cardinals, will undergo surgery today for torn ligaments in his right knee, an injury sustained Sunday at Yankee Stadium.
FAREED NaJeeb Kiamie, a businessman and investor who has been irked by repeated reports that the "high-fliers" took a drubbing in the bear market, has consulted his computer for the facts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 Officials of the Democratic National Committee confirmed today that the committee had refused to distribute a resolution by the College Young Democrats of America that is critical of Government policy on Vietnam.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., Nov. 7 Mr. and Mrs. George Sekeres have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Ann Sekeres, to Pfc. Paul M. Weller, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Solwin Weller of North Evans.

IS an opera house truly an opera house if the trumpets of the Triumphal Scene in "Aida" have never blasted forth from its stage? Last night they did for the first time in the new Metropolitan, and the house seemed to come into its own.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 7--Student demonstrators threw themselves beneath a car carrying Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara today and forced him out for a shouting "debate."
The Guggenheim Museum has begun construction of a twostory office annex, instead of a four-story structure as originally planned, and now most of its neighbors seem happy.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 102.4 on Friday from 102.5 on Thursday.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 7 (AP) United Utilities, Inc. reported today third-quarter earnings of 28 cents a share, 12 per cent above those of the 1965 period.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 7 (AP) Jackie Mason, comedian, says someone fired three shots into his hotel room here last night.
Dow Jones Co., Inc., and Richard D. Irwin, Inc. announced jointly yesterday that their merger proposal had been dropped. Discussion had been under way for the last month.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 The Supreme Court upset today the tax fraud conviction of Fred B. Black Jr., a business associate of Robert G. Baker, because Federal agents had eavesdropped on conversations between the defendant and his lawyer.
The Inter-American Development Bank announced yesterday it had approved two loans equivalent to $19.2-million to help finance an urban development program in Buenos Aires.

An alleged international plot said to have been organized here to affect the world price of copper by destroying a vital bridge in the African country of Zambia, may be related to the arrest of four persons in Israel.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 7 A mammoth demonstration in front of Parliament against the slaughter of cows turned into a riot today in which at least four persons were killed and 22 seriously injured.

Irish International Airlines has announced in Dublin the appointment of Brendan W. O'Kelly as vice president sales in North and South America and Australasia. He was formerly sales manager of that division.

The writers who rank the country's college football teams for the Associated Press and the coaches who rank them for United Press International agreed on the first nine teams this week, which was surprising in view of the fact that the upsets of Florida and University of California, Los Angeles, last Saturday brought about major revisions in both polls.
YOU could have heard a lemon peel drop at Columbia University the other night when 45 undergraduates attended a two-hour lecture in bartending.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 The Voice of America started using a faster and brighter broadcasting technique today in a move to persuade millions of overseas listeners that the United States is a dynamic "up-tempo" nation.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7 (AP) Negotiations were at a standstill and approximately 11,000 West Coast shipyard workers were still off the job today as picketing electrical workers kept 13 yards shut down.
PANTS, at least the daytime variety, received short shrift as New York spring fashion shows entered their second week yesterday.

PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 7 (UPI) United States space Scientists said the Lunar Orbiter 2 spacecraft was "behaving properly" on its journey to the moon today and they predicted a "more successful mission" than the Orbiter 1 to find a safe landing site for astronauts.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 7 Alan S. Boyd, appointed yesterday by President Johnson to head the new Cabinet-level Department of Transportation, tonight urged caution in solving the nation's transportation problems and warned of seemingly simple solutions.

Queens District Attorney Nat H. Hentel said yesterday that seized records in the possession of his office linked 19 Minute men arrested here on Oct. 30 to Robert De Pugh, national leader of the extreme rightist group.

Republican control of several additional states and a smaller Democratic majority in the House of Representatives are the most likely results of the midterm elections that will be held in every state today.

"Friends and Nabors," a special show that starred Jim Nabors, was No. 1 in the national Nielsen television ratings released yesterday. The Columbia Broadcasting System program beat out N.B.C.'s usual frontrunner "Bonanza," which came in second. The survey covered the two-week period ending Oct. 23.

Grants totalling $3,000 will be given the winners in the forthcoming 1966 National Student Film Awards contest, it was announced here yesterday by John Brockman, coordinator of the event for Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. The contest is sponsored by Lincoln Center, the Motion Picture Association of America and the United States National Student Association.
A small but growing segment of the American electorate is being drawn directly into the computer age by new voting methods.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 7 Joseph J. Aylward, manager of the product-control laboratories of the Canada Dry Corporation here, died today of a heart attack while at work. He was 49 years old and lived at Jeanne Court, Stamford.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 7 (UPI) The Cuyahoga County coroner said today that the weapon with which Marilyn Sheppard was fatally bludgeoned in 1954 may not have been a surgical instrument.
Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., extended yesterday its tender offer for shares of its own common stock to Nov. 18.
Seymour H. Knox 3d was elected yesterday to the board of the Crescent Niagara Corporation, a Buffalo producer of hand tools.

LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP) Organizers of a Vietnam charity concert bowed to protests from show business figures last night and agreed that the money they raised would pay for medical aid to both sides in the war, not just the Vietcong.

PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, Nov. 7 (AP) Josh Edison Mandarino upset Dennis Ralston in a five-set struggle to give Brazil a 3-2 victory over the United States in the Davis Cup interzone tennis semi-final today. The scores were 4-6, 6-4, 4-6, 6-4, 6-1.
Stock prices traced an irregular course yesterday as the market marked time before Election Day.

LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP) Rare Communist documents were knocked down today to the highest bidders at A. Southby's action on New Bond Street. The auction coincided with the 49th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution.
ALBANY, Nov. 7 Educational centers for adults will be established on most major State University campuses under a plan approved here today by Governor Rockefeller.

New York premieres of compositions by Estela Bringuer, Eda Rapoport, Eugene Seaman and Timothy Thompson and a performance of George Kleinsinger's Quintet for Clarinet and Strings filled a chambermusic program given at Town Hall last night. Among the 16 performers of the evening were Mr. Seaman and Mr. Thompson, pianists; Yvette Bader, violinist; James Douglas, clarinetist, and the members of the Kohon String Quartet.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7 (AP) Jess Nicks, the president of General Brewing Corporation, said today that the United States Supreme Court decision against the Schlitz Brewing Company "represents a victory for the management of General Brewing."
The Kraken, Howard Polinger's seasoned turf campaigner, registered a convincing victory on the grass at Aqueduct yesterday.
For traders in world sugar futures, yesterday was a day to remember. The spot price moved to its lowest level in 25 years 1.45 cents a pound.

Supreme Court Justice Edward T. McCaffery yesterday dismissed an indictment charging attempted murder because an 18-year-old Bronx youth was not advised he was entitled to a lawyer before he confessed.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 7 (UPI)--The Texas White House announced today that the General Services Administration would defer the purchase of at least 1,000 automobiles for Federal agencies to help fight inflation.
Three youths were arrested yesterday in the fatal stabbing of a 16-year-old boy Sunday night during a clash between two gangs in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

Bruno Sammartino retained his Madison Square Garden wrestling championship by defeating Bulldog Brower last night before a crowd of 14,159. Sammartino, from Abruzzi, Italy, used a back-breaker hold to defeat his opponent from Toronto at the 11:58 mark.
DETROIT, Nov. 7 (AP) Auto makers scheduled a fourth successive week of 200,000-plus auto production this week as they reported demand for 1967 cars still running strong.

The Music Theater of Lincoln Center, of which Richard Rodgers is president and producer, may alter its summer policy of doing two revivals of six weeks each at the New York State Theater in favor of having one revival run 12 weeks, to avoid a deficit operation. Tours after the center performances would be eliminated because of the expense involved.
A SHORT epigraph to F.M. Esfandiary's third novel reads, "For those who don't know the Middle East, it may be well to mention that this is not a work of satire."
When a sleek "floating hotel" nestled into Pier 97 yesterday morning, agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation closed in for a close appraisal of the faces of the 770 passengers who got off.
Tom Kennedy, a 25-year-old unmarried school teacher and quarterback, was asleep in his room at the Hotel Shelton here yesterday morning when the phone rang at 11 o'clock.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 7 (AP) Hungary took a commanding lead over the Soviet Union, with the United States in third place today after two events in the world modern pentathlon championships.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Nov. 7 Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Schenkel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Schenkel, to Harvey B. Savitzky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Savitzky of Brooklyn, New York.

THE most precious commodity in football is the quarterback and quarterbacks are in such demand that emergency calls for help often go unanswered. In the wake of Earl Morrall's slight wrist fracture the ill-starred Giants now suffer in juries in the equivalent of touch football the New Yorkers inquired around their league yesterday for a back-up passer to caddie for Gary Wood, the only healthy quarterback they have left on the premises.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 Nine residents of the District of Columbia filed a suit here today demanding that the Federal courts do what Congress has refused to do grant the district the right to elect its own local government.
Trans World Airlines has announced that it plans to build fully automated air-cargo terminals between 1968 and 1970 at major United States and European airports.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 7 Dr. Robert A. Alberty, dean of the graduate school of the University of Wisconsin, will become dean of the school of science at Massachusetts Institute of Technology Feb. 1. He will succeed Dr. Jerome B. Wiesner, who has been acting dean since July 1.
In the state of Mysore in the south of India, Hindu children recite this nursery rhyme about the cow:
Narcotics detectives raided a 12-room penthouse atop a midtown commercial building last night, arrested the tenants and confiscated marijuana, hashish, heroin, LSD and a coffin.
The fund for dependents of 12 firemen killed in a fivealarm fire three weeks ago last night has reached $338,009, with donations still arriving at the rate of 200 letters a day.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7 Gov. Edmund G. Brown appealed today for a big turnout in tomorrow's election to sustain his reputation as a fast finisher.

FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 7 Lieut. Gen. William F. Train, commanding general of the First Army, approved today the courts-martial conviction of three privates at Fort Dix in September for refusing to go to Vietnam.
MIAMI, Nov. 7 (AP) A lateseason storm called Lois developed winds of hurricane intensity today and threatened shipping in the Atlantic.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 7 Foreign Minister Adam Malik said here today that the Soviet Union would not attend a meeting of Indonesia's creditors scheduled for Paris next month.

A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that agreements and court decrees of separation entered into before the passage in April of the state's new divorce law can be converted into divorces, beginning Sept. 1, 1968.
Most issues on the American Stock Exchange just managed to end in the plus column yesterday as late profit taking reduced some of the earlier advances.
A recommendation that the United States break down the barriers that isolate Communist China is contained in a book that McGraw-Hill will publish for the Council on Foreign Relations next Monday.
TEDDY TINLING, who designed former tennis star Gertrude (Gussie) Moran's famous lace panties, believes the "sugar plum fairy look" is now as obsolete on the tennis court as a wire-strung racket.
A decline in the French franc was reported yesterday in foreign exchange dealings in Paris, London and New York.
LATIN QUARTER, 200 West 48th Street. Julie Gibson, dancer.
MOSCOW, Nov. 7 The Soviet Union celebrated today the 49th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution, with Communist China's representatives repeating yesterday's walkout from the festivities.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 7 Arthur J. Goldberg, United States delegate to the United Nations, reported to President Johnson today that he had detected "very faint, very indirect" signals from countries that "used to be as rigid in their posture as Hanoi" but now seemed interested in joining the search for a peaceful settlement of the conflict in Vietnam.
NEWARK, Nov. 7 (AP) A fire that broke out in the kitchen of a 2 -story frame home took the lives of four children today. The two youngest died in their cribs.
FILLMORE, Utah, Nov. 7 (AP) Two men died while working in a shaft sunk in search of what they believed might be ancient hidden records.

The Most Rev. Fulton J. Sheen will recommend to the nation's Roman Catholic bishops at their annual conference in Washington next week that the church in America spend "no less than 5 per cent" of its revenues on aid to the world's poor.
THE annual Pro-Am tournament of the Hampshire Country Club, Mamaroneck, was played Sunday night, and 28 New York experts were teamed with club members.

Representatives of the Philadelphia Orchestra musicians met yesterday afternoon with a three-man Board of Public Accountability appointed by Mayor James H.J. Tate of Philadephia to help settle the musicians' seven-week old strike against the orchestra.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 7 Finland's Social Democratic party, which heads the four-party Government, has been accused by one of its coalition partners of not having done enough to win lasting Soviet acceptance.
AUCKLAND, N.Z., Nov. 7 The war in Vietnam has become a major issue in the general election campaign in New Zealand.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 The United States Treasury's shortterm borrowing costs rose sharply today.

MONTREAL, Nov. 7 (Canadian Press) Air Canada announced tonight that it was taking the necessary steps to suspend its flying operations if airline mechanics and ground handlers carry out a threatened strike next Monday.

THEY DON'T have turnstiles at Madison Square Garden, just ticket-takers, so it can't be said that turnstiles will be clicking merrily again tonight when the second National Basketball Association double-header of the season takes place.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 7 Miss Roanne Bockar and Paul Katcher plan to marry Dec. 11. Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Bockar have announced their daughter's engagement and forthcoming marriage to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Moses Katcher of New York.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 7 Starlight Way, who had not won a stakes race since last July 1, captured the $30,060 Lady Suffolk Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The winner is trained by Forrest Gerry Jr., who has not had a stakes victor since 1964.
The Independent Citizens Committee Against Civilian Review Boards and by implication its advertising agency was strongly criticized yesterday by some other agencies and ad people.

Criminal Court Judge Benjamin H. Schor was relieved yesterday of all assignments, pending completion of a judicial investigation into his alleged role in the attempted $5,000 shakedown of applicants for a Queens liquor license.
Jose Rambaldi, a pianist born in Argentina, who now teaches at Whitman College in Walla Walla, Wash., made his local debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
The campaign to save the old Metropolitan Opera House suffered another major setback yesterday.

A referee's report recommending the settlement of a minority stockholder suit that followed the removal of James T. Aubrey Jr. as a vice president of Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., was confirmed yesterday in New York State Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) The Commerce Department lifted today the export controls it imposed last March on cattle hides, calf and kip skins and bovine leathers.

NASSAU, N.Y., Nov. 7 (UPI) The pilot of a small plane that crashed yesterday near East Nassau died today in Albany Medical Center Hospital. His two passengers were killed when the plane hit the side of a hill.

Hart Schaffner Marx, a men's clothing manufacturer and retailer based in Chicago, reached an agreement in principle yesterday on plans to acquire Jaymar-Ruby, Inc., of Michigan City, Ind., a manufacturer of slacks, on a pooling-ofinterests basis. The transaction involves $12,251,000 in stock.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 7 (UPI) Murray D. Lincoln, a founder and retired president of the Nationwide Insurance Companies of Columbus, died at Grant Hospital this evening at the age of 74.

The sixth annual Evening in Vegas benefit for the women's division of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City is planned for Nov. 18 in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton. Proceeds will aid the group's rehabilitation, educational and research programs.
The United Aircraft Corporation reported yesterday a decline in earnings for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30.

ROCK HALL, Md., Nov. 7 If one studies the habits of ducks and geese to any extent, all sorts of interesting questions arise. Last year this writer asked why the waterfowl flew in a V formation. He was informed that each bird utilized the air turbulence created by the one in front to conserve flying energy.
THE elegant donas of South America used to be the principal clientele of the Paris couturiers, but lately some of them have been staying home to do their shopping.

Harold B. Seligman, a vice president and a director of the Witco Chemical Company, 277 Park Avenue, manufacturers of soaps and detergents, died on Sunday at Memorial Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 8 East 83d Street.
LONDON, Nov. 7 Of all the many pleasures of London the most gratifying for the American traveler in Europe is the opportunity to talk again.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 7 --Jonel Jorgulesco, an artist, a stage designer and an architect, died today at St. Thomas, V. I., where he had lived for the last six years. He was 62 years old and was a former resident of Tarrytown.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 7 (AP) Three young gunmen robbed tonight the home of Henry Kramer, president of the Southern division of the Food Fair grocery chain, and took cash and jewels reported to amount to more than $100,000.

TRENTON, Nov. 7 Democratic party leaders here insisted today that their candidate for United States Senator, Warren W. Wilentz, had caught up with Senator Clifford P. Case and that tomorrow's election would be close.
ALTMAN'S has decided that the increasing num bers of wine drinkers should not have to fumble around a bar shop to find the right accessories for the imbibing of the grape.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--More vaccination of children against influenza is the best answer to the threat of epidemics, scientists told an international conference on vaccines here today.
ROME, Nov. 7 Italy dug out of the mud and debris of what her Interior Minister said today were the worst floods in the recorded history of the country.
Coverage of important election races in New York and throughout the country will be provided direct from the news room of The New York Times beginning election night at 8 P.M. by WQXR.
The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company's net income for the first nine months increased to $25,715,666, or $1.82 a share, from $24,368,412, or $1.73 a share, in the 1965 period.
The United Service Organizations is people.

BONN, Nov. 7 "Is it starting again?" The question was largely unspoken. But it seemed to have been in the minds of many West Germans who read in their newspapers today that the extreme right-wing National Democratic party had won a foothold in the newly elected government of Hesse with an unexpected show of popular support.

Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that President Johnson merited the "political slap" given him by former Vice President Richard M. Nixon because of the pre-election timing of the Manila conference.
Robert Chesebrough Rathbone, chairman and director of R.C. Rathbone Son, New York insurance brokerage firm, died yesterday in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 87 years old and lived in Englewood, N.J.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 7 Two rockets, two spacecraft and two astronauts all appeared ready today for the scheduled launching Wednesday of the final Gemini mission the fourday flight of Gemini 12.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether alien homosexuals may be deported from the United States under a law that excludes persons afflicted with a "psychopathic personality."
"I have a hunch that anyone who gets two million votes can win," Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. said yesterday.

After 129 days of hearings and after studying approximately 5 million words in 750 pages of testimony, Mr. Lyle and Henry C. Darmstadter Jr., the other examiner, recommended on March 29, 1965, that the merger of the New York Central and the Pennsylvania be approved. They produced a 591page opinion.
St. Patrick's Cathedral and St. Thomas Episcopal Church, which are almost opposite each other on Fifth Avenue, have been designated as landmarks by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) made 13 new loans totaling $327-million during the quarter ended Sept. 30, the bank reported yesterday.

ATLANTA, Nov. 7 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. plans to meet Wednesday with James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, to appeal for financial and organizational assistance for the civil rights movement.

The five educational television stations in the state will be interconnected by next November to form the State University of New York Communications Network, Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday.
The General Electric Com pany announced here yester day the appointment of James F. Young as vice president in charge of engineering serv ices.

St. Louis, Nov. 7 (AP) The conviction of Stephen Lynn Smith, 21 years old, in United States District Court at Des Moines, Iowa, for burning his draft card was upheld today in St. Louis by the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 6--The atmosphere for foreign private investment in Mexico is beginning to sour.
IT was becoming so dark toward the end of the Syracuse-Penn State game last Saturday that the spectators at State's Beaver Stadium had a difficult time in seeing the ball.
A 65-year-old house painter, trapped by rubble after an explosion in Brooklyn yesterday, shouted instructions to his rescuers as they dug for half an hour to free him.

LONDON, Nov. 7 The House of Lords, adhering to its role of preserver of tradition, has struck a blow in defense of the time-honored right of British children to filch an occasional egg from a bird's nest.

Despite the so-called cultural explosion, American theater audiences are dwindling. The theater is not attracting writers of content and concern, and 30 years of misuse of the Stanislavsky method have left actors untrained and undisciplined.
