FARGO, N.D., Nov. 9 (AP) Republicans made a clean sweep in North Dakota's general election yesterday by winning two Congressional seats and taking control in both houses of the State Legislature.

Each of New York's two statewide minor parties the Liberals and the Conservatives polled an astonishing total of slightly more than a half-million votes for its gubernatorial candidate Tuesday. Numerically the Liberals came out a little ahead in this sub-duel within the larger contest for Governor, but in terms of party commitment the Conservatives made the more impressive showing.

Edwin D. Etherington, outgoing president of the American Stock Exchange, suggested last night that the investment community consider creating "a securities industry council" in an effort "to ease the way toward more useful discussions" within the industry and with government.

William Arden Hoffman, a former member of the American Stock Exchange and partner in his father's former New York stock-brokerage concern William P. Hoffman Co., died Tuesday at St. Thomas, the Virgin Islands, where he lived. He was 56 years old.
With the returns still incomplete, the Democrats appeared yesterday to have a slight edge in their battle with the Republicans for control of next year's State Constitutional Convention.
The Rangers performed another of their weird psychodramas at Madison Square Garden last night, exhibiting their guilt feeling at being on top.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 9 The North Atlantic Alliance's 15 ambassadors went "househunting" in Brussels today.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 9 (UPI) About one million Missouri voters turned out yesterday to return incumbents to state and national offices, but the Republicans appeared to have made significant inroads in the State Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9--A live virus vaccine against mumps may become available next year in the United States, and a vaccine against German measles may be ready before another major epidemic of that disease occurs, experts predicted today.

Governor Rockefeller, elated over his third-term victory, repeated "unequivocally" yesterday that he would not run for President in 1968. But he served notice that he in- tended to "play a role" in furthering what he called the "basic mainstream thinking" in the party.
PRAGUE, Nov. 9 A number of religious leaders here are saying in effect that they have seen the future of Christianity under Communism, and it works.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 9 Once again, the Gemini 12 astronauts were forced to delay the start of their four-day space mission today when new trouble cropped up in the guidance system of their rocket.

A wooden mannequin called Elwood is joining the exclusive clique of men whose tatooed arm, blond beard or eye patch allow them to spend their lives smoking Marlboros, sipping Schweppes or modeling Hathaway shirts.
PARIS, Nov. 9 France is adopting a package of financial reforms that will make her system more similar to the major Western money centers.
The election of Duncan Macfarlan as senior vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company was announced yesterday in Newark.

The Inter-American Press Association reiterated yesterday its request that President Joaquin Balaguer of the Dominican Republic permit the Dominican journalist Rafae Bonilla Aybar to return to his country "and freely exercise his profession."
WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 9 (AP) A Republican tide that was felt across the country carried the party to victory in Delaware and ended a 10-year term in Congress for Representative Harris B. McDowell.
DAUTIENG, South Vietnam, Nov. 9 American infantrymen have blunted the spearhead of the enemy's winter offensive in South Vietnam, a United States Army general said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) Federal mediators today brought negotiations for striking electrical workers and the Westinghouse Corporation back to the bargaining table for the first time since the walkout began nine days ago.

Robinson Smith, producer and co-producer of several Broadway plays in the nineteen-thirties, died Sunday in his home at St. Thomas, V.I. He had been serving there as an officer of Island Interiors, Inc., and the St. Thomas Historical Trust. His age was 54.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 9 There was "a fantastic amount of ticket-splitting" in Rockland County in Tuesday's election, spokesmen for both major parties agreed today. One observer called the election "a paradox unexplainable to students of politics here."

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 9 The devastating Republican sweep of Minnesota was summed up today by a noontime exchange in a hotel lobby between Vice President Humphrey and Senator Walter F. Mondale, a key Democrat who survived the debacle.
Mostly small gains predominated on the London Stock Exchange yesterday. The market opened strongly but demand slackened, pushing prices down from their best levels.
ATLANTA, Nov. 9 Negroes and white liberals have succeeded in forcing Georgia's governorship election into the State Legislature and courts.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 9 The United States posed the possibility of establishing a single system of controls over automatic power reactors to prevent their diversion from peaceful to military uses.

HONG KONG, Nov. 9 The analyst of Chinese affairs leaned forward and cleared his throat. Those seated with him in the Foreign Correspondents Club on the top floor of the Hong Kong Hilton gave him their full attention.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Nov. 9 A program entitled "Magic Moments of Ballet" will be given on Sunday at the Locust Valley High School to benefit the Nassau County chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.
A preview of the annual Easter Seal Home Service art show will be held at 6 P.M. on Monday at the Carnegie Endowment Center, First Avenue and 46th Street.
Wall Street construed the upsurge in the stock market yesterday as a "Republican celebration" and it was hard to find an analyst willing to argue with the tape.
The effect of the 1966 midterm elections was to redress the balance of the nation's politics and put the Republicans back in the position of strong and effective challengers.
Mrs. Helen Lewis Skouland Matthews, the wife of H. Freeman Matthews, former Ambassador to Austria, died of a stroke last Saturday aboard the Kungsholm. She was 68 years old.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 9 Czechoslovakia urged the General Assembly today to appeal immediately for an end to the war in Vietnam and for strict observance of the United Nations Charter by the United States.
The State Liquor Authority has been temporarily prevented from forcing Joseph E. Seagram Son to price its liquor at wholesale in New York at levels no higher than in any other state.
The Transit Authority has removed closed-circuit television scanning systems that had been installed in three subway stations as an experiment in crime prevention.

Republicans sought court orders yesterday for quick recounts in an effort to pick up two more Congressional seats. They acted after a dramatic gain had won them a House seat in an Albany area that the Democrats had held since 1921.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday plans to sell $250million of debentures in January, giving a big boost to the volume of corporate bonds scheduled in coming months and causing a decline in prices among issues already outstanding.
RICHMOND, Nov. 9 Virginia voters answered some old political questions yesterday but they also raised some new ones.
MAYOR LINDSAY "proclaimed" New York City the "Cuisine Capital of the World" yesterday.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Nov. 9 Mrs. Charles Elwood Gray has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Alice Martha Gray, to James David Harris, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Lionel Harris of Los Angeles.
The preliminary merger agreement between Litton Industries, Inc., and American Book Company, which was announced in July, 1966, has been revised, it was announced yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 9 District Court Judge Isidor M. Dubrow was found dead in his chambers at the Middlesex County Courthouse last night. He was 63 years old and lived at 44 High Street, Perth Amboy.
The plan of the city's Marine and Aviation Department to develop a containership port on the Eastern shore of Staten Island has raised questions about the effect of the project on Federal anchorages.
LISBON, Nov. 9 The Portuguese political police have arrested a leader of the new Christian Democratic opposition for "activities against the security of the state," it was officially ocnfirmed today.

The New York City Opera gave "The Tales of Hoffmann" its final performance of the season last night at the New York State Theater. Six of the cast were appearing in their roles for the first time at the new house.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 9 (UPI) Republicans elected their second successive Governor in Oklahoma history yesterday, and picked up one Congressional seat.
RANDOLPH CHURCHILL is building for his father, Sir Winston Churchill, a biographical monument as massive as the place where Sir Winston was born-- Blenheim Palace.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 9 (UPI) United States Navy jets braved heavy anti-aircraft fire today and bombed a bridge in North Vietnam.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP)--The chairman of the United States Steel Corporation said tonight inflation could only be dealt with successfully "by erasing seemingly irreconcilable differences between good politics and good economics."

HOUSTON, Nov. 9 Cassius Clay, the fighter who produces more allegory than gore, put on one of his livelier performances today. But though he managed to upstage Jimmy Brown, he failed to rattle Cleveland (Big Cat) Williams.
A truck salesman was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of defrauding "investors" of $1-million in a scheme to buy and sell repossessed trucks.
LEAMINGTON SPA, England, Nov. 9 In the ancient and leafy towns of Warwick and Leamington Spa, Sikhs with loaded shotguns are standing guard tonight over their shops and homes.

ATHENS, Nov. 9 Premier Stephanos Stephanopoulos plans to reorganize his Government tomorrow, three days before the Greek Parliament reassembles after a six-month summer recess, for a crucial vote to elect its new president. The 35 Cabinet Ministers resigned tonight to facilitate the reshuffle.
BOISE, Idaho, Nov. 9 (UPI) Senator Len Jordan led a Republican sweep of eight of 11 major offices in Idaho's elections yesterday with a victory over former Representative Ralph Harding, a Democrat.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 Representative Craig Hosmer of California, senior Republican House member on the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee, charged today that the Administration was "covering up" evidence indicating that the Soviet Union might have violated the nuclear test ban treaty in an explosion Oct. 27.
What happened a year ago yesterday? A small and unscientifically chosen cross-section of New Yorkers, intercepted as they were headed for the Times Square IRT subway station, didn't remember.
FEW fields are so fertile for the observing eye of the sociologist or maybe the anthropologist as the clothes people wear while out hunting and fishing.
DETROIT, Nov. 9 An exuberant George Romney, who led a massive Republican sweep in yesterday's Michigan elections, moved deeply into contention today for the G.O.P. Presidential nomination in 1968.
ALGIERS, Nov. 9 American oil companies bowed today to Algerian demands that they pay back royalties on their terms within 24 hours or face Government action.

St. George's Episcopal Church, 207 East 16th Street, has been made available to the Professional Theater Wing, whose object is to discover new playwrights by testing their scripts with the aid of experienced performers and directors.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 9 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi planned a major Cabinet shuffle today and then drew back.

Commissioner Joseph F. Periconi has tried to resign as head of the Sanitation Department, but has agreed to stay on briefly to complete a reorganization of the department and allow the Mayor time to recruit a successor for his controversial post.

WHEN the news came, Joey Archer shrugged off his disappointment without any outward display of emotion. He is a gentle and mild-mannered man--at least outside the ring. But Jimmy Archer exploded when he heard the news. Jimmy is Joey's brother and also his manager, an intense and fast-talking guy with a much lower boiling point.

Miss Margaret Ann Malin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Malin of Forest Hills, Queens, and Michael Oppenheimer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Oppenheimer of Bayside, Queens, plan to be married in February.
The elections for the Governors of New York and Minnesota provided the only major embarrassments yesterday for the people who take pre-election polls.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 The General Conference of the Methodist Church today set 1972 as the target date for elimination of the denomination's racially segregated structures, but it stopped short of making desegregation mandatory.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 9 Claude R. Kirk Jr., the 40year-old Republican who confounded Florida political experts by being elected Governor yesterday, said today he would begin to clean up crime in Miami without waiting to take office in January.
STRATFORD, Conn., Nov. 9 Theodore H. Krueger, an inventor of various sealing wax dispensers, died last Thursday of a heart attack in Yale New Haven Hospital. He was 77 years old.

New York City suffered a major blow and won a minor victory in the statewide balloting on propositions and constitutional amendments. The defeat of Amendment 3, which had been strongly backed by Mayor Lindsay and many civic groups, was a serious setback to the cause of better housing.

NASHVILLE, Nov. 9 (AP) The Republican party basked today in the light of its biggest statewide election victory of the century sending Howard Baker Jr. to the senate, picking up one House seat and gaining 14 seats in the Legislature.

MRS. EVELYN MONTE, who lives in a New York apartment and runs dogs in field trials when she isn't judging them, disagrees with those who say that a hunting dog should not be given so much as a kind word and should never, never be brought into the house.
Albert Sturmer, the cantor who chants the prayers at Mount Neboh Temple at 130 West 79th Street every Friday night, is studying to become a stockbroker.

Richard M. Nixon yesterday described the Republican party's gain of 47 seats in the House of Representatives as "the sharpest rebuff of a President in a generation" and a "rebuke to the President's lack of credibility and lack of direction abroad."

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP) The National Safety Council reported today that 38,190 persons died on the nation's highways in the first nine months of 1966, an increase of 10 per cent over the level in the first three-quarters of 1965.

DUBLIN, Nov. 9 John Mary Lynch, whom the Irish are expected to elect Prime Minister tomorrow, is a tall man with kindly blue-gray eyes, the swing of an athlete in his stride, and the soft musical brogue of Munster on his tongue.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9 Philip Feldesman, a New York expert, moved into the lead of the International Team Trials at the end of the second round here tonight. He teamed with Richard Freeman of Atlanta to defeat B. Jay Becker and Mrs. Dorothy Hayden, 27-15. This score, combined with an earlier win, 38 -3 , over Hermine Baron and Meyer Schleifer of Los Angeles, to give the Feldesman pair a total of 65 .

HAVANA, Nov. 9 The United States team defeated East Germany 1 - , with two games adjourned, in the fifth round of the premier finals of the 17th Chess Olympics at the Havana Libre Hotel here last night.

KARLSRUHE, Germany, Nov. 9 (AP) The Federal Supreme Court today sentenced an American engineer and a German to two years in prison for having plotted to set up a new Nazi regime in West Germany. Two other Americans who have left the country were named by the court as fellow-conspirators.

IF a wager were made to name the restaurant in New York with the most enthusiastic clientele, with customers who willingly bide their time an hour or more waiting for a table, the average bettor would probably lose. The restaurant is neither French, Italian nor Chinese. It is, in fact, Mexican and the name is El Parador. It is at 561 Second Avenue (at 31st Street).
RAILROAD bonds, which are now offering their highest yields since the nineteen-thirties, appear to provide a greater degree of investment quality in view of the growing strength of the industry.

MONTREAL, Nov. 9 (UPI) A goal by Jim Pappin midway through the final period with the Canadiens short two men gave the Toronto Maple Leafs a 3-2 victory over Montreal tonight and moved them into second place in the National Hockey League.

WEST POINT, N.Y. Nov. 9 Army players who last spring were "lost" and "confused," according to their captain, and "orphans," according to their coach, are winners now. These athletes achieved the cadets' first winning year in three seasons last Saturday with their sixth triumph of the campaign.

A recital by Phyllis Curtin, soprano, that was taped at the Berkshire Music Festival in Lenox, Mass., last August will be televised from 8:30 to 10 P.M. Tuesday over Channel 13. Miss Curtin was accompanied by Ryan Edwards, pianist. The program will be repeated next Thursday at 11 P.M.

The annual dinner dance of the National Tay-Sachs and Allied Diseases Association has been arranged for Sunday in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria. The columnist Earl Wilson will be honored for his support of the association.
The president of City College refused yesterday to bow before a student threat to hold a sit-in demonstration in the college's administration build
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 9 (AP) Republicans gained their greatest stronghold on Kentucky's Congressional delegation in yesterday's election in this border state.

When Joseph Fuchs plays, he makes most other violinists seem musically slipshod. This was the case once again in his recital last night, in Carnegie Hall, where he offered an interesting mixture of familiar and unfamiliar works with his customary colleague, Brooks Smith, at the piano.
Two major building associations here called yesterday for immediate government intervention to end the long plumbers' strike which they said was paralyzing the construction industry.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 9 Prompt and vigorous reaction by Arthur J. Goldberg, chief United States delegate, to a proposal to shift a greater share of the financial burden of peace-keeping operations to the developed countries made it almost certain today that the project would be rejected.
BOSTON, Nov. 9 The Commonwealth of Massachusetts, which gave the nation its first Roman Catholic President, today hailed the first Negro to be elected to the Senate directly by the voters.
RENO, Nov. 9 (UPI) Lieut, Gov. Paul Laxalt, Republican and son of an immigrant Basque sheepherder, swept to an easy victory over the incumbent Gov. Grant Sawyer yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 9--A substantial easing of Britain's divorce laws, including a modified form of divorce by consent, was suggested today in a white paper.

Three Wall Street stockbrokers and a salesman were arrested yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and accused of operating a coast-to-coast confidence game that brought them about $250,000.
RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 9 The defeat of Representative Harold D. Cooley, long-time chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, represented a major triumph for the Republican party in North Carolina.
The New York lottery amendment that trotted to victory on Tuesday was merely the first heat.

Alfred Hayes, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and a ranking official of the Federal Reserve System, directly challenged yesterday President Johnson's judgment that there had been "a very healthy movement toward price stability in recent weeks."

CLEVELAND, Nov. 9 (UPI) The state rested its case today in the retrial of Samuel H. Sheppard after presenting testimony by a blood technician that the defendant's wrist watch was speckled with "flying drops blood in motion."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission ordered the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today to revise its rates for its Telpak service.
MONTPELIER, Vt., Nov. 9 (UPI) Democrats, who wrested control of Vermont from the Republicans in the Johnson landslide two years ago, retained power today behind Gov. Philip H. Hoff.
Ken Boyer, the grand old man of the New York Mets, stopped by Shea Stadium yesterday, re ported that he had no aches or pains and predicted that he would play in 145 or so baseball games next season.

A special three-judge Federal court will hold a hearing here Tuesday on a petition for an interlocutory judgment that would restrain the Pennsylvania and the New York Central Railroads from proceeding with their merger without first including the bankrupt New Haven in the consolidated system.
HONG KONG, Thursday, Nov. 10 (UPI) A Chinese Communist newspaper hinted today that the current "cultural revolution" was affecting industrial and agricultural production.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 9 (AP) Capt, Jim Coots of the United States Army broke the 300-meter free-style swim record tonight for the world modern pentathlon, but Hungary virtually was assured of retaining the individual and team championships.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 9 Democrat Robert Docking became the first Democrat ever to unseat an incumbent Republican Governor seeking re-election in Kansas when the 41year-old Arkansas City banker yesterday soundly defeated William H. Avery, who was running for a second two-year term.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) The Zambian Embassy said today it has temporarily stopped issuing visas "as a security precaution."
ATLANTA, Nov. 9 (UPI) An escape artist, Jesse James Roberts, and a 29-year-old companion scaled the 30-foot-high wall of the Federal prison here tonight and fled in the rain and darkness.

The city yesterday unveiled a model of the schoolyard of the future." The design will make it possible for a casual observer to tell a school play yard from an outdoor prison compound at a glance. Things like sculptures by Costantino Nivola will help.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (UPI) The New York Knickerbockers rallied the last half tonight, led by Emmette Bryant's best National Basketball Association scoring performance ever, to beat Chicago, 103-98, and knock the Bulls out of the Western Division lead.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 The United States hinted today that it might reduce or end its aid program to Guinea because of Guinea's decision yesterday to expel the Peace Corps.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9--Mrs. Harold Lee Parrish has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Parrish, to Henry P. Glendinning Jr., son of Mrs. Glendinning of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Glendinning.
HARTFORD, Nov. 9 The overwhelmed Connecticut Republican party struggled for unity today, under threat of internal upheaval.
BRUSSELS Nov. 9 The Common Market acquires a new dimension tomorrow, with a million Italian farmers the direct beneficiaries.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 9 (UPI) Louisiana voters gave landslide victories to three Democratic candidates for Congress yesterday and overwhelmingly approved a constitutional amendment to permit Gov. John J. McKeithen to run for election to succeed himself.
Some of Aqueduct's younger riders combined to make the lot of the plunger a happy one yesterday while such stars as Robert Ussery and Braulio Baeza nursed minor illnesses at home.
The appointment of William P. Tavoulareas as executive vice president of the Mobil Oil Corporation and as president of its North American division was announced here yesterday.
Two major utility systems announced yesterday plans for spending in excess of $1.55billion over the next five years.
AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 9 Kenneth M. Curtis, a 35-yearold seaman turned lawyer and politician, upset Gov. John H. Reed, the Republican incumbent, in the gubernatorial contest in Maine yesterday.

It was good news for baseball fans among servicemen in United Service Organiza tions centers in the Thule Air Force Base in Greenland, when they learned that members of the New York Mets were visit ing U.S.O. camps.
Firemen aided the police yesterday in a search that led to the capture of a bandit suspect. He ws held in the wounding of a Harlem coin laundry owner during a robery attempt.

Indications in the steel industry yesterday were that the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation would be all alone for awhile with selective price increases on stainless strip and sheet products. The rises take effect today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 The Government significantly broadened its involvement in birth control programs during the last year and will continue to do so.

The City Planning Commission acted yesterday to expedite Mayor Lindsay's policy of concentrating new urban-renewal projects in ghetto areas. In a special meeting, the commission approved the new East River renewal development in Harlem.
SELMA, Ala., Nov. 9 Sheriff James G. Clark Jr., the controversial figure in the Selma civil rights demonstrations last year, was defeated yesterday in his bid to retain his post by writein votes.
TULARE, Calif., Nov. 9 (UPI) Bob Mathias, two-time Olympic decathlon champion, headed for a new career in Congress today by winning his first bid for political office.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 9 Robert Taft Jr., has again emerged as a potential national Republican political figure by scoring a solid victory over an attractive first-term liberal Democrat.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 9 Arizona has given the Republican party its first clear mandate in the state's history.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Creighton Rice have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Collins Rice, to R. Bruce Rosenbauer. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred W. Rosenbauer of North Tarrytown, N.Y.
TREASURE ISLAND, Calif., Nov. 9 A general court-martial heard final arguments today in the case of Navy Capt. Archie C. Kuntze on charges of illegal transactions in Saigon.
BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Nov. 9 (UPI) This city voted overwhelmingly yesterday not to participate in the Federal antipoverty program.
MANCHESTER, N.H., Nov 9 New Hampshire Democrats re-elected Senator Thomas J. McIntyre and Gov. John W. King yesterday, but on the day after Election Day, the joy among them is not unconfined.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 9 Inspiration and psychological warfare will be big factors in the outcome of the Yale-Princeton football game here Saturday, according to Carmen Cozza, Yale's coach, and Nassau's victory over Harvard has given the Bulldog inspiration above and beyond its normal itch to flay the Tiger.
Ryder Truck Lines, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Earl N. Hoekenga as president and chief executive officer to succeed R. H. Stier, who was named chairman.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Nov. 9 All three Democratic incumbents from New Mexico's were returned to Congress in yesterday's election.
The improved showing that Republicans made on Election Day apparently had a bullish effect on most issues on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
Saverio Soranno, an immigrant who rose to national prominence in the coal and fuel oil business, died Monday in St. John's Hospital. He was 68 years old.

New York voters weaved through one of the complicated sections of Tuesday's ballot to approve a proposition and eight constitutional amendments and reject three amendments, according to incomplete returns.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 9 George Sholty, who by standing on the tip of his toes might stretch to a height of 5 feet 1 inch, rides tall in a sulky. The 33-year-old former basketball player from Logansport, Ind., will be driving the favored Polaris in the Dexter Cup race for 3-year-old trotters at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 E.G. Rawson Lloyd, vice president, secretary and a director of the Wellington Fund, Inc., one of the world's largest mutual funds, died yesterday in Lankenau Hospital here. He was 62 years old and lived at 536 Panmure Road, Haverford, Pa.
An international arbitration council ruled last night that the Soviet Union and the United States must play off a previously forfeited four-game match at the 17th Chess Olympics in Havana.

Personal papers, documents and pictures of Sir Winston Churchill will be published today in a portfolio of facsimiles by the K.S. Giniger Company in association with University Microfilms, a subsidiary of the Xerox Corporation.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 9 (AP)-- The Baltimore Colts said today that Gino Marchetti, their eight-time all-league defensive end, had agreed to come out of retirement.

KINGSTON, N.Y. Nov. 9-- The brunet Italian-American couple who sought unsuccessfully to adopt their four-and-ahalf year old blonde foster child were rejected solely for medical reasons, according to the office of the Ulster County Welfare Commissioner today.
GENEVA, Nov. 9 The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, said today his agency faced a major financial crisis.

The formation of an executive committee to press for the refinancing of the Child Development Group of Mississippi, whose funds were recently cut off by the Office of Economic Opportunity, was announced here yesterday.
Northrup R. Knox of East Aurora, N.Y., was elected chairman of the United States Polo Association yesterday at the organization's 76th meeting of delegates at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

DETROIT, Nov. 9 Detroit's three largest banks and a bank in Grand Rapids, Mich., have filed suit in United States District Court in Washington seeking to enjoin the Controller of the Currency from allowing the acquisition of the Michigan Bank, N.A., of Detroit by the Michigan National Bank of Lansing.
WASHINGTON, Nov.9 (UPI) The Defense Department called today for a draft of 27,600 men in January.
Bernard H. Baum, president of the Effanbee Doll Corporation of Brooklyn, died yesterday at Cumberland Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage. Mr. Baum, who lived at 515 East 89th Street, was 57 years old.

DENVER, Nov. 9 Colorado Republicans bounced back from their 1964 losses to score impressive victories in yesterday's general election, which brought the greatest voter turnout of any non-Presidential year in the state's history.

BADEN-BADEN, Germany, Nov. 9 (AP) Official representatives of the French, American and West German armed forces attended the burial today of former Gen. Dietrich von Choltitz, the Wehrmacht commander who defied Adolf Hitler's orders to burn Paris in 1944.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 Trade association meetings, so boring and seemingly alien to the typical consumer, could provide him with a wealth of vital information about the thought processes and plans of the "opposition" the highly competitive contenders for his money.

THE New York Jets will make four personnel moves for Sunday's key American Football League game at Buffalo, Jim O'Mahoney, Pete Perreault and probably Earl Christy will be activated, and Emerson Boozer will see more service at halfback.
The backlash vote in Tuesday's elections was highly erratic, but the frontlash, the Negro vote, showed a high degree of sophistication and selectivity, an analysis of the voting revealed yesterday.

About 90 members of the International Council of the Museum of Modern Art were guests at tours and receptions of other museums as they gathered yesterday in New York for the council's 10th annual meeting.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 9 In the election yesterday, Westchester County returned to its traditional role as a banner Republican couny a role it has filled for most of the last 57 years.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9-- Nearly complete unofficial returns confirmed today a modest Republican sweep in Pennsylvania, apparently not so substantial as that in many other states nor so large as Republicans here had expected.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 9-- Iran has decided to develop her own oil tanker fleet to reduce dependence on foreign vessels. Four tankers have already been delivered and another four are being ordered from Japanese shipbuilders, according to National Iranian Oil Company sources.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 Senatorelect Charles H. Percy today attributed his victory over the Democratic incumbent, Paul H. Douglas, to voter dissatisfaction with inflation, the war in Vietnam and "civil rights and civil disorder."
ANCHORAGE, Nov. 9 (AP) Republicans displaced Alaska's Democratic Governor and Representative at Large today in a surprising show of strength that may also lead to control of the State Legislature.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 9-- Iran has decided to develop her own oil tanker fleet to reduce dependence on foreign vessels. Four tankers have already been delivered and another four are being ordered from Japanese shipbuilders, according to National Iranian Oil Company sources.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 Senatorelect Charles H. Percy today attributed his victory over the Democratic incumbent, Paul H. Douglas, to voter dissatisfaction with inflation, the war in Vietnam and "civil rights and civil disorder."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) The nation's voters made far-reaching decisions Election Day on taxes, state constitutions lotteries, drinking and obscenity. They also apparently doomed five men in Colorado.

Leaders of the four-year-old Conservative party, whose candidate for Governor polled more than a half-million votes, jubilantly proclaimed yesterday that they had replaced the Liberal party as the state's third most important political force.

The Advanced Science Writing Program, which has been supported by the Sloan Foundation at the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism, will also be shifted to the new institute. A quarter of the Sloan Foundation's million-dollar grant is slated for continuation of the writing program.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Vice President Humphrey, in an unusual public challenge to the military regimes in Latin America, declared today that they were inadequate to meet the goals of the Alliance for Progress.

BACH'S Suite No. 3 in D started the Philharmonic program last night, but everybody was waiting for the big piece, the Beethoven Ninth. Lorin Maazel conducted. He gave us, on the whole, an old-fashioned Bach, one with lots of strings, but a fine presentation of its kind.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 10 Dr. John W. Lederle, president of the University of Massachusetts, and Mrs. Lederle have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Jean Lederle, to Joseph Marro Jr., son of Mrs. Marro of New Haven and the late Mr. Marro. The wedding is planned for Dec. 23.
The volume of new bond issues for sale continued to mount yesterday as California announced plans to sell $100million on Nov. 22.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Studies of an additive to an influenza vaccine show that it increases the potency and duration of the vaccine's protective effect.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 10 The Vietcong, whose supporters have been vehement in protests against American use of tear gas, attacked a patrol of the United States First Infantry Division today with nonpoisonous gas grenades, a United States spokesman said.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 10 (AP) Jim Ferree shot a four-under-par 66 today and took the first-round lead by a stroke in the Caracas open golf tournament.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 10 Everybody concerned with the Washington D.C International tomorrow expressed satisfaction with what went on today at the Laurel Race Course. The draw for post position of the 10 participants in the $150,000 turf race took place in the morning, and no one disapproved of the allocations in the 1 -mile invitation test.

PARIS, Nov. 10 The French highway death toll, one of the worst in the world, declined last summer for the first time in 10 years. Announcing the figures, the Government said the drop resulted, at least in part, from its crackdown on reckless drivers.
Mrs. Sarah Spencer-Churchill Russell obtained a license here today to be married to a New York art dealer, Guillermo Burgos.

PRIOR to his appointment as head football coach at Cornell, Jack Musick served under Bob Blackman at Dartmouth for 10 seasons. During that span as a defensive specialist, Musick, with Blackman, painstakingly mapped game plans for 70 Ivy League games. The collaboration resulted ...
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Friday, Nov. 11 Rhodesia is marking today the first anniversary of its declaration of independence from Britain.
The outcome of a constitutional amendment that would permit Court of Appeal judges to continue in office, if needed, past the retirement age of 70, remained in doubt yesterday.

Don Spero, the world's singles sculls champion, was among the athletes honored last night at the New York Athletic Club's annual all-sports dinner, which was attended by 1,000 guests. Jerome F. Healy, the club president, presided and Richard E. Long was chairman of the dinner, held at the N.Y.A.C. clubhouse.
BONN, Nov. 10 Kurt Georg Kiesinger, whom the Christian Democrats have selected as their candidate for the Chancellorship, has spent eight years of selfimposed "exile" from Bonn.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Freight traffic volume generated by carloadings on U.S. railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Nov. 5 were both ahead of the corresponding week of 1965.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10 (AP) George Gallup, the national pollster, today credited the Republican party's success in Tuesday's election to the Vietnam war.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Ongioni of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Adrienne Ellen Ongioni, to Daniel Lynn Burroughs, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Lynn Burroughs of Trenton, Mich.

BERLIN, Nov. 10 The East German Communists said today that Germany's Nazi past had been given a new chance to raise its head through the nomination by the Christian Democrats of Kurt Georg Kiesinger to succeed Chancellor Erhard.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) The State Department acknowledged today that "a small amount of radioactivity" was accidently released into the atmosphere on Sept. 12 after an underground nuclear test in Nevada.
Drivers who have had a single cocktail or a bottle of beer have fewer accidents than those who have drunk no alcohol at all, according to a study carried out under a grant from American distillers.
At Lincoln Center today: "Antony and Cleopatra," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; "The Magic Flute," New York City Opera, New York State Theater, 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 2:15.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 The head of a steel company that announced price increases earlier this week came to Washington today to confer with Gardner Ackley, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. He came at the invitation of the council.

The Democratic party is in trouble today partly because it is deeply divided in several of the big industrial states, partly because its National Committee organization is poor, and partly because it can no longer count on the allegiance of a massive unified labor vote.

The presence of racial antagonism in a political campaign is like the presence of a plague in a stricken city. When it turns out to have been less deadly and less far-reaching than had been feared, the general sense of relief is so great that the tendency is to overlook how much damage it really did do.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 10 (AP) Messages from President Johnson and Senator Edward M. Kennedy were read today after dedication of the John F. Kennedy Building at the Hadassah Hebrew University Medical Center.
RYE, N.Y., Nov. 10 Residents at an angry public meeting last night demanded that Mayor Edmund C. Grainger Jr. "throw urban renewal out of Rye." The Mayor quietly but firmly refused.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 10 Twelve members of the International Law Commission were re-elected to fiveyear terms today by majority votes in the General Assembly. The 13 other nominees for the 25-member panel were elected for the first time.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara has said that a lottery would be one way to achieve a more equitable draft system.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 10 A group of Suffolk taxpayers, angered over an expected sharp increase in county welfare costs, charged here today that welfare rolls were rife with parasites. They charged among other things that welfare recipients owned color television sets and drove automobiles rented to them by the county.

A 61-year-old woman, unconscious in a blazing East Side apartment, was tugged to safety early yesterday by a Fire Department lieutenant who crawled on his hands and knees through thick smoke and intense heat.

NATALIE WOOD more or less reviews her own new picture, "Penelope," when she sprints to the blackboard, ravenously pursued by an anthropology professor, and chalks up one word: help! The inane, silly and strained Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer comedy archly skipped into the Radio City Music Hall yesterday. Skipped, slipped and flipped.

BURLINGAME, Calif., Nov. 11 (AP) Eddie Erdelatz, former head football coach for the United States Naval Academy, St. Mary's College and the Oakland Raiders of the American Football League, died early this morning at Peninsula Hospital. He was 52 years old.

An increase of 5 per cent in capital spending, a highly significant measure of industry's confidence in the economy, has been forecast for 1967.

Mayor Lindsay declared yesterday that though "I have feelings just like those of any other man," his official attitude toward waitresses in topless uniforms in this city would be guided by the police and courts.

The board of directors of the Paramount Pictures Corporation, meeting here yesterday, voted to give substance to the rumors of executive changes that have been circulating since the company became a wholly owned subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries last month.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 10 The Stanford University chapter of Sigma Chi has voted unanimously to leave the national fraternity after what it called an unsuccessful fight to end racial discrimination.

JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Nov. 10 Following is the official transcript of today's news conference at the LBJ Ranch involving the President, Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara and Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff:
The New York Civil Liberties Union said yesterday that legal action in an attempt to save the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board was "under very serious consideration."
Prompt re-evaluatlon of the role that all types of the country's seagoing merchant ships play in the national defense system was urged here yesterday.
Elected 25 members of International Law Commission.

The Swingle Singers were back in Town Hall last night bubbling through Bach. There was also some Telemann, Vivaldi, Chopin and Mendelssohn in typical seat-chorus vocal arrangements. The four women and four men again showed what clarity and bounce could be added to some moldy figs of the classical repertory as they grouped and regrouped themselves about the five microphones and ran their cascades of "do-be-do-be-dos."

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 10 The engagement of Miss Nancy Louise Wright, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roberts J. Wright, to Dr. Norman Dishotsky, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents. The future bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Dishotsky of Bayside, Queens, New York.

The Pacific Southern Broadcasting Company has purchased for $15-million WAII-TV Atlanta, Ga. and WIBC-AM and FM, Indianapolis, it was announced yesterday by DeSales Harrison Jr., chairman of the executive committee of the company.
A top legal authority on the Kennedy round of tariff-cutting negotiations warned here yesterday that the talks in Geneva are moving into a critical phase this month.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., Nov. 10 Miss Judy Ann Rosenberg and Stephen Berman, who are studying for master's degrees at Indiana University, have become affianced.

Vladimir Horowitz will play a recital at Carnegie Hall on Sunday, Nov. 27, at 3:30 P.M. and will repeat the program Saturday, Dec. 10 at 3. The pianist will offer that program first in Woolsey Hall at Yale University in New Haven this Sunday at 5:30.

Alan S. Boyd, chosen by President Johnson as first Secretary of the new Department of Transportation, takes on the task of evolving a coordinated national transportation policy under a Congressional mandate that gives him far too little jurisdiction or power.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 10 Arthur O. Louis, until 1964 senior partner in the admiralty law firm of Hill, Rivkins, Louis Warburton of 96 Fulton Street in New York, died today in the St. Peter's General Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 1050 George Street and in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
Moody's Investors Service, Inc., is studying the possibility of diversifying into the mutual fund field.

Columbia University announced yesterday the creation of an institute that, with the aid of leading scientific and sociological scholars, will seek to clarify present and potential roles of science in our society.

Carl W. Gardner, formerly executive vice president of Elizabeth Arden Sales Corporation, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of the concern, which manufactures cosmetics and operates beauty salons.

Keep America Beautiful, an organization dedicated to litter prevention, presented a special citation to Laurance S. Rockefeller yesterday for his "leadership and personal contributions" to conservation and beautification. Mr. Rockefeller, a brother of New York's' Governor, is chairman of the Palisades Interstate Park Commission and ... the Hudson River Valley Commission.

John P. Clark, a lawyer and real estate consultant to railroads, has been named director of real estate for the Reading Railroad. Mr. Clark is a former president of the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad.

LONDON, Nov. 10 (Reuters) Newspapers from London to Moscow said today that the results of the United States elections were a blow to Negro civil rights and the Great Society programs of President Johnson, but represented no clear expression by the American people on Vietnam.
BONN, Nov. 10 Kurt Georg Kiesinger, Minister-President of Baden-Wurttemberg, will be West Germany's next Chancellor if he forms a coalition.
DETROIT, Nov. 10 (AP)-- United States auto makers chalked up their fourth successive week yesterday when production exceeded 200,000 as output touched an estimated 208,185 units this week.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 10 A letter signed by 2,700 Harvard University undergraduates was sent today to Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara in an apology for "unruly behavior" toward him here Monday.

Control of the New York State Legislature will remain divided for the next two years between a Republican Senate and a Democratic Assembly, just as it has been this year. But now that Governor Rockefeller is safely installed in the Executive Mansion for another four years, possibly there will be more constructive results than last winter, when the coming gubernatorial race influenced every move.
"I DON'T like his work," said a skinny young man clutching some textbooks covered in wrappers marked St. Francis College. "But I came anyway to see Andy Warhol because he's a phenomenon."
GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 10 J. Russell Maguire, industrialist, financier and oil producer, died this morning at Greenwich Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at Harbor Drive, Greenwich.
World sugar prices registered some new lifetime lows yesterday in the distant-month contracts. However, the closing prices managed to show some slight gains.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) George Meany denied at a Federal hearing today that he had directed an 11-union committee that won a new contract with the General Electric Company recently.
PARIS, Nov. 10--President de Gaulle, who vetoed the British bid to join the Common Market in 1963, remains cool to Britain's membership and doubtful about the seriousness of her intentions.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10 George Rapee of New York and Sidney Lazard of New Orleans surged into the lead in the International team trials here tonight. They won a key match in the seventh round by winning 27-15 against the previous leaders, Lew Mathe and Robert Hamman of Los Angeles. This gave Rapee and Lazard a total of 176 , half a point ahead of the Californians.
DEER PARK, L.I., Nov. 10 The debut of The Suffolk Sun, a morning newspaper planned for eastern Long Island, has been postponed a week until Nov. 21.
The stock market's postelection rally continued yesterday as prices advanced in heavy trading.

The most essential and immediate step to save Staten Island is passage of a bill requiring pre-mapping of land before a building permit is issued. This measure, already defeated twice by the City Council, has been consistently opposed by Borough President Connor for nearly a year.
HONG KONG, Nov. 10 The Soviet Union, China and several other Communist countries have agreed to give North Vietnam more aid, Hanoi reported today.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he won Tuesday's election because he had acquainted the public with his own record and because Frank D. O'Connor did not have a program and "never convinced the people he was a viable alternative."
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 10 Can a poor Russian boy from Aleksandrovskoye and a waif from Tbilisi make good in the rolling capitalistic hills of Maryland's horse country?

PARIS, Nov. 10 Najeeb E. Halaby, the senior vice president of Pan American World Airways, said today that the Government should build two prototype supersonic aircraft one Boeing and one Lockheed using the same prototype power plant in both.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 10 --Dr. Benson Y. Landis, for many years keeper of the most widely recognized count of religious membership in the United States, died of a heart attack today in his home, at 124 Branbach Road here. He was 69 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara's disclosure that the United States now believes Russia probably is deploying a missile defense around the Soviet Union may be the opening round in an Administration effort to stave off potentially overwhelming Congressional pressure ...

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 10 (Reuters) The Beirut prosecutor's office has issued a summons for Youssef Beidas, founder and former chairman of the crisis-hit Intra Bank here, to appear before an examining magistrate.
CHICKASHA, Okla., Nov. 10 (AP) An Oklahoma Congressman shed of his 4-B public official deferment faces possible military draft in the near future.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) Less than half of the eligible voters turned out at the polls Tuesday, but the nearly 56 million ballots cast was still a record for a midterm election.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 10 The 12th and last of the Gemini series of space flights is scheduled to be launched tomorrow after a two-day delay caused by a malfunctioning rocket guidance system.
WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 10 Carlisle, driven by Billy Haughton, easily captured the $87,180.36 Dexter Cup in the rain at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Nov. 10 A graduate instructor in English at the University of North Carolina has been reinstated in the classroom from which he was removed three weeks ago amid charges that he had assigned a theme dealing with seduction.
PARIS, Nov. 10 (AP) The North Atlantic Treaty Organization lifted its embargo today on the sale of large-diameter pipe to Communist countries.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) The Department of Agriculture estimated today that this year's corn crop would total 4,129,896,000 bushels, compared with last year's crop of 4,171,000,000 bushels.

With the end of the New York racing season only a month away, the horsemen are showing the usual end-of-theseason interest in Aqueduct's waning stakes program. Fourteen sprinters are listed for today's $50,000 added Vosburgh Handicap, while about a dozen probably will participate in tomorrow's $50,000 added Roamer for 3-year-olds.

The Chicago Symphony Orchestra, playing its second concert of the week last night in Carnegie Hall, offered three works conventionally disposed, with Jean Martinon again conducting. From the classic period there was Haydn's Sinfonia Concertante for Violin, Cello, Oboe and Bassoon; from the romantic period, Schumann's Piano Concerto, with Wilhelm Kempff as soloist, and from this century, Stravinsky's "Petruchka." On paper, the concert looked uneventful, if pleasant enough. In performance, it had its unsettling phases.
Led by the glamour issues, the American Stock Exchange ran its post-election rally through a second consecutive session yesterday.
Richard P. Cooley was elected yesterday as president of the Wells Fargo Bank of San Francisco, the nation's 11th largest commercial bank.
The modern tournament golfer may be something of a magician on the putting greens, but according to Bobby Jones, he consumes too much time cleaning and lifting the ball.
Two emergency programs to alleviate critical personnel shortages and antiquated condi- tions at Bellevue Hospital, ordered a month ago, have not yet been started.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 10 The Indiana State Board of Health yesterday approved for the first time the use of state funds for birth control pills and other contraceptives.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Alan S. Boyd believes it will take him a year to organize the new Department of Transportation that President Johnson has named him to head.
SAN MARINO, Nov. 10 (AP) After a 100-day crisis, the 38-square-mile Republic of San Marino today got back the same coalition Government she has had since 1957.

MOSCOW, Nov. 10 Canada urged the Soviet Union today to authorize specific new functions for the enfeebled International Control Commission in Vietnam as an initial step toward peace, according to qualified sources.

SALISBURY, Friday, Nov. 11 (Reuters) Prime Minister Smith early today rang in the second year of Rhodesia's independence and told cheering white fellow countrymen: "This is the beginning of a wonderful era."
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 10 The Government today banned 11 candidates from running in next week's elections and stripped them of their political rights for 10 years.
Burton L. Kamberg has resigned as president of Coordinated Apparel, Inc., a major manufacturer of boys' apparel, following a policy dispute with the Dutch interests that...
SAIGON, Nov. 10 American battle casualties, reflecting the sharp actions in Tayninh Province last Friday and Saturday, rose sharply last week.
The spot rate on the British pound dropped 11 points to $2.7915 in fairly busy trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The decline largely reflected weekend considerations.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 10 Tom Cahill, Army's "interim" football coach, lost the qualifying adjective today when he was rewarded with a contract for the 1967 season. The announcement was read to the cadet corps at noon mess, and it touched off a tremendous ovation for the man who has guided Army to its most suc- cessful season since 1963.
Frank D. O'Connor, back at his desk as president of the City Council, talked about the election yesterday with more anger than he displayed during his long campaign for Governor.
The young wife of a 34-yearold former Park Avenue executive now serving a prison sentence of 30 years to life for the murder of his bookmaker won court permission yesterday to resume her maiden name.
The Soviet Union yielded yesterday on a major international chess controversy with the United States, and as a result the American team moved into first place in the 17th Chess Olympics in Havana.
FLORENCE, Italy, Nov. 10 Ermenegildo Cardinal Florit, Archbishop of Florence, splashed through muddy streets today and rode in an amphibious vehicle to inspect flood damage and relief operations.
The Maytag Company, a Newton, Iowa, producer of washing machines, announced yesterday the election of Horace L. Hahn as a director.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 10 (AP) Andras Balczo, a 28-year-old mechanic, retained his individual title today and led Hungary to a second straight team victory in the world modern pentathlon championships.
Although the city's water reserves rose 200 million gallons yesterday, the total was 6 per cent below normal for the date, but nearly double the drought-shrivelled figure of last year.

Florence and Venice, in their different ways, are the most precious jewels in Italy's crown. The storms and floods that have been devastating much of central and northern Italy have no precedent in recorded history, and it was a tragic coincidence that these two cities should have been the chief sufferers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara has written Dean John U. Monro of Harvard University that an incident of rude behavior by a group of Harvard students Monday "should not be a basis for curbing dissent...."

The old Metropolitan Opera House if the law permits could be prepared to open within weeks at a cost of $100,000 to $300,000, according to those trying to save it. But if the building is left unprotected over the winter, it may take $1-million.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 10 Britain faces tough but not insoluble problems in her new efforts to join the Common Market.
With Tuesday's election out of the way, City Hall returned yesterday to normal business and some of the business was the announcement of new salary increases for public officials.
The Defense Department is still drawing on classical sources to name its missiles, leaning more to the Greek than the Latin.

IT probably was more coincidence than design that Election Day was chosen for the announcement of the voting for the most valuable player in the American League. This was one poll that was utterly devoid of the element of surprise. Frank Robinson of the Baltimore Orioles was swept into office by a landslide, the unanimous choice of a special committee from the Baseball Writers Association, two electors from each city.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Net farm income next year may drop as much as 5 per cent from the estimated total for 1966 of $16.2-billion, the Department of Agriculture predicted today.
A HUGE, hulking cluster of polyethylene containers, as strange and brooding as a deserted city on the moon, stood in the lobby of the Pepsi-Cola building at 500 Park Avenue (59th Street).

SHORT STORIES are collected all the time, short novels rarely. "The World of Modern Fiction' brings together both forms in what must be called a pivotal collection of the most excellent and representative serious short fiction written in the last 25 years.

DAUTIENG, South Vietnam, Nov. 10 When they tried to convince the Rev. Michael J. Quealy that he should not go forward to a jungle battleground where American troops were under heavy attack from the Vietcong, he replied, "My place is with them."

FLORENCE, Nov. 10 (Reuters) The Italian Broadcasting Company announced today that Mrs. John F. Kennedy would head an American committee of an international appeal to restore Florence's damaged art works.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10 California's top Democratic survivors of Tuesday's electoral whirlwind hastened today to proffer olive branches of cooperation to the incoming Reagan administration.

The United States, a latecomer among maritime nations employing modern concepts in the fishing industry, will help a newly formed trawler company build two of the most up-todate fishing vessels in the world.
TEL AVIV, Nov. 10--Nine Israeli Arabs from a village near the Jordanian border were held today as suspected members of a ring spying for Jordan.
MONTVILLE, N.J., Nov. 10 (AP) An Erie-Lackawanna Railroad freight train was derailed here tonight on an overpass above Route 202 between Boonton and Lincoln Park. There were no injuries.

PARIS The autumnal vista from the Elysee Palace must seem especially agreeable these days to its present tenant, Charles de Gaulle. The general has always advocated movement, whether in warfare or politics, and these days the movement is going his way.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) Secretary of State Dean Rusk named today a 19-man advisory panel on East Asian and Pacific affairs headed by Prof. Edwin O. Reischauer of Harvard, former Ambassador to Japan.

Calls for an immediate rebuilding of the Democratic party in New York State rose from many quarters yesterday as Democratic leaders turning from an appraisal of Tuesday's stunning defeat in the governorship race, agreed the party must project sharper images on basic issues.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) The Pentagon announced that it plans to divert some of its multimillion-dollar trucking business in this country to farm cooperatives, which can do the job cheaper.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 People with low incomes who are trying to run a business with insufficient capital or who would like to start a business will find a sympathetic listener and lender in Bernard L. Boutin.

TOKYO, Nov. 10 George Knudson of Canada led a wholesale assault on par today as the annual Canada Cup golf tournament opened on the Yomiuri Country Club course, where the ingenious Japanese had treated brown patches in the fairways with green dye to cover up the ravages of approaching winter.
The New York County American Legion will begin at 10 A.M. to march from 39th Street down Fifth Avenue to Madison Square Park at 24th Street.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 10 (AP) A witness for Samuel H. Sheppard said today that unidentified blood had been found at the scene of Mrs. Marilyn Sheppard's murder in 1954. He also testified that her killer was left-handed, using "something like a baseball swing" in the bludgeon slaying.
Frank Wille, the New York State Superintendent of Banks, ordered yesterday the 14 foreign bank branches that do business in New York to take special precautions...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) The Office of Federal Contract Compliance reported today the first refusal of a company to supply employment information in connection with a check on possible racial discrimination.

William F. McKee, Administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency, has advised the Port of New York Authority that his agency "has no plans under consideration" that would move international flights from Kennedy International Airport.

The president of City College charged yesterday that a sitin demonstration that began at noon in the college's administration building was being used by a small group of "Communist" students to "take over the college" and "reduce it to anarchy."

ATLANTA, Nov. 10 (UPI) Tornadoes, gales and pounding thunderstorms raked the heart of the southland today, knocking down trees and power poles and shearing roofs from buildings. Only one injury was reported.

Harris L. Wofford Jr., the 40year-old associate director of the Peace Corps, has been named president of the State University of New York's new liberal arts college that will be situated at Old Westbury, L.I.

LISBON, Nov. 10--A group of 118 Portuguese of Socialist, Christian Democratic and Liberal views has demanded the dismissal of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, the dissolution of the National Assembly and the establishment of a government of national union.

JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Nov. 10 Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara said today there was "considerable evidence" that the Soviet Union was building and deploying an anti-ballis- tic missile system, probably requiring an increase in the United States' offensive capacity.

BOSTON, Nov. 10 (UPI)-- The Boston Bruins snapped the Toronto Maple Leafs' seven-game unbeaten streak behind the goaltending of Gary Cheevers tonight, scoring a 4-0 victory in a National Hockey League game.

LONDON, Nov. 10 The chairman of the British Broadcasting Corporation, Lord Normanbrook, offered today to provide entertainment "including 'pop' most of the hours of the day" when the pirate stations are "driven off the air by legislation."

Miss Susan Barbara Fillin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Fillin of Rockville Centre, L.I., was married yesterday to Jen Yeh, son of Prof. and Mrs. Chai Yeh of Ann Arbor, Mich. State Supreme Court Justice Samuel M. Gold performed the ceremony in his chambers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Further signs of a slowdown in the business boom were disclosed today in Commerce Department reports on corporate profits, the gross national product and retail sales.

Henry H. Fowler, Secretary of the Treasury, announced yesterday the appointment of Daniel J. Haughton as chairman of the United States Payroll Savings Committee for 1967. Mr. Haughton is president of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and a former regional chairman of the committee.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 North Atlantic Treaty sources indicated today that Britain would postpone indefinitely her suggested troop cuts in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 "Is that all you rely on?" That was the incredulous response of Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan Jr. today to the State of Georgia's justification for having denied Julian Bond the Negro pacifist, his seat in the State Legislature.

LONDON, Nov. 10 A young peer received an everso-polite brushoff today from the House of Lords for suggesting that London's traffic congestion would be relieved if Queen Elizabeth II moved her garden parties, each of which is attended by over 7,000 guests, from Buckingham Palace to Windsor Castle, 25 miles west of here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10-- Secretary Robert C. Weaver of the Department of Housing and Urban Development predicted today that the next Congress would adequately finance the controversial rent supplement and model cities programs.

ATLANTA, Nov. 10 (UPI) The managers of WSB Television and WSB Radio said today that they would complain to the National Broadcasting Company about the network's early and erroneous election projection of Lester G. Maddox as the new Governor of Georgia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Attacking the "twilight budgetary zone" occupied by about 75 separate Government credit programs, a member of the Federal Reserve Board added his voice tonight to the call for central control of Government borrowing.
