WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Stuart T. Saunders, chairman of the Pennsylvania Railroad, agreed today to appear on Wednesday at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing for questioning only after being told that a subpoena would be issued by the commission at the request of the Norfolk Western Railway.
PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 10 (AP) Lunar Orbiter 2 joined the Soviet Luna 12 in moon orbit today, but United States space agency scientists said there was no danger of collision or radio interference.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 10 Clark J. Lawrence, a retired architect who practiced in New York, New Haven, Chicago and Palm Beach, died yesterday of a heart attack in New York. He was 77 years old and lived at Castle Hill, Cobham, Va.
CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Nov. 10 Miss Lydia Merritt and Byron P. Fink 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fink Jr. of Braintree, have made plans to marry next February.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy has written a sharp criticism of television programing for the forthcoming issue of The Viewer magazine.

THE one truly distressing thing about "Viet Rock," the antiwar pageant that opened at the Off Broadway Martinique last night, is that it is never aware for one moment that it is behaving precisely as mindlessly as the conduct it means to mock.

Women partners in brokerage firms are still rare enough for the New York Stock Exchange to take note of them. Yesterday the Big Board announced that Miss Sheila Baird, 29 years old, had become the 50th woman partner or voting stockholder of a member firm. She also is one of the youngest.

"Blitzstein!," a program culled from the output of the late Marc Blitzstein, composer and author, will open Nov. 30 at the Provincetown Playhouse, 133 Macdougal Street. Mira Gilbert and Norman Friesen will be the only performers. Peter Basquin will accompany them on the piano.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 10 Rutgers University celebrated its 200th birthday today with 73 parties throughout the world and with the announcement of plans to plant or drop the university flag on famous peaks in four continents.
Nearly all sectors of the London Stock Exchange moved ahead yesterday, aided by the upturn in stocks Wednesday on Wall Street.
HOUSTON, Nov. 10--Cleveland Williams never had much business sense.

The Grand Council of Columbia Associations demanded yesterday that Governor Rockefeller and the State Human Rights Commission start investigations into the refusal of the Ulster County Welfare Commissioner to permit a brunet Italian-American couple to adopt a fourand-half-year-old blond child.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 10 Prime Minister Wilson's statement today on British membership in the common market was gen- erally received in market circles as inadequate but better than continued silence.

ROME, Nov. 10 (AP) A Rome court today convicted Baroness Afdera Franchetti, former wife of the American actor Henry Fonda, of having tried to smuggle marijuana into Italy. It gave her a suspended sentence of eight months.

LA JOLLA, Calif., Nov. 10 Sitting in Dr. Jonas Salk's office at the Salk Institute for Biological Studies, one looks out of tall windows at the Pacific Ocean rippling and tumbling toward the curving coast. The view is tranquil and spectacular, and Dr. Salk, developer of the Salk anti-polio vaccine, fully ...

BALTIMORE, Nov. 10 (AP) Senator Mike Mansfield, of Montana, called today on the United Nations Security Council to hold a "cards-on-the-table" session on the Vietnam war with all interested parties invited, including Communist China, North Vietnam and the Vietcong as well as South Vietnam.

DETROIT, Nov. 10 (UPI) Alex Delvecchio scored two goals and Roger Crozier posted his second straight shutout tonight as the Detroit Red Wings beat the Chicago Black Hawks 3-0, in a National Hockey League game.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Ray C. Bliss, the Republican National Chairman, today described his party's victories in Tuesday's elections as a "sweep in depth" that reached young people, Negroes, big city dwellers labor and other traditional sources of Democratic strength.
Democratic control of next year's State Constitutional Convention seemed certain last night, on the basis of unofficial returns from Tuesday's election of 186 delegates.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) The Treasury Department said today it would seek to raise $1.2-billion in cash Nov. 17 through an auction of bills maturing next March, April and May.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10 (AP) Barry Goldwater, the Republican nominee for President in 1964, listed five possible Republican Presidential candidates for 1968 today.
The American Broadcasting Company has received thousands of protests from persons who are fighting mad because the Fighting Irish will not be televised in their home areas on Nov. 19.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 102.7 on Wednesday from 102.4 on Monday.

Two window washers clung to a tilted scaffold eight stories above West 52d Street for 15 minutes yesterday morning before firemen clambered up a towering aerial ladder and picked them off their perch.
The trend toward merger and acquisition in the New York banking community gained fresh impetus yesterday with two important announcements:
NASSAU, the Bahamas, Nov. 10 (AP) Senator and Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy and three friends have arrived here for a brief post-election vacation.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 10 Princeton has made the descent from Cloud Nine on which it has been floating since its stunning football victory over Harvard, to the hard reality of its task of stopping one of the best Ivy League passers in its meeting with Yale in the Bowl at New Haven Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Federal mediators called today for suspension of a West Coast shipyard strike in the interest of national defense and asked negotiators to come here to resume bargaining on a new contract.

NEWARK, Nov. 10 Today Newark's Mayor, Hugh J. Addonizio, proclaimed "Garden State Ballet Day in Newark." Tonight there was a benefit performance at Newark's Symphony Hall, a champagne reception and what is called a "Swan Lake Ball" at the Essex House Hotel.
The Ford Motor Company announced executive changes yesterday in which two of its key vice presidents exchanged jobs.
ALBANY, Nov. 10 William S. Hults, the State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles since 1959, has submitted his resignation to Governor Rockefeller effective Dec. 31, a spokesman said today.

"There are some who are not sure you can sell a college like you can a breakfast cereal," said Thomas W. DeMint, of the J. Walter Thompson Chicago office. But that's what he and his alma mater are trying to do in the current issue of Time Magazine.

CITING a study to the effect that a nonsmoker in New York City inhales pollutants equivalent to two packages of cigarettes a day, Harris Upham reviews favorably the prospects of companies in the antipollution business.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 10 The world's first nuclear submarine, the Nautilus, rammed the aircraft carrier Essex while running submerged off the North Carolina coast today. One crewman was slightly injured. The Navy said that the mishap occurred.
LONDON, Nov. 10 Prime Minister Wilson today declared Britain's "clear intention and determination" to become a member of the six-nation European Common Market.
The impression that Federal Reserve policy may have shifted subtly in the direction of easier money gained ground yesterday with the publication of the latest Federal Reserve report.
The 23d annual Brick Presbyterian Church Christmas Fair will open early Thursday evening at Watson Hall of the church, at Park Avenue and 91st Street, and continue through Friday afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 Larry E. Gubb, former board chairman of the Philco Corporation, now Philco-Ford, died today at his home in suburban Rydal. He was 74 years old. Mr. Gubb was born in Batavia, N.Y., and was graduated from Cornell University in 1916.

IRVINGTON, N.Y., Nov. 10 Miss Alexandra Cleland Marshall and Timothy Lee Buxton will be married Dec. 30. Mr. and Mrs. William B. Marshall have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Dr. and Mrs. C. Lee Buxton of New York and New Haven.

The New York region of the Women's Division of the American Technion Society is sponsoring an art tour Tuesday afternoon. Mrs. Harold Korzenik, president of the region, is chairman of the tour, which will visit the homes of five collectors: Mrs. Albert A. List, Mrs. Ben Heller, Larry Aldrich, Col. Samuel Berger and Mrs. Allen D. Emil.
TREASURE ISLAND, Calif., Nov. 10 Three admirals and six captains recessed today until Monday their deliberations on the fate of Capt. Archie C. Kuntze, who is charged with misconduct in Saigon.

AMID the welcome and generally justified enthu- siasm surrounding the New York Knickerbockers, some of their deficiencies have been minimized or completely overlooked. The last two games, however, laid bare their greatest weakness with inescapable clarity.
DUBLIN, Nov. 10 The Dail Eireann today elected Jack Lynch as head of the Irish Government by a 71-to64 vote.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) For the second time in six weeks the Soviet Union has launched secretly a spacecraft that shattered into many parts.
GEOFFREY BEENE seems to work best under a handicap.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10 Tom Kennedy, the new quarterback, officially went on the New York Giants' roster today, and Francis Peay, the injured offensive tackle, went off. Kennedy is the 25-year-old Los Angeles native son purchased on Monday from the Brooklyn Dodgers ...

PEKING, Nov. 10 Mao Tsetung, the architect of China's Communist revolution and a man usually considered unsentimental, appeared to be deeply moved today as he stood on the gilded vermilion Gate of Heavenly Peace and watched a stream of 600,000 of his nation's 700 million people pass, half of them in trucks.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Nov. 10 President Johnson, although unhappy at Democratic losses, accepted with philosophical resignation today the large Republican gains in the midterm elections Tuesday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 Delegates to the general conference of the Methodist Church have apparently overcome the obstacles that racial segregation within the denomination had posed to its pending merger with the Evangelical United Brethren Church.
A 12-story office building at 50 Pine Street was sold for $500,000 yesterday to the Sylvan Lawrence Company at the monthly auction of city-owned property conducted by the Department of Real Estate.
The Board of Elections said yesterday that official tabulations of the four principal parties and two minority parties in last Tuesday's elections here would be announced in the week of Nov. 20.

A forthcoming Federal program to try to provide jobs for Negroes in the South and thus hold down the Negro migration northward was disclosed here yesterday by Eugene P. Foley, formerly Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Economic Development and now a Federal consultant.

Mayor Lindsay disavowed yesterday any intention to seek advancement to a higher political office in 1968. He pledged again to serve his full four years as Mayor to "do the best job I can for the people of the City of New York."

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10 (UPI) A Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company blimp, one of two helium-filled dirigibles still airborne in the United States, plunged into power lines near Wilmington tonight, causing a power blackout over an area of several blocks.

North American Aviation, Inc., was one of the few aircraft companies to show increased sales and earnings over the previous year. The annual statement issued yesterday by the El Segundo, Calif., company also showed a substantial order backlog.
Veterans Day, a tribute to those who have served their country in times of crises, ...

The Freedom National Bank announced yesterday it would offer 30,000 shares of new common stock on a pro rata basis to its stockholders of record Oct. 29. Holders will be able to purchase one new share at $28 for each two shares held.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission is going to examine the possibility of making the rental of electronic computers subject to Government regulation.

DAUTIENG, South Vietnam, Nov. 10 Two generals of the United States Army's First Infantry Division escaped unhurt in separate helicopter accidents today while directing more than 14,000 American troops pursuing elements of the elite Ninth Vietcong Division.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Nov. 10 Svante Magnus Swenson, board chairman of the Swenson Land and Cattle Company, Inc., which breeds Hereford cattle in Texas, died today in his home here at 6 Welsh Road after a short illness. He was 76 years old.

YONKERS, Nov. 9 Corydon Bushnell Dunham of 97 Hudson Terrace, senior partner in Dunham, O'Brien Evans, lawyers at 15 William Street in New York, died of a stroke yesterday at the Kingston City Hospital.
WASHINGTON, Nov, 10 Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge will return to the United States from Saigon early in December for several weeks of home leave, State Department sources said tonight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 The new Association of Chicago Priests announced today that the Most Rev. John Patrick Cody, Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago, had agreed to establish a "dialogue" with it on such questions as reassignment and retirement age.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 10 Gov. George C. Wallace predicted today that his third party movement would become the largest in the nation's history, larger even than Theodore Roosevelt's Bull Moose party.
Potato futures have been pos- ing an interesting question recently. Has their recent downward trend discounted an increase in production?
Sizing up Republican Presidential hopefuls yesterday, Senator Jacob K. Javits likened Richard M. Nixon to an old race horse that has been on the track too long.

THE Metropolitan Opera National Company, now in its second year, unveiled its current troupe for the first time in the New York area Thursday night with a performance of "La Boheme" at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 (AP) The Philadelphia 76ers outscored the Chicago Bulls by a 20-1 margin in a 5-minute stretch of the second-period tonight and then used Wilt Chamberlain's 37 points for a 126-113 victory.
An afternoon recovery move overcame earlier weakness in the stock market yesterday and prices finished slightly higher on average.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 11 (AP) The Daily Freeman, Kingston, N.Y., an evening newspaper of more than 18,000 circulation, was purchased by Mid-Hudson Publishing, Inc., which has offices here, it was announced today.
Protestants in the United States and Canada contributed more than $3.3-billion last year to 44 denominations a record high.

Rudolph P. Neptun, vice president in charge of field sales of the S. B. Penick Co., manufacturers of pharmaceutical and botanical drugs, chemicals and other products, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at the Statler Hilton Hotel in Los Angeles.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 (AP) A. Harvard University professor of economics believes that the key problem in world survival will be the distribution of the world's wealth, not population control.

LYONEL FEININGER (1871-1956) was an artist who divided his life between two countries the United States, where he was born and where he lived out his last years, and Germany, where he spent the most fateful years of his artistic development.
Northwest Airlines announced yesterday it had placed an order with the Boeing Ccmpany for 10 747 superjets and six 707320 fan jets.

BURLINGAME, Calif., Nov. 11 Eddie Erdelatz, who brought the United States Naval Academy some of its finest moments on the football field during nine stormy seasons as head coach, died last night at Peninsula Hospital. Mr. Erdelatz, who was 53 years old, had been operated on for stomach cancer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 The Federal Reserve System is considering fundamental changes in the way it operates its discount window one of the devices it uses for influencing the course of the economy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI) Tentative agreement was reached tonight to end the 11-day strike against the Westington Electric Corporation.
The recent floods at Florence, Italy, are expected to delay shipments of fashion apparel to American stores. Some buying trips to the area will be postponed.
When Charles Potyala talks to the miniskirted waitresses at Churchill's, a neighborhood bar in Manhattan's chic East Seventies, he usually talks tough.

LONDON, Nov. 11 Sir Evelyn Wrench, founder of the English-Speaking Union, died here today. He was 84 years old. In furtherance of the British Empire and, subsequently, of Commonwealth unity and Anglo-American cooperation, Sir Evelyn founded the Overseas League in 1910, the EnglishSpeaking Union of the Commonwealth in 1918, the EnglishSpeaking Union of the United States in 1920 and, finally, the All Peoples' Association in 1929.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 The use of laboratory-grown human cells in the production of viruses for vaccines has several advantages over current methods, a scientist said here today.
STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 11 Paul Schwartz, a former deputy sheriff here, died yesterday at a local convalescent hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 838 Newfield Avenue.
A 21-year-old factory worker pleaded guilty yesterday to second-degree murder in the slaying of Arthur F. Collins, who was stabbed in a subway last year as his wife watched.
The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service has just concluded what industry sources believe to be the largest charter of commercial tonnage in a bloc in the service's history.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Walter P. Reuther's relations with George Meany appear to have taken another bad turn in a development that may create a major strain within the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

A number of alleged underworld figures have suddenly developed acute illnesses, United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau reported yesterday. But he diagnosed most of the illnesses as designed to frustrate a Federal grand jury investigation of the Mafia.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 11 The last of the Gemini astronauts raced into orbit today and, despite a balky radar unit, steered their spacecraft to a successful rendezvous and linkup with an Agena target vehicle.
BOTH the New York Jets and the New York Giants will be on display on television tomorrow in a nonconflicting span of almost six hours.

MOSCOW, Nov. 11 (Reuters) Prof. Lev A. Zilber, a leading virologist who devoted his life to studying the causes of plague, cholera, smallpox, and cancer, died yesterday at the age of 72, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.
LONDON, Nov. 11 Prime Minister Smith's statement that he felt that the time had arrived for "man-to-man" talks, was regarded by informed sources here as a propaganda gesture.
The nation's past and present fighting men were honored yesterday at parades and wreathlaying ceremonies in the annual observance of Veterans Day.

ABOUT 250 people displayed the stuff their dreams are made of Thursday night at the Watson Keep Blairs' "Come as Your Favorite Dream" party. Judging from the costumes, nightmares are quite prevalent among the affluent these days.
MIAMI, Nov. 11 (UPI)--Bill Miller's passing paced Miami to a 38-14 victory over Pitt tonight in the Orange Bowl.
The Consolidation Coal Company has announced the appointment of John L. Cowan as a vice president. Mr. Cowan was formerly an assistant vice president of the First National City Bank of New York.

Mrs. Sylvia Harris Of 150 East 69th Street, who with her husband, Joseph, was an officer in the Broadway producing company of Fryer, Carr Harris, Inc., which staged "Mame" and "Sweet Charity," died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. She was 60 years old.
BONN, Nov. 11 Kurt Georg Kiesinger, the Christian Democratic candidate to replace Chancellor Ludwig Erhard, said today that he had been completely exonerated by Allied

HONG KONG, Nov. 11--A Chinese Communist newspaper in Hong Kong has made an oblique attack on Premier Chou En-lai. Some analysts here interpreted it to mean that he had been attempting to impose a restraining influence on the Red Guards.
Dr. Wallace P. Cohoe, a consulting chemist and former president of the Society of Chemical Industry, died Thursday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived at 131 East 69th Street.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 11 (AP) A number of topranking military officers, including members of the National Guard headquarters garrison, have been arrested in connection with a frustrated military uprising last month, it was disclosed today.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 Dr. Joseph B. Wolffe, cardiologist and founder of the Wolffe Hospital here, died in Istanbul, Turkey, last night while on a world trip with his wife. He was 70 years old.
STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 11 George Athol VanBrunt of Flushing, Queens, an authority on electric power generating and transmission equipment, died today at Stamford Hospital. He was 81 years old.
ATLANTA, Nov. 11 A three-judge Federal court said here today that it held "a strong view" that it would not allow the Georgia Legislature to choose the state's next Governor.

The political affiliations of students who participated in a sit-in demonstration at City College this week are irrelevant to their demands for a greater voice in administrative decisions, the college's president said yesterday.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., NOV. 11 Wheatley Stable's Successor was installed today as the 8-5 favorite despite bad habits when he starts running for the Garden State Stakes at Garden State Park tomorrow.

WARSAW, Nov. 11 (Reuters) Poland adopted today a new five-year plan designed to raise industrial production by more than 40 per cent by 1970 and increase the flow of foodstuffs and consumer goods. The plan was approved after a three-day session of the National Assembly.
Leaders of two of the largest Jewish organizations in the United States denounced yesterday the nomination of a former Nazi as Chancellor of West Germany.

Leaders of the Cuban exiles who laid siege to the Playboy Club here last Sunday to protest a magazine article on alleged immoral practices in Cuba said yesterday they were not satisfied with a letter they had received from the author. They demanded an apology from the publisher.

George Spelvin, bit actor has finally made it. His activities merit a 500 word biography in the "Biographical Encyclopaedia Who's Who of The American Theater," published this year by James H. Heineman, Inc. No other theater "Who's Who" acknowledges his existence.

United States shipbuilders face a growing trend toward mass production of ships from a basic design--Donald A. Holden, president-elect of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers said yesterday.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 11 (UPI) There was a Republican meeting today at the San Juan International Airport, quite by coincidence.
TORONTO, Nov. 11 (Canadian Press) Commandant William Ringrose of Ireland won the Welcome Stakes tonight in the international horse show at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show.

Little M. Farm's Impressive was the morning-line favorite for the 27th running of the $57,700 Vosburgh Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday, but J. Graham Brown's Gallant Romeo was the "people's choice" and it was the public that proved prescient.

The re-election of all seven of the freshman Democrats from New York who were first sent to the House of Representatives from suburban and upstate districts in the anti-Goldwater landslide of two years ago is remarkable because it runs counter to the national trend, in which Republicans gained 47 House seats.

The Northern States Power Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a gain of 11.8 per cent in third quarter net income to $7,605,515, or 40 cents a share, from $6,404,578, or 33 cents a share, a year earlier. This was traced mainly to an unusually hot summer which increased kilowatt-hour sales by 16.2 per cent over the 1965 period.
A group of civil rights lawyers said yesterday they would begin a fight to establish the right of an indigent person accused of murder to choose his own lawyer.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 11 In the gallery of the usually staid Westchester Art Society tonight, belly dancers and an amused public cavorted amid tents of plastic displaying Ritz cracker earrings, plasticized bagels and brightly colored plastic pillows and shopping bags.
MILWAUKEE, Nov.11 (UPI) Michael Lee Herrington, a 23year-old tool and die maker, was arrested today and charged with the knife slayings of two Milwaukee girls.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Nov. 11 William J. Buff Jr., who had served in the diplomatic service as a liaison officer between this country and the Netherlands from 1939 to 1950, died here today at the age of 57.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 11 (Reuters) Shareholders of Intra Bank, one of the Middle East's biggest commercial banks, decided at a meeting tonight that the bank should resume operations.
MEADVILLE, Pa., Nov. 11 (AP) Widowed twice by the Vietnam war, her family fatherless for the second time, Mrs. Bernard Kistler lay in shock today in a hospital.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 11-- Secretary General Thant has defined and enlarged his differences with United States policy by calling for a final and unconditional cessation of the bombing of North Vietnam.
THERE is a movement towards "new antiques" that spurns even Victorian as too old. If the evidence at Madison Square Garden can be credited, that movement threatens to become a stampede.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Three major steel compaines joined others today in increasing prices on certain grades of stainless steel.
A new wholesaler franchise program to give distributors greater control over their operations was announced yesterday in Washington by the Falstaff Brewing Corporation.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 11 (UPI) The University of Michigan said today that a "confidential" Defense Department report describing the school as "basically for rich white students" should not have been made public.
The London Stock Exchange failed to maintain an initially firm trend yesterday and prices fell to Thursday night's closings.
The rally that started on the American Stock Exchange for lowing Tuesday's elections continued yesterday for the third consecutive session.
PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, Nov. 11 Foul weather threatened today a major part of a $10-million international scientific program to study tomorrow's solar eclipse in this area.
There are some things a middle-aged man can't explain to his children about his part in World War II, for instance.
Refuse collectors had a holiday yesterday, and New Yorkers waiting for a special makeup collection tomorrow were urged to remember that trash cans have "built-in compaction."

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 (AP) The president of the National Broadcasting Company said tonight that the network plans to start a new weekly television program early next year keyed to live reports from news correspondents in Europe and Asia.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 11 The General Assembly elected 5 new nonpermanent members to the 15-member Security Council today in accordance with the established formula for maintaining geographical distribution.
BONN, Nov. 11 The leader of West Germany's extreme right-wing National Democratic party has sent a letter to Bonn's foreign press corps denying that he or his party is Nazi or Nazi-influenced.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 11 (Reuters) Gerhard Bohne, an alleged Nazi war criminal, was flown to West Germany tonight to answer charges of having murdered 15,000 mentally and physically disabled people during World War II.

Mrs. Helene Ambrose Greaza, a stage actress and the wife of Walter N. Greaza, also a stage and screen performer, died yesterday after a long illness at her home, 105-28 65th Road, Forest Hills, Queens. She was 62 years old.

Molly Picon will withdraw from the musical "Chu Chem" after tonight's performance at the Locust Street Theater in Philadelphia, Henrietta Jacobson will assume Miss Picon's role opposite Menasha Skulnik on Monday.

SRINAGARA, India, Nov. 11 (Reuters) Moslem students burned an effigy of Prime Minister Wilson and copies of the London newspaper. The Times today in protest against a cartoon considered derogatory to the Prophet Mohammed.

For the first time in its history, Fordham University, a Jesuit institution, has a rabbi on its faculty giving a course in Judaism. Seven other Catholic institutions of higher learning in the United States also have placed Jewish spiritual leaders in their departments of theology in the past year.

Alvin Rivera scored two touchdowns and passed for three conversions yesterday to spark Monroe High School to a 36-6 football victory over Alfred E. Smith at Monroe Field. The triumph was Monroe's third against two losses and one tie. Smith has lost all six games this season.
GREENVALE, L.I., Nov. 11 More than 500 Long Island University students demonstrated at the campus here today to protest a proposed increase in tuition.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) The Republicans have taken control of 19 chambers and about 700 seats in state legislatures, apparently gaining most of them as a side effect of their gubernatorial and Congressional election comeback.
STOCKHOLM, Nov. 11 Something almost "un-Swedish" appears to be under way here and gaining momentum.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov, 11 President Sukarno urged closer cooperation today among Southeast Asian nations and renewed his call for a continued fight against "Imperialism."
PARIS, Nov. 11 France honored again today the fading memory of her 1,357,000 sons who died in the 1914-18 war.
TORONTO, Nov. 11 (Canadian Press) The mediator in the Air Canada labor dispute said today that he saw little hope of averting a strike of 5,200 machinists that would shut down the airline Monday.
LONDON, Nov. 11 Prime Minister Wilson's move yesterday toward British membership in the European Common Market received a generally favorable reception here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 (AP) Electricians continued their strike against West Coast shipyards today despite a warning from the Federal Mediation Service that the week-old tie-up "poses a potential danger to the nation's defense needs."

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 11 Miss Carol Janet Cameron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Bryson Cameron of Englewood and North Haven, L.I. was married today to Harry Ramsdell Harwood, son of Mrs. Ramsdell Harwood of Greenwich, Conn., and Bartlett Harwood of Beverly Farms, Mass.
It took the Mamas and the Papas, the pop quartet, a maddeningly long time to get to the stage at Carnegie Hall last night, but it was worth the wait.

HEWLETT BAY PARK, L.I., Nov. 11 Mr. and Mrs. Jacob A. Melnick have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Ann Melnick, to Kenneth James Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Miller of Great Neck. The bride-to-be, a graduate of the Woodmere Academy, is a junior at Hofstra University. Her fiance is a graduate of the University of Vermont. A spring wedding is planned.
JERSEY CITY, Nov. 11 Mayor Thomas J. Whelan said today that a delay in releasing the city's election returns had shaken public faith in the election process.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stowe C. Phelps of New York and Fishers Island N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sophia Yarnall Phelps, to John M. Sturges Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sturges, also of New York and Fishers Island.

MADRID, Nov. 11 (UPI) In a move to ease the still bitter legacy of the Spanish Civil War, Generalissimo Francisco Franco decreed a pardon tonight for all those convicted of political crimes before and during the war.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Nov. 11 (UPI) Superior Court Judge Elvin R. Simmill set Dec. 5 yesterday as the tentative trial date for Dr. Carl A. Coppolino in the 1963 murder of his former neighbor Col. William E. Farber.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 11 For the fifth time in the history of the Washington D.C. International, the strains of "La Marseillaise" rang out today to serenade the winner of the famous $150,000 invitation event on the turf of Laurel Race Course.

The United States Trust Company, a blue-chip Wall Street bank that is one of the nation's leading specialists in personal trust administration, has developed a novel plan to offer its investment management services outside the United States.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 11 Five civil rights workers, including James Forman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, were convicted today in Montgomery Municipal Court of disorderly conduct. The charge involved incidents that occurred just before the Selma-to-Montgomery march in 1965.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 (AP) The University of Pennsylvania said today that it was trying to farm out a controversial and secret $485,000 Air Force contract on chemical and biological warfare.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Sex education is being introduced by mail to 30,000 Job Corpsmen, male and female.

JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Nov. 11 W. Averell Harriman said today he had found some encouraging signs in Vietnam on his recent trip to Asian and European nations, but that Peking and Hanoi apparently still were determined to continue the conflict.

Strong but diplomatic pressures are being exerted to align diverse groups in the city behind a sort of ombudsman to ease the bitterness over the defeat of the Police Depart-... ment's Civilian Complaint Review Board in Tuesday's election.
TORONTO, Nov. 11 Favorable wheat crops around the world are causing Canadians concern over the disposition of this year's record harvest of 844 million bushels.
The Hunter College Concert Bureau, which has been contributing so much of excellence to New York's musical scene, opened another new series last night at the school's Assembly Hall.

Michigan State is heavily favored to beat Indiana today and carry off the Big Ten football championship for the second time in succession preparatory to its meeting next week with Notre Dame in the prospective game of the year.

GEORGE SCHAEFER, producer of the "Hallmark Hall of Fame," accorded "Barefoot in Athens" every consideration last night, but making a viable play out of Maxwell Anderson's study of Socrates is probably a hopeless and certainly a thankless ...

VIENNA, Nov. 11 A new electoral law in Hungary, abolishing single rigid lists of candidates and allowing the voters to choose between several candidates, was enacted by Parliament today, the official Hungarian press agency, M.T.I., reported from Budapest.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 Dr. James Anderson Crabtree, dean of the Graduate School of Public Health at the University of Pittsburgh, died last night at Presbyterian-University Hospital. He had been ill three months. He was 64 years old.

The United States hardly could have done less than to recall for consultations its Ambassador to Guinea after the utterly unjustified abuse heaped on this country by President Sekou Toure and the mobs he incited. There is a good case for doing more.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 The Food and Drug Administration said today that the Kroger Company had recalled its brand of instant dry milk from all 1,400 stores in the country after one batch had been found to be contaminated with Salmonella.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. Nov. 11 (AP) The Rutgers Medical School will operate a new state neuropsychiatric institute to be built on the University Heights campus adjacent to the medical school.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 The State Department called in the Soviet Ambassador today to request information about a large Soviet underground nuclear explosion that may have violated the limited treaty on a test ban.
Assemblyman Stanley Steingut of Brooklyn announced yesterday that he planned to introduce two election-reform bills in the 1967 Legislature.

THE one truly distressing thing about "Viet Rock," the antiwar pageant that opened at the Off Broadway Martinque Thursday night, is that it is never aware for one moment that it is behaving precisely as mindlessly as the conduct it means to mock.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 11 Frank Gullino, assistant concertmaster of the New York Philaharmonic, was soloist tonight with the Ridgewood Symphony Orchestra in its first concert of the season. The concert was given in the Benjamin Franklin Junior High School and was conducted by Arthur H. Christmann.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce said today a poll of 9,964 of its members showed overwhelming support for changing the dates of some holidays so they will occur regularly and uniformly on Mondays. Such changes would create more three-day weekends.

The essential issue in the student sit-in at City College is not Communism but orderly democratic process in academic affairs. The demonstrators are seeking to coerce Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, the college president, into usurping powers that belong to the faculty and the Board of Higher Education all in the name of promoting greater campus democracy.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 11 A pilot from Florida wrote a will in his hotel room here, left a $5 tip for the maid, rented a plane and then crashed it into a friend's backyard here, in an apparent suicide.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Nov. 11 (AP) President and Mrs. Johnson got a telephone call tonight from a former first lady, Mrs. Harry S. Truman, inquiring about the President's health.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) Mohawk Airlines has proposed to the Civil Aeronautics Board a new "weekends unlimited" fare of $25.

TOKYO, Nov. 11 (AP) Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus of the United States held the lead for the team championship today at the end of the third round of the Canada Cup international golf matches, completing 54-holes with a combined total of 406.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 11 Drivers and mechanics of the Hempstead Bus Corporation voted today to end a 42-day strike of the line. The vote was 76 to 15.
A civilian employe of the Army was indicted yesterday on charges of accepting money and liquor to help men get into the Army's Reserve program instead of being drafted.
DEER PARK, L.I., Nov. 11 The Suffolk Sun, a new morning newspaper for eastern Long Island, is about to publish its first edition with a picket line at the front door.
WIDELY hailed prospects for runaway color-tele vision set sales in 1967 were challenged several times this week, and the stocks of set makers reacted accordingly.
LONDON, Nov. 11 Steel industry leaders are worried by increasing Soviet steel exports to Britain and other parts of Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 The Justice Department reported today that at least 10 Negroes were elected to public office Tuesday in rural areas of the Deep South. With very few exceptions, Negroes have not won offices there since Reconstruction.

MORE than 13 years ago, on the eve of his inau guration as president of the City College of New York, Dr. Buell Gordon Gallagher assessed his task and said: "The biggest job of all, I think, is to find some means of giving each student a share in running the college
FURNITURE collectors old hands or tyros will find an emphasis on 18th-century Americana at the six-day States Antiques Show, opening Monday at the Westchester County Center in White Plains.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 11 (UPI) The nation's top-ranking Air Force general said today that development of an "effective" antimissile system by a potential enemy could lead to nuclear war.

The question of Communist China's entry into the United Nations is coming up for its annual trial, probably the week after, next. As usual, the issue is being confused by emotions, guesswork and some old-fashioned thinking about the cold war.

LONDON, Nov. 11 France and Britain may not be getting along too well these days, but their current political differences have not affected gastronomic relations between the two old allies. This was handsomely illustrated at the swank Mayfair restaurant, the Diplomat, last night as diners happily swigged and swallowed their way through a menu containing 20 specialties of Paris's famous Grand Vefour restaurant.
The American Jewish Congress offered its legal services yesterday in the fight over the rejection of an upstate ItalianAmerican couple's application to adopt their blonde foster child
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 11 Referring to a Vietcong tear-gas attack on a First Division patrol last night, spokesmen said today they believed this was the first time the Vietcong has used gas.

Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, former president of the American Red Cross, yesterday was elected chairman of the English-Speaking Union of the United States, succeeding former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, who was named an honorary chairman.

BONN, Nov. 11 (AP) John T. Connor, Secretary of Commerce, said today that the United States was moving "slowly but deliberately" toward separating trade from politics in dealing with Communist countries.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 11 Jim Hall of Midland, Tex., raised his one-lap record for the three-mile Stardust Raceway today to 114.29 miles an hour. Hall wheeled his all-white Chevrolet-Chaparral on the course 30 minutes after the start of qualifying runs for Sunday's 210-mile final in the Canadian-American Challenge cup series for sports cars.

Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor" will be given its first Metropolitan performance of the season Monday, Dec. 12, when the company raises its ticket prices. Joan Sutherland will sing the title role, and her husband, Richard Bonynge, will make his Met debut as conductor.

LITCHFIELD, Conn., Nov. 11 Mrs. Louise Hitchman Young and Ian Heriot Dunn, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Howard Frederic Dunn were married tonight in the chapel of St. Michael's Episcopal Church by the bridegroom's father. The bride is the daughter of Mr, and Mrs. William Hitchman 3d of Royal Oak, Mich.

JOGJAKARTA, Indonesia Prof. Setiadji Sastroamidjojo spends most of his time with cows. The choice would be understandable if the 40-year-old educator were an agronomist, but he is on the faculty of physics at Gadja Mada University here.

Japan Air Lines will begin its Tokyo-to-New York service today. A DC-8 jet carrying an official party of 60 is due to arrive at the United Air Lines terminal at Kennedy International Airport at 3 p.m. The party will be met by Commissioner John S. Palmer, the city's official greeter.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 11 J. Duke Broomhall, New York manager of Broomhall's Corn Trade News, a daily grain trade newspaper published in Liverpool, England, died today of a heart attack at his home at 43 Long Drive here. He was 78 years old. His office was at 27 Whitehall Street, New York City.
ROME, Nov. 11 (AP) The head of the Vatican press office indicated today that Pope Paul VI would call for another Christmas cease-fire in Vietnam.

FLORENCE, Nov. 11 (AP) Prosecutor Nicola Serra announced tonight that he had or dered an investigation to learn whether the Florence flood disaster was worsened by improper operation of a dam on the Arno River.
HOMER, Mich., Nov. 11 (UPI) A freight train derailed today and rammed an oil storage tank, unleashing a poisonous World War I trench gas.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 11, Eugene R. Black, President Johnson's special adviser on Southeast Asian economic and social development, said today that he had told Indonesian leaders that they could "rely upon friendly United States support in their efforts to achieve goals they are setting for themselves."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 11 Political unrest is building up again in South Vietnam after several months of relative tranquility.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 11 (AP) The little boy of 12 years ago, whose mother was murdered in the bedroom next to his, stepped forward today to answer questions in the Samuel H. Sheppard murder case.
Safeway Stores, Inc., the retail food chain, announced yesterday in Oakland, Calif., the election of Quentin Reynolds as president.
chair to read in. The back is too high and too straight, which makes for good posture but positively inhibits curling up with a good book.

This week has seen two impressive demonstrations of United States space capabilities. First, Lunar Orbiter 2 was maneuvered into position to take the desired pictures of the moon's surface. Then yesterday's precision launchings of Gemini 12 and its Agena target vehicle began the final experiment in the highly productive Gemini series.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 Sears, Roebuck Co. moved today into the North Michigan Avenue area, opening an elegant art gallery, among Chicago's most exclusive shops, a world away from the company's us- ...
NANTUCKET, Mass., Nov. 11 -- An Air Force radar picket plane crashed and exploded in the Atlantic Ocean today. All 19 crewmen aboard were presumed dead.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 11 William A. Hanley, 79 years old, a director and retired vice president in charge of engineering for Eli Lilly and Co., died yesterday at Indianapolis Methodist Hospital.

KENNETH KING, who gave a sort of performance called "m-o-o-n-b-r-a-i-n" at the Gate Theater late Thursday night stands, with all respect, almost more in need of analysis than criticism. Basically, he is a dancer who has decided that the most valuable form of dance he can offer is non-dance. And this, as foolish as it sounds, is perhaps not as stupid as it seems.

The Sunbeam Corporation, a maker of household appliances, announced yesterday that net income rose to $4,692,000, or 63 cents a share, for the second quarter ended Sept. 30 from $4,199,000, or 57 cents a share, in the 1965 quarter.

BOSTON, Nov. 11 The New York Knickerbockers battled the Boston Celtics right down to the last two minutes tonight before bowing to what seems to be the inevitable and losing, 111-106, before a capacity crowd of 13,909 at the Boston Garden.
Concierges from European hotels were milling around Manhattan hotel lobbies yesterday, looking in vain for a concierge.
TORONTO, Nov. 11 Canadian bankers are split over whether United States and other foreign banks should be permitted to open bank agencie in Canada.
Directors of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steel producer, authorized here yesterday a special year-end dividend of 30 cents a common share.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 11 The town of Pound Ridge, a rural community of 2,962 residents in northern Westchester County, was held responsible by a State Supreme Court jury here last night for highway ice and snow that caused a collision of two cars.
WALLOPS ISLAND, Va., Nov. 11 (UPI) The space agency today reported a possible first in space recovery.
Miss Lenore Veit, daughter of Mr. and Mrs, Ivan Veit of 70 East 10th Street, was married yesterday to Thomas Clifford Gale, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Gale of Scottsdale, Ariz.

A new class in flower-arranging will begin Tuesday at the Greenwich House Pottery School, 16 Jones Street. Emphasis will be on Japanese techniques, and instructions will cover preparation of plant material and selection of containers.

DAUTIENG, South Vietnam, Saturday, Nov. 12 Enemy soldiers fired about 200 mortar shells, into the field headquarters of the United States First Infantry Division here in two attacks late last night and early this morning.
Soybean traders took heart yesterday and prices took off. The reason was a more encouraging Government crop report than had been expected.
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 17.5 per cent in production for the week ended Nov. 6, compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week.
MOSCOW, Nov. 11 Paul Martin, Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs, met tonight with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party chief, for talks on Vietnam and other issues.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 11 A Negro social studies teacher at East Orange High School has been relieved as adviser to the student council because "provocative" Negro poetry was read at a student assembly on Nov. 2.

A six-member delegation of Opposition leaders from the Bahamas left Kennedy International Airport last night for London to petition the Colonial Office to arrange a Royal Commission investigation into published reports that American gamblers associated with Meyer Lansky, underworld gambling figure, had worked their way into casino gambling at the colony.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 11 When Ramanathan Krishnan played his first Davis Cup match for India, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru was trying to settle the Korean War.
HOUSTON, Nov. 11 In his field box at the Astrodome today, Roy Hofheinz flicked a cigar ash into a gold tray shaped like a baseball glove and said, "It's costing us plenty, but we like extravaganzas."

SAN ANTONIO, Tex. Nov. 11 (AP) Shirley Englehorn tied the Pecan Valley Country Club course record today with a fourunder-par 68 and took a onestroke lead in the $12,500 Alamo women's open golf tournament.

Governor Rockefeller disclosed yesterday that in the election he had told his Demoelection he had told his Democratic opponent, Frank D. O'Connor, that he was "sorry" for the political implications of the "missing-file" investigation.

At Lincoln Center today: "Die Frau ohne Schatten," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P.M.; "La Traviata," New York City Opera, New York State Theater, 2:15; "La Traviata," Metropolitan Opera, 8; "The Barber of Seville," New York City Opera, 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.

FORT BELVOIR, Va., Nov. 11 The Brigade Chapel here was the setting for the marriage today of Miss Katharine Lyle MacKinnon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gregory MacKinnon of Bathurst, N.B., to Capt. Daniel Davies Morgan Jr. of the Army Medical Corps. He is the son of Mrs. Morgan of New Haven and the late Mr. Morgan.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 The United States is engaged in a new review with a number of nations on what position to take on the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 The general conferences of the Methodist Church and the Evangelical United Brethren Church voted today to merge into the nation's largest Protestant denomination.

The Metropolitan Opera, faced with its worst financial crisis in 35 years, said yesterday that it would be forced to raise its ticket prices at mid-season. It is the first time in the company's 83-year history that an emergency mid-season increase has been necessary.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 By coincidence, two Gov ernment agencies received patents this week for methods of controlling the weather. Both propose to draw off ...

HAVANA, Nov. 11 The United States team dropped to third place last night after completion of the sixth round in the premier finals of the 17th Chess Olympica as a result of a 1 -1 tie with Hungary. The finals are being played at the Havana Libre Hotel.
A 20-year-old youth accused of leading 16 police cars on a wild chase in upper Manhattan early yesterday, faces eight charges.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 11 Prime Minister Ian D. Smith assured the people of Rhodesia tonight that a year of economic warfare and political hostility from the rest of the world had failed to shake their independence.
Archbishop Iakovos, Greek Orthodox Primate of North and South America, will leave tomorrow on a month-long pastoral mission to the Far East including a six-day visit to South Vietnam.
ROME, Nov. 11 Premier Aldo Moro pledged today that the Government would make enough of an "effort and sacrifice" to repair the ravages of the recent floods.

IF you're going to belt the waist, don't be timid about it," Pauline Trigere advised the audience at her spring showing yesterday as she went bravely about reviving the waist-cincher. A number of her dresses were caught firmly by big, wide belts, many in patent leather.
The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation announced here yesterday the appointment of Vernon H. Hartmann as production vice president of the agricultural chemicals division.

GENEVA, Nov. 11 Switzerland today urged a redoubling of efforts to dismantle trade barriers by assuring the success of the next round of tariffcutting negotiations despite Britain's new bid to join the European Common Market.

Lester Taylor returned to Town Hall last night for his first local recital since his debut in 1964. The years away brought nothing new to his playing, unfortunately, for it was still a combination of solid musicianship and zero communication.

Mrs. Sarah Consuelo Spencer Churchill Russell, daughter of the Duke of Marlborough and his late wife, was married yesterday afternoon to Guillermo Burgos Ossa, who is co-owner with her of the Burgos Galleries, Ltd., at 127 East 57th Street and Southampton. L.I.
News coverage of the civilrights movement was cited yesterday as an example of how advances in communication technology may have outpaced the ability of journalists to use their skills.
FLORENCE, Nov. 11 A $3.2-million fund for flood-damage loans to needy shopowners and artisans was established today.

Capital outlays of the Commonwealth Oil and Refining Company, San Juan, P.R. are expected to rise to $15-million next year from $13-million in 1966, Sam H. Casey, president and chief executive officer, told the New York Security Analyst yesterday. He said $15-million more could be added to 1967 capital spending in negotiations under way for new chemical plants.
Joe Friday, the hard-nosed detective of "Dragnet" whose tag line was "Just the facts, ma'm," will get a demotion, when the series returns to the National Broadcasting Company Jan. 12.
GENEVA, Nov. 11 Hungary has asked for authorization to follow the work of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world's leading forum on trade issues.
The ultimate United States troop strength in Vietnam now 345,000 men and scheduled to increase to 425,000 by next May is still uncertain, President Johnson said last week.
An off-duty policeman who had been celebrating his 36th birthday was arrested yesterday on charges of fatally shooting the owner of a bar and grill in Queens.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Nov. 12 (Reuters) The police burned thousands of dollars worth of Chinese goods today that they confiscated from the black market.

WARSAW, Nov. 11 (AP) The Soviet Union will sell Poland one million tons of its 1966 bumper grain crop and Warsaw plans increased consumer goods exports to Moscow in a step-up of trade and economic cooperation between the two Communist countries.
HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON N.Y. A shy gray-haired great grandmother here has built an elegant $500,000 library as a gift to the community.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 11 An international incident, Junior grade, was averted by the batting eyelashes and soft smile of a Laurel-type girl today and the 15th Washington D.C. classic was permitted to go on with the favored Assagai in the cast of characters.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Officials of the Defense Department and the Selective Service System disagreed sharply today on how and at what age young men should be drafted for military duty.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 11--The Common Market allows imports of strictly limited quantities of steel from Communist countries and has adopted measures to prevent the imports from having any disruptive market effects.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 Philip Feldesman of New York moved back into the lead in the eighth round of the International Team Trials here tonight. Playing with Richard Freeman of Atlanta, he beat Tobias Stone of New York and Ivan Erdos of Los Angeles, 37-5, for a total of 218 victory points.

NASHVILLE, Nov. 11-- Harold S. Vanderbilt, president of the Vanderbilt University Board of Trust, announced today a personal, matching gift of $11-million to the university's current capital gifts campaign.

The vacuum left by the decisive defeat of the Civilian Review Board must be filled as a matter of orderly administrative procedure, and particularly as an assurance to members of minority groups that they have not been rejected by the rest of the community.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Secretary of State Dean Rusk has directed the State Department not to comment on the West German political crisis to avert any charges of United States involvement in West Germany's domestic affairs. The Secretary has warned particularly that there must be no discussion of the controversial political background of Kurt Georg Kiesinger.

Emma Jo Williams cooked stew beef and rice, string beans and squash, and baked a chocolate cake for the 14 prisoners in the Spalding County Jail yesterday. As is usual these days, her work was continually interrupted by deputy sheriffs who wanted to know how she felt, what she thought, and what her son planned to do tomorrow night.

THE naturalist who writes about his animal friends has three choices. He can be scientifically detached and write a flat, factual report as impersonal as a column of statistics. He can personalize the animals, write "from the heart" and risk the charge of sentimentality.
A development that will contain 40 homes in one-story, splitlevel and two-story designs has been opened on Eileen Way, off Grandview Avenue, in Edison. N.J.

ORANJESTAD, Aruba, N.W.I.--This tiny Dutch island is having a hard time building hotels fast enough to keep up with the tourist boom, but one problem that those recruiting hotel staffs do not have to worry about is the language barrier. Most of the islanders speak five languages.
TORONTO, Nov. 12 (UPI) A fired-up Canadian equestrian team, on its home ground, continued to dominate the international jumping contests tonight at the Royal Winter Fair Horse show.
Arthur J. Goldberg pleaded last night for the rule of law in the international realm and an international police force to maintain peace.
ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Nov. 12 The Academy of Sciences and Arts celebrated its centennial this week under the sign of "brotherhood and unity" among the nationalities of Yugoslavia.

It was like the kind of thing seen in Washington when a cabinet head or some other high-level official resigns.

MILT KAMEN, the comedian, doesn't have to play French horn for a living any more, but he still goes to a lot of concerts. There, as everywhere, he finds something to smile about. During intermission the other night at Philharmonic Hall, for instance, Kamen was talking about concertgoers who never get to the concert on time.

DACCA, Pakistan A capital city from 1608 to 1704, and a capital city again since 1947. In the years between, "the city of the long sleep." This is Dacca, which is now very much on the move, although not above a little yawn now and then.
The political equivalent of the batting championship for the 1966 campaign season went to former Vice President Richard M. Nixon hands down.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 12 (UPI) Fourth-ranked and unbeaten Nebraska defeated Oklahoma State, 21-6, today to clinch its fourth consecutive Big Eight football championship.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Nov. 12 Dr. Hugh Chaplin has made known the engagement of his daughter, Miss Virginia Chaplin, to Robert S. Atkinson of White Plains, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Carleton Atkinson of Pataskala, Ohio.
GREENPORT, L.I., Nov. 12 Al Woodson, a 245-pound sophomore, booted a 20-yard field goal today to give Riverhead a 3-0 upset victory over Greenport.
MONTREAL, Nov. 7 To Montreal nothing like its Metro can be found anywhere else.

Lauer Jr. in All Saints Chapel here.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 12 Adelphi University's stout defensive line and strong ground game proved to be too much today for Marist College in a club football game at Adelphi's Stiles Field.

METUCHEN, N.J., Nov. 12 Mr. and Mrs. Maximilian F. Weil have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wendy Holmes Weil, to the Rev. David Paul Daniel, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. John Daniel of Bethlehem, Pa.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 12 (AP) David S. Weaver, a North Carolina farm leader and educator, died today in Methodist Hospital, Philadelphia. He was 70 years old.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 12 Canada has begun diplomatic consultations with France, Japan and a number of Far Eastern governments on bringing Communist China into the United Nations through the two-Chinas formula, qualified sources said today.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 12 Kentucky Republicans, elated over their fine showing in Tuesday's election, have high hopes of electing a Governor next year for the first time in more than 20 years.
FORT DIX, N.J., Nov. 12 Pvt. Alan J. Willen, who had been a clerk on the metropolitan desk of The New York Times, died of a blood infection early today in Walson Army Hospital. He was 22 years old.

The last of Boston's big commerical banks to announce plans to reshape the city's downtown skyline has just joined the parade. The National Shawmut Bank of Boston will build a new highrise headquarters and office building in the middle of the financial district.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 12 (UPI) The Houston cougars scored 10 of the first 14 times they had the ball today as they crushed Kentucky, 56-18.

FOR those Broadway savants who, after gazing upon the early crop of presentations, already have begun to "wait until next year," producer Joseph Cates brings news to wait for. He has gotten a yes from Leslie Caron to appear as the distaff side of Ervin Drake's musical version of Shaw's "Caesar and Cleopatra."

GUATEMALA, Nov. 10 President Julio C sar M ndez Montenegro has now weathered two right-wing plots to overthrow him. But with leftist guerrilla, activity continuing, the general feeling in political circles here is that he is far from out of danger.
BILL FRANK AND COMPANY opened a series of three performances at the Henry Street Playhouse on Friday night and, at once, disconcerted.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 12 Israel M. Goodelman of 27 Gladstone Road, a pharmacist and the author of history books in Yiddish for children, died Thursday in New Rochelle Hospital.

Production schedules of Deere Co., maker of farm implements and industrial equipment, have been set about 10 per cent above those of the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, Clifford L. Peterson, vice president of finance, told the Philadelphia Society of Security Analysts last week.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y. The importance of artificial snow how to make it and how to preserve it filled the speechmaking and discussion hours here recently, when ski-area operators got together for a winter sports forum sponsored by the New York State Winter Sports Council and the State Department of Commerce.

Passenger traffic on Pan American World Airways showed an increase of 32.4 per cent for the first 10 months of the year over the corresponding period last year, the company has announced. Cargo traffic was up 30.2 per cent.

SALT LAKE CITY. Nov. 12 (UPI) Kent Oborn and Virgil Carter triggered a three-touchdown barrage in the second quarter today as Brigham Young University crushed Utah, 35-13, to stay alive in the Western Athletic Conference pennant race.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 12 (AP) Dick Vidmer threw two long touchdown passes and sneaked across the goal for another score today as Michigan beat Northwestern, 28-20, in a game between Big Ten alsorans.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 12 Mr. and Mrs. Hubert L. Carter have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise, Elveta Carter, to Robert L. Stenhouse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Stenhouse of Buffalo.
Riverdale whipped Poly Prep, 21-13 yesterday at Poly Prep for its sixth straight victory.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Nov. 12 Tom Cassese caught three passes for touchdowns today to lead C.W. Post to a 23-16 triumph over Wagner's eleven.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska How much pride can you squeeze into 40 acres? Alaska is squeezing plenty into a site that size four miles outside this city. The tokens and trophies of its history from wasteland days to statehood are being assembled for an exposition that will open next year as Alaska 67.
ROOSEVELT, L.I., Nov. 12 The undefeated Roosevelt High eleven stretched its threeyear winning streak to 22 games today crushing Malverne, 58-0, today.

Notre Dame, the country's No. 1 ranked college football team, rolled to a 43-0 half-time lead and crushed Duke, 64-0, yesterday at South Bend, Ind.

TEL AVIV, Sunday, Nov. 13 Israeli and Jordanian fighter planes clashed this morning over the eastern Judean desert and one Jordanian plane was shot down, an Israeli Army spokesman announced.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 12 Hundreds of species of North American migratory birds that winter below Mexico City are threatened by the rapid growth in Latin-American population, a conservationist warned today.

This, it now appears, Mr. Wilson is prepared to do.

ONE of the most charming aspects of the American medical scene is the tradition that distinguished doctors turn, in their later years, to the writing of medical history and biography. The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity rose to 302.2 in the week ended Nov. 5 from 296.4 in the preceding week. A year earlier it was 270.

HOLLYWOOD. A YOUNG actor named Robert Redford quietly turned up in town this week after having pulled one of Hollywood's more surprising disappearing acts. A year ago Redford had just completed his third movie in a row and had achieved that distant dream of all Hollywood actors instant stardom. Producers were banging at his door, a blizzard of scripts inundated his office and his agents were busily planning all sorts of big-money ventures.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Nov. 13 An enemy force penetrated a United States Marine platoon's position yesterday and attacked with hand grenades, satchel charges and small arms, inflicting heavy casualties, a United States spokesman reported today.

ATLANTA, Nov. 12 (AP) Attorney General Arthur K. Bolton announced today that the state would appeal to the United States Supreme Court a finding by a three-judge Federal court that the Legislature cannot choose between Howard H. Callaway, Republican, and Lester G. Maddox, Democrat, for Governor.

CLIFTON, N. J., Nov. 12--Clifton High turned back a last-minute drive by Montclair today to preserve a 7-7 tie before 8,000 fans. The deadlock was the first in this 20-year-old series between the two schools.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Organized labor fears that the Congressional elections this week have erased its hopes of winning major legislation for two years and have put it on the defensive to protect gains already made.

A company of consulting engineers recommended last week to the 27 power companies in the Northeast shut down by the power failure last November that they establish a single regionwide system security center to guard against future power failures.

WASHINGTON, Nov.12 One of the time-proven maxims of American diplomats for dealing with the Russians is that patience, perseverance and time can be more important than diplomatic maneuvers in producing an agreement. CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in a 2-to-1 decision announced today, said a suit questioning the constitutionality of the House Committee on Un-American Activities should be heard.

THE strongest women chess players in the world gathered recently in Oberhausen, West Germany, to contest the Women's Team Championship. Fourteen countries were represented in this round robin, in which the entrants played two boards per team in each match.

So wrote Ezra Pound in 1914, in a poem, "Salutation the Third:' What Pound failed to understand is that it we want to consider a person insane, we need not "drive" him mad; we cats simply "declare" him mad. Like Pound, many people do not grasp the double meaning of the concept of madness, and, like Pound, they often pay dearly for their ignorance.

PARIS, Nov. 10 Paris has never looked more disheveled or dug up. All over the city, there are bulldozers, cranes, derricks and drills carving out giant trenches and great pits where sidewalks used to be. Many boulevards, bridges and squares are for the time being a trial to the city's high-strung drivers and an eyesore to the strollers.

PARIS. FOR several days running, Jean Genet's "Les Paravents" ("The Screens") had been under attack by the French right wing. There had been demonstrations, prolonged boos and finally an overheated patriot climbed on the stage to slap an actor's face. The students from the nearby Sorbonne decided to defend Genet and his play. The cause of the mutual outrage? Several scenes offensive to French patriotic sentiments and one that mortified middle-class French sensibilities.

The annual luncheon and fashion show of the women's division of Maimonides Institute will be held on Tuesday in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton. Proceeds will enable mentally handicapped children to attend the institute at 34-01 Mott Avenue in Far Rockaway, Queens.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov, 12 (UPI) Wes Ellis and Art Wall Jr. shot three-under-par 67's over a rain-sodden course today to tie for the lead at the midway point of the 72-hole Caracas open golf tournament.

NEWARK, Nov. 12 The effect on police morale of recent United States Supreme Court decisions dealing with criminal prosecution is scheduled for discussion next week at the 51st annual conference of the New Jersey League of Municipalities.

DESPITE the pervasive, perhaps central, role that the law plays in American society and in the lives and thoughts of Americans, our leading American philosophers seemed to be unaware of its significance or even existence.
LONDON, Nov. 12 Britain took a first step this week down a road that could lead to fundamental change in the post-war pattern of relations among the United States, Britain and continental Europe.

One of the best-kept secrets in the food industry last week was what Thanksgiving tur- keys will cost. Spokesmen for a number of leading chains refused to discuss the matter "for competitive reasons."
STOCKHOLM, Nov. 12 The Yugoslav laborer, who had dreamed of finding a new life in Sweden, started this week on the long train ride home at the Swedish Government's expense.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 12 A dinner dance on Friday at the Garden City Hotel will benefit the building fund of the Cathedral School of St. Mary. The School Mothers Association has arranged the event.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 A bleak future for the antipoverty program, at least in its present form, was written large in Tuesday's election.
PATERSON, Nov. 12 Passaic had to contain a determined Paterson Kennedy team to gain a 12-6 victory in a Passaic Valley Conference game at Hinchliffe Stadium today.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Nov. 12 (UPI) Bernie McCall, a quarterback, kept bowl-minded Colorado moving consistently today as the Buffaloes scored in every quarter to defeat Kansas, 35-18 in a Big Eight conference game.

A Yale freshman in the newly released documentary film, "To Be a Man," wore the Ivy League mantle with the arrogant assurance of one who knows himself to the purple born. He admitted that, on arrival in New Haven, he took a dim view of his dormitory neighbors.
The last previous mass slaying in the United States occurred on Aug. 1 when a former marine, Charles J. Whitman, kneeled atop a tower at the University of Texas and shot 45 persons. Fourteen died.
MANCHESTER, Mass., Nov. 12 Mrs. William Barnett has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nancy Jean Barnett, to John Franklin Fort 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fort Jr. of Potomac, Md.

Dr. and Mrs. Edwin Newman Beery of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lillian Charlotte Onken Beery, to David Field Willis of New York and Andover, Mass. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Arnold Willis of Andover.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 12 Frank Arentowicz, a reserve halfback from Dover, N.J., ran for 153 yards and two touchdowns today as Bucknell overpowered Lehigh, 45-0, for its fifth victory against three defeats.

WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 12 Mr. and Mrs. John J. Gaherin have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Stephanie Maria Gaherin, to William Francis Keane 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Keane of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Breezy Point, L.I.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., NOV. 12 Trailing by 41-20 late in the third quarter, Upsala struck back on the passing of Lou Checchetto to gain a 42-41 victory over Albright in a Middle Atlantic Conference game here today.

NEW DELHI, Nov, 12 "It just doesn't seem fair," an official said last week as he stood in a parched field in eastern Uttar State. "One year of drought we could handle, but two in a row; that just doesn't seem fair."

Mathemetician, philosopher, Nobel Prize winner for literature in 1950 and a voluble anti-American-Lord Russell now is 94. What other top-flight horsemen cannot do at any harness racing track in this state, Sacher Werner can. The Viennaborn reinsman, who has spent a good portion of his 67 years staying a hop, skip and jump ahead of trouble, is the only trainer, driver or owner permitted to remain in the paddock on nights when he has no horses entered.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 Too often the housewife buys food on the basis of what is outside the package rather than on what is inside, a farm economist, Dr. George E. Brandow, says.
LONDON, Nov. 12 Chic Calderwood, the British lightheavyweight boxing champion, was killed tonight in a car crash on a lonely road near Glasgow, Scotland.
SUFFIELD, Conn., Nov, 12 Dave Kiarsin ran for three touchdowns and established a school season scoring record today as Suffield Academy routed Wilbraham, 32-0.
Miss Joan Elizabeth Markey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond H. Markey of 103 Thayer Street, was married here yesterday to Thomas E. Burke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Burke of Brooklyn.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. The General Assembly of the United Nations has adopt ed by unanimous vote a resolution designating 1967 as International Tourist Year. The vote came slightly more than a year after the International Union of Official Trav el Organizations (I.U.O.T.O.) agreed at its world convention in Mexico City to promote worldwide observance of tourism for a full year.

FOR over a hundred years the un expurgated memoirs of Casanova were carefully preserved in the vaults of Brockhaus of Leipzig, but in 1945 they only just escaped both from a direct hit by an American bomb and from incarceration in East Germany.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 12 Pocomoonshine, a product of the New York Sire Stakes, made up almost two lengths inside the final one sixteenth of a mile and defeated Rivaltime by a length in tonight's $15,000 one-mile handicap pace at Roosevelt Raceway.
GREENVILLE, N.C., Nov. 12 (UPI) East Carolina College clinched at least a tie for the Southern Conference championship today by defeating Richmon, 28-16.
MONTREAL, Nov. 12 A sidewalk superintendent's utopia has been created on two islands and a peninsula called a pier in the St. Lawrence River.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 12 Plans by Zambia and Chile, the second and third largest copper producing nations after the United States, to establish a joint pricing, marketing and production policy for the widely used metal, appear to be go ing ahead.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 12 Republican leaders in Nassau County are intent on getting a "dominant" role in steering the party's course in New York.
Stanley Howells Fuld, who has spent an important part of his judicial life in lonely dissent, found himself surrounded by consensus last week.

COMPARATIVELY few people in the United States will have seen her dance, and yet, equally, few people at all interested in dancing will not have encountered her influence. Her name is Mary Wigman and today is her 80th birthday, and she will spend it, together with many of her students, from both the United States and Germany in her dance studio in West Berlin.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov, 12 Undefeated Muskingum College of New Concord, Ohio, posted its eighth triumph today by beating Hofstra University, 27-19. Hofstra suffered its seventh loss in nine contests, but scored more points against the Muskies than the combined total of all other opponents of the Ohio eleven. The Muskies had recorded five shutouts and had allowed 8 points.
LONDON, Nov. 12 (Reuters) A British publisher warned today that an ingredient mentioned in some recipies in a new cookbook was poisonous.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 12 (UPI) Buddy Gore, a flashy tailback, scored one touchdown and kept Maryland off balance with electrifying runs today and the Clemson secondary picked off two fourth-quarter passes deep in its own territory to preserve a 14-10 victory.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 12 A small event as dog shows go had some of the country's leading campaigners in its entry today. When it was over the title of best was held by an orange belton English setter, Ch. Merry Rover of Valley Run, owned by Mrs. George Abbott and Mrs. Charles Van Buren of New Canaan, Conn.

CORVALLIS, Ore., Nov. 12 (UPI) Oregon State took a 17-0 half-time lead and withstood a fourth-quarter rally today to post a 24-13 Pacific Eight victory over Washington.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I. Nov. 12 A dead American elm tree here has, in effect, "given birth" to a cedar that resembles a Christmas tree.

There may be more layoffs in the construction industry here as a result of the long strike of construction plumbers in Manhattan and the Bronx.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 12 (UPI) This city by the Mississippi is close to realizing an educator's dream a college education for everyone who wants it and can bet through high school.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 12 Jim Hall of Midland, Tex., and Phil Hill of Santa Monica, Calif., disclosed today a simple plan for winning most of the money and the glory in tomorrow's rich Stardust Grand Prix. The plan calls for Hall to finish first and his partner second in the 210-mile contest, which is the last of six in the newlyorganized Canadian American Challenge Cup series for sports cars.

PARIS On my office wall hangs an initialed memorandum dated Munich, April 14, 1961, which says: "Cy Sulzberger bets Franz Josef Strauss one case of French champagne payable in the year 1970. C.L.S. bets that by Jan. 1, 1970, Strauss will either be Chancellor of Germany or will have been Chancellor of Germany. F.J.S. bets the contrary."

A three-level house with double stairways that curve upward toward a horseshowshaped balcony leading to four bedrooms is being offered in a new Westchester development. The balcony overlooks a rear-facing living room, which is on a separate level.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) Union leaders moved quickly today to secure the approval of electrical workers on a tentative contract agreement it was hoped would end a 12day strike against the Westinghouse Corporation.
