A Christmas bazaar will open 7 P.M. Friday in the Church House of the Middle Collegiate Church, 50 East Seventh Street. A ham dinner will precede it. On Saturday, the bazaar will continue from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., and luncheon will be served.

Trans Caribbean Airways has been granted a permanent certificate by the Civil Aeronautics Board for the New York-San Juan, Puerto Rico, route, which it has been flying under temporary certification since 1957.
IOWA CITY, Nov. 12 Ohio State spotted Iowa a fourthquarter touchdown, roared back for one of its own and then stopped an Iowa drive 9 yards short of a touchdown today for a 14-10 Big Ten victory.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 12 (Reuters) European kings, princes and aristocrats took part today in a royal hunt for wild boar, deer and other game in the Ardennes Forest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 The roadways of the nation are now completely free of notorious speed traps, the American Automobile Association has told its members, with the removal of the "speed trap" warning label from Coleman, Fla.

SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 12 South Korea is considering sending military reservists to South Vietnam as security guards and transportation, housing and supply troops. This would be done instead of increasing the South Korean 44,000-man combat force there.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 (AP) Delegates to the annual convention of Sigma Delta Chi professional journalistic society feated today proposals to admit women as members and change the organization's name.

The Chapel of Trinity Episcopal Church was the setting here yesterday morning for the marriage of Miss Linda Louise Root of New York, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Cullen Root of Largo, Fla., formerly of Cleveland, to Lester LeRoy Cooper Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cooper of Charlottesville, Va.

BARRINGTON, R.I., Nov. 12 Mr. and Mrs. John H. White have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Perrin White, to the Rev. Keith Elden Scott. He is the son of the Rev. Ernest Fillmore Scott, rector of Christ Episcopal Church in Pittsford, N.Y., and Mrs. Scott.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 12 A 1.5 per cent payroll income tax will go into effect here next January.

JOGJAKARTA, Indonesia No exercise bars line the walls and no mirrors reflect back the dancers' posturings, but for all its seeming informality, including the ragged children gaping at the pupils, the Conservatori Krido Bekso Wiromo here is a ballet school.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 12 Books critical of United States policy in Vietnam are neither listed in the card catalogue nor displayed on the shelves of the United States Information Agency library in downtown Saigon.
MANILA, Nov. 12 (Reuters) The World Medical Association ended its 20th general assembly here today with a reaffirmation of its stand against abortion.

THE Voice of America has lifted its skirt above its ankle. The radio arm of the United States Inforination Service instituted last week a breezier and crisper format for at least six hours of its Englishlanguage transmissions to the world, and the result promises to be a decided improvement.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Nov. 12 Miss Kathrin Perutz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tino Perutz, was married today to Michael Studdert-Kennedy, son of the late Rev. G.S. Studdert-Kennedy and Mrs. Studdert-Kennedy of Worcester, England. The Rev. John Fischback performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Perutz home.

BETHANY, Conn., Nov. 12 Quincy Porter, whose "Concerto for Two Pianos and Orchestra" won the Pultizer Prize for music in 1954, died tonight, apparently of a stroke, in his home here, He was 69 years old.

The speed with which science is altering man's life, his concepts and his problems is revolutionary. No deceleration is in sight. TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 12 Sleepy Hollow High School of the Tarrytowns scored on the last play of the game before 9,000 fans at Washington Irving Stadium today to defeat Ossining, 12.6, in a battle of two previously, unbeaten football teams.

In St. James's Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Talia Bliss Soper, daughter of Mrs. Harold M. Manser of 141 East 88th Street and the late Leslie Bliss Soper, was married to Harry Terhune Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Terhune of Glen Rock, N.J.

DON'T kick in your TV screen. Beginning Monday, Jan. 9, television will be "nice" and "ter rific." "Captain Nice" will be introduced by the National Broadcasting Company and "Mr. Terrific" by the Columbia Broadcasting System. The comedy shows about similar superheroes will be on backto-back Mr. T. from 8 to 8:30 P.M. and the Captain from 8:30 to 9.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 In addition to deploying a missile defense around the Soviet Union, the Russians are markedly increasing the pace of their build-up of offensive missiles.

BALDWIN, L.I., Nov. 12 Rick Coll scored two touchdowns, the first on a 12-yard pass from Joe Lescody, the second on a 42-yard pass from Bob Medwin to lead East Meadow to a 33-0 victory over Baldwin in Division I, Couth Shore Athletic League, today. Dick Koch also scored twice.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 12 (UPI) Floyd Little scored 20 points and led Syracuse to a 37-21 victory over Florida State today.

The Children's Health Service will celebrate its 94th year at a dinner dance on Thursday at the St. Regis-Sheraton. Mrs. Boris Gresov is general chairman of the evening. Mrs. Barbara A. Schick and Mrs. Henry C. Citron are vice chairmen.

Columbia's football team discovered yesterday that all losing streaks must come to an end. After seven consecutive setbacks this season and 11 straight since a 1965 victory over Rutgers, the Lions bounded back to beat Penn by 22 to 14.
After 18 years in business, a Bronx real estate broker specializing in home sales has decided to give his eight salesmen Sundays off.

Some $9,254,000 was spent in Atlanta in direct connection with the arrival of major league baseball in the latest season. By changing hands several times, this sum generated an additional income of $30-million for people in the city.
A nonprofit foundation to develop middle-income housing in Chicago has been formed by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America (AFL-CIO).
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) The postmasters of the nation's three largest post offices New York, Chicago and Los Angeles have one thing in common: all are Negroes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Nobody puts his fortunes and his ego more publicly on the line than the politician running for office. An election defeat is not a private anguish; Walter Cronkite tells the world about it, the newspapers analyze the weaknesses and deficiencies that caused it, and faceless statisticians record the unalterable fact for one's great-grandchildren to read.

Failure to draw the line between "responsible" and "irresponsible" criticism of American policy in Vietnam could encourage the Communists to delay peace negotiations, according to a statement by 138 prominent Americans, including former President Eisenhower.

Sabicas, the flamenco guitarist and composer, returned to Town Hall Saturday night for the sort of exciting recital his devotees have come to expect each year about this time.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)--A Senate panel will begin advance work for the 90th Congress--which opens Jan. 10 --with public hearings this week on cutting red tape of more than 170. Federal programs involving state and local governments.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 The United States Controller of the Currency, James J. Saxon, reaffirmed today his belief that the merger of the CrockerAnglo 'National Bank of San Francisco and the Citizens National Bank of Los Angeles was beneficial for California.
Rome, Nov. 14 Restoration of paintings damaged by the flood in Forence will take at least 20 years, an American art historian said here today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 Let's hope that the 500 European travel agents and travel writers arriving in New York today for an inspection of American tourist facilities are arriving with open minds.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The United States Government was reported today to be trying behind the scenes to ease the dispute between American oil companies and the Algerian Government.
Gold ingots, pieces of eight and other samples of buried Spanish treasure have turned up at a site that would astonish Captain Kidd the Madison Avenue auction galleries of Parke-Bernet.
A union representation election will be held Nov. 23 among 250 employes of Sloane House, a resident hotel owned and operated by the Young Men's Christian Association at 422 Ninth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov.14 (AP) The Supreme Court decided today that the United Gas Pipe Line Company must obtain Federal Power Commission approval of a plan to discontinue purchases from the Continental Oil Company in the Johnson Bayou field in Louisiana.

The New York Knickerbockers begin a home-and-home series with the powerful Philadelphia 76ers at Madison Square Garden tonight in a National Basketball Association game starting at 8:30. In a preliminary game at 6:45, Bishop Reilly High School of Fresh Meadows, L.I., will play Augustinian Academy of Staten Island.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 14 Rutgers University received grants, gifts, contracts and bequests totaling a record high of more than $13-million during the 1965-66 fiscal year, according to Dr. Mason W. Gross, the president of the state university.

WATERVILLE, Me., Nov. 14 Mr. and Mrs. John H. McGowan of Waterville and Sidney have announced the engagement of Mrs. MeGowan's daughter, Miss Rosemary Alexandra Karran McGowan, to Anthony Francis Phillips. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Phillips of Hartford and Hollywood, Fla.

Aymar Embury 2d, an architect whose designs had a mayor impact on the skyline and waterway appurtenances of New York and on residential areas in its suburbs, died yesterday an Southampton (L.I.) Hospital after a long illness. He was 86 years old and lived in East Hampton and at 430 East 57th Street here.
Wallace Mondschein, a Certified Public Accountant with offices at 2 Park Avenue, died on Sunday in his home at 515 West End Avenue. His age was 64.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 14 In what Lima newspapers called the "cleanest" and "fairest" elections ever held in Peru, President Fernando Belaunde Terry's minority Government alliance suffered losses in the countryside but gained a large victory in Lima.

DANCE is stirring in Greenwich Village, and stirring in most surprising directions, for the Village seems to be turning over a new terpsichorear leaf. At a time when happenings are tending not to happen, no less than two classic ballet companies, the Manhattan Festival Ballet and the Village Theater Ballet, have announced long seasons.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Nov.14 Administrative personnel of Middlebury College searched the campus here today for several hundred student personnel files that disappeared from the office of the dean of men over the weekend.
CLINTON, Okla., Nov. 14 (AP) Some veterans have begun a movement in Oklahoma's Sixth District to fight the seating of Congressman-elect James V. Smith of Chickasha.

More than 200 women with investments in mind listened intently to eight prominent men yesterday, and what they heard came straight from the shoulder. The occasion: the ninth annual women investors' clinic of the Federation of Women Shareholders in American Business, in the Waldorf Astoria hotel.
City Council Majority Leader David Ross accused Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello yesterday of saying one thing publicly about pending Council legislation and another thing privately.

The new man behind the New York Mets is a blue-eyed, 49year-old Missourian named Vaughan Palmore Devine who has spent the last two years prowling the country getting to know young baseball players and who will be able to tell most Met rookies what they batted in high school.

NEWARK, Nov. 14 (UPI) Unidentified flying objects were reported in four separate sections of northern New Jersey yesterday. The objects were described as triangular in shape and changing colors from red to white to green.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 Roman Catholic Cardinals and Bishops of the United States charged tonight that the Johnson Administration was putting pressure on the poor to practice birth control.
The City Controller has found $140,000 worth of unused medical equipment stored in the sub-basement of the City Hospital at Elmhurst.
HOUSTON, Nov. 14 "Move, Cleve, move," the Cat's admirers yelled. "Hook, Cleve, hook, they screamed.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 The United States opened its campaign today to bar Communist China from the United Nations. It submitted a draft resaolution affirming that Peking's admission is a "question of importance."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) The Supreme Court refused today to examine a former judge's complaint that an Ohio newspaper had abused freedom of the press by false defamation in a successful campaign to defeat him at the polls in 1961.

Abraham Mendelowitz, vice president of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union, died yesterday in Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 72 years old and lived at 83 Sheridan Avenue, Mount Vernon, N.Y.

MADRID, Nov. 14 The long-awaited constitutional law designed to lead Spain toward a freer and more representative system of government is to be presented to the Cortes (Parliament) by Generalissimo Francisco Franco on Nov. 22.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The deficit in the nation's balance of international payments in the third quarter was $217million, seasonally adjusted, the Commerce Department reported today.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 14--Robert Bolivar DePugh and two members of his secret Minutemen organization were convicted today of violating the Federal Firearms Act. They accepted the verdict without comment.
WASHINGTON, Nov.14 (AP) The key to victory in the war in South Vietnam is defeat of a guerrilla terrorist force of more than 150,000 men, according to Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge.

WHEN the New York Knickerbockers had good teams and they did have good teams, you know, more than a decade ago-their chief characteristic was team balance. In an era when most teams relied on five men (before the 24-second rule), Coach Joe Lapchick employed eight "regulars" on a rotating basis. Through hustle and proper blending of complementary talents, the Knicks often defeated more talented opponents.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 14 (UPI) Senator Thruston B. Morton, Republican of Kentucky, turned down today suggestions that he seek the 1967 governership nomination and announced he would run for reelection to the Senate in 1968.

Friends and "responsible" foes of the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board, which was killed by last Tuesday's referendum, have been invited by the New York Civil Liberties Union to discuss, an ombudsman as an acceptable substitute.

Mr. and Mrs. William A. Meaders of the United States Consulate General in Sao Paulo, Brazil, have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christine Louise Meaders, to George H. Durham 2d, son of Dr. and Mrs. G. Homer Durham of Phoenix, Ariz.
The attitude of Wall Street analysts toward the stock market remained gingerly optimistic yesterday as the DowJones industrial average fell 5.34 points to finish at 813,75.

Hornbeam moved up steadily in the stretch to take the feature test of seven furlongs at Aqueduct yesterday, under a fine ride by Manuel Yeaza. At the finish of the race for 2-yearolds, Hornbeam, owned by Louis Lee Haggin 2d, had a margin of 1 lengths over Judith Burke's Shah, with William Kosnick's Osage next in the field of seven.

As he shapped the red yarn stretched across the finish yesterday, Charlie Messenger didn't look like a runner who had just shattered the Var Cortlandt Park and Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America cross-country records.

ASTORIA, Ore., Nov.14 (AP) A second bomb found aboard an outbound Liberian wheat ship was disarmed today by a Navy demolition team. The first killed the captain and a motorman and injured seven other crewmen.
The appointment of Walter LaM. Sparry as vice president of Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., has been announced by William H. Hamilton, president of the real estate concern.

CUCHI, South Vietnam, Nov. 14 (UPI) Specialist 4 William Wallace of Williston Park, L.I., who commanded a battered American infantry company last week, has received the nation's third highest decoration for valor.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 With students costs continuing to mount, an Indiana educator called today for free tuition at all of the nation's state-supported colleges and universities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 Despite prospects that the new Congress will take a long look at Great Society domestic programs, Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman plans to increase his department's efforts toward a better life in rural America.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 14 Katharine C. Richmond, who owned Miss Conklin's Secretarial School in Manhattan from 1920 to 1940, died yesterday in a nursing home in Cedar Grove, N.J. She was 81 years old and lived in the Claremont Inn.
Bond prices declined yesterday. Corporate underwriters prepared to bid on the largest issue offered for sale since Sept. 1 and municipal bond dealers headed into a week of heavy volume.

TOKYO, Nov. 14 (UPI) An All-Nippon Airways turboprop plane with 41 persons aboard, many of them newlyweds heading for honeymoons in southern Japan, was forced to turn back to Osaka today because of landing gear trouble. It landed safely.

The so-called Ali Shuffle, as seen through poor focus and distortion on the screen of the Warner Theater on Broadway off 47th Street, was clearly the cause of Cassius Clay's victory over Cleveland Williams last night. For starters, it kept the champion from getting bored.

AMSTER Yard was declared a city landmark last August, 20 years after James Amster, the interior decorator, had rescued the East 49th Street courtyard from the tin cans and debris. Naturally, there had to be a party to celebrate the event. It was held, a little belatedly, last night.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 14 (AP) Zell Rabin, editor of The Sydney Daily Mirror and former Australian newspaper correspondent in New York, died in Prince of Wales Hospital last night of cancer. He was 34 years old.
WASHINGTON, Nov.14 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission proposed today to force marketers of glass fiber fabrics to make plain the danger of their products.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 11 The novel court order virtually excluding the out-of-town press from covering the murder trial of Samuel H. Sheppard has caused confusion and annoyance here.
The city's 17,000 hospital aides won an increase of $600 a year yesterday in their minimum wage, which will now be $4,100. The raise lifts them from their rank as the city's lowest paid employes.

TWO one-act plays by Ken Friedman now on view at Off Broadway's Theatre 62 are not so compelling as to make your presence absolutely imperative. But they do suggest that Mr. Friedman's next play might be worth the trip.
QUEBEC, Nov. 14 (Canadian Press) Mrs. Louis St. Laurent, the wife of the former Prime Minister, died at her home here last night at the age of 78.

Brooklyn authorities said yesterday that they had a record in the writing of a reputed Mafia leader that listed the names of 34 persons, including "highly placed underworld figures," with amounts of money "totaling hundreds of thousands of dollars."

TWO one-act plays on how moving one's belongings from familiar surroundings can mark turning points in an individual's existence constituted last night's bill of the New York Television Theater" on Channel 13. One playlet had the virtue of novelty in suggesting the finality of approaching death; the other was the conventional suggestion that a new locale can stimulate a renewal of human will.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Nov. 14 (Reuters) President Julius K. Nyerere angrily denied tonight that pressure had been put on him to quit Lord Bertrand Russell's peace Foundation, which is arranging a "trial" of United States leaders for alleged Vietnam war crimes.
Dr. Henry A. Mehldau, obstetrician and gynecologist at Lutheran Medical Center, Brooklyn, died there Sunday, after a short illness. He was 64 year's old and lived at 226, 76th Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Nov.14 (AP) Dr. Reginald A. Hawkins, a Negro dentist of Charlotte, N.C., was denied today a Supreme Court review of his contention he should be tried in Federal court on a charge he interfered with a voting registration commissioner in Charlotte.
President Johnson has acted wisely in vetoing the District of Columbia crime control bill, which was repressive in its nature and badly drafted in its form.

Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving invited New Yorkers to gather in Sheep Meadow in Central Park at midnight tomorrow for his biggest "happening" to date the expected 3-hour shower of Leonids that occur only once in a generation.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 14 A general loosening of the mortgage market by the middle of next year is foreseen by most of those most intimately connected with the delicate workings of the economics system that forms the underpinning for construction and realty trading.
GENEVA, Nov. 14 France's intention to withdraw from the intergovernmental Committee for European Migration was deplored today when the agency began its 26th session.
TORONTO, Nov. 14 (Canadian Press) Jim Day of the Canada Equestrian Team, riding Top Gallant, won the Scurry Stake tonight at the Royal Winter Fair horse show.

The London stock market was listless yesterday although the majority of industrial issues drifted down slightly on a slackening of business.

MESA, Ariz., Nov. 14 (AP) Authorities pressed the prosecution today of a schoolboy killer of five an accelerated student now under psychiatric care and described as a brilliant "loner" by the few who knew him well.

The Departments of Defense and State have asked the Federal Maritime Commission to reject an agreement by six American steamship companies covering ocean shipment of household goods and personal effects for Government personnel.

Parochial school leaders threatened yesterday to ask the state and Federal Government to hold up $65-million for programs here for disadvantaged children, unless assurances were given that their students would benefit "in a comparable and equitable manner" with public school pupils.
OSWEGO, N.Y., Nov. 14 (AP) Two adults and five children perished early today when fire swept through a one-anda-half-story frame house near this central New York city. A sixth child escaped unharmed.
The United Federation of Teachers will seek a basic annual salary scale running from $7,500 for beginning teachers to $15,000 for experienced instructors. The present basic range is $5,400 to $9,950.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 14 (UPI) The Michigan State scouting report on Notre Dame came out today, and it described the fighting Irish as "the team that has everything."

Hundreds of people from 73 countries have joined in an advertisement accusing the United States of provoking a wider war in Vietnam and appealing for the withdrawal of American troops.
WESHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) The Nimbus weather satellite, launched six months ago, has taken almost a million photographs.

WESTBURY, L. I. Nov. 14 Two of the remaining five stakes on the Roosevelt Raceway calendar will be held tomorrow night, but only one will offer wagering.

BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 14 (QO) It is time for American businessmen, especially publishers, to rally to the defense of advertising, which is being attacked as never before, Southern newspaper publishers were told today.

Stainless-steel price increases became industrywide yesterday. As expected, the United States Steel Corporation, the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation and the Armco Steel Corporation matched the increases of the rest of the industry yesterday.

CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 14 The Timken Roller Bearing Company denied today a Federal report that the company had refused to furnish employment information for a check on possible racial discrimination. Timken holds a Government contract.

MOSCOW, Nov. 12 Using his sense of political atmosphere, in which hard evidence and concrete deeds are still largely absent, Foy D. Kohler is letting himself be optimistic as he retires as United States Ambassador.
Jack L. Warner, a founder, president and the largest stockholder of Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc., has agreed in principle to sell his interest in the company to Seven Arts Productions, Ltd.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 14 A record Suffolk County budget of $114.3-million was approved here tonight by the County Board of Supervisors.

The stock market's post-election rally ran out of steam yesterday.

IT is the Earl of Warwick who remarks in Bernard Shaw's "Saint Joan" that there is nothing more exquisite than a bonny book with illuminated pictures. But, he adds, "Nowadays instead of looking at books, people read them."

MIAMI, Nov. 14 (UPI) Cuban refugees swarmed today to Immigration Service offices, taking advantage of a new law which allows them to apply for permanent residence in the United States and thus open the door for better jobs and possible citizenship.

Mrs. Paul Wesley Gibbs of Riverdale, the Bronx, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss. Barbara Joan Gibbs, to Lloyd Bain Robertson of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Lonoke, Ark. He is the son of Mrs. Veasey Bain Robertson of Lonoke and the late Mr. Robertson.
RIVERHEAD, L.I. Nov. 14 Suffolk County's first Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Conservation was appointed by the Board of Supervisors today in an atmosphere of political controversy.

DETROIT, Nov. 14 A prominent rabbi succinct ly voiced the thought that almost certainly flashed through many minds here today on the election of the Most Rev. John Francis Dearden, Archbishop of Detroit, as president of the National Conference of Bishops.

In every free society, as well as in many societies that are struggling to be free, universities have a vital political role. Because their chief purposes are to transmit existing knowledge and, through research, to expand what is already known, they necessarily encourage a critical, questing spirit.
Profit taking weakened most issues on the American Stock Exchange yesterday after four consecutive sessions of advances.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 14 (AP) Gov. George C. Romney of Michigan, after a private meeting with former President Dwight D. Eisenhower today, said that they had discussed Democrats and Republicans but nothing about 1968.
TRENTON, Nov. 14 Democrats named five party insiders today as members of a commission that will draw new assembly districts.

BUCK HILLS FALLS, Pa., Nov. 14 New York State's atomic energy chairman said today that the fish-killing problem at the Consolidated Edison nuclear power generating plant at Indian Point, although eased, had not been solved and that studies were under way to see what additional remedies might be necessary.
The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra's second concert in Carnegie Hall this month, given last night, was nicely balanced between novelty and staple.

THOSE two appealing characters, Sally Bowles and Holly Golightly, who are about to appear on Broadway in separate musicals, had, according to their original creators, Christopher Isherwood and Truman Capote, a certain fashion style. Sally, who was well-born British, and Holly, a hillbilly American, may not have been exactly chic, but whatever they wore enhanced their individuality.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 14 The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled today that a union representing the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company's East Gadsden plant in Alabama had violated sections of the National Labor Relations Act by refusing to process grievances of eight Negro employes.
BERLIN, Nov. 14 East Germany's party leader, Walter Ulbricht, has called for an early political, settlement of the war in Vietnam.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 14 (UPI) Richie Guerin, the player-coach of the St. Louis Hawks, was given a two-year contract extension today. Ben Kerner, the owner of the National Basketball Association team, surprised the 34-year-old Guerin during a team practice session in Kiel Auditorium.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 102.6 on Thursday from 102.7 on Wednesday.
A controversy over whether a photograph showed a man aiming a rifle in front of President Kennedy the day he was killed in Dallas was stirred up yesterday by Esquire magazine.

IN the first act of "The In fantry," which opened off Broadway last night at the 81st Street Theater, the tough, gritty sergeant, who is called Mother, tells his griping, battle-weary men: "Somebody has got to be in the infantry."
Seth Aronson, president of Mark Rafalsky Co., a 61year-old real estate concern, died yesterday in his home, 31 East 21st Street, Brooklyn. He was 72 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The way Sargent Shriver cut off funds for the Mississippi Head Start project known as C.D.G.M, (Child Development Group of Mississippi) may lead to a lawsuit Based on a novel legal concept that groups receiving grants have certain rights.

Now that Mayor Lindsay has definitively rejected the Lower Manhattan Expressway, either in the elevated form favored by Robert Moses or the depressed roadway proposed by the Regional Plan Association, it is imperative that another way be found to relieve the intolerable traffic in the area.

DAYTON, Ohio, Nov.14 (UPI) An apparent black market trade in Sunday newspapers flourished here yesterday as a result of a two-week-old strike that has forced suspension of this city's two daily newspapers.
Kenneth Kaunda, President, of Zambia, said yesterday that "in many ways" the United States held the key to the solution of racial problems in southern Africa.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 14 A. Bruce Bowden, executive vice president of the Mellon National Bank and Trust Company since 1965, was named president today, effective Jan. 1, 1967.

VIENNA, Nov. 14 President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Unborn, accompanied by his 21-year-old daughter Nataliya, arrived today in a jovial mood for a week-long state visit, sightseeing and low-pressure politics.

The head of the World Bank came to Wall Street yesterday and warned a blueribbon group of investment bankers that the industrialized nations must provide adequate financial assistance to help the underdeveloped world rise above "the rag ged edge ...

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 14 (Reuters) The governing National Renewal Alliance of Brazil was expected to retain its dominance in both houses of Congress tomorrow in the first parliamentary elections since an army-backed revolution in 1964.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The Supreme Court, after a fiveyear record of consistently striking down arrests of sit-in demonstrators in the South, upheld today the trespass convictions of 32 Florida demonstrators.
TAYNINH, South Vietnam, Nov. 14 (AP) The world's only inflatable combat hospital has received a bloody introductions to war in the jungles of South Vietnam.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 14 Lebanon decided today to discontinue the services of Eric D. Millan, a partner in Price Waterhouse in London, a major British accounting concern and an affiliate of the United States firm of the same name, for making what was described as premature and unwarranted statements about the financially troubled Intra Bank.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 14 Twenty-eight speakers told the Westchester County Board of Supervisors at a hearing today that its reapportionment plan fitted neither the needs of the county nor the equal-representation ruling of the United States Supreme Court.

BONN, Nov. 14 Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin, the leader of the Social Democratic party, sharply criticized the United States Embassy in Bonn today for what he termed its "mixing in" in West Germany's domestic political affairs.
Those people out at St. Joseph's College in Rensselaer, Ind., just didn't know what they were starting when they used a full-page ad in last week's Time magazine for a fundraising pitch.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 President Johnson returned to the capital today after 10 busy days of work and rest at his Texas ranch.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 14 Giant B-52's bombed an area of the Central Highlands today near the site where North Vietnamese troops inflicted heavy casualties yesterday on an American infantry company.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 14 Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson proposed today a $201-million county budget for 1967 that calls for the largest property-tax increase in Nassau's history.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Nov. 14 Mr. and Mrs. Frederic S. Cluthe have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leigh Cluthe, to Geoffrey Grant Tilden, son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Tilden 3d of Summit.
HAVANA, Nov. 14 (UPI) The Government reported today that an unidentified aircraft bombed and damaged a chemical plant on the shores of nearby Matanzas Bay early yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The Supreme Court declined today to review the Supreme Court of Iowa's decision to deny a California man of "Bohemian" habits the custody of his 8-year-old son.

MOSCOW, Nov. 14 Nikolai G. Ignatov, a former minor official of the security police who twice rose to the top levels of the Soviet leadership, died today at the age of 65, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., Nov. 14 William Perrott, formerly manager of construction of the United States Lines, died today in North Hudson Hospital in Weehawken. He was 80 years old and lived at 7505 Palisades Avenue, North Bergen.

The Pioneer Finance Company of Detroit, which is in default on all of its debts of more than $116-million, said yesterday that it was holding discussions with "several companies" aimed at ending its financial crisis.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Nov. 14 (AP) Yells of delight in six languages greeted the blastoff of an internationally developed rocket today at the Woomera rocket range.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 14 A mob shouting anti-American slogans stoned the United States Consulate and the United States Information Service building and wrecked the offices of the Red Cross late last night at Adana, Turkey's largest southern city.
HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 14 (AP)--Mario Chamlee, a tenor who sang with the Chicago, San Francisco and Metropolitan Opera Companies, died yesterday at the age of 74.

Bloomingdale's, a department store group operated by Federated Department Stores, has named Franklin Simon vice president in charge of the men's and boys' departments as part of a series of merchandising appointments.
Leaders of commerce and conservation took battle positions yesterday in a new phase of their four-year conflict of law and words over the proposed Storm king Mountain power project.
STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 14 Dr. Robert C. Hirt, an authority in the field of ultra-violet spectroscopy, died Saturday at St. Joseph's Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived at 44 Barrett Avenue.

W. W. McCallum, president of John Morrell Co., said yesterday that he personally "welcomes" the interest of the AMK Corporation in Morrell. However, Mr. McCallum said that his company's stockholders must determine for themselves the advisability of tendering their stock under a tender offer made over the weekend by AMK.
Genesco, Inc., the apparel and footwear manufacturer and retailer, showed record sales and earnings in its first fiscal quarter, it was announced yesterday.

Negotiators for the television and radio networks and performer unions continued bargaining sessions last night in an effort to reach agreement on new contracts. The present pacts expire tonight at midnight.
FREEHOLD, N.J., Nov. 14 A jury found William G. Doss guilty of first-degree murder with no recommendation for mercy today after deliberating nearly eight hours.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Nov. 14 The Bulgarian Communist party issued a formal call today for a conference of the world Communist movement to deal With the Chinese "heresy."

WASHINGTON, Nov.14 (AP) The Supreme Court dismissed today an appeal from an Indiana motorist who contended the Federal Constitution's prohibition against double jeopardy was violated in his second trial for an auto fatality.
The Port of New York Authority has announced the appointment of Louis Achitoff as chief of the newly created aviation technical services division in the agency's aviation department.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 14 Al Baath, the Damascus daily newspaper that speaks for the ruling Baath Socialist party in Syria, declared today that the Israeli raid on Jordan "is a maneuver to divert attention away from an all-out attack Israel is preparing to wage against Syria." The paper accused the United States of helping Israel prepare the attack and added that Israel resorted to such tactics in 1956 shortly before her attack on the Egyptians.
The petroleum industry is in the total-energy business, not just the oil business, A. C. Rubel, retired chairman of the Union Oil Company of California, declared here yesterday.
HOUSTON, Nov. 14 Roman emperors had slave girls to fan them at the Colosseum, but it was hardly the kind of splendor in which Sky Box patrons watched tonight's first boxing program at the Astrodome.
ATHENS, Nov. 14 Twentyeight Greek officers appeared before a court-martial today charged with having plotted a revolt and with high treason.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 14 The Soviet Union is buying South Vietnamese piasters for the Vietcong in a complicated series of transactions stretching hall way around the world, informed sources said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) Representative Hugh L. Carey, Democrat of Brooklyn, announced today that the new National Technical Institute for the Deaf would be located in Rochester.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 14 (AP) Some 9,200 electrical workers were on strike today at Westinghouse Electric Corporation plants despite a national agreement reached in Washington last week, a company spokesman said.
THE New York Jets, who have only five games re- maining, learned yesterday that they would lose their double-threat fullback, Matt Snell, for at least three of those contests.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The Justice Department announcecd today it was dismissing an antitrust suit against the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, which sought to block an acquisition by General Telephone of the Western Utilities Corporation and its three operating tele phone-company affiliates.
OTTAWA, Nov. 14 Air Canada, this country's publicly owned airline, closed down completely this afternoon after a failure of negotiations with the International Association of Machinists.
LONDON, Nov. 14 Prince Charles, the Prince of Wales, turned 18 today, which meant that constitutionally the heirapparent to the British throne has come of age.
A Cuban diplomat who defected in England recently made a public appearance here yesterday to urge Cuban exiles to "merge into one, united force" to combat the regime of Premier Fidel Castro.
HAVANA, Nov. 14 The Soviet Union took a 1 - lead over the United States tonight in a crucial match of the 17th Chess Olympics.

TREASURE ISLAND, Calif., Nov. 14 A general court-martial found Navy Capt. Archie C. Kuntze guilty today on three specifications of a charge of conduct in Saigon that was "unbecoming of an officer and gentleman."

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 14 (UPI) Kevin Hardy, Notre Dame's standout defensive tackle who starred on Coach Ara Parseghian's first Irish team that barely missed winning the national title in 1964, said today that the present team was better.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 Once upon a time the problem of defeating resolutions to admit Communist China to the United Nations was simple. Few favored admission except the Communist countries, and the United States was able to impose the so-called "moratorium" policy under which the General Assembly declined to discuss the matter.
The musicians union yesterday struck the New York City Ballet on the eve of its scheduled opening tonight.

HOUSTON, Nov. 14 Several minutes after his knockout of Cleveland Williams, Cassius Clay came within a few goodnatured slaps tonight of squaring off in his dressing room with his next likely challenger Ernie Terrell.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) A Pan American World Airways jet cargo liner with a crew of three crashed during a landing attempt in the Soviet sector of divided Berlin today, United States officials said here.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 14 Westchester County was given 120 acres of land today for a new park bordering Long Island Sound's Milton Harbor at Rye.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 Following is the text of a statement on the Government and birth control adopted today by the Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States:

The sixth season of the Young Concert Artists Series began auspiciously at Carnegie Recital Hall last night with the New York debut of Christiane Edinger, a petite 20-year-old violinist from Berlin who has great talent.
A weather "fluke" was blamed here yesterday for the drowning of countless white-tail deer, wild hogs and raccoons last summer in the Everglades in Florida.

Irish-Americans here, incensed at a sharp drop in the number of immigrants to be allowed to enter the United States from the Emerald Island, are organizing a pressure group against a ban on bartenders, bookkeepers, hotel maids and others in similar job categories.
WOODCLIFF LAKE, N.J., Nov. 14 Several months ago a 15-year-old boy who had previously been in trouble for shooting a BB gun at passersby purchased a mail-order rifle from California.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 14 A feeling of uneasiness seemed to hang over Israel today in the aftermath of yesterday's raid south of Hebron in Jordan.

THREE collegiate football coaches yesterday criti cized actions of some officials and, in particular, expressed a dislike for the work of the back judges, who have worked their games this season for the first time.

HOUSTON, Nov. 14 There was an embarrassing delay at the weighing-in ceremonies at noon today for tonight's heavyweight championship fight between Cassius Clay and Cleveland Williams. Williams failed to bring along his boxing trunks. Maybe he had more important things on his mind.
PARIS, Nov. 14--Manlio Brosio, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said today that the Western alliance had become more divided than the Soviet bloc.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The index of primary market prices remained unchanged at 105.8 during the week ended Nov. 8, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products advanced in price while processed foods declined. Industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

HONG KONG, Nov. 13 One year has passed since the attack on a Peking opera drama began to mushroom into a momentous, often violent, cultural revolution in Communist ... China, In that time the analysts here have recorded an astounding series of purges and political convolutions, confusing rampages by millions of Chinese youngsters organized as Red Guards and sweeping disorientation of Chinese society.
HANOVER, N.H,, Nov. 14 (UPI) Stokely Carmichael, a Negro leader, urged Negroes today to say "hell, no" to their draft boards.
WHERE are the growth stocks of yesteryear? With that thought in mind, Walston Co., Inc., takes a bemused look at its own favorites of 12 years ago.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 14 For the third time in three days, Maj. Edwin E. Aldrin Jr. of the Air Force braved the void of space outside Gemini 12 today as it orbited toward the completion of its four-day mission.

Acting at the suggestion of Mayor Lindsay, the city amended its cabaret code yesterday to bar bare-breasted waitresses, then followed up by arresting two of them in the Crystal Palace, the city's first and possibly last topless-waitress night club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The Supreme Court sidestepped a controversial church-state issue today by declining to review a decision in Maryland that declared unconstitutional public grants to church-affiliated colleges.

The spot rate on the British pound sterling here ended unchanged yesterday from last Thursday's level of $2.7915 in moderately active trading. The currency traded in a narrow range, from $2.7914 to $2.7916. Dealers reported a good commercial demand for sterling.
OTTAWA, Nov. 14--Former Prime Minister John Diefenbaker opened the convention of the Progressive-Conservative party today lighting to retain his role as leader of the Opposition.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 Organized labor's high command unanimously re-endorsed its foreign policy positions today in what amounted to a rebuff to Walter P. Reuther.

"New Dimensions in Political Economy," by Walter Heller, will be issued by Harvard University Press next Monday. Mr. Heller, who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers during the term of President Kennedy and for the first year of President Johnson's Administration, proposes a revenuesharing plan.

Cassius Clay overpowered Cleveland Williams last night, knocking the challenger down four times, and retained his world heavyweight championship on a technical knockout in the third round at the Houston Astrodome.

Unfortunately, President Johnson failed to use his veto power to block another bill, equally obnoxious but for quite different reasons. He signed the "Christmas Tree" tax bill, although he acknowledged that some of its provisions would "confer special tax windfalls and benefits upon certain groups."
TWO new snack items are ready and waiting on More shelves for the upcoming holiday and entertaining season. Shrimp Crisps have a melt-in-the-mouth texture and a decided shrimp flavor.

Ferment in Spain, both inside and outside the Franco regime, is quickening the pace of political liberalization. There, is now the possibility that direct national elections may be held next spring for the first time in three decades with Opposition candidates permitted on the ballot.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 14 (UPI) The state and defense rested their cases today in the murder retrial of Samuel H. Sheppard without the defendant's taking the stand in his own defense.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Nov. 14 (UPI) Garbage collectors refused to work and the police threatened to make fewer arrests for minor offenses in a dispute today with the city over wages.

Dr. and Mrs. Maurice R. Friend of 262 Central Park West have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen London Friend, to Steven Robert Avedon, son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert B. Avedon of 336 Central Park West.
James J. Saxon, whose fiveyear term as Controller of the Currency ends today, plans to join the American Fletcher National Bank and Trust Company in Indianapolis in the near future.
A Bronx man who carried on a 20-minute gun battle with the police was shot and killed yesterday as he emerged from his year gas-filled sniping post still firing his automatic rifle.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 14 An increase of $20,211,761 in Westchester spending next year was proposed by County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian today in a budget submitted to the Board of Supervisors.

Steel production this year, which edged ahead of the cumulative 1965 total two weeks ago despite a week-to-week drop, was pushed to a strong annual gain in the week ended Saturday, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.

I.W. Abel, president of the United Steelworkers of America, told the Economic Club of New York City last night that perhaps the time has come for the President of the United States to convene a "summit conference."
George M. Weiss, the impresario of New York baseball since World War II, stepped down yesterday as president of the Mets.
Five women were named as winners of the annual journalism awards of the Newspaper Women's Club of New York last night.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 14 In an effort to encourage industrial growth, the Indian Government relaxed restrictions today on businesmen who seek to open or expand production facilities in a broad range of small industries.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 14 (UPI) India completed a 3-2 victory over West Germany today to enter the interzone Davis Cups tennis final against Brazil.
The New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women will give its 15th annual Angels Ball on Nov. 29 in the New York Hilton's Grand Ballroom.
HOUSTON, Nov. 14 For the first time in a controversial career, Cassius Clay looked like a tremendous fighter tonight as he made a punching bag of Cleveland Williams in the Astrodome.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The United States Conference of Mayors is protesting the proposed transfer of three new employment programs from the Office of Economic Opportunity to the Labor Department.

MENDON, Vt., Nov. 14 When Vermont's deer season opened Saturday, 50 members of an association known as the New England Outdoors Writers gathered in a solemn and sober caucus at an inn on Mendon Mountain.
Discussed strict observance of prohibition of threat or use of force in international relations and right of peoples to self-determination.
Discretionary purchasing power of American households has shown signs of faltering. At midyear, it was substantially lower than in the record fourth quarter of 1965.
Louis Kolodney, a lawyer with an office at 401 Broadway, died in New York Infirmary yesterday after a short illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 159-00 Riverside Drive West.

WASHINGTON, Nov.14 (AP) The Supreme Court upheld today Interstate Commerce Commission approval of a joint plan of seven railroads to extend rail service to the Lake Calumet harbor of the Chicago regional port district.

Dr. Carl H. Kraeling, a theologian who became a prominent educator, archeologist and authority on the Middle East, died yesterday at the Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 1199 Whitney Avenue in Hamden, Conn.
Criminal Court Judge Benjamin H. Schor will use the Good Samaritan defense against the charge that he took part in the alleged attempted shakedown of applicants for a liquor license.
The Interstate Commerce Commission approved yesterday a bid by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway to control the Chicago. South Shore South Bend Railroad.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 14 Philip Feldesman, the New York star, retained his lead in the International Team Trials here this afternoon. In the first of the nine final sessions, he and Richard Freeman of Atlanta crushed Lew Mathe and Robert Hamman, members of the 1966 North American team, 77 -6 .

A bumper crop of Florida oranges is due this year. The United States Department of Agriculture estimated yesterday that this year's crop would reach a record 142.4 million boxes weighing 90 pounds each. This compares with a recent estimate of about 139 million and with last year's crop of 100.4 million boxes.

Mitchell Sharp, Canada's Minister of Finance, urged here last night that the United States and Canada start planning policies toward freer world trade that might be applied after the Kennedy round of tariff-cutting negotiations ends.
LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 15 (AP) Squads of policemen battled boxing fans who besieged a theater showing a live telecast of the Cassius ClayCleveland Williams title fight here early today.
FLORENCE, Italy, Nov. 14 (UPI) Following is a list of some major objects damaged or destroyed by the flood here:
New car sales by the "Big Three" car makers fell 5.5 per cent in the first 10 days of November, according to reports received yesterday from Detroit.
PLAINVILLE, Conn., Nov. 14 (AP)--The priests at Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church asked a favor of the parishioners.
LOS ANGELES, Nov.14 (AP) Eddie Fisher sued Elizabeth Taylor for divorce today, charging desertion and saying her 1964 Mexican divorce was invalid.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 Treasury bill rates showed mixed movements at today's auction, with three-month bills rising slightly from the level last week and six-month bills falling slightly.

WASHINGTON. Nov.14 (AP) The United States Tax Court ruled today that a salary paid to a chauffeur is not deductible from income taxes as a medical expense even if a physician orders the taxpayer to stop driving an automobile.
The election of Thomas James Barlow as president and chief executive officer of Anderson, Clayton Co., was announced yesterday at the annual stockholder meeting in Houston.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 14 The Eastern States Antiques Fair, which opened here today, is, year after year, a collector's hunting ground and a market place for a sizable public.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 A citizens advisory panel was named today to draw up a blueprint to reduce manmade pollutants in the air, on the land and in water.
Mayor Lindsay made public yesterday the broad outlines of his long-heralded plan for consolidating most of the city's agencies and services into 10 superdepartments, or administrations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 New York State's controversial Medicaid program has been approved by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. The long-awaited decision is expected to be officially announced tomorrow.

To those who have watched demonstrators sleep in city hall corridors, lie across highways and shackle themselves to courthouse pillars, the uneasy question has often presented itself: where are the limits to the democratic right of peaceful protest?
Emile Francis counted his blessings yesterday, and even from the eternal optimist, they sound convincing.
NEWINGTON, Conn., Nov. 15 A Searle Pinney, State Republican chairman, announced his resignation tonight at the first meeting held by the G.O.P. since its crushing defeat one week ago.
SOARING earnings have helped a number of stocks move impressively against the trend of the bear market this year.

Admiral Yoshida commanded two Japanese naval training ships that visited New York in 1936. The vessels, anchored in the Hudson River opposite Grant's Tomb, were visited by 15,000 people, and the then vice admiral and his officers were feted at many receptions and other parties.
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Nov. 15 The master plan for a vast recreational preserve a few hours drive from New York City was made public here today by the National Parks Service.

Bizarre was the word for the basketball game at Madison Square Garden last night. The Philadelphia 76ers defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 113109, but the score told only one part of the story the technically illegal on betting side.

TRENTON, Nov. 15 Political leadership of the state Republican party shifted today from the conservatives toward United States Senator Clifford P. Case. The liberal Republican won a third term last week in a landslide victory.

Many department stores that have furniture departments are "simply churning up vast amounts of money, using huge space and employing vast amounts of manpower" for what in the end is little more than "fruitless exercise," Walter N. Rothschild Jr., president of Abraham Straus, Gold an industry audience yesterday.
Led by the glamour group and a few selected issues, the American Stock Exchange managed a modest advance yesterday.
PARIS, Nov. 15 There was a pop and champagne bubbled from the magnum of Pommery. Henri Levesque was celebrating again.
MENDON, Vt., Nov. 15 Seven bucks fell to hunt ers staying act an inn here during the first two days of Vermont's deer season.

Dr. Cary Eggleston, a leading cardiologist and founder of the American Academy of Compensation Medicine, died yesterday at the Homestead Nursing Home in Stamford, Conn. He was 82 years old and lived at 215 East 72d Street.
IN virtually every pictorial style there is an element of charm and an element of rigor, a quality that solicits our interest and a quality that sustains it.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15-- The National Conference of Catholic Bishops set up today a new theological committee to evaluate questions on doctrine.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 15 Recruiting is going on openly in South Africa for tough white mercenaries, allegedly to fight for former Premier Moise Tshombe against Gen. Joseph D. Mobutu's Government of the Congo. An invasion of the Congo is be lieved to be scheduled for January.
HOUSTON, Nov. 15 (AP)-- William N. Blanton, the Harris County Democratic chairman, nursed a chin abrasion today, souvenir of a noisy fight at a party executive committee meeting.

HOUSTON, Nov. 15 Cassius Clay reached his hotel room last night and flopped onto the bed, exhausted but exhilarated. It was perhaps two hours after he had overwhelmed Cleveland Williams with a smothering display of all-round skills in the Astrodome. The champion stared at the ceiling, letting the thoughts tumble through his mind. Then he mentioned aloud the one thing that troubled him most.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15 The New York candidates for the 1967 North American team continued to dominate the standings in the International team trials here today.

TUYHOA, South Vietnam, Nov. 15 Lieut. Col. Alan Wockenfuss eased his F-100 Super Sabre jet onto a 9,000foot aluminum mat runway today to open the ninth United States fighter-plane base in South Vietnam. A tenth will be opened early next year.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 15 (AP) Vladimir Kazan-Komarek, who was arrested in Prague, is a native of Opava, Czechoslovakia, and was taken prisoner by the Germans in World War II.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 16-- The loss of five helicopters to enemy gunners was announced by the United States command yesterday. Contact between United States and enemy troops was reported to be light and scattered.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 Sargent Shriver, who terminated a Mississippi Head Start project six weeks ago and stirred a protest of national dimensions, is resisting the demand of Gov. Paul B. Johnson Jr. of Mississippi for similar action on another project in that state.
What was apparently a plot to rob Kings County Hospital was uncovered last night, the police said, with the arrest of 10 persons in Brooklyn and Manhattan.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 15 At loyalty oath required of Medical applicants not covered by Social Security has been ruled unconstitutional by a threejudge Federal court here.
The French Government is subsidizing a troupe from Le Treleau de Paris appear from Feb. 4 to Feb. 18 in Moliere's "Les Femmes Savantes" at the Barbizon Plaza Theater, 106 Central Park South.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15-- Total inventories at the manufacturing and trade level rose substantially less in September than in any previous month this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

Braulio Baeza, the imperturbable Panamanian, who has done lots of winning in New York stakes events this year, faces a chance today to improve on one of the few unimpressive statistics on his 1966 record.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 15 The proverbial bull in the china shop has had nothing on the Indian cow this last week. Usually lethargic and amiable, the cow has somehow managed to upset much of India's political crockery in its current rampage.

FERDINANDO SARMI, the Italian-born designer who insists that his clothes make women look like women: Dominic Toubeix, who picked up a Coty Award after transferring his allegiance from the Paris couture to Matty Talmack on Seventh Avenue, and Gustave Tassell, the Californian whose austerely elegant clothes belie their point of origin, all showed spring collections this week. All ran true to form.

Two wholesale drug companies filed independent antitrust suits yesterday in Federal Court here seeking a total of $15-million in damages against a group of major pharmaceutical manufacturers and manufacturers of cosmetics and perfumes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 Government officials concerned with distributing birth control information and materials affirmed in the strongest terms today their strict adherence to voluntary methods.

After three hours of fruitless talk on what was to have been the opening night of their new season, negotiations were broken off yesterday between the New York City Ballet Company and its striking musicians.

UNITED NATIONS N.Y., Nov. l5 President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia implored the world's major powers today to act positively and promptly to avert a possible "major racial conflict" in southern Africa.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 15 (AP) A Federal court has been asked to forbid Mississippi draft boards to induct or classify Negroes until members of their race are appointed to the boards in proportion to local population.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 15 George Gund, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Cleveland Trust Company, died today at Cleveland Clinic Hospital. He was 78 years old.

HOUSTON, Nov. 15 His left eye was puffed and it twitched occasionally. His lower lip was swollen and there were five stitches in it. But the big hurt was inside Cleveland Williams today as he spoke of his plans and his problems.

BETHESDA, Md., Nov. 15 President Johnson entered the Bethesda Naval Hospital late today to undergo corrective surgery tomorrow on his abdomen and throat.

ARMONK, N.Y., Nov. 18 What estate owners along Chestnut Ridge had feared for five years happened today: the state asked for bids on construction of Interstate Highway 87 as a six-lane divided superhighway through their woodlands and scenic lakeside vistas.
THE D'Oyly Carte Opera Company returned to New York last night, after a season's absence, with a performance of "The Pirates of Penzance" at City Center.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 President Johnson served notice today that the nation's natural resources were "priceless treasures that must be developed with wisdom and foresight" in the public interest.
The shrill college chant of "We're No. 1" is certain to pierce the autumn air Saturday, when the Irish of Notre Dame meet the Michigan State Spartans in East Lansing, Mich.
The controversial matter of public ownership in member firms of the New York Stock Exchange is being aired anew behind closed doors at the Big Board.

HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 15--The West Coast branch of Actors Studio announced today plans to develop an important theatrical center on the $l.2-million estate of William S. Hart, the old-time Western movie star.

THE Americas Opera Society not only presented Donizetti's "Anna Bolena" last night in Carnegie Hall. It also presented the conductor, Henry Lewis, and several singers in their New York operatic debuts.

WHEN Arnold Constable decided a year ago to change its image from comfortable middle age to the snap, crackle and pop of youth, its first step was to open a section called Chicatique at the back of the street floor.

The word from Governor Rockefeller's inner circle is that he is intent on ending the uneasy, wary relationship between himself and Mayor Lindsay so they can develop a coordinated attack on the problems of New York City.
ATLANTA, Nov. 15 A new round of legal motions was field today that could further entangle the efforts of two competing segregationists to become Governor.

A drastic reorganization of the top management of the United States Lines, including the resignation of William B. Rand, president and a director, was announced yesterday following a meeting of the board of directors.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 15 New York Sire Stakes trotters, competing for more money than many of their drivers ever had gone for in a previous single race, topped tonight's harness-racing card at Roosevelt Raceway.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) The president of the National Newspaper Association has urged an American Bar Association panel to reconsider "some of the more extreme measures" it recommended to safeguard criminal cases against prejudicial publicity.

The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn has been urged to set aside an opinion it hanged down five years ago because, it is argued, Presiding Justice George J. Beldock should have disqualified himself.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 15 (AP)-- The state renewed at the last minute today its charge that the motive for the bludgeon slaying of Marilyn Sheppard in 1954 was the bygone love affair of her husband, Samuel H. Sheppard, with Susan Hayes.
The bond market plunged yesterday into the heaviest schedule of new-issue sales this fall and the volume pushed some interest rates back up to where they were in early September.

United Air Lines, in a prospectus filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said it had placed a $100-million order for five Boeing 747's and optioned five other of the big jetliners.
ROCHESTER, Nov. 15 The settlement of the contest over a secretary's $19-million will here, indicated today that Georgetown University and the University of Notre Dame each would receive $7.1-million.
Conservationists and bass lovers of every stripe some waspish, some poetic, some scholarly yesterday helped tens of thousands of words of scorn on the proposed Storm King Mountain power project.

George L. Bliss, president of the Council of Mutual Savings Institutions, a trade group that says it represents 145 of the nation's more than 6,200 savings and loan associations, declared yesterday that mutual savings associations and mutual savings banks should be exempt from Federal taxation.
R.H. Macy Co., Inc., showed a 15.7 per cent gain in net earnings and a 7.4 per cent increase in sales in the first quarter ended Oct. 29. Jack I. Straus, chairman, reported yesterday.

WENDOVER, Utah, Nov. 15--In last Sunday's Stardust Grand Prix at Las Vegas, Nev., one of the most interesting of many duels for places behind the leader was that between Mark Donohue of Stony Brook, L.I., and George Follmer of Pasadena, Calif., both in Lola-Chevrolets.
MEMPHIS, Nov. 15 (AP) Edward J. Meeman, long-time editor of The Memphis PressScimitar, died today at his suburban home. He was 77 years old.
The spectacularly precise return of Gemini 12, witnessed by millions as it happened yesterday, was a triumphant end both to a great space flight and to the entire brilliant Gemini series.

The hernia repair Dr. George A. Hallenbeck of the Mayo Clinic and his helpers will perform on President Johnson today is a textbook procedure known either as a "vest-overpants operation" or the "Mayo operation."
A one-time high school dropout has been nominated for the second-highest post in the city school system the $32,500-ayear position of Executive Deputy Superintendent.
HAVANA, Nov. 15. The United States team lost its secondround postponed match to the Soviet Union in the 17th Chess Olympics yesterday by 2 -1 at the Havana Libre Hotel.

GREENVALE, L. I., Nov. 15 -- Long Island University will raise its tuition fees between $3 and $8 a credit hour next September. The university trustees cited inflation, higher academic and staff salaries and increased operating expenses in announcing the increases today.

A representative of Pope Paul VI yesterday asked a Bible so ciety which four 19th-century Popes had condemned as having perverted the Scriptures to help produce a joint ProtestantRoman Catholic Bible translation.
During the hours following midnight tonight it may look, at first glance, as if the stars are falling from their fixed positions in the sky.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 15--The nation's $l.35-billion Gemini program to prepare the way for manned flights to the moon came to a safe and successful conclusion today with the splashdown of Gemini 12 after a record-setting mission.

PINEHURST, N. C., Nov. 15 (AP)-- The medalist team of Curtis Person and John Jacobs defeated C.E. Palmer of Sarasota, Fla., and Julian Stanley of St. Marys, W. Va., 7 and 5, today in the first round of the world senior four-ball golf tournament of the Southern Golf Association.

HONG KONG, Nov. 15 --Communist China declared today that it would never be a party to a treaty banning the spread of nuclear weapons. It asserted that it was continuing development of its own nuclear weapons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15-- A State Department spokesman, Robert J. McCloskey, emphasized today that the Government remained adamantly opposed to any proposal that would admit Communist China to United Nations membership and expel Nationalist China.
WASHINGTON, Nov.15 The Justice Department admitted today that Government agents had recorded numerous conversations involving Robert G. Baker, the former Secretary to the Senate Democratic majority.
A student protest yesterday forced Columbia University to curtail a series of student interviews with a personnel recruiter for the Central Intelligence Agency.
RIO De JANEIRO, Nov. 15-- Nearly 20 million Brazilian men and women voted today for a new Congress and thousands of lesser offices.
JERUSALEM (Jordan), Nov. 15 Young men rioted in the dusty streets of Hebron today. It was reported that they were demanding to be armed against further Israeli forays.

WASHINGTON, Nov.15 (AP) A legislative specialist in the Office of Education said today Federal aid programs under which grants are given to church-affiliated colleges would "continue as they have been."

HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif., Nov. 15 (UPI) The authorities were investigating today the death of an internationally known physicist whose speeding automobile struck the rear of a cement truck yesterday a few minutes after hitting another car.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 16-- A senior American Naval officer disclosed today that nuclear-powered United States submarines have been operating in the Gulf of Tonkin off the North Vietnamese coast for many months.
JERUSALEM (Israel), Nov. 15 Premier Levi Eshkol asserted tonight that Syria bore responsibility for the border terrorism that led to the Israeli retaliation raid into Jordan Sunday.
A rumor that began in London yesterday drove copper futures here down the 2 cent-apound limit.
Several companies in a variety of industries voted increased and special dividend payments yesterday.

Edward J. Logue, who last month recommended a radical reorganization and expansion of the city's attack on slums, has turned down Mayor Lindsay's offer to head New York's redevelopment operations, according to high officials in the Lindsay administration.

Deputy Mayor Robert Price has told Mayor Lindsay that he wants to leave his City Hall post Jan. 1. His resignation is scheduled to be announced Friday by the Mayor.

Dr. Leland Rex Robinson, an economist, financier, educator and humanitarian, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital after a long illness. He was 73 years old and lived at Stoneleigh One in Bronxvilie, N.Y., and at The Birches in Jefferson, N.H.

The Board of Elections here rejected yesterday a recommendation that it count paper ballots that fell to the bottom of the voting machines in last week's election of 15 delegatesat-large to the state Constitutional Convention.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 Officials of the United States and Mexico began a three-day meeting here today on steps to control the steadily growing smuggling of narcotics and other dangerous drugs across the 1,500-mile border between the two countries.
Beset by Government investigations and consumer boycotts, the entire food industry has started a campaign to give the public its side of the story.

Negotiations between the radio and television networks and the performers' unions continued this morning past a previously announced midnight strike deadline.
Shaking off early weakness, the stock market got back on the upward track yesterday.

The Maltese Ball will be given on Dec. 1 in the Crystal and Terrace Rooms at the Plaza by the Hungarian Knights of Malta in Exile. Countess John Palffy is chairman for the annual invitational champagne supper dance, a benefit for the organization's relief program.

In the best of circumstances, India would be an extraordinarily difficult nation to rule but the circumstances are not the best. India has more languages than Europe, more tribes than the Congo, more people than any nation in the world except Communist China. For the second year in succession there has....
LONDON, Nov. 15 Britain's trade balance moved into surplus in October for the first time in 1966.
Puerto Rican civic leaders here clashed in a debate yesterday with the author of a new book that starkly portrays a slum family in San Juan and New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 An American travel agent who was born in Czechoslovakia was jailed there on the way back. from a meeting in Moscow when the Soviet Aeroflot plane on which he was a passenger made a detour to land at Prague.
VIENNA, Nov. 15 President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union gave Austria a friendly but firm, warning today against involvement in the European Economic Community.
A transportation authority warned the commercial aviation industry yesterday to watch out for possible artificial barriers set up by the new Department of Transportation that could stunt its growth.
GAITHERSBURG, Md., Nov. 15 An Air Force plan to have university experts investigate unidentified flying objects is getting "good acceptance" in the academic world, Dr. Edward U. Condon said today.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 15 (AP)--A dozen students clashed with policemen tonight in a Pembroke College auditorium after a speech on Vietnam by Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Nov. 15--The Soviet Union gave implicit support today for a conference of the world's Communist parties on China, but, also implicitly, Rumania rejected it.
MESA, Ariz., Nov. 15 (AP) While his father sat silently without show of emotion, Robert Benjamin Smith was named by a coroners' jury today as the killer of four women and a child.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 The most durable public official in Washington today is W. Averell Harriman, diplomat, croquet champion of the universe, and dean of Yale's "old boy network," who came here temporarily in 1934 and just got back this week from a world peace mission in time to celebrate his 75th birthday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 15 (AP) On a recent muggy morning, Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge took a short stroll around the corner from the embassy down a narrow stall-lined street with the quaint name PX Alley.

The New York Giants underwent the biggest midseason shake-up in their six years under Coach Allie Sherman yesterday as five men were benched and nine were either elevated to starting roles or assigned new ones.

The Bankers Trust Company is banking on the appeal of such contemporary phenomena as the bunny filled Playboy Club and other key clubs, and is adopting a flight path chartered by the stewardess-equipped airlines. Yesterday Bankers Trust introduced its first two "hostesses" to the normally oxfordgray financial world.

Mayor Lindsay named Markets Commissioner Samuel J. Kearing Jr. yesterday to replace Joseph F. Periconi as Sanitation Commissioner with a specific directive to reorganize the scandal-shaken department.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 15 (UPI) Jim McManus of Berkeley, Calif., and Allen Fox of Los Angeles lost singles matches in the New South Wales lawn tennis championship today while Rosemary Casals of San Francisco advanced in the doubles.

OTTAWA, Nov. 15 Air travelers sought alternative means of transportation as the strike by machinists and other ground personnel against Air Canada entered its first full day. The walkout against the national airline began at 4 P.M. yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov.15 (AP) Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler today called undesirable any attempt by the Federal Government to hold down American travel abroad as a way to end the dollar drain.
Mailbag International, Inc., a sophisticated direct-mail approach to the profitable teenage market, is now wholly owned by its creator and its president.

Although he is one of the newest and least known of the cinema moguls, Eliot Hyman observes the traditions of the trade. "You might say," he said yesterday, "that I got into this business through gin rummy."
GAITHERSBURG, Md., Nov. 15 The Federal laboratories that define the basic characteristics of cars, television sets and the rockets that will send men to the moon were dedicated here today.
The American Tobacco Company announced yesterday it is negotiating to acquire a majority interest in the James B. Beam Distilling Company.
