The American Tobacco Company announced yesterday it is negotiating to acquire a majority interest in the James B. Beam Distilling Company.

PARIS This week's truculent Israeli raid into Jordan came as an unhappy reminder that not only Vietnam but numerous other legacies of partition remain still capable of producing sudden major war in Germany, Berlin, India, Korea.

FOR the first time since the Ivy League began formal competition in 1956, the cham pionship could end in a triple tie, with Dartmouth, Harvard and Princeton sharing the title. Victories by all three will bring that about.
Heard address by President Kaunda of Zambia; discussed prohibition of force in international relations, and right to self-determination.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 15 Real estate brokers from around the country agreed today that ownership of property and particulary raw land served as the best hedge against the inflation that appears to have become a semi-permanent fixture of the American economy.
The name of Abel Lauvray, a minor French follower of the impressionist school who died in obscurity 16 years ago, has flared up in a sudden blaze of publicity.

Two women who worked as bare-breasted waitresses and the manager of the Crystal Room, the nightclub that employed them, were held yesterday on charges of indecent exposure, creating a public nuisance, maintaining a public nuisance and permitting a building to be used for a public nuisance.

A special three-judge Federal court reserved decision here yesterday on a petition by a major holder of first-mortgage bonds of the New Haven Railroad for an interlocutory judgment that would hold up the merger plans of the New York Central and Pennsylvania railroads.
WASHINGTON, Nov.15 Organized labor said today that it would make a comprehensive study of its political program to find out why it suffered a major defeat in this year's elections.

By his own admission, Sir Malcolm Sargent has "known, loved, rehearsed and performed" Handel's "Messiah" for nearly 40 years. He is one of its most ubiquitous interpreters in his native England, and he has...

ALBANY, Nov. 15 State Senator Jack E. Bronston, who unsuccessfully sought the Democratic leadership in the Senate last year, proposed today a series of legislative and electoral reform bills as a "base" to strengthen the Democratic party in the state.
BONN, Nov. 15 The Free Democratic party appeared today to be edging closer to a coalition with the Social Democrats.
HOUSTON, Nov. 15 -- Ernie Terrell, the long-armed jab-and-clutch artist they call the Octopus, will be Cassius Clay's next title opponent.
Litton Industries, Inc., Beverly Hills, Calif., an electronics concern, announced yesterday a net profit of $16-million, equal to 65 cents a share, for the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) Mrs. Lyndon B Johnson today presented 13 industrial landscaping awards of the American Association of Nurserymen.

THE books mentioned in yesterday's roundup stayed pretty much in the Western world, but "The Book of Por celain" makes a leap to the other side of the globe and into the 18th century (Macmillan. $25). A series of Chinese water-colors, 34 in number, it offers a step by step account of the making of Chinese pottery.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary will announce next week the formation of the Police Department's new five-man Complaint Review Board, armed with a new procedure for investigating civilian complaints against the police.

More than 80 per cent of the 1,700 college graduates trained for teaching this summer in a seven-week emergency program have been assigned to schools with heavy concentrations of disadvantaged pupils.

OLSO, Norway, Nov. 14 Norway has been governed for more than a year by a nonSocialist Coalition that took over after three decades of Labor party rule, but scarcely anyone here has noticed much difference except in atmosphere.
ROME, Nov. 15 The Italian Government today considered a combination of new taxes and borrowing to finance reconstruction after the floods in central and northern Italy.
TORONTO, Nov. 15 (AP) Moffatt Dunlap of Canada, on Grand Nouvee, won the International Maple Leaf Stakes tonight at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair's horse show.
A pioneer in the chemical treatment of cancer and a leadink explorer of living cells have been chosen as recipients of this year's Albert Lasker Medical Research Awards. Each will receive $10,000.

A GENERAL review of the labor movement was pre sented last night by "C.B.S. Reports;" it was a document that touched on most of the strengths and advantages of unions and also their weaknesses and excesses.
The London stock market closed firm yesterday. Sentiment was buoyed by the report that Britain had a favorable trade balance in October.

Persistent famine conditions in India have led wheat traders to have some second thoughts, and yesterday their buying pushed up prices for this basic commodity, despite the expected worldwide bumper crop.

NEW YORK'S hunting season swings into the final stretch as the second half of the duck and goose gunning session opens on Long Island Saturday. The entire state will have legal deer hunting on Monday when the southern zone opens.
The Appellate Division sharply criticized and then rejected yesterday the methods of the Federal Government in trying to establish neighborhood law offices here to assist the poor.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 16 Across the Notre Dame campus, the Golden Dome atop the administration building glistened today in the late afternoon sun.
Stock prices surged upward in heavy trading yesterday following the successful completion of minor surgery on President Johnson.

DEMOPOLIS, Ala., Nov. 16 Donald A. Jelinek, a New York lawyer who has represented civil rights workers in the South for more than a year, was jailed here today on a charge of practicing law without an Alabama license.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 16 Unless the nation develops a more flexible fiscal policy, the mortgage market will undergo recurrent "problem years" in the foreseeable future, Sherman J. Maisel, a governor of the Federal Reserve System, said today.
FORT DIX, N.J. Nov. 16 For tens of thousands of New Yorkers and their families the most important hospital is located 72 miles southwest of Manhattan, deep in the New Jersey woodlands.
James W. Davant, managing partner of Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, said yesterday he was opposed to any "piecemeal" changes in the New York Stock Exchange's minimum-commission structure.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 A safety device of the brain is its automatic noise cutoff. We enter a restaurant where music by Muzak is oozing out of walls and ceiling and the cutoff switch, activated by the first bar of "Mammy's little baby loves shortnin' bread," instantly deadens the brain's Muzak receptors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 The merger plan of the Pennsylvania and the New York Central railroads "is going to collapse" if those two big lines encounter any further "substantial" delay in starting unified operation, the Pennsy's chairman, Stuart T. Saunders, said here today.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., Nov. 16 A civic controversy over the state's plan to widen a picturesque but congested road here took on political overtones today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 Sargent Shriver is giving $1.27million to antipoverty projects in Mississippi and Alabama that the Governors of those states do not want.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Nov. 16 Frank Wosser of San Francisco scored a double victory today in the international One-Design Class world championships in Bermuda by winning the opening race of the series in the morning and repeating in the afternoon for a commanding six-point lead over Kalle Nergaard of Oslo, Noray.
THE surprise of the Onondaga Kennel Association show is Syracuse last Sunday was the number of Alaskan Malamutes that was entered.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz proposed a new "policy for youth" tonight that would register all 18-year-olds for two years of education, employment, military service or community service.
THE program called "A.B.C. Stage 67" tried another musical tack last night and once again misfortune attended its ambitions.
HERB SLATTERY of Delaware, Tom Cassese of C.W. Post, Jim Murphy of Bats and Tom Phillips of Williams have not been getting big Sunday morning headlines coast to coast.
Sales of the nation's leading chain organizations rose 7.1 per cent in October from the level a year earlier the smallest percentage increase in 16 months.

A Brooklyn business man, identified only as a prominent building contractor in his fifties, charged yesterday that two men had taken him out to sea, beaten him and threatened him with drowning unless he paid them $7,000.

BETHESDA, Md., Nov. 16 The President's surgeons said today it was unlikely that Mr. Johnson would suffer a recurrence of either the polyp that was removed from his throat or the incisional hernia that was repaired in his abdomen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP)-- The American travel agent jailed in Czechoslovakia on charges of treason and espionage was once employed by the United States Army Quartermaster in Germany, the State Department said today.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Nov. 16--Heavy fighting broke out today for the first time in six weeks near the demilitarized zone dividing North Vietnam from South Vietnam.
A leading small-boat operator took a critical look last night at his industry's performance over the past 25 years.
The advisory council of the American Bible Society responded favorably yesterday to Pope Paul VI's proposal for point Protestant-Roman Catholic translation and distribution of the Scriptures.
The Chicago Black Hawks' explosive power was throttled last night by an eager, unintimidated bunch of Rangers who took the offensive and played the Hawks to a 2-2 tie.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 One lapse, which extended over the last two minutes of the third period and the first two minutes of the fourth, undid the New York Knickerbockers tonight as they lost again to the Philadelphia 76ers, 117-108.
ROME, Nov. 16 Pope Paul VI delivered today an exceptionally sharp warning to elements in the Society of Jesus whom he accused of "strange and sinister" distortions of its 400year-old principles.

LONDON, Nov. 16 The international war crimes tribunal sponsored by Bertrand Russell, which plans to "try" the United States next spring on charges of war crimes in Vietnam, announced today that it "hoped" to gather evidence "on the spot."

Warning that "pressure is being exerted" to reduce Federal aid grants to airports, George E. Keck, president of United Air Lines, proposed legislation yesterday to make Federal loans available for financing airport improvements.

Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Avenue at 55th Street, will celebrate its 120th anniversary at a dinner on Dec. 4 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. On the program will be a dramatic presentation written by Alfred Levinson about the years of service by the Reform temple.
Several thousand New Yorkers trooped out to the Sheep Meadow in Central Park last night and early this morning to watch a shower of Leonid meteors.
The appointment of Andrew W. Tarkington, 55-yearold president of the Continental Oil Company, as chief executive officer effective Jan. 1 was announced yesterday.
A major breakthrough was made yesterday in the five-yearold power struggle in American amateur sports.

An impressive front-running performance was contributed by J. Graham Brown's Woozem in the $28,900 Demoiselle Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. Kenny Knapp moved the daughter of Hail to Reason into the lead shortly after the start, and she enjoyed her pace-setting role so much that she moved away from her pursuers with every stride.

MOVED by the assassination of President Ken nedy, and stimulated by Aaron Copland's "Lincoln Portrait," William Sydeman has composed a work for narrator and orchestra named "In Memoriam John F. Kennedy."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16 The four major powers in the United Nations vigorously condemned Israel today in the Security Council for her reprisal raid last Sunday in Jordan.

THE French have that convenient connotation "the theater of miracles," and it will do well enough as genre term for "The Apparition Theater of Prague," which opened a limited engagement at the Cort Theater last night. Unquestionably this show constituted the cleverest conjuring trick I have ever seen ... and also the longest.
Jack Sterling, who was WCBS-radio's early morning man for 18 years, is expected to sign a contract soon with station WHN. He will broadcast from 6 to 10 A.M., Mondays through Fridays.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 16 The Cleveland Museum of Art opened today a triumphant exihibition, "Treasures from Medieval France," that has been four years in the planning and shows it in every detail of the selection and installation of 160 sculptures, paintings, drawings, tapestries and enamels covering seven centuries of French art.
READING Sir Harold Nicolson's diaries is exhilarating. It is like being pelted by confetti made from Burke's "Peer age," Hansard's Parliamentary reports, and the British "Who's Who."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16-- An experienced diplomat recently expressed grave doubt whether continued membership in the United Nations was in the interest of his government or any "advanced, responsible government."

ALBANY, Nov. 16 Chief Judge Charles S. Desmond of the Court of Appeals, Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia and former Mayor Robert F. Wagner of New York City have emerged as the three leading Democratic contenders to preside over the 1967-State Constitutional Convention, party sources said today.

WHEN women see Roberta perform at Macy's, their usual comment is "harumph." Men, on the other hand, often express the desire to take her home. Roberta is 5 feet 8 inches tall, measures 38-24-36, and weighs 65 pounds. She wears black leotards, a green minidress and sunglasses. But her most attractive feature to men, anyway is that she can be turned on and off at will.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 18 The Michigan State football squad that Coach Duffy Daugherty is honing for the "Poll Game" against Notre Dame here Saturday has so many fine players it's almost unfair to pick one for special mention.
Edward J. Logue has rejected Mayor Lindsay's invitation to lead an attack on New York's slums which harbor about a million people in substandard housing. His decision raises two key questions.
A preliminary survey by the State Health Department recommended yesterday that the city delegate more power to administrators of its 21 hospitals to remedy glaring inefficiencies.

Mayor Lindsay's plan for streamlining the vast and unwieldy executive branch of the city government into ten administrations, plus the Police and Fire Departments, offers real hope for improving administrative efficiency. But it also may create new problems.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 16 John Marbach, city assessor here since 1952, and former president of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards, died of a heart attack today in St. Agnes Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 455 North Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 Industrial production moved up again in October, after a onemonth interruption, but the rise was one of the smallest of the year.
More than 600 schoolchildren many from neighborhoods where "cop" is a curseword cheered and applauded yesterday afternoon as policemen called in a man near Randalls island and took him away.

HOUSTON, Nov. 16 The first of the glamour college quarterbacks to be snatched from the National Football League by the fledgling Americans was Don Trull of Baylor. Yet for two and a half seasons he squirmed with growing impatience on the Houston Oiler bench, waiting for old age to catch up with George Blanda.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16 Norman Call, convicted in the murder of Dow Wilson, a union official, testified today that he and Max Ward, a painting contractor, had also taken part in the killing of a second labor leader, Lloyd Green.
Mayor Lindsay, who had opposed bare bosoms for waitresses on Monday, revoked a 1959 ruling yesterday to permit bare bosoms for members of the Guinean dance troupe, Les Ballets Africains.
Roberto Clemente of the Pittsburgh Pirates was elected the most valuable player in the National League yesterday, eclipsing Sandy Koufax of the Los Angeles Dodgers in a photo finish.
THE HAGUE, Nov. 16 The Netherlands, in the midst of economic troubles and a political crisis, turned to an economist today to try to form a new government.

Deputy Mayor Robert Price will formally submit his resignation to Mayor Lindsay today to become executive vice president of the Dreyfus Corporation, which manages one of the country's largest investment companies, the Dreyfus Fund.

The American Stock Exchange made its broadest advance in more than five weeks yesterday in very active trading. The market opened higher and steady increased its gains throughout the session. Brokers said the improvement stemmed largely from news of President Johnson's successful operation yesterday morning.

The $130-million Pacific Telephone Company debenture issue marketed on Tuesday was reported completely sold yesterday, and the success of the sale prompted a rise in the rest of the corporate bond market.
PARIS, Nov. 16-- The French Cabinet approved new rules today for the National Assembly elections next spring.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 16 A major step toward cooperation among the Lutheran Churches in America was taken here today with the formation of the Lutheran Council in the United States of America.

BARRINGTON, R.L., Nov. 16 The engagement of Miss Sherrie L. Stephens to Laurence S. Cutler, son of Dr. and Mrs. Hermann S. Cutler of New Haven, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. H. Frederick Stephens of Barrington and St. Croix, the Virgin Islands.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 16 Lieut. Col. Yakubu Gowon, Nigeria's head of state, announced today the suspension of constitutional talks to reshape Nigeria's political future.
IT MAY SEEM superfluous to suggest selling shares to realize capital gains in a year when stock prices have been mostly lower.
ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 16 (UPI) The Florida Supreme Court will be asked to decide whether a judge's order restricting coverage of a trial violates the freedom-of-the-press guarantee of the Constitution.
The Lindsay administration abandoned the polite soft-sell of its campaign to keep New York City clean yesterday and moved into a hard "hit-'em-as-they-litter" approach.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 The United States partly fulfilled a long-standing offer today by permitting. United Nations representatives to look at a oncesecret reactor that produced plutonium for hundreds of atomic bombs. It was closed down two years ago.

Emerson Boozer, a rookie who has never started a professional football game, will start at halfback for the New York Jets Sunday Mark Smolinski, who hasn't started since the last game last year, will start at fullback. Bill Mathis, who has started 56 straight games at halfback or fullback, will be on the bench.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 16 The winner of Big Three honors for the third successive year, Princeton closes its football season in Palmer Stadium Saturday against Corneal with the opportunity of at least sharing in the Ivy League championship for the third time in four seasons.
Persons who would live close to the proposed power project at Storm King Mountain testified yesterday in its favor in the third day of Federal Power Commission hearings here.

A $900,000 experimental theater, seating 200 people, is scheduled to open in February at Syracuse University. The house has not been named yet. The late J. Robert Rubin, vice president and general counsel of Loew's, Inc., contributed $300,000 toward its construction.
Whatever else Robert Goldsand is and his pianism was several things last night he is always interesting.

TOKYO, Nov. 16 In the estimation of millions of baseball-mad Japanese, the Los Angeles Dodgers lost the real World Series today when they were beaten by the Yomiuri Giants of Tokyo for the fourth straight time in a series of seven games. The Dodgers won the three others.
The Society of Jesus was founded in 1540 with the twin goals of defending the faith against heresy and of carrying the message of the Roman Catholic Church to the heathen throughout the world.

Aluminum shipments will rise 10 per cent to a record this year and uses of the metal in transportation equipment may exceed construction uses for the first time, William T. Ingram president of the Aluminum Association, said here yesterday.
TEXTILES for fashion and interior decorating may soon be created with a pen that writes with light on an electronic drawing board linked to a computer.
A political associate of Mayor Lindsay in his successful campaign last year has been employed as public relations consultant to' the Department of Real Estate at $15,000 a year.
GENEVA, Nov. 16 Funds of the Chase Manhattan Bank on deposit in Swiss banks were attached today by order of a Geneva civil court.
DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 16 (AP) Two large bronze plaques were hoisted into place on a slab of granite today, telling in words and a relief map about the assassination of President Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16-- Robert C. Weaver, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, cautioned a Senate subcommittee today against "a monolithic approach" to the problem of coordinating Federal aid to states and localities.
WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 16 Danny Row Gil romped to an eighth-length triumph over Nibble's Bonny in the one-mile pace for New York-bred 4-year-olds tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 Once again the nation has been fortunate. It has passed without incident through a period, this time mercifully brief, when its President lay totally incapacitated.

The statement by the Roman Catholic cardinals and bishops of the United States that the Government and its agencies are using "coercion" to make underprivileged American families practice birth control will come as a great surprise. No persons will be more surprised than United States Government officials and state and municipal welfare organizations.
The longest color transparency in the whole wide world will make its debut after Thanksgiving in the new Pennsylvania Station.

KUCHING, Malaysia, Nov. 16 Sarawak, one of the largest, emptiest, poorest and most politically disrupted of the 13 states in the federation of Malaysia, was propelled into union with Malaysa three years ago. It now seems to be pushing its way out.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 The Association of State Colleges and Universities endorsed today Congressional efforts to force judicial review of the validity of Federal aid to church-related institutions.
Mitchell Sviridoff, the city's new Human Resources Administrator, accused the state yesterday of shirking while "sprawling ghettos threaten to destroy its cities."

VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 16 (AP) Gen. Kong Le, commander of the neutralist Laotian Army, returned to Vientiane last night and took refuge in the Indonesian Embassy, senior officers of the rightist Royal Army reported today.
The formation of a new service to guide schools in the purchase of teaching materials and textbooks was announced yesterday.
DETROIT, Nov. 16 Students at the University of Michigan voted today in a referendum on whether academic class standings should be compiled for the Selective Service System.
Mayor Lindsay asked the State Industrial Commissioner yesterday to appoint a board to study and report on the 116day-old strike of 4,000 construction plumbers in Manhattan and the Bronx.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 16 Louis Nizer, the lawyer, tonight assailed recently published criticisms of the Warren Commission's report on President Kennedy's assassination. He called them "an outrage."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 The National Conference of Catholic Bishops created here today a General Secretariat for Ecumenical and Interreligious Affairs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 Months before the financial dealings of Robert G. Baker became known in September, 1963, the Federal Bureau of Investigation suspected him of using his political influence as Senate Democratic secretary to help Nevada gambling figures, a Federal Court was told today.
When will the Securities and Exchange Commission issue its long-awaited report on mutual funds?
Profit taking caused prices to drift down on the London Stock Exchange yesterday, reversing a firm opening trend.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UPI) Representative Adam Clayton Powell has canceled a proposed black power national conference and withdrawn as its "sole convener," his office disclosed today.
HONG KONG, Nov. 16 A report from Peking implies that the Standing Committee of the Communist party's Politburo has been enlarged from seven to 10 or more members.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Nov. 16-- The call for a conference of the world's Communist parties on China showed signs today of turning into a serious setback for the Soviet Union.

A committee that has surveyed the cultural resources of the city at the request of Mayor Lindsay recommended yesterday that the Mayor set up a 13member council to coordinate and guide the city's cultural life.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 Military hospitals may perform surgical sterilization on women dependents for sound medical reasons, but not for social on economic reasons, the Defense Department said today.

Thirteen directors of the Hilton Hotels Corporation have agreed to pay $825,000 over a period of six and a half years to the corporation to settle stockholder suits that charged they sold shares back to the corporation at inflated prices.

BATH, Me., Nov. 16 William Zorach, the Lithuanianborn American artist whose sculptures of children, animals, lovers and Biblical figures are in the permanent collections of more than 80 museums and galleries, died last night in Bath Memorial Hospital. He was 79 years old.
BETHESDA, Md., Nov. 16 A team of surgeons successfully removed a nonmalignant polyp from President Johnson's throat this morning, then repaired a small ventral hernia in an old surgical scar.
PEKING The Communist regime has maintained silence on the forthcoming debate on who should sit in China's seat at the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 President Johnson's top economic advisers have urged him to reach and announce by early next month a decision on whether a tax increase is needed for next year. This became known today as Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler asserted in a speech in Chicago that Government policy had already succeeded ...

Leon Shimkin, president of the book publishing concern of Simon Schuster, Inc., has pledged $2-million to New York University's capital fund. Dr. James M. Hester, president of the university, announced the gift yesterday.
VIENNA, Nov. 16 While President Nikolai V. Podgorny's state visit is occupying Austrian officialdom, his 21-yeas-old daughter Natalya, known to friends as Natasha, has won Viennese hearts.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 16 (UPI) Brown University, following the example of fellow Ivy League institution Harvard, apologized today to a top-ranking Defense Department official for a student outbreak during his campus appearance.
The owner of two popular East Side night spots is contesting in Federal Court the right of the State Liquor Autthority to take away the liquor licenses of The Living Room an The Phone Booth.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 16 Samuel H. Sheppard was found not guilty tonight of killing his pregnant wife, Marllyn, in her bedroom 12 years ago.
Mayor Lindsay announced the appointment yesterday of Harry J. O'Donnell, one of the state's top-ranking political publicity men, as his new press secretary.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 16 Edgar Kaplan of New York and Norman Kay of Philadelphia took the lead in the sixth round of the International team trials here tonight by crushing B. Jay Becker of Flushing and Mrs. Dorothy Hayden of Hastingson-Hudson, N.Y., 75-9.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 Richard Speck, 24-year-old itinerant seaman, made his 10th court appearance today since his arrest three months ago on charges of killing eight student nurses here.
HAVANA, Nov. 16 The United States team was held to a 2-2 tie by Bulgaria in the 10th round of the premier finals of the 17th Chess Olympics here last night.
The three-day musicians' strike that blocked the opening of the New York City Ballet Company's season at at the New York State Theater was settled yesterday.

The academic freedom committee of the American Civil Liberties Union urged the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools yesterday to revoke the accreditation of St. John's University.

The gasoline engine, despite the recent flurry of interest in electric powered autos, will continue to be the main power source for the motor vehicle for many years to come, Lynn A. Townsend, president of the Chrysler Corporation, said yesterday.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Nov. 16 While Zambia struggles to shake loose the trade strings that tie her to Rhodesia, South Africa has been picking them up and has emerged as-Zambia's main trading partner.
PARIS, Nov. 16 Le Figaro, as much a part of the French bourgeois breakfast as cafe au lait, celebrated today its 100th anniversary as a daily newspaper.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 Jesse M. Unruh, Speaker of the California Assembly and a key figure in the Democratic party, left the impression here today that he thought Ronald Reagan might make a good Governor.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 16-- Premier Nguyen Cao Ky's Government took three steps today to neutralize widespread political discontent.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 16-- A committee of Princeton undergraduate leaders proposed today the end of the "bicker" system of selecting members for the university eating clubs.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 16 Arthur James Davis, accused of slaying six people here in a wild search for his estranged girl friend Aug. 6, was found guilty by a three-judge panel in Superior Court this afternoon of six counts of first-degree murder.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration has ruled as unacceptable the research of Dr. Robert A. Wilson in connection with the oral birth control drug Enovid, a spokesman for the agency said today.
The Board of Education last night approved a $55-million program for disadvantaged children.

Ralph Nader, the auto safety advocate who led a successful fight for Federal legislation, filed a $26-million invasion of privacy suit against the General Motors Corporation yesterday in State Supreme Court here.
When the Furness liner Queen of Bermuda sails from here on Saturday it will be her last round trip to Hamilton, Bermuda Or any other port as a passenger carrier.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 16 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi appealed today for an end to political agitation that would disrupt the flow of food to drought areas. "This is no time for general strikes and work stoppages," she declared.
The First National City Bank, which moved its main office from 55 Wall Street to 399 Park Avenue five years ago, disclosed plans yesterday for a new, automated bank back on its old stamping ground.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 16 First returns from Brazil's Congressional election showed the Opposition winning in major cities, as expected. But the Government was piling up majorities in rural areas and smaller towns.
JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 16 Roy C. Wilkins, whose name used to be anathema here, today completed a five-day speaking tour of Mississippi that was marked by several surprising developments.

YONKERS, Nov. 16 Thomas M. Tobin, president since 1920 of Thomas M. Tobin, Inc., insurance agents, 20 South Broadway here, died yesterday in Yonkers Professional Hospital after a brief illness. He was 80 years old and lived at 461 Riverdale Avenue.

Two once-prominent sugar trading concerns, Olavarria Co. and the Galban Lobo Company, Ltd., which have been struggling for more than two years to work out financial difficulties under Chapter XI of the bankruptcy act, yesterday admitted defeat.
The mailman soon will be delivering to each taxpayer a packet of Federal income tax returns that will have a somewhat new look.

SOUTH PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 16 W. Manning Barr, who retired two years ago as senior partner of the municipal bond firm of Barr Bros. Co. at 40 Wall Street, New York, died here yesterday. He was 75 years old and lived on Woodland Avenue.

THE characteristic moves of the Gruenfeld Defense are 1 P-Q4, N-KB3; 2 P-QB4, P-KN3; 3 N-QB3, P-Q4. Its singular idea--Black's 3... P-Q4--was conceived by the Viennese grand master Ernst Gruenfeld about 1922 in an attempt to bolster the defender's play in the regular King's Indian, and it leads to a sharp confrontation by both sides.
OTTAWA, Nov. 16 Young rebels who dealt a blow to John Diefenbaker at this week's Progressive Conservative party convention have opened new challenges to the party's future.

HAVANA, Nov. 17 The United States team secured its hold on second place in the 17th Chess Olympics by defeating Czechoslovakia 2 -1 in the 11th round at the Havana, Libre Hotel here last night. The Americans have scored 29 points, a full point ahead of third-place Hungary, with two rounds to go.
VENICE, Nov. 17 (Reuters) More than 3,000 inhabitants of the Po Delta villages of Scardovan and Bonelli were evacuated today for the second time in two weeks after a dike gave way.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 Maj, Gen, Harold N. Gilbert, who during World War II was called the "builder of the Armies" and the Army's master salesman," died of a heart ailment yesterday at the Walter Reed Army Hospital. He was 70 years old.

CASTEAU, Belgium, Nov. 17 Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, inaugurated work on a 500-acre site near this Belgian village today for the new Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe. It must be operative by April 1.
Polato futures had a down and up day yesterday, with prices at the close showing only a small change.

The scope of the subtle shift toward slightly easier money that has been going on for the last few weeks became a bit clearer during the week ended Wednesday, banking statistics released yesterday by the Federal Reserve indicated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 The Administration will seek in the new Congress four controversial outdoor recreation and conservation measures denied by Congress this year, Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said today.
PARIS The bidet, a humble piece of French plumb ing, is moving into grand days.

WHEEL WRIGHT, Ky., Nov. 17 An era of benevolent and sometimes not so benevolent paternalism that has been dying in the Kentucky coal fields for two decades ended finally here today with the sale of the state's last Company-owned coal town.
The city's 20-cent bus and subway fare will be maintained at least through June 30, 1967, the end of the current fiscal year, a Transit Authority member assured the Board of Estimate yesterday.
MADRID, Nov. 17 Tensions between Morocco and Spain over Spanish African territories are rising rapidly.

There were strong indications yesterday that the new Commissioner of Markets would be Gerard M. Weisberg, the present first deputy commissioner of licenses and an important figure in the Liberal party.
The criminal courthouse at 100 Centre Street will be open 24 hours a day seven days a week beginning Jan. 1, to permit arraignment of suspects at any time.

Cornell's hopes of sharing in the Ivy football championship virtually ended last Saturday when its 17-7 lead over Dartmouth proved unavailing against the resourcefulness and passing of Mickey Beard, but the Big Red, in the words of Coach Jack Musick, "is definitely going down to Princeton with the idea of going after 'em."

An organization representing 250 union leaders in New York and New Jersey criticized the national leadership of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. yesterday for supporting the Johnson Administration policies in Vietnam and called for an immediate de-escalation of the war.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 17 The new Lutheran Council of the United States is part of the new hope for unity of Lutheranism in America, Dr. Jerald C. Brauer, dean of the divinity school of the University of Chicago, said last night.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 17 (AP) The Detroit Pistons blew a 13-point second-half lead tonight but rallied behind Coach Dave DeBusschere to defeat the New York Knicks, 123-108.

Parent and citizen groups opposed to public aid for parochial-school pupils appealed yesterday to the State Education Commissioner to stop the Board of Education from proceeding with its $65-million program for disadvantaged children.
The American Stock Exchange's rally, which started on Wednesday, ran out of steam yesterday.

ROME, Nov. 17 (AP) Three of the oldest Roman Catholic Cardinals, including the dean of the Sacred College, have resigned from their Italian dioceses while retaining their Vatican posts, the Vatican announced today.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 17 The National Association of Real Estate Boards reaffirmed today its opposition to laws seeking to promote equal access to housing for racial minority groups.

THE most profound problems for contemporary Christian theologians were defined more than 20 years ago in a Nazi prison. There Dietrish Bonhoeffer, the German theologian who was soon to be martyred for his role in the plot to kill Hitler, wrote a series of letters, describing the religious implications of man's "coming of age." It used to be, he said, that man needed the ...

CAMP CARROLL, South Vietnam, Nov. 17 Slowed by monsoon weather, United States Marines and South Vietnamese troops chipped away today at enemy positions just south of the demilitarized zone separating North Vietnam and South Vietnam.

RIO GRANDE CITY, Tex., Nov. 17 (AP) A Starr County grand jury asserted yesterday that a strike by Rio Grande Valley farm workers was "unlawful and un-American" and "abusive of rights and freedoms granted them as citizens."

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 17 A leading American anthropologist warned tonight that secrecy and pressures by United States intelligence agencies were eroding the effectiveness and prestige of American scholarly research abroad.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 17 Senior officials of the United States aid program conceded today that there was corruption and thievery to the extent that $35-million to $40-million worth of American commodities would be lost in Vietnam in the current fiscal year.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 17 The seventh round of the International Team Trials began here this afternoon with New York players in a commanding position. Three pairs have outdistanced their competitors to such an extent in the first six rounds that it seems unlikely that they will be overtaken.
Borough President Herman Badillo of the Bronx proposed 174 borough improvements to the City Planning Commission yesterday for inclusion in the 1967-68 capital budget.
SYRACUSE, Nov. 16 Indians living on the Onondaga Indian Reservation do not have to collect or pay a sales tax on items sold in their trading post gift shops, a State Supreme Court justice has ruled.

The Rev. Dr. Josef L. Hromadka, a Czech Protestant theologian who is visiting the United States, thinks that Marxists in Eastern Europe are showing a new interest in the contributions religion can make to a Communist society.
The Kimberly-Clark Corporation, a producer of book and fine papers, announced yesterday it achieved record sales and earnings in the second fiscal quarter and first six months.

LINZ, Austria, Nov. 17 President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union used a visit to the Largest Austrian steel works today to add an economic inducement to his warning against Austrian association with the European Common Market.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 By a vote of 3 to 1 the National Conference of Catholic Bishops agreed today to petition the Vatican for permission to use English in the canon, or the heart of the mass.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 17 Ara Parseghian, the coach, and Terry Hanratty, his boy wonder quarterback, were play ing catch today on Cartier Field in a warming-up exercise.
PARIS In no city but Paris and perhaps for no newspaper but Le Figaro could a centenary be celebrated with such combined chic and flamboyance as that now being observed.

LANSING, Mich. Nov. 17 (UPI) Robert J. (Jack) McIntosh, director of the Michigan Department of Commerce, resigned today to begin active and "immediate" work to win the 1968 Republican Presidential nomination for Gov. George Romney.
James Roosevelt is expected to resign soon as United States delegate to the United Nations Economic and Social Council to become president of a subsidiary of Investors Overseas Service.

The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists began a work stoppage yesterday against taped television shows whose producers would not promise to keep the programs off the air in case the union strikes the networks. Contracts with all national networks expired at midnight Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 Freight traffic volume generated by carloadings on U.S. railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Nov. 12, which included the Veterans Day holiday and Election Day were both ahead of the corresponding period of last year.

Erwin Wasey, Inc., which is part of the Interpubiic Group of Companies, Inc., is moving its headquarters from New York to its Los Angeles office and is installing a high command with "strong" international advertising experience.
GEORGE STAVROPOULOS has his classic chiffons, Tzaims Luksus his explosive prints, and all's well in the world of evening fashions.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 President Johnson's promised worldwide war on hunger appears to be bogged down in red tape and power struggle.

PARIS, Nov. 17 In its sheer physical dimensions, the exhibition "Homage to Picasso," being inaugurated here tomorrow night and opening to the public Saturday, is the champion tribute ever paid to a living artist. It must equal, as ...

CLEVELAND, Nov. 17 Kirk Willis, coordinating director of the Cleveland Play house, a resident professional theater, died here today in Lakeside Hospital of cancer after a long illness. He was 60 years old and lived at 1715 Lee Road, Cleveland Heights. The Play House operates the Brooks, Drury and Euclid-77th Theaters here.

The concept of an ombudsman, or public protector, is much more than a suddenly agreeable substitute for the now dead Civilian Complaint Review Board in the Police Department. It isn't that simple. The bandwagon enthusiasm for an instant device to assure all citizens that they have the right of redress is commendable; but it needs to be channeled into a thorough study lest the controversy that ended the review board be renewed in another form.
Crucial developments both bullish and bearish for bond prices broke into the open in quick succession yesterday afternoon.

AFTER changing his mind several times about the concerto he wanted to play he was announced for the Rachmaninoff D minor, then switched to the Beethoven G major Emit Gilels finally walked on the stage of Philharmonic Hall, listened to the ...
The hearsay testimony of six prison inmates won a new trial for a narcotics defendant, but it failed to bring an acquittal for him.

LAST August, Al Sherman, the coach of the New York Giants, had convinced himself and some of his players that their team would be a contender for the Eastern championship of the National Football League. "I'm going for it," said Sherman.
The Communications Satellite Corporation announced yesterday that its Lani Bird satellite would be in the right position tomorrow and Sunday for limited telecasts to and from Honolulu.
DIETER SCHULZE, a 34year-old German who lives in Austria, started by automobile for Arizona yesterday to take part in an outboard motor boat race.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 17 Texas oil producers got a $5-million Christmas bonus today from the Texas Railroad Commission, when it increased oil production for December by some 1.6 million barrels over November's rate.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Nov. 17 New Zealanders today have reason to hope that a $300-million aluminum smelting plant will be built here in the South Island.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 17 Some 250 Europion statesmen and diplomats saluted Walter Hallstein today as the president of the European Economic Community's Executive Comission celebrated his 65th birthday at a twohour midday reception. Later about half attended a luncheon ...
BETHESDA, Md., Nov. 17 President Johnson was not as speechless as his doctors would have wished on this, his 32d wedding anniversary.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 Robert Baldwin left his cows in Charlotte Valley, N.Y., and descended on the capital today with 349 fellow farmers.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Nov. 18 Vietcong guerrillas attacked the Longbinh ammunition dump 13 miles northeast of Saigon early this morning for the second time in three weeks.
PARIS, Nov. 17 France's most controversial law which forbids not only the sale of contraceptives to women but also any publicity about them faces a challenge in the National Assembly.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.
A singer billed as India's foremost vocalist scored a triumph for herself and her country's music last night at Town Hall, with only 600 persons there to bear witness.
The Continental Telephone Corporation and the Superior Cable Corporation announced yesterday that directors of both concerns had agreed in principle to Continental's acquisition of Superior.
WHEN is the proper time to panic? Lou Jacobi knows. It's not when you've just been arrested as an American spy behind the Iron Curtain, as Mr. Jacobi is in Woody Allen's "Don't Drink the Water."

JERUSALEM (Israel), Nov. 17 Israeli defense officials tonight made public aerial photos of the Jordanian village of Es Samu in an attempt to refute contentions that Israeli forces wrought widespread destruction in their raid last Sunday.
"Chu Chem" will close for repairs after tomorrow night's performance in Philadelphia.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed with little change yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 17 The Exit, One of the first churchrun coffehouses in the country, burnt out this morning in two-alarm blaze that apparently began in a storage room.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 17 To top off Michigan State's preparations for Notre Dame in Saturday's "Poll Game' between the nation's two topranking college football teams, Coach Duffy Daugherty gave the Spartans today what he calls his "Thursday night play."

A strong gust of midday selling shook the stock market out of its recovery phase yesterday. Three electronics companies that are leading producers of integrated circuits Fairchild Camera, Texas Instruments and Motorola bore the brunt of the selling onslaught.

HOUSTON, Nov. 17 Smooth swinging Julius Boros scored a 66 today to lead the $110,000 Champions' international golf tournament. The 46-year-old former United States Open champion, who hasn't won a tour event since 1964, shattered the Champions' Club par by five strokes to gain a one-stroke lead.

BONN, Nov. 17 Well-placed sources in the Social Democratic party reported today that Christian Democrats had approached the Social Democrats with offers to drop ... Kurt Georg Kiesinger as their candidate to succeed Dr. Ludwig Erhard as Chancellor.

Mac's Sparkler of the Hobeau Farm won the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday, taking the mile test by three lengths over the Harbor View Farm's Sailor Princess. Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Priceless Gem finished third in the field of eight fillies and mares.

The Rev. Dr. Harry L. Bowlby, for 40 years general secretary of the Lord's Day Alliance, died yesterday in the Bennett Nursing Home in Bloomfield, N.J., after a brief illness. He lived in Bloomfield at 67 Park Place and was 92 years old.

An expert witness, summoned in support of the plan to build a hydroelectric project on the Hudson River, testified under cross-examination yesterday that his report on the project was based solely on material put cut by the Consolidated Edison Company.
The condemnation of Israel in the Security Council for her punitive raid on Jordan does not resolve the tension in the Middle East.
Stocks of the leading integrated-circuit makers were thrown for severe losses in yesterday's trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
The city is considering a proposal to build airstrips that would jut into the Hudson River for short take-offs and landings in the vicinity of the World Trade Center.

Pacific Gas Electric Company announced yesterday that it had awarded a contract to Westinghouse Electric Corporation to supply the reactor, turbine-generator, nuclear fuel and other components for a million-kilowatt atomic power plant in California.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Nov. 17 A leader in a drive to improve migrant labor conditions on South Jersey farms charged here today that she and her family were being evicted in retaliation for her outspoken criticism of the way farmers treat Negro workers.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 17 The Iraqi Government has asked the Iraq Petroleum Company to increase production and exports from its present fields by 10 per cent, Radio Baghdad announced today.
Changes in top management were announced yesterday by the Eastman Kodak Company, the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation and the Burroughs Corporation.

SAN DIEGO, Nov. 17 (AP) Two attorneys for the Warren Commission, which investigated the assassination of President Kennedy, clashed today with two critics of the commission's report. A challenge to file a libel suit was issued.

FOR Wagner, music lovers flock to Bayreuth. For Mozart, its Salzburg. How lucky Savoyards are that the D'Oyly Carte Opera comes to us. The company opened a four-week engagement Tuesday at the City Center, and last night it gave its first "Mikado" of the run.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 Edward Bennet Williams, defense attorney for Robert G. Baker, said today that the Government had admitted to the trial judge that Government agents had violated the former Senate Democratic aide's constitutional rights with eavesdropping devices.

EDWIN NEWMAN, critic at large for the National Broadcasting Company, recently was awarded the Order of Merrick Broadway's David disinvited the commentator from being an eyewitness to an accidental production called "We Have Always Lived in the Castle."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 The automobile internal combustion engine and the interests of the American people are on a collision course, John W. Gardner, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 17 The Government took extraordinary precautions today to prevent a national protest march by students here tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 United States officials expressed concern today over the likely political and economic consequences of the Israeli attack on Jordan Sunday.

If any leader of the new Africa has a right to criticize British policy and tactics in Rhodesia it is President Kaunda of Zambia. His country has been subjected to severe strains by his neighbor's unilateral declaration of independence and by Britain's failure, in a year of effort, to end the white minority rebellion.

PARIS, Nov. 17 The venerable members of the Academie Francaise stole a march today on the venerable members of the Academie Goncourt by naming their choice for the novel of the year four days before the Goncourts' annual selection.
LISTS of stocks that should be sold for tax losses and those that should be picked up in their places are commonplace now on Wall Street. Almost any broker will supply his customers with a rundown.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, Nov. 17 The Government, which is known to be deeply concerned over recent Soviet arms deliveries to neighboring Algeria, proudly displayed today Morocco's first Americanbuilt military jets, four F-5's, named Freedom Fighters.

The new president of the American Stock Exchange warned the securities industry yesterday against approaching such major problems as giveups, volume discount and institutional memberships "on a simplistic basis."

The Acme Missiles and Construction Corporation has charged three brokerage firms with circulating "false and defamatory" statements about its prospects and attempting to manipulate the company's stock.

When a dealer spends time at an antique show, he ostensibly is there to sell. Burr Patchell, a dealer from Raleigh, N.C., has spent the week at the National Arts and Antiques Festival in Madison Square Garden's basement, but he has sold nothing because he has nothing to sell.

Troubled by technical failures, but still struggling to meet their tight schedule, officials of the nation's Apollo man-to-themoon project announced yesterday a broad reshuffling of manned test flight launchings for 1967.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 Following is the text of the Federal Court decision barring the election of Georgia's next Governor by the stater legislature:

DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Nov. 17 (UPI) Col. James Jabara, who shot down 15 MIG fighters in the Korean war and became the nation's first jet ace, was killed today when an automobile driven by his teen-age daughter went out of control and overturned an a turnpike.

TOKYO, Nov. 17 La Belle Epoque has come to the Ginza. The first Asian branch of the famous Paris restaurant Maxim's, which opened here Oct. 31, is so faithful a copy of the original that Maurice Carrere, general manager of the establishment at 3 Rue Royale, had to think hard last night to find a flaw in the clever Japanese reproduction.
It was the gathering of the clan yesterday for the rubber industry as more than 200 top executives congregated in the Essex House for the 51st annual meeting of the Rubber Manufacturers Association.

An illusion that a mid-air collision with another airliner was imminent probably caused the crash off Jones Beach, L. I., of an Eastern Air Lines plane on Feb. 8, 1965, the Civil Aeronautics Board found yesterday. All 84 aboard the Eastern craft were killed.
Pause a moment, if you will, from the cares of the day for a musical interlude entitled, "The Commercial Is Gone, But the Melody Lingers On."
The most spectacular celestial fireworks of this century were observed early yesterday morning over the southwestern United States.
BOSTON, Nov. 17 Senator Robert F. Kennedy said today that the Democratic party did not elect a Governor in New York this year because "we failed to project" an-attractive image.

F. Lee Bailey relaxed in a Cleveland restaurant the other night after a hard day's work defending his client, Samuel H. Sheppard, and said that his "brethren" at the bar had for a long time been "Inhibited" from practicing criminal law.
Lady Tweedsmuir glanced out over the New York harbor from the 15th floor of the Downtown Athletic Club and remarked at the lovely view.
WILL Harvard faces turn crimson with chagrin? Will the Dartmouths be green with envy? Will the Tiger drown his sorrow in his tank?
The specter of a "biologically planned society" in which scientists control human behavior and decide who shall live and who shall mate was raised yesterday by Mrs. Sargent Shriver.
SELDEN, L.I., Nov. 17 A 19-year-old parolee was killed here last night as he allegedly assaulted an off-duty policeman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 The United States plans to halt its military build-up in Thailand in the near future and to stabilize the number of American servicemen there at a level of about 35,000, informed sources said today.
TWO of the leading periodicals aimed at the out door-minded have produced particularly interesting issues this month.

A former security guard at the Shore Club, a go-go establishment in Sayville, L.I., has identified a police photo of Julius Klein, a former convict, as that of the man he had seen pocket as evening's cash receipts of the club.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 17 Argentina, Japan and New Zealand added their voices in the Security Council today to the growing condemnation of Israel's raid into Jordan.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 Housing construction fell to its lowest level in 20 years in October, the Government reported today.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 17 Reunion of the Eastern Orthodox and Roman Catholic Churches will be achieved in the foreseeable future, the world's ranking Orthodox prelate said in a wide-ranging interview here yesterday.

James R. Hoffa and the teamsters union put on a razzle-dazzle organizing rally last night, with colored balloons, cowbells, noisemakers and promises of bigger and better contracts for Pan American World Airways office workers "if you vote teamster."
DETROIT, Nov. 17 A student referendum at the University of Michigan reflected overwhelming opposition to the compilation of academic class standings for use by the Selective Service system.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Nov. 17?The National Democratic party, two-year-old organ of West Germany's extreme right, has brought its top leaders here in a major effort to win to win representation in the Bavarian state Parliament.

Specific amendments to the Merchant Marine Act of 1936 were proposed here yesterday by a high-ranking shipping executive to allow American shipbuilding to be established with its own separate Government support program.

Twenty-five architects, builders and landscape designers were honored by the Long Island Association of Commerce and Industry last night for contributions to the esthetic appearance of Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
Controller Mario A Procaccino last night held up more than $5,000 in fees and expenses billed for public relations services to the Department of Real Estate by Gilbert A. Robinson, Inc.

S. Klein Department Stores, Inc., has achieved its first profitable quarter in several years in the three-month period ended Oct. 31. However, sources close to the promotional department store chain reported that the earnings were "minimal."

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 17 Christ Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Virginia Jay Meyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Christopher Meyer Jr., to Lieut. Wilfred George Grandison, U.S.A. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred Squire Grandison of Boston.
Eleven writers poets, playwrights, actors and critics joined the American Jewish Congress yesterday in a protest and a call for a boycott of the Oberammergau Passion Play in West Germany.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 17 Margaret Mead surprised more than 600 Yale undergraduates in her introductory anthropology course today by giving out almost all A's and B's on the midterm examination.

THE New York Mets' executive team of Bing De vine and Wes Westrum took the field in Shea Stadium yesterday. Westrum, the second manager in Met history, flew from his home in Phoenix., Ariz., to spend the day with the man who on Monday became the second president in Met...

The directors of the Tidewater Oil Company approved and authorized yesterday a plan to invite tenders on 1.1 million shares of Tidewater common stock at $74 a share. The shares closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 68 3/8, up 1 1/8 on a turnover of 5,200 shares.
An important experiment is now going on behind the scenes to organize the Republican Governors into a coherent planning force for the political battles of the next two years.

MOSCOW, Nov. 17 Two Soviet officials in charge of restoring old churches and other architectural monuments have been sentenced to a year of hard labor in the destruction of treasured religious frescoes in Ioanna Predtechi Cathedral in Yaroslavl, it was reported today.
ATLANTA, Nov. 17 A three-judge Federal Court ruled here today that the State Legislature cannot elect Georgia's next Governor.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz has suggested that, in view of inflation, major labor agreements that cost about 5 per cent a year are not unreasonable.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 17 When Notre Dame's offensive unit trots up to the line of scrimmage for its first play on Saturday, Terry Hanratty, the sophomore quarterback, expects to be looking across at Michigan State's mammoth middle guard, Charles (Bubba) Smith.

BETHESDA, Md., Nov. 17 President Johnson, making a "very satisfactory" recovery from surgery, suggested today to former President Dwight D. Eisenhower that the General of the Army make a goodwill mission to Asia and other parts of the world.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 16 Republican leaders, encouraged by their gains in the Nov 8 elections, have decided to make a plan for sharing Federal tax revenues with the states one of their major objectives in the 90th Congress.
The State Supreme Court yesterday ordered Representative Adam Clayton Powell jailed for 30 days, starting Wednesday, for criminal contempt of court.
BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Nov. 17 (UPI) Art Arfons cracked up his jet-powered racer and lived to tell about it today in a 585-mile an-hour run on Western Utah's salt flats.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 18 Najib Salha, managing director of Intra Bank, said today that an independent report fixing the bank's liabilities at 24million Lebanese pounds ($8million) in excess of its assets was "unfair."
A committee of the New York County Lawyers Association sharply criticized yesterday what it called the "inconsistencies, ambiguities and contradictions" of the state's new liberalized divorce law.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 Three Ku Klux Klan leaders pleaded guilty today to contempt of Congress for not having produced Klan records subpoenaed by the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
MOSCOW, Nov. 18 The Soviet Union denied today any collusion in the arrest of an American citizen by Czechoslovakia on Oct. 31, the United States Embassy has reported.
The television and radio networks and the performers' unions agreed yesterday to continue their contract negotiations until midnight tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--Following is the text of the Pastoral Statement of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops on Penitential Observance for the Liturgical Year adopted today by the hierarchy at its annual meeting here at Catholic University:

ROME, Nov. 18 The Jesuit order, which has silently accepted a recent rebuke to its progressive wing by Pope Paul, announced today decisions introducing measures of decentralization and democracy into its structure.
Stock prices continued to decline yesterday with electronics and automobile issues leading the way downward.
"It was an awfully quiet market. There wasn't even a good rumor," a sugar dealer said yesterday. Volume totaled only 471 contracts in world sugar futures trading, a dull day by any count.
BETHESDA, Md., Nov. 18 President Johnson will leave the Bethesda Naval Medical Center tomorrow for an extended period of rest and work at his Texas ranch.

According to the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service, some savings have been achieved in the latest series of military cargo transportation contracts awarded under the Defense Department's new policy of competitive bidding.

MADRID, Saturday, Nov. 19 The first photograph of an area of the moon where United States astronauts may land before 1970 a crater-pocked section of the Sea of Tranquillity was transmitted to the earth last night by Lunar Orbiter 2.
MADRID, Nov. 18 Spain's proposed new constitution, to be unveiled by Generalissimo Francisco Franco Tuesday, will grant the vote to some married women and widows.
FROM the Hotel Pierre to Washington Square, they're everywhere: Manhattan's soldiers, marching in their doughboy jackets, Navy pea coats and Yves Saint Laurent originals.

LONDON, Nov. 18 Anthony Berry, a Conservative member of Parliament and banker, asserted today that a syndicate with newspaper and bank support might make a bid for The Times of London as an alternative to its proposed takeover by Lord Thomson.

ALBANY, Nov. 18 New York State will have to pay $140-million more in school aid in its next fiscal year just to keep up with its existing aid programs, Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the state Education Commissioner, disclosed today.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed mixed in quiet trading yesterday.
The five-year drought that has plagued a 400,000-square-mile area in the Northeast "has been badly dented and it very well may be broker," an expert on hydrology declared yesterday.
The May Department Stores Company announced yesterday in St. Louis that its net income in the three and nine months ended Oct. 31 declined from 1965 levels.

THE HAGUE, Nov. 18--The fifth biggest bank in the Netherlands has taken a major step to increase the flexibility of the Dutch money market and add to the slow but steady development of European financial centers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 The United States Treasury announced today that three additional helicopters would be granted to the Mexican Government for use in finding and destroying illegal cultivation of opium poppies and marijuana.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 18 (AP) Dr. James Archibald Jones, president of the Union Theological Seminary here since 1956, died Thursday night of a heart attack.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 18 Jordan's representative warned the Security Coun cil today that if the United Nations failed to take effective action to prevent further attacks by Israel, his Government might also resort to force.
THE burgeoning community of English artists who now make their home in New York--their spiritual home certainly,...
Theodore C. Sorensen, who was special assistant to President Kennedy, will address a "by-invitation-only" audience of...
The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose to a historic high of 14,135,515 shares in mid-November. The previous peak of 12,604,533 shares was established a month earlier.
Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler indicated yesterday that the decision on whether Federal income taxes will be increased in 1967 was wide open.
