When the New York Jets were introduced to the crowd before yesterday's game with the Miami Dolphins, there were cheers for Emerson Boozer and jeers for Joe Namath. By the time the gun sounded after the Jets' 30-13 victory, there had been plenty of cheers for both.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 The sharp decline in residential and commercial construction this year has had only a small impact on production in the manufacturing, mining and utilities industries, a Commerce Department study disclosed today.

FLORENCE, Italy, Nov. 20 Results of a judicial inquiry on the operation of the Levane and La Penna Dams on the Arno River during the floods two weeks ago will be made public in about two weeks, an investigator said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) Americans now would favor Gov. George Romney of Michigan for President over Lyndon B. Johnson, according to Louis Harris, the poll taker.
"What are we going to be?" asked one of a group of little girls in light blue leotards.
HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 20 (AP) Los Angeles will have its symphony season after all its musicians voted 69-20 today to ratify a new contract.
LONDON, Nov. 20 Lord Thomson of Fleet sought today to disparage the efforts of a syndicate of rival bidders for The Times of London.
Outstanding bankers' acceptances in the United States declined by $11-million in October to $3,359,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported over the weekend.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 20 The National Association of Real Estate Boards has rejected a proposed merger of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers, one of its constituent organizations, with the Society of Real Estate Appraisers.

"A very agreeable girl" who works for United Air Lines has a vocabulary of only 48 words. But she manages to make sense when talking to the thousands of the airline's repair and maintenance men who call her each day.

Miss Joancarole Wexler, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David J. Wexler of Islip, L.I., was married last evening to Alan Howard Rosenbloum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Rosenbloum of Atlanta and Pensacola, Fla.
MIAMI, Nov. 20 The reaction to the 3M Company's synthetic race track here has been something less than an unqualified "mmm!"

Governor Carrillo fell in love with Alma Reed while she was engaged in archeological research in Yucatan and he commissioned a musician to compose in her honor a song, "Peregrina." The Governor was killed by a firing squad at Merida on Jan. 3, 1924, 12 days before their scheduled wedding.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Nov. 20 (AP)--It cost a little more than most window shades, but X-15 rocket plane engineers figure it will save $50,000 a year.
JERUSALEM (Israel), Nov. 20 One of the American agencies that has long dealt with Israeli financing developed a telegraphic designation some years ago for Levi Eshkol. It was "farmer."

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, Nov. 20 Delegates from 35 American colleges and universities today concluded a fourday conference on draft reforms, which was highlighted by a walkout of delegations from Yale University and Lawrence University of Appleton, Wis.

Cargo traffic through the St. Lawrence Seaway from April to October this year amounted to slightly more than 41.3 million tons, according to Joseph H. McCann, administrator of the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation.
SKIERS who take the sport seriously usually take the most current ski fashions with a grain of salt. This season is no exception.
HOLLYWOOD Nov. 20 (AP)--About 50 more young people were arrested last night in the second weekend of teen-age rebellion against a 10 P.M. curfew on Sunset Boulevard.
Menasha Skulnik, star of "Chu Chem," which closed for repairs Saturday night in Philadelphia after a brief tryout, said yesterday he would not return to the show.

ATLANTA, Nov. 20 (UPI) The American Civil Liberties Union will join the State of Georgia tomorrow in asking the Supreme Court for a temporary stay of a lower court ruling that the State Legislature cannot elect a governor.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (UPI) A nationwide idea bank for educational data was outlined today by the director of the Education Commission of the States, an organization designed to help states help themselves with problems of education.

Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz observed critically yesterday that the controversial question of birth control had not been discussed openly "unless to be derided" at the recently held election campaigns throughout the country.

Miss Susan Rosenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Rosenberg, was married last evening to Dr. Abraham Meltzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hymen Meltzer of Garfield, N. J. Rabbi Alexander Rosenberg performed the ceremony at the Regency.
DORADO, P.R., Nov. 20 (UPI) Ramon Sota of Spain posted a par 72 for a 284 today to win the Puerto Rico open golf tournament at the Dorado Hilton course.

Two antitrust lawsuits calling for $68.4-million in treble damages and charging "predatory rate cutting" have been filed in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia against four steamship conferences.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) Floyd B. McKissick, national director of the Congress of Racial Equality, said today that CORE was thinking of concentrating its efforts next year on Cleveland and Newark. If the organization's budget permits, he said, CORE will add Oakland, Calif., to that list.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Nov. 19 A thousand years of artistic heritage of the Champa Empire of Vietnam Is disappearing beneath the refuse and indifference of war.
CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) The American Medical Association's Council of Environmental and Public Health said today that physicians and local medical societies should lead the drive to conquer measles.
JERUSALEM (Israel), Nov. 20 Premier Levi Eshkol today told his Cabinet that a major effort would be launched to seal Israel's borders against Arab infiltrators.

A vest-pocket Vienna Festival began Sunday afternoon at Philharmonic Hall, with the first of four monthly recitals by pianists from the Austrain capital. Yesterday's artist was Friedrich Gulda, and a large audience was on hand to greet his first American appearance in six years.

AFTER sampling the sizzle at many showrooms during the last three weeks of spring fashion openings on Seventh Avenue, store buyers sat back contentedly Thursday to enjoy the hearty fashion fare served by Norman Norell.

PATFRSON, N.J. Nov. 20 (AP) The police arrested today an 18-year-old Paterson youth who they said stabbed another youth to death in a tavern after an argument over a $1 bill that had fallen to the floor.

The Transamerica Corporation and United Artists Corporation announced over the weekend that an agreement in principle had been reached for the acquisition of United Artists by Transamerica through an exchange of shares.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 20 The Arab League boycott conference voted unanimously in Kuwait today for a ban by all Arab countries on dealings with the Ford Motor Company and the Coca-Cola Company.
A three-pronged program to promote air cargo development has been started by the civil Aeronautics Board as a result of the recently concluded nationwide series of air cargo workshops.

President Johnson's recently announced decision to visit Europe reflects recognition of a general deterioration in American relations with the NATO allies. The President's voyage next spring, though long overdue, undoubtedly can help stop the rot.

Roan Selection Trust, Ltd., a major copper producer in Zambia, set production, sales and profit records in the fiscal year ended June 30, despite chaotic political and economic conditions in Central Africa, the company disclosed yesterday.
COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 20 Robert J. Johnston Jr., manager of the Cooperstown branch of Hugh Johnson Co., stockbrokers, died today in Bassett Hospital. He was 65 years old.
Wilhelm Kempff, the German pianist, who will be 71 years old next Friday, gave a recital at Philharmonic Hall yesterday afternoon.
Mayor Lindsay declined yesfavored a ban on autos in midtown Manhattan to combat air pollution.
GLACE BAY, N.S. Deuterium of Canada, Ltd., one of the showcase features of Nova Scotia's so-called "industrial renaissance," is ...
RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 20 King Hassan II of Morocco has the reputation of playing an excellent game of political chess a game he plays simultaneously on a great number of boards.

Leroy Kelly's 56-yard touchdown run and an alert defense paced the Cleveland Browns to a 14-3 victory over the Washington Redskins today and kept the Browns in contention for the National Football League's Eastern Conference title.

Federal antipoverty officials warned Mayor Lindsay yesterday that the city could lose S3.5-million worth of legal services to the poor because of the Appellate Division's rejection of a plan to establish neighborhood law offices.
The Ashland Oil and Refining Company plans to acquire the Fisher Chemical Company, New York, it was announced jointly by the companies over the weekend.

A letter on this page today points out a situation that daily imperils pedestrians' lives if they attempt to cross Fifth Avenue at certain intersections between 59th and 110th Streets. Many of these pedestrians are mothers who take their children across the avenue to play in Central Park.
TORONTO, Nov. 20 (Canadian Press) Australis, owned by Danny Lopez of New York, was named the open jumper champion of the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair last night.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 20 (UPI) Oscar Robertson sank a onehander with eight seconds left to give the Cincinnati Royals a 125-123 victory over the Baltimore Bullets in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
DENVER, Nov. 20 (AP) The Oakland Raiders kept their Western Division title hopes alive with a 17-3 American Football League victory over the Denver Broncos today.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 20 In the West Hempstead Jewish Center this afternoon, Miss Florence Miriam Srebnick, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Louis Srebnick and niece of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Gurland, all of New York, became the bride of Norman N. Zelenko. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Zelenko of New York.

Paul H. Raymer, president and founder in 1932 of the Paul H. Raymer Company, national radio and television representatives, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at 417 Park Avenue. He was 70 years old.
JERSEY CITY, Nov. 20 After each side had scored a touchdown on the first two kickoffs, North Bergen High School defeated Snyder High School, 48-13, today before 6,000 fans.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 20 The Pittsburgh Steelers weren't up to their role of David against Goliath this week. Instead the Stealers, who had upset the St. Louis Cardinals and the Cleveland Browns in their last two games, made costly mistakes that helped the Dallas Cowboys to a 20-7 victory.

DORADO, Puerto Rico, Nov. 20 Gov. George Romney of Michigan arrived here today for a vacation and immediately attacked Governor Rockefeller's "consensus" proposal for Republican strategy in the Presidential contest in 1968.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 Dr. Alfred P. Fishman, an authority on heart and lung diseases and director of the cardio-respiratory laboratory at Columbia University-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York, has been named to the faculties of the University of Chicago and the Michael Reese Medical Center.

THREE centuries and 13 years separate the first monumental work on a sports subject written in English, Izaak Walton's "The Compleat Angler," and the most recent, George Plimpton's just-published "Paper Lion," which, if not "monumental" is awfully close to it a perfectly wonderful book, and if you haven't got hold of it yet, do so.

President Johnson's economic advisers think that it will be possible to decide during the next few weeks whether a tax increase will be needed next year. They are only awaiting fresh estimates of military spending, which up until now have been running far ahead of expectations. Once these are in hand, they urge that Mr. Johnson end the suspense over tax policy.
The possibility of a strike by television and radio artists ended last night when the performers' union and the national networks agreed on new contracts.
David Dellinger, editor of the pacifist magazine Liberation, said yesterday that United States bombing of North Vietnam had only made the population more determined to "fight back harder than ever."
Thousands of American Indian children in Governmentrun schools are becoming hopeless "no-culture people," a group of specialists on Indian affairs charged here last week.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 20 (UPI) Zeke Bratkowski, substituting for the injured Bart Starr, threw two touchdown passes to Carroll Dale today and led the Green Bay Packers to a 13-6 victory over the Chicago Bears and the lead in the National Football League's Western Division.
One day last week Weeb Ewbank, the coach of the New York Jets, was going over some bills. Among them was a tab for $300 for three contact lenses, all for George Sauer's right eye.

Joseph Macaluso, president of Macaluso Homes, Inc., of Staten Island, denied yesterday that his company performed any work on the shells of 10 houses that are to be demolished this week by the Department of Buildings.
Getting tickets to the Metropolitan Opera will be a little easier for the general public next season than it has been this year.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. Nov. 21 Alex R. Petrie, former president of the now defunct H.W. Clark Biscuit Company in North Adams, died yesterday in North Miami, Fla. He was 74 years old.
TRENTON, Nov. 21 The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the constitutional safeguards barring involuntary confessions now applied to juvenile as well as adult defendants.

Ernest Ulmer, a member of the faculty of the Manhattan School of Music, has given several piano recitals here since his debut in 1950. He appeared again in Town Hall last night to play Mozart's Fantasy in C minor (K. 396), Beethoven's Sonata in A (Op. 101), Bartok's Improvisations (Op. 20), Ned Rorem's Second Piano Sonata and four short pieces by Brahms.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 21 Guy Warner Vaughan, who as president and chairman of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation was among the first to apply mass-production techniques to the aviation industry, died here today at the age of 82.

DARIEN, Conn., Nov. 21 Mr. and Mrs. T. Roger Craig have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Bryant Craig, to Kenneth Byron Knapp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth W. Knapp of Schenectady, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 The Post Office Department said today that legislation might be needed to control unsolicited and potentially dangerous sample items now going unchecked through the mails.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 Administration sources privately discounted today talk of a Nazi revival in West Germany.
The nation's governors and mayors were asked yesterday to help in building a United States-flag merchant marine.

The third-quarter report on the nation's balance of payments makes familiar and dreary reading. The United States is still chalking up a deficit in its financial transactions with the rest of the world. This country is not so deeply in the red as it was two or three years ago, but the cushion of safety represented by the nation's gold stock has also been reduced.

The United States has at last made a small concession in the direction of considering the possibility of some form of "two-China" solution or an invitation to Communist China to join the United Nations. This happened when Ambassador Goldberg agreed yesterday to an Italian proposal to establish a special U.N. committee to study the Chinese question.
A three-man public panel was sworn in yesterday to study the 121-day-old strike of 4,000 construction plumbers in Manhattan and the Bronx.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 21 The Franciscan Order in Brazil has decided to ask permission from the Vatican to sell its cloisters and lands so that its members can live among the poor.

ATHENS, Nov. 21 Two defendants asserted today that they had been brainwashed and had been offered bribes to testify that Aspida, a secret army organization, was connected with former Premier George Papandreou and his son, Andreas.
Israel Schawartzberg, a 51year-old law clerk convicted in March of conspiracy to obstruct justice, was sent to West Street jail yesterday by Federal Judge Harold R. Tyler Jr.
MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 21 (AP) Matthew Begovich, former basketball player, coach and referee, died here yesterday. He had been believed to be recovering from a recent heart attack. He was 56 years old.
The spot rate on the British pound was steady in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.7914, up 1 point from the Friday level.

WINDS of change are rippling up the hairdos at the Saks Fifth Avenue beauty salon. There are plans to redecorate the salon, which has reacquired the services of Pierre Henri to create new styles and to train and supervise the staff. (Mr. Henri left Saks in 1961 to open his own salon on West 57th Street. It is now closed.)

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 21 (AP) Three officials of the right-wing National States' Rights party were sentenced today to two years in prison on charges of inciting a riot, conspiracy to riot, disorderly conduct and violating city park rules.

THE old song was wrong when it asserted "It ain't what you do, it's the way that you do it." In art, as in all questions of morality, it is vitally important what you do. This high moral clariontone is struck in welcome to the Manhattan Festival Ballet, which opened its first New York season last night at the small but elegant Theater 80, St. Marks Place.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 21 Wasfi al-Tall, Premier of Jordan, said today the Nov. 13 attack on the Jordanian village of Es Samu by Israeli was a "test of the Arab unified military command and of the Arab strategic claim that any part of the Arab front line with Israel is indivisible from entire Arab front with Israel."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI)--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara turned out today for a poetry recital by Yevgeny Yevtushenko. The Soviet poet made an eloquent appeal for better Soviet-American relations.

Twenty-one years after the fall of Hitler it is dismaying that a party branded neo-Nazi by the West German Government can poll 780,000 votes in a Bavarian election Bavarian election law allows each voter to cast two ballots. The heavy-handed Franz Josef Strauss adds to the dismay by calling this showing of the National Democratic party (N.P.D.) "an answer to all those who have tried to pull Germany through the dirt."
Ernest G. Hesse, vice president of the American Cyanamid Company, was elected yesterday to the board of the Wayne, N.J., chemicals producer.
Mayor Lindsay is dismayed over New York's continued untidiness and is considering asking the Police Department to enforce recently strengthened regulations against littering.

The National Basketball Association, which has had as many as 17 teams, as few as eight and now has 10, announced yesterday that it would add two franchises for next season and expand to an 18-team circuit by 1970.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 The Supreme Court barred today further lower court proceedings in the Georgia governorship case and scheduled a hearing for Dec. 5.
THE life and times of the quarterbacks in pro foot- ball are becoming more and more perilous. Consider what happened on the National Football League scene last Sunday.

The American Opera Society, in cooperation with the Committee for the Rescue of Italian Art, Inc., and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, will present a benefit performance of Cherubini's "Medea" at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 12.

President Johnson's energy is a wonderful thing. He has successfully overcome a heart attack and he has bounced back from serious surgery before, but he really should listen to his doctor's advice the way other people do.
Representative Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, the House Republican leaders, said yesterday that "a tax increase in 1967 could be a tragic mistake."
BONN, Nov. 21 Following is a listing of the major parties in West Germany and their political views:

SANDY KOUFAX never hesitated to use guile on the pitching mound because that is an accepted and legitimate part of the business. But off the field he is so honest and forthright that it galled him to equivocate and to practice little deceits when asked about his future, especially when he had reached the fateful decision to retire abruptly from a sport he had served with such distinction.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 On the eve of President Johnson's third anniversary in the White House, the predictable news has been published that Gov. George Romney of Michigan leads Mr. Johnson by 54 to 46 per cent in a Presidential preference poll. Other Republican possibilities, like Richard M. Nixon, trail Mr. Johnson by varying margins.

Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler accused the German-language newspaper Staats-Zeitung and Herold yesterday of an "ostrich-like stance" in the face of efforts to halt the rise of neo-Nazism in Europe.
Notre Dame and Michigan State battled to another tie yesterday in the weekly news service polls to determine the No. 1 college football team.
Stocks closed lower, with auto, electronic and special situation weakest in moderately active trading; volume, 7.45 million shares.
Mayor Lindsay named Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving as head of a new Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration yesterday.

Directors of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., voted yesterday to pay stockholders a year-end dividend of $2 a common share. This is a decline from the 1965 year-end distribution of $2.25 a share. It is payable Dec. 14 to holders of record Nov. 29.
Two men were arrested yesterday and accused of pushing counterfeit $20 bills that appeared so authentic they fooled even bank tellers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 The United States is considering additional military aid to Jordan in view of the Israeli attack Nov. 13 on the village of Es Samu.
The selection of Southern California to represent the Pacific Coast Conference in the Rose Bowl was the only major surprise yesterday as 11 of the 16 places in the major bowl games were filled.

BREAKFAST radio long has needed someone who resents mornings, cheerfulness and promptness. The torrent of contrived patter, tunes intended to instill a bright outlook and weather reports confirming in depth whether the sun is out or not has impinged on the one period of the day when a viable antisocial attitude is the hallmark of civilized normality.
Steel production rose for the second successive week in the period ended Saturday, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

THE best repertory company we possess has now es tablished itself on Broadway, at the Lyceum, with a production of "The School for Scandal," and by the time it gets around to the celebrated screen scene it gives us some performing to celebrate.
DETROIT, Nov. 21 (AP) The auto industry faced up reluctantly today to the fact that it would fall some 58,000 units short of its goal of an estimated 900,000 car output in November.
ALGIERS, Nov. 21 The presidents of two independent American oil companies began negotiations here today with top Algerian officials in an effort to resolve a dispute over prices and taxes.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 21 The United States and the Soviet Union were among the 14 states named today to study the proposed transfer of South-West Africa from South African to United Nations administration.

A group of 350 residents of five blighted areas sat in at City Hall for more than 12 hours yesterday in an effort to get Mayor Lindsay to help continue the flow of Federal funds for the upkeep of slum houses.
The integrated circuit, which has been making news in the last week, is really nothing more than the latest plaything for the electronics industry.
JERUSALEM (Israel), Nov. 21 Israeli leaders have decided on two major efforts to secure border peace. One involves greater vigilance along the frontier. The other focuses on exposure of Arab policy.

On the third anniversary of President John F. Kennedy's assassination today, the twoyear-old Warren Commission report on his death is the subject of intensive attacks. But commission members uphold their findings that a lone assassin, Lee Harvey Oswald, was guilty.

The subject of the 3M Company's synthetic race track was pretty widely discussed by the jockeys at Aqueduct, even though the local riders have yet to see the new surface. A product of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, the man-made track was tried for the first time on Saturday, at Tropical Park.
RAINBOW GRILL, R.C.A. Building, Avenue of the Americas and 50th Street. The Teachers, vocal-instrumental group. Held over: Jonah Jones Quartet.
BELGRADE, Nov. 21--President Tito has acknowledged criticism of his Communist party by Eastern European parties for the first time in more than five years.
Officials of the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company and the American Optical Company disclosed yesterday that discussions had been held looking toward the possible merger of the two companies.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 21--Secretary General Thant was urged to continue in office for another full term in an open letter signed by 129 prominent Americans and made public today.
MEDFORD, Mass., Nov. 21 (AP) A tribute was paid tonight to President Kennedy at Tufts University in a memorial mass, in which the responses were sung by folk singers.
A seasonably named Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt representative, Flying Tackle, won the feature event at Aqueduct yesterday, to the delight of the favorite-players in the crowd of 24,539.

Mrs. Marjorie Jacobi McAneny died after a short illness Saturday in Norwalk, Conn., where she had been visiting friends. She was 87 years old and lived at 43 Spring Street, Princeton, N.J. Her husband, the late George McAneny, served the city of New York as a public official, city planner, transit expert and civic leader.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Nov. 21 Gen. Wladislaw Bortnowski who commanded the Polish Army that unsuccessfully defended the maritime provinces of Poland in World War II died today in Glen Cove Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 89 15th Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 At the 17th annual Debutante Cotillion and Thanksgiving Ball, to be held at the Sheraton-Park Hotel here Thursday, 29 young women will make their formal bows. Proceeds will go to the Damon Runyon Memorial Fund for Cancer Research.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 21 Employers are being asked to supply transportation for any employes who become intoxicated at office parties. The idea is to cut down traffic accidents during the coming holidays.
LONDON, Nov. 21 Foreign Secretary George Brown said today that the fear of Germany felt in many countries for reasons of history was now out of date.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21 Marshall McLuhan, whose books have puzzled many readers, confounded others and inspired some, gave the whole thing away in an interview here today.

A naturalized American citizen seized by the Czechoslovak police at the Prague airport three weeks ago was linked by the Czech authorities 15 years ago to the case of William N. Oatis, an American newsman who was tried in Prague held incommunicado since his on espionage charges.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration said today that all children's aspirin bottles sold after next July 1 would contain no more than 36 tablets each in an effort to reduce accidental overdoses.
A sharp decline in mining shares and British Government bonds was the feature of slow trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 21 Mr. and Mrs. Edward Bartley Osborn of Bronxville and Mahogany Hill in Tryall, Jamaica, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Barrie Osborn, to Warner Bader Bishop. He is the son of Mrs. Warner Brown Bishop of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Mr. Bishop. A February wedding is planned.
Three integrated-circuit manufacturers made announcements yesterday two bullish and one bearish but all their prices nevertheless fell on the New York Stock Exchange.

DEER PARK, L.I., Nov. 21 Angry officials of The Suffolk Sun complained today that the newspaper's debut was severely hampered during the night by the disappearance of a large part of its first edition.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 21 (AP) Jackie Mason was in a hospital this morning after a head-on auto collision just south of Las Vegas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 The Soviet Union has become so concerned over increasing tensions in its relations with Communist China that it has taken steps to bolster their frontier and to discuss the problem with Washington.

Ten per cent of the $500,000 investment by 134 backers in "Cabaret" was mailed to them yesterday, the day after the musical opened at the Broadhurst. It cost $400,000 to bring the show in. The management kept the other $50,000 as a reserve.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) Mrs. Kathryn O'Hay Granahan has submitted her resignation as Treasurer of the United States. She has been in ill health for many months.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) The Supreme Court ruled today that a bank that honored checks of a bankrupt depositor was not liable to the trustee in bankruptcy when the bank had no prompt notice of the bankruptcy proceeding.
A three-pronged push from economic developments drove the bond market yesterday to its biggest gains since midOctober.
THE HAGUE, Nov. 21 A 39day old Cabinet crisis in the Netherlands ended today with Dr. Jelle Zijlstra, the governordesignate of the Central Bank, as the new Premier.

Alex Rose, vice chairman of the Liberal party, denied yesterday the quotation attributed to him in The New York Times of Nov. 14 in which he was reported to have made an uncomplimentary remark about Senator Robert F. Kennedy on the night John V. Lindsay was elected Mayor in 1965. According to the story, Mr. Rose said, "We have to cut that little punk Kennedy down to size."

WETUMPKA, Ala., Nov. 21--A 27-year-old Negro who, acquaintances said, had talked back to a white deputy sheriff and had refused to submit to arrest for drunkenness was taken dead from a jail cell here early yesterday.
Beginning Dec. 12, wholesalers of liquor in New York State will be required by the State Liquor Authority to affirm each month that prices to retailers here are as low as in other states.
ANCHORAGE It's cold and snowy here, but An chorage is a dressed-up city and nearly every woman of means has one or two elegant fur coats.

Gilbert A. Robinson, whose public relations agency's $15,000 contract with the city's Department of Real Estate was canceled by Mayor Lindsay last week, said yesterday that "the thought never occurred" to him that the deal may have been a political payoff.

Nobody ran out on Wall Street yesterday and deliberately kicked a Cadillac in the fender, but there was open talk about General Motors stock nudging the market down- hill. "Some people watch G.M. because they think we have an auto economy," observed William L. Jiler, president of the Trendline division of Standard Poor's Corporation.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 21 (AP) A 26-year-old mother stood in silent mourning today at a gravesite here as her husband's body was laid to rest in the land he died for fighting in Vietnam.
TRENTON, Nov. 21 (AP) Charles R. Farmer, a wealthy industrial designer accused of murdering his wife in 1963, must stand trial again, the State Supreme Court ruled today.

BONN, Nov. 21 The principal Government spokesman and several leading West German newspapers joined today in insisting that other nations were taking an exaggerated view of the strong showing by the extreme rightist National Democratic party in the Bavarian state election yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 21 The New York State Superintendent of Banks called today for an overhauling of the present system of selecting trustees for mutual savings banks in New York State.
"The Wild Angels," the controversial and profitable drama about an outlaw West Coast motorcycle gang, is prompting a new film series from American International Pictures.
The Boston Maine Corporation, owner of the Boston Maine Railroad, announced yesterday the election of Richard J. Mulhern as chairman, president and chief executive officer.

DETROIT, Nov. 21 (UPI) George Chuvalo, the Canadian champion, stopped Boston Jacobs of New York on a technical knockout in the third round of a scheduled 10-round heavyweight fight in Cobo Arena tonight.

For Americans of Roman Catholic faith no innovation could more dramatically symbolize the changes in their church than the decision of the bishops of this country to relax the rule making it a sin to eat meat on Fridays.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21 The selection of the University of Southern California to represent the Pacific Eight Conference in the Rose Bowl was received with mild dismay today by Tommy Prothro, coach of the University California, Los Angeles. Bruins victors over U.S.C. last Saturday.

Salvator J. Curcio of Jackson Heights, Queens, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Madeleine Cecilia Curcio, to Stephen P. Kaduboski, son of Mrs. Stephen P. Kaduboski of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Mr. Kaduboski.

TILLSON, N.Y., Nov. 21 (AP) Ulster County has conceded temporary custody of a blond 4-year-old-child to an Italian-American couple pending a second Family Court hearing on whether the couple can adopt the child they have reared since her infancy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 Following is the text of a pastoral statement of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops on peace released today:
LANSING, Mich. Nov. 21 (UPI) The United States Supreme Court was asked today to take 200 square miles of mineral-rich Lake Erie from Ohio and give it to Michigan.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 The Treasury bil rate dropped sharply at today's auction from last week's levels, the Treasury reported tonight.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 21 Civil and military spokesmen for the Haitian Government today dismissed reports of an invasion as rumors started by the country's enemies.
Former Judge John E. Fetzer of the Civil Court in Pelham, N.Y., died Sunday in Sarasota, Fla., where he lived. His age was 83.

Even the football fans questioned while they were shuttling through Times Square at rush hour yesterday could not agree on who should be rated the No. 1 college football team, Notre Dame or Michigan State.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 21 (UPI) President Johnson announced today the selection of 10 outstanding high school students to attend a two-week science seminar in Australia under scholarships set up in his honor.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission, in a 4-1 decision, ruled today that the merger of two large Chicago-area dairies was illegal and ordered the combination dissolved.

NEW DELHI, Tuesday, Nov. 22 (Reuters) The police arrested one of India's most revered holy men before dawn today in the hut where he was fasting in support of demands for a total ban on the slaughter of cows.
NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 21 (AP) A major breakthrough in naval aviation occurred today aboard the aircraft carrier America when a series of jet planes landed without the aid of their pilots.
JERICHO, L.I., Nov. 21 Three foul shots in the last 30 seconds gave the Israeli national team a 68-65 basketball victory over the New York Institute of Technology tonight.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 22 (AP) North Vietnam said today that it was harvesting "a fairly good" autumn rice crop despite United States air raids and bad weather.

The Ford Foundation announced yesterday a $1-million grant to establish a legal organization to accept civil and criminal cases that involve indigent persons and that are likely to establish a legal precedent.
The first two decades of this century were rich in social and technological change and personalities. This slender volume is a nostalgic look back at those years.
A dispute broke out here yesterday over how water service would be affected, if at all, by shutting off the Catskill Aqueduct.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 Despite indications of mounting concern from New Delhi, President Johnson is delaying action on an extensive wheat agreement with India until an American survey of the food crisis there is completed.
With meatless Fridays no longer required for Roman Catholics starting next month, stronger prices were registered yesterday by meat futures contracts.

CALDWELL, N.J., Nov. 21 (UPI) Four prisoners were charged today with inciting a riot and three others with atrocious assault in the aftermath of a rebellion that erupted in the mess hall of the Essex County Penitentiary.

THE two methods for roasting turkey given here are recommended by the National Turkey Federation for better flavor and appearance, minimum shrinkage and less loss of juice, but the preparation of the bird for any method is the same.
WITH 18 of the 81 games, or two-ninths of the schedule, played, a brief report on the status of the New York Knickerbockers is in order.
DETROIT, Nov. 21 The American Motors Corporation reported the second largest loss in its history today, but officials said the amount was "substantially lower" than expected.
OTTAWA, Nov. 21 Canada's prosperity near the end of 1966 is "flattening" out, and some relaxation in anti-inflation restraints on investment may soon be in order.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 20 A special session of the Puerto Rican Legislature has just ended after adopting a crash program designed to aid the island's agriculture, which is lagging behind the industrial expansion.
LONDON, Nov. 21--The House of Lords, condemning the "mishmash of ancient and hoary statutes that govern our Sundays," today unanimously endorsed proposals for a future of brighter Sundays in Britain.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 21 The United States today backed an Italian draft resolution proposing that a United Nations committee explore the question of Chinese representation and recommend "an equitable and practical solution."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) The Supreme Court let stand today a civil contempt judgment against the Prince Edward County (Va.) Board of Supervisors based on hurried distribution of $180,000 in school tuition grants to white parents in 1964.

James H. Meredith said yesterday that he had been banned from speaking at a "Mississippi Day" rally in Columbus, Ohio, by Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association of the Advancement of Colored People.
Prices fell yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. The volume was 1,856,410, only slightly more than Friday's 1,841,450.

The 33d annual "Night of Stars," a four-hour show for the benefit of the United Jewish Appeal, was presented last night at Madison Square Garden. More than 1,000 stage, screen and television performers and technicians donated their services.

Representative Joseph Y. Resnik said yesterday that Commissioner Fitzsimmons had been illegally appointed to his post in Ulster County. Mr. Resnik, a Democrat, has backed the Liunis' efforts to adopt their foster child. He announced that an investigation by his staff had turned up evidence pointing to a "conspiracy" in evading state legislation on the status of welfare commissioners.
By a process of academic fission, the City University may soon have a new senior college.

ALTHOUGH no one in the dim ruby and sapphire Victorian parlor actually got up and cried: "Women of the world, unite! You have nothing to lose but your chains," that was the prevailing sentiment yesterday morning at the crowded press conference held by the newly formed National Organization for Women.
Atlantic Container Line, an international enterprise composed of four foreign-flag steamship lines, is about to double the size of its transAtlantic operation.
ROCHESTER, Minn., Nov. 21 (AP) President Johnson is a very good patient and complies with his doctors' orders, one of his physicians said here today.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Nov. 21 (AP) Nine oil companies, indicted on Federal price-fixing charges in the sale of liquid asphalt to the State of Kansas, were permitted today to change their pleas from not guilty to no contest.

The 25th anniversary of Music Journal will be celebrated next Sunday with a dinnerdance at the Plaza Hotel. Proceeds from the event will be contributed to various colleges and universities to assist them in their music education programs.

The lawyer for representative Adam Clayton Powell argued yesterday before the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, for a reversal of one of four jail sentences pending against the Manhattan Democrat for contempt of court.
DETROIT, Nov. 21 (AP) A former bank director charged in a $63-million suit in Federal court today that Federal and state officials conspired to defraud the stockholders of the defunct Public Bank.

Acting in his capacity as president of the New York City Center Mayor Lindsay presided over a sampling of the center's wares staged for an audience of 2,000 corporation executives last night at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21 The nation's leading anthropologists over the weekend hailed the Leff Collection of primitive African art as one of the world's finest private collections of ancient and tribal works.
A seven-month, $240,000 painting job began yesterday on the Queensboro Bridge over the East River.
Out of the mouths of babes (college babes, that is) are coming the latest punch lines for the 15-month-old campaign of Peck Peck, "There is a certain kind of woman who ..."

CHILDHOOD memories are often as important to a family Thanksgiving as the traditional turkey. Peeling chestnuts, chopping nuts, grinding cranberries and cleaning silver are some of the tasks that allow the entire family, down to the toddler, to take part in the preparations.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Nov. 21 Three governmental agencies imposed elaborate security controls today while workmen began demolition of a stillradioactive concrete plant in which radium was once recovered from the faces of old watches and navigation equipment.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21 Former Gov. David L. Lawrence, a power in Democratic national politics, died this afternoon in Presbyterian-University Hospital at the age of 77. He was stricken with a heart attack on Nov. 4 while addressing a Democratic political rally here and had been in a coma since.

WNYC, the voice of New York City, came up with a frog in its throat last night when a poetry reading on its FM station was suddenly curtailed by decision of the program director, who was monitoring the reading at his home.

LONDON, Nov. 21 An English version of the Oberammergau Passion Play will be staged in Britain despite objections to it from Jewish organizations, Philip Solomon, whose company will produce the play, said here tonight.
The city's medical schools are preparing a joint application for a Federal grant that they believe could have a major impact on medical services here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) The airlines won a temporary, court order today blocking the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission from deciding whether the airlines can keep their age limit rules for stewardesses.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Sharp of Miami Beach won the mixed pair championship, which ended last night, in the American Contract Bridge League's fall nationals. They totaled 881 match points, a mere two points ahead of Sylvester Lowery and Mrs. Alfred Blasband of Philadelphia.

Dorothy Minty, violinist, and Bertha Melnik, pianist, had equal billing in the recital of violin sources that they presented last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. This was justified since the two performers were about as equally matched as they could be in ability, intelligence, temperament and stylistic approach to the program.
Stock prices tumbled yesterday as the market reacted to a series of bearish news developments.

PARIS, Nov. 21--Edmonde Charles-Roux, who was dismissed four months ago as editor of the Paris edition of Vogue, won France's top literary award today with her first novel, a harsh portrait of American women's magazines, American preoccupation with success and American estrangement from European values.

Richard Fink, president of the Fink Baking Corporation, 5-35 54th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, died yesterday in Mount Vernon (N.Y.) Hospital, after an illness of several months. He was 50 years old and lived at 21 Buena Vista Road, Eastchester, N.Y.
The Greek Line yesterday announced the withdrawal from cruise and trans-Atlantic service of the 20,648-ton passenger liner Arkadia.

ATLANTA, Nov. 21 Bobby Jones, the top golfer of a golden age of sports, received a modern tribute today. President Johnson and former President Dwight D. Eisenhower sent him congratulatory messages as he was presented a new award for distinguished sportsmanship.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) Gen. William C. Westmoreland said today it was naive to think that either a pause or a slowdown in the bombing of North Vietnam would gain the United States an advantage in the Vietnam conflict.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 21 (AP) Eight college players have been chosen by the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame as scholar-athletes who will receive $500 graduate fellowships.

A dispute between J. Raymond Jones, the New York County Democratic chairman, and two East Side Reform leaders was temporarily disposed of yesterday with a resolution that left neither side the winner.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 The national passion for overdoing things is getting worse. Last week, to cite an example, the newspapers displayed yet another batch of close-up snapshots of the moon's surface.

The annual holiday fair of the Walden School will be held by its parents association Dec. 2 and 3 from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. at the school, 1 West 88th Street. Among items offered will be Small antiques, silver, china, handicrafts, art, books, records and women's clothing.

LONDON, Nov. 21 In the 10 days since Prime Minister Wilson's announcement of a fresh British initiative toward entering the European Common Market, the idea has again become the central concern of British political and economic life.
Two men were indicted yesterday on a charge of plotting to destroy a Zambian railroad bridge.
MOSCOW, Nov. 21 (UPI) An electronic chess game between the Soviet Union and the United States opened today and may the best machine win.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 The American Roman Catholic hierarchy supported the United States "presence" in Vietnam today, but said that "we must clearly protest whenever there is a danger that the conflict will be escalated beyond morally acceptable limits."

Federated Department Stores, Inc., and the Associated Dry Goods Corporation two of the nation's largest department store chains reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the fiscal first nine months.
An Eastern Air Lines official, discussing that phenomenon of air travel known as the Eastern air shuttle, said recently:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP)--The United States Tax Court ruled today that a teacher who quits his job to return to school full-time for further training cannot deduct his educational expenses from income for tax purposes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21--The Supreme Court took the following actions today:...
SOFIA, Bulgaria., Nov. 21 Zvetko Grigorov sat under the picture of Lenin behind his desk and extolled the virtues of expensive perfume.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 21 Gen. Kong Le today accused the United States of having backed the neutralist colonels who eased him from his position as commander of the neutralist army last month. The general said he opposed the integration of the neutralist and rightist armies, which was believed to have been the goal of his removal.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 102 on Friday from 102.5 on Thursday.

Negotiations have been reopened for a 90-minute television production of "Annie Get Your Gun," starring Ethel Merman. The Irving Berlin musical probably will be televised early next year by the National Broadcasting Company.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Nov. 21 The pastor of the fashionable Swarthmore Presbyterian Church has been asked to resign because of civil rights activity and what was called his failure to preach more sermons on "peace of mind" and the "joy of salvation."
A team of Midwestern nuclear physicists has "probably" peeled apart a proton--one of the fundamental particles of the atom0--like an onion.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 21 (Reuters) Three followers of Mihajlo Mihaplov, the outspoken anti-Communist intellectual who is serving a oneyear jail setence, were arrested today informed sources said tonight.

HERNANDO, Miss., Nov. 21 Aubrey James Norvell, a white one-time hardware salesman from Memphis, pleaded guilty today to shooting down James H. Meredith, a Negro civil rights leader, along a Misisissippi road last June.

Once again there is cause for alarm over the course of events in Haiti. President Duvalier has just dismissed 21 staff officers of the Haitian Army. Reports of an invasion by anti-Government exiles have been issued and denied.
ROSCOE, N.Y., Nov. 21 The New York State Southern Zone big-game hunting season opened yesterday with a record number of hunters gunning for bear and deer in ideal weather.
COTONOU, Dahomey, Nov. 21--Togo's tiny army swung into action this morning to crush an attempt at a dawn coup against President Nicholas Grunitzky.

Norton Simon, a colorful California entrepreneur with direct and indirect interests in more than 20 companies, resigned yesterday as chairman and a director of one of them the Wheeling Steel Corporation.

MADRID, Nov. 21--Generalissimo Francisco Franco presided today over a ceremony for the Falange on the eve of his presentation of the new constitutional law that, in effect, does away with the party's role as Spain's only authorized political party.
President Grayson Kirk of Columbia University defended yesterday the university's right to permit on-campus recruiting by the Central Intelligence Agency. He addressed 500 protesting students.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21 Members of a Soviet friendship delegation that cut short a visit to China indicated today that they had been met with hostility, intimidation and "crude insults" nearly everywhere during their tour.

Joseph E. O'Grady resigned yesterday as chairman of the Transit Authority, effective Dec. 1, thus creating a vacancy into which the Lindsay administration hopes to put City Transportation Administrator Arthur E. Palmer Jr.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower checked out of Walter Reed Army Medical Center today after a series of routine cardiac tests and said, "Everything's fine all okay."

The Fox Eastern Theatres Corporation, subsidiary of the National General Corporation, will be a principal tenant in Suffolk Plaza, a shopping center planned in Suffolk County, L.I., by the A.V.R. Construction Corporation of White Plains.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 21--Jordan asked the Security Council today to brand Israel an aggressor and impose economic sanctions against her as punishment for a military attack Nov. 13.
DORADO, Puerto Rico, Nov. 21 Gov. George Romney of Michigan endorsed in principle today Governor Rockefeller's "consensus" approach to winning the Presidency for the Republicans in 1968.
The Phillips Petroleum Corporation annuonced yesterday plans to acquire a 35 per cent interest in Klember Colombes Plastiques, a French producer of plastic products.
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 21 (AP) Superior Court Judge Allen H. Gwyn said today "it is the wish of this court, though not a judicial mandate" that Ku Klux Klansmen excuse themselves from jury duty.
BOSTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) A 20-year-old convicted draft dodger was sentenced today to three years in Federal prison while his pacifist supporters staged a noisy courtroom protest.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Nov. 21 (UPI) Gerry Lindgren, a Washington State sophomore, won the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 28th cross-country championship today with a record-shattering performance of 29 minutes 1.4 seconds for the six-mile grind, but Villanova captured the team title.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 21 Edward J. Logue, who last week turned down an offer to held a sweeping housing development effort he had suggested for New York City, took swipes at the city and, by implication at Mayor Lindsay, and the Federal Government today.
PARIS, Nov. 21 Triumph could seldom have tasted sweeter than it did today to Edmonde Charles-Roux. Four months ago she was dismissed after 16 years as editor of the French edition of Vogue.
CAMBRIDGE, Md. In this pre-Revolutionary city along the eastern shore of Maryland, the pace is slow, the homes are gracious and the people seem genuinely relaxed.

ALBANY, Nov. 21 The state administration asked the Appellate Division today to uphold a controversial new law that requires public schools to lend textbooks to parochial school pupils in grades 7 through 12.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 21 An American platoon, surrounded and outnumbered by North Vietnamese regulars, was almost completely wiped out by enemy assaults today in the upper reaches of the Iadrang Valley.
Miss Pamela Noreen Drexel was married yesterday afternoon to Bradford Hastings Walker.
In recent years David Leo Lawrence showed strong dislike for the title of "boss," but his disclaimers aside, he was one nevertheless.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 Robert G. Baker's lawyer argued in Federal District Court today that the Justice Department should be compelled to make available to the defense a secret recording of a conversation between Mr. Baker and a former friend who is a prospective witness against him.
AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 21--President Johnson spent today at his ranch relaxing, working and talking on the telephone with high Administration officials.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Nov. 21 Glen B. Winship, former bank advertising manager of The New York Times, died yesterday at Muhlenberg Hospital Plainfield. He was 79 years old and lived at 30 Highland Avenue here.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 21 Some 300 members of Local 1134 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers stayed away from work today as a wildcat strike against the Public Service Electric and Gas Company's electrical distribution division entered its second working day.
The Frank G. Shattuck Company, operator of the Schrafft's chain of restaurants, announced here yesterday the election as vice presidents of Carroll J. Burns, Joseph T. Quinn and Eugene J. Reilly.

Harrison W. Peck, owner of the Harian Press, printers and engravers at 270 Lafayette Street, died of a heart attack on Saturday at Lafayette College in Easton, Pa., where he had gone to attend a football game. He was 60 years old and lived in Fort Lee, N.J.

A dispute over the construction of St. Peter's Bascilica in Rome was one of the sparks that ignited the Protestant Reformation. Few challenged the idea of building such a great church. The issue was whether indulgences should be used to raise the necessary funds.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 21 (AP) About 40,000 public school pupils were shut out of classes today in Youngstown and nearby Hubbard by a teachers' union strike.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 21 Westchester County's 20 privately operated bus lines, which are used by 120,000 riders a day, are in serious financial trouble, the State Office of Transportation told the County Board of Supervisors today.
The city will soon open a "drying-out center" for Bowery alcoholics who will be taken there by the police solely on a voluntary basis.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 21 (UPI) Terrorists riddled a supermarket with submachinegun fire today in the fourth act of Communist-inspired terrorism since Friday.
The election of Elliott Averett as senior vice president was announced here yesterday by the Bank of New York. He was also named senior commercial banking officer.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Nov. 21 (Canadian Press)--The Swedish industrialist Axel Johnson of Stockholm said yesterday that his Johnson Line had ordered six modern ocean freighters for $54-million to serve the west coast of North America.
THE American Constitution has provided so many dramatic moments in our history that it is only fitting that it should have an equally dramatic birth.

The American people by almost 5 to 1 believe that President Kennedy will go down in history as a greater President than President Johnson, according to a public opinion survey by Louis Harris published in The New York Post yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) The Supreme Court rejected again today a Delaware request for permission to file suit challenging the constitutionality of state unit-vote system of choosing Presidential electors.
The election of Dr. Francis Clark Wood as a director of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States was announced here yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 22.--France opposed today as unrealistic an Italian draft resolution proposing as inquiry into Communist China's attitude toward the United Nations. The French demanded admission of the Chinese Communists now as a matter of "political necessity."
Prices drifted down on the London Stock Exchange yesterday as traders awaited publication of the Government's white paper on economic restraint.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) Three corporations and two executives were indicted today on a charge of illegally fixing the prices of Honda motorcycles and parts in Ohio, the Department of Justice said.

PARIS, Nov. 22 Jean Caille of the Paris police, who refused to answer questions during the Ben Barka affair on the ground of professional secrecy, was promoted today to deputy director of his division.
Los Angeles Joe Frazier, 205 pounds, Philadelphia, knocked out Eddie Machen, 192, Berkeley, 10 rounds.

A privately owned fertilizer plant that will require an investment of about $70-million will be built near the port city of Santos, Brazil, it was announced here yesterday.

NAPLES, Fla., Nov. 22 (AP) Herbert C. Wyman, retired advertising director of The Toledo (Ohio) Blade and The Toledo Times, and vice president and director of the Toledo Blade Company, died yesterday in Community Hospital. He was 62 years old.
It is little more than a year since John V. Lindsay was elected Mayor of New York City. Much has been accomplished in that year, and the basis of even greater achievement has been firmly established.

Bearish economic news continued to depress the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The list declined for the fourth consecutive session.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 22 Two United States union organizers denounced Brazil's labor policies today as "undemocratic" and "conducive to Communism."
A stockholder of Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc., filed suit yesterday in New York to block the projected purchase of onethird of the company's common stock by Seven Arts Productions, Ltd.
After a 10-day Puerto Rican vacation dominated by talk about Presidential politics, Goverror Rockefeller returned to New York last night for some more talk about Presidential politics.
ALBANY, Nov. 22 Consolidated Edison Company's electric and steam rates will go up Friday, and its gas rate will go down, the Public Service Commission decided today.
The Radio Corporation of America announced yesterday the development of what it described as "a revolutionary, tubeless television camera smaller than a man's hand."
About 50 Brooklyn high school students played hookey yesterday morning to picket outside City Hall.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 22 Miss Belinda Jane Pope, daughter of Mrs. Jesse Arthur Mason of Pine Orchard, Conn., and Henry Vincent Pope of Delray Beach, Fla., was married this evening to William Downes Payne, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Atkins Payne.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 Automobile manufacturers have notified the Federal Government of about 40 safety defects in late-model cars, trucks, buses and motorcycles.

MERIDIAN, Miss., Nov. 22 (UPI) A news cameraman who became embroiled in a scuffle while covering a racial story contended today in Federal Court here that he had been attacked by the man who has brought a $550,000 damage suit against him and the Columbia Broadcasting Company.

TOKYO, Nov, 22 With the opening of the Asian Development Bank, Japan will embark upon a far-reaching undertaking in which Asians will use at their own initiative monetary resources collected from all over the world for fostering economic growth in Asia.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Nov. 22 (AP) Bob Charles of New Zealand shot a final round of 63 that included seven consecutive birdies on the 28-stroke back nine and won the Hastings tournament.

Consolidated Edison submitted an air pollution control plan to Mayor Lindsay ysterday that the company contends will reduce the amount of pollution its city power plants produce by about two-thirds within 10 years.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22--Defense spending fell back in October after its big surge in September, the monthly Treasury statement disclosed today.
Two major companies reached outside their own organizations yesterday for new presidents.

Folks who insist on hearing pieces as their composers wrote them, must have had a hard time of it last night at Nina Simone's Philharmonic Hall concert. But obviously there weren't too many of them on hand, because the large crowd roared its approval loud and long after each of the singerpianist's extended numbers.

BONN, Nov. 22 East German authorities denied today any knowledge of the whereabouts of George Blake, the Communist spy who escaped from a British prison Oct. 22.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 22 Arthur Ellison Wheeler, a former director of the American Can Company and a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, died here today at his home. His age was 69.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 The Federal housing agency indicated today that it would henceforth pursue a tougher national policy toward suburban communities that fail to live up to plans for orderly metropolitan growth.

The latest inventory of works of art in Florence, damaged by the recent flood, put by Italian officials at 885 panels, canvases frescoes and sculptures, gives only a hint of the extent of the damage, an expert said yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 22 North Vietnamese Army regulars badly mauled outnumbered American infantrymen in a five-hour battle yesterday in the Central Highlands, a United States military spokesman said tonight.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 102.4 on Monday from 102 on Friday.
LONDON, Nov. 22 The directors of The Guardian disclosed tonight that they had decided against joining in any effort to stop the merger of The Times of London with Lord Thomson's Sunday Times.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 Something remarkable has happened in dance across the country. It is called the Martha Graham Dance Company, now on its first national tour in many, many years. Miss Graham and her art have long been regarded as a trifle esoteric, a little special something hardly, let us say, popular.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 Charles H. Percy of Illinois wore the Republican new look at a Washington showing today and it made him look suspiciously like a Presidential candidate.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 22 President Johnson conferred this morning with Budget Director Charles L. Schultze and other senior budget officials to determine how at least $3-billion can be cut from Federal programs in the 1967 fiscal year to combat inflation.
Mayor Lindsay created a new administration yesterday to direct an expanded campaign against the slum conditions in which more than one million New York City residents live.

Jack Rohan, Columbia's youthful-looking varsity coach, was speculating yesterday about his starting five for the Lions' annual opener with City College on Dec. 1. Just then word arrived that Dave Newmark, his 7-foot star, had undergone a successful tonsillectomy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 Contrary to the prevalent opinion, Bill Elias predicted today that the Army-Navy football game in Philadelphia Saturday will be an offensive, rather than a defensive, battle.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 (AP) Ray Charles, 35 years old, the blind pianist and singer, received a five-year suspended jail term and was fined $10,000 today in Federal District Court on two counts of possession of narcotics.

Phyllis Curtin, long one of the adornments of the New York musical scene, sang one performance as Fiordiligi in "Cosi fan tutte" with the Metropolitan Opera five years ago. Last night she was back with the company for her second local appearance.

Leslie A. Hodson, project manager of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's telecommunications group, North America, died on Monday while on a business trip in the Virgin Islands. He was 48 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N. Y.
