WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board estimated today that the smaller airlines would need about $68-million in Federal subsidy in the current fiscal year.

NASHVILLE, Nov. 22 (AP) A Federal judge, in the first test case of the 1966 Bank Merger Act, approved today the merger of the Third National Bank of Nashville and the Nashville Bank and Trust Company.
PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 22 (AP)--The face of the man in the moon appears to have moles, judging from a picture taken by Lunar Orbiter 2 and released today by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory.
The spot rate on the British pound was firm in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.7916, up 2 points from Monday.

SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Nov. 23 (AP) The United Nations command said today that three South Korean Navy patrol boats had been fired upon by North Korean shore batteries yesterday and returned the fire. No one was killed or injured and one boat was slightly damaged.
The stock market went down yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 22 (AP) Delegates from 23 countries and 9 international bodies met today for a week's discussion of how to solve the jet-noise problem for people living near airports.
A leading international banker urged yesterday that European bankers alter their lending practices to enhance capital formation and promote economic development.
Hijackers kidnapped two trailer-truck drivers yesterday and made off with their cargoes of more than $300,000 in Scotch whisky and electric shavers.
W.J. McNeil, president of the Grace Line, announced yesterday that the company's board of directors had elected Donald E. Grimm a vice president.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 22 (AP) Frank Robinson of the Baltimore Orioles, the American League's most valuable player, had a cracked medio cartilage removed from his right knee today.

BONN, Nov. 22 Christian Democratic members of the Bundestag today confirmed their endorsement of Kurt Georg Kiesinger, the party's candidate for Chancellor, in the face of East German charges that he was a key official of the Nazi Propaganda Ministry during World War II.
A PRIMER on modern Red China, more concerned with every-day living conditions than ideological issues, was presented last night by "C.B.S. Reports." The pro-...

The United States Freight Company announced yesterday an increase in the quarterly dividend and the year-end extra dividend. It said sales and earnings rose in the third quarter and first nine months.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 22 Hicki Hi was what his driver, Al Burton, said he was: "A kind of crazy, mixed-up horse." That was Burton's appraisal of Hicki Hi before the field of six 4-yearold trotters started in the $49,025 New York Sire Stakes at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 22--A Roman Catholic priest has left the priesthood and married a divorc e who is the mother of five children, it was disclosed today.
A high-ranking government official told business leaders yesterday that the voluntaryrestraint program on foreign investments would be continued at least through 1967.
Following are biographical sketches of the five members appointed to the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board:
LONDON, Nov. 22--The Bermuda Constitutional Conference ended here today with the leader of the island's minority Opposition party rejecting the recommendations "lock, stock and barrel."

Miss Marilyn Bette Fink, daughter of Civil Court Judge J. Daniel Fink and Mrs. Fink of New York, was married yesterday evening to Michael Howard Gerber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Gerber of New York and Miami Beach.

HONG KONG, Nov. 22 The purge of Communist party officials in China has fallen especially heavy on propaganda chiefs. At least 20 of the party officials known to have been purged, or more than a third of the total, were propaganda or literary officials.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 Today was a working day like any other for Peter Cleland on this, the third anniversary of the assassination of John Fitzgerald Kennedy.
Paramount Pictures, which last month became a wholly owned subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., gave evidence yesterday that it would continue as a major supplier of theatrical films.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 The Department of Justice challenged today the legality of a new Alabama law that declares Federal school desegregation guidelines "null and void."
The widow of one of the twelve firemen killed in a blaze that destroyed three buildings opposite Madison Square Park on Oct. 17 will sue the building owners for $1-million.

ROCKVILLE, Conn, Nov. 22 Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Hooker have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Mather Hooker, to Ens. B. Gresh Lattimore Jr. U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram G. Lattimore of Dunedin, Fla.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 22 (AP) The St. Louis-San Francisco Railway asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for permission to eliminate the railroad's last four passenger trains.
SELMA, Ala., Nov. 22 (UPI) Stokely Carmichael failed to appear today for his trial on charges of inciting a riot and his case was postponed for one week.
"TEXAS ACROSS THE RIVER," a Universal Western comedy-drama with Dean Martin, Alain Delon, Rosemary Forsyth and Joey Bishop, is the attraction at local theaters.

AT the time the observation was made, it was not meant to be at all profound. Yet there was much more depth to it than the typical flippancies constantly supplied by the late Tom Meany, aide to George Weiss of the New York Mets. It came during spring training three or four years ago when the front-office boss in St. Petersburg, Fla., labored longer hours than the ballplayers.

The ice is breaking in Spain. This is what makes the governmental and constitutional changes announced yesterday by Generalissimo Franco, and promptly acclaimed by the rubber-stamp Cortes, so important.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, sixth-ranked United States producer, announced yesterday that the Koppers Company would be the prime contractor for a continuouscasting unit to be installed at the Aliquippa mill, near Pittsburgh.
ROSCOE, N. Y., Nov. 22 Doug Bury didn't say he'd been attacked by the dangerous, bloodthirsty animal. In time he will.

Communist expansion in Southeast Asia and the extent of American involvement there will be the subjects of a threepart documentary study the National Broadcasting Company will televise starting Friday, Dec. 16, at 10 P.M. The series of one-hour color specials will be called "the Battle for Asia."
LOME, Togo, Nov. 22 President Nicholas Grunitzky sought to form a new government today as police and soldiers began rounding up suspected leaders of yesterday's attempted coup d' tat.

Director John S. Gottschalk of the Interior Department's Bureau of Sport Fisheries and Wildlife stated recently that hunting is necessary to control the number of deer and other large, plant-eating animals when they become too numerous and overgraze their range. This is true, particularly where man has

Federal Court Judge Dudley, B. Bonsal dismissed yesterday, a suit that challenged Representative Adam Clayton Powell's right to hold office. The suit argued that Representative Powell was not an inhabitant of New York, as required by the Federal Constitution.

ALGIERS, Nov. 22 The Government-run press reported today that talks yesterday between Industry and Energy Minister Abdesselam Belaid and the presidents of two American oil companies took place in a "favorable atmosphere."
TOKYO, Nov. 22. A new trade agreement signed by Japan and Communist China in Peking yesterday has caused disappointment and even dismay among trading concerns here.
Jesse Gray, the Harlem rentstrike leader, was convicted in Criminal Court today of disorderly conduct in a row with a traffic policeman.

A leading Jewish spokesman taxed the Johnson Administration yesterday with complacency over the rise of neo-Nazism in Germany and chided it for what was termed a "rather harsh" denunciation of Israel's military raid on Jordan by Arthur J. Goldberg.
Earnings of Botany Industries, Inc., advanced to $1,127,000, or 62 cents a share, in the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31 from $1,065,000, or 59 cents a share, in the year-ago period.
A plan to redevelop seven and a half blighted blocks in the western part of Coney Island won approval yesterday from the City Planning Commission.
Roy C. Megargel, counsel of the Hewitt-Robins division of Litton Industries, Inc., was named yesterday to the additional post of vice president.

GENEVA, Nov. 22 The Chase Manhattan Bank, New York, moved today to have released all its now-attached assets in Switzerland with the exception of those in a Swiss bank that has guaranteed it $500,000.

THE problem of what to wear to the Party of the Year, the fashion industry's biggest annual social gathering, was minimized for 38 of the 900 guests who drank, dined and danced last night in the Great Hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

STORRS, Conn., Nov 22 Joe Casey, Army's All-America forward, scored two goals to lead the cadets to a 2-1 soccer victory over Connecticut in the first round of the National Collegiate tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 As President Johnson starts his fourth year in the White House, one fact is not only clear but undisputed: his Administration is poorly organized to administer the domestic programs he has introduced, and the administrative chaos of the state and local governments is even worse.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 22 Mr. and Mrs. Humboldt Walter Leverenz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Humboldt Leverenz, to George Tufts Dewey 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dewey Jr. of Paxton, Mass.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 22 (UPI) County supervisors moved against teen-age nightclubs on the Sunset Strip today.
Two pilots and two stewardesses are the first crew members to be honored by the Air Line Pilots Association for "heroic actions beyond the call of duty."
The reflecting pool at Lincoln Center's north plaza has developed a persistent leak, and the city is considering legal action against its builders.

GLENVIEW, Ill., Nov. 22--The Rev. and Mrs. Gordon Lyall have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Lyall, to John Welles Wight Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wight of Madison, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) Dr. Leonard D. Fenninger, the medical director of the University of Rochester's Strong Memorial Hospital, has been named to head the Public Health Service's new Bureau of Health Manpower.

Four repeaters were named to The Associated Press 1966 All-Ivy League football team yesterday but the only unanimous choice of the coaches was Mickey Beard, Dartmouth quarterback, who received only honorable mention a year ago.

FOR 46 years, under one name or another, the National Orchestral Association has been training young instrumentalists in the special skills needed to transform talented students into qualified orchestral musicians. A part of the training program, which is financed philanthropically, involves the playing of four concerts each season at Carnegie Hall.
HOUSTON, Nov. 22 (UPI) Bill Yeoman, whose Houston Cougar football team is rated No. 11 in the coaches poll, signed a new, five-year contract with the school today.

Archie Shepp, the jazz saxophonist, is the author of "June Bug Graduates Tonight! (Are You There, America?)," a play with music that will be performed from, Jan. 17 until Jan. 31 at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Apostles, Ninth Avenue at 28th Street.

TOKYO, Nov. 22 (AP) Jilchiro Matsumoto, a left-wing Socialist who devoted his life to fighting for the rights of the eta, the Japanese outcast, died in Fukuoka, southern Japan, today of acute pneumonia and stomach ulcer. He was 79 years old.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 22 (UPI) The St. Louis Symphony Orchestra went to the junkyard to fill out its instruments for this week's concerts.

While new voices called for another inquiry into the assassination of President Kennedy, Democratic and Republican leaders of the House of Representatives contended yesterday that the basic questions' had been answered by the Warren Commission.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 22 (AP) Notre Dame's already depleted offensive unit received another jolt today when it learned that Bob (Rocky) Bleier, a halfback, would miss the Southern California game Saturday.
Msgr. John E. Kelly, a chaplain at St. Vincent's Hospital who, crippled for 17 years by arthritis, visited other patients in a wheelchair, died at the hospital on Monday. He was 59 years old.
A $9-million, 5,000-foot auto bridge from Astoria, Queens, to a burgeoning modern prison complex on Rikers Island was dedicated yesterday as a "bridge of hope."

BERLIN, Nov. 22--The Soviet Ambassador to East Germany Plotr A. Abrasimov, and his wife came to West Berlin tonight to dine for the first time at Mayor Willy Brandt's official guest house. Mr. Abrasimov gave a dinner for the Brandts Oct. 12.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 22 President Johnson, working at his ranch 60 miles west of here, announced today the formation of an Advisory Council on Vocational Education, which will review the administration of the programs of the Vocational Education Act of 1963.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Wednesday, Nov. 23--Premier Jens Otto Krag won a new mandate in yesterday's parliamentary elections for four more years of Social Democratic minority rule, but his party's representation was sharply reduced.

Earl Morrall, the regular quarterback, was throwing passes during the New York Giants' brief workout at Yankee Stadium yesterday but the passes were not going far. Morrall, who broke a wrist bone Nov. 5, was testing his ability for the first time since the injury.
AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 22 Roast wild turkey will join the usual tame domestic variety on President Johnson's Thanksgiving dinner table Thursday.
Laffit Pincay Jr., the hungry young Panamanian jockey they say may eventually replace Braulio Baeza as "Numero Uno," rode seven horses for six trainers yesterday at Aqueduct.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) The Air Force announced today that more than 5,100 officers due for retirement in the next two years would be offered a chance to stay on active duty for an indefinite period.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 A brief, private ceremony commemorating the death of President Kennedy was held this morning at the United States Mission to the United Nations.
Twenty-five players, including two quarterbacks, Steve Spurrier of Florida and Bob Griese of Purdue, were named to the 1966 all-America team yesterday by the American Football Coaches Association.

OBERAMMERGAU, Germany, Nov. 22 (AP) The mayor of this Alpine village said today the text of its world famous passion play would be examined at a Roman Catholic monastery for alleged anti-Semitic overtones.

Mrs. Elizabeth Ottmann Wheeler, former amateur golf champion, died on Monday in her home at Harrison, N. Y. She was 81 years old and the wife of Isaac M. Wheeler, former president of Gunther-Jaeckel, Inc., Fifth Avenue fur store.
Mayor Lindsay and members of the Board of Estimate were given a preview yesterday of a planned campaign to "sell the city" to New Yorkers and the rest of the world.

Investors in mutual funds redeemed substantially fewer shares in October than they did in September, according to figures released yesterday by the Investment Company Institute, the industry trade association. For the first time in seven months, investors increased their purchases.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 The Czechoslovak Embassy asserted today that the safety of foreign tourists traveling to Czechoslovakia "has been and is fully insured."
Edward J. Logue, Administrator of the Boston Redevelopment Authority, declared yesterday that college presidents, business executives and public officials were indifferent to architecture.

Mrs. Reba Paeff Mirsky, musician, educator and the author of children's books, died yesterday in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 64 years old and lived at 350 Central Park West. Her husband, Dr. Alfred E. Mirsky, is a biochemist and a professor at Rockefeller University.
LONDON, Nov. 22 The shrinking British aircraft industry is going to shrink some more.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 22 (UPI) Iranian leaders conferred today with an international consortium, including 15 American oil companies, to resolve a dispute threatening to develop into an international crisis.
American owners of 1967 models of Rolls-Royce, Volkswagen and Renault automobiles have no cause to worry about defects, spokesmen for the three foreign companies said yesterday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (UPI) Dick Gregory, the entertainer, said today that he intended to go to North Vietnam regardless of how United States officials may feel about such a trip.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 22 Lord Chalfont, Britain's Disarmament Minister, warned today that the development of an antiballistic missile system would have dangerous and costly effects on the existing nuclear balance.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 22.--Jeremy Flint of London and Peter Pender of San Francisco led the field of 60 qualifying pairs into the final session of the life master men's pair championship here tonight with a total of 456 points. Second with 438 were Ray Zoller of Cincinnati and Carl Hudecek of Toledo, Ohio.
THE paths of two brave men crossed last week on the vast salt flats of western Utah.
The city's rent administrator charged yesterday that a onemonth mail survey by his department had shown there was "a higher percentage of rent gouging than we think."

The always controversial and sensitive issue of commission rates the fees charged by brokers on purchases and sales of securities promises to become more sensitive and controversial than ever in the next few months.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) The dean of the Harvard Divinity School said today theological education in the United States was in need of a "largescale housecleaning."
In Vietnam our armed forces are facing two formidable foes--the Communist...
It was a cold mid-November for the nation's auto industry as the four largest car makers reported yesterday a 10.2 per cent decline in new-car sales in the Nov. 11-20 period.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Nov 22 Striking longshoremen at the Cambridge port rejected by a 16-to-2 vote last night a second management proposal to settle their monthlong wage dispute, which has closed the deepwater port since Oct. 18.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 The President's National Crime Commission has split with the Justice Department over wiretapping and electronic eavesdropping by law enforcement officers.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 22 The United Nations Theater Club will present from Dec. 5 to 9 five performances of John Van Druten's "I Am a Camera," the play, based on Christopher Isherwood's stories of pre-Hitler Berlin, that inspired the current musical "Cabaret. "
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 Israel has assured the United States that no American-supplied tanks were used in the Nov. 13 attack on a village in Jordan, State Department officials said today.

EASTCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 22 The president of the General Foods Corporation urged businessmen tonight to build backfires to combat the "consumerism" that he said Congressmen were promoting to woo the consumer.

SEA GIRT. N. J., Nov. 22 William C. Weber, who retired 11 years ago as treasurer of B. J. Van Ingen Co., Wall Street bond dealers, died today at Point Pleasant Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 402 Brooklyn Boulevard.
Ten companies engaged in importing Chilean fruits and vegetables filed a $1.4-million reparations suit yesterday against the Grace Line. The suit will be heard before the Federal Maritime Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 (AP)--Walter Reuther, United Auto Workers president, said tonight the nation's labor movement, under the leadership of George Meany, national president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., is failing in its responsibility to the American people.
LUXEMBOURG, Nov. 22 France has once again reversed her position and turned cooperative on a European economic issue.

GRANITE QUARRY, N. C., Nov. 22 (AP) Robert Jones, Grand Dragon of the North Carolina Ku Klux Klan, said today Superior Court Judge Allen H. Gwyn was not "practicing what he preaches" when he asked Klansmen yesterday not to serve on juries in his court.

James E. Trainer has been elected to the board of directors of Day Zimmerman, Inc., of Philadelphia, engineering and construction concern. He is a former director and executive vise president of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 The State Department denied today a report that the Soviet Union had discussed, in toplevel talks with Washington officials, concern over problems along the Soviet border with Communist China.
WATERTOWN, Conn., Nov. 22 William Frederick Geigar, who was the oldest living graduate of Dartmouth College, died Sunday at Waterbury Hospital.

Steve Spurrier, the University of Florida quarterback who is regarded as likely to be the No. 1 draft choice of the New York Giants, had his bargaining position enhanced yesterday when he was named as the winner of the 1966 Heisman Memorial Trophy, symbolic of the nation's outstanding college football player.
THOSE alarming economic statistics sluggish au tumn retail sales, slipping third-quarter corporate profits and the like may not be as serious as they appear.
MOSCOW, Nov. 22 Heightened concern about civil defense preparations against possible threats of nuclear attack is being voiced in the Soviet Union.
DETROIT, Nov. 22 (UPI) Charlie Hodge of Montreal picked up his first shutout of the season tonight, blanking the Detroit Red Wings, 3-0, in a National Hockey League game.
UVALDE, Tex., Nov. 22 (UPI) Former Vice President John Nance Garner celebrated his 98th birthday today and said he hoped to live "to a hundred, and maybe one or two more."

A Briton who was instrumental in saving the pound in 1964 made a plea here yesterday that the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development take charge of developing the world's capital markets.
THE D'Oyly Carte Company brought "Ruddigore" into its current run at the City Center for the first time last night, and delivered it to the avid audience with a sparkling air of wicked innocence,
LISBON, Nov. 22 Portugal will give "absolute priority" to military expenditures in 1967 to preserve her overseas possessions, it was announced today.
LONDON, Nov. 22 The freeze on wages in Britain will continue in only slightly modified form for a second sixmonth period, until July, 1967.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary announced yesterday the names of five senior officials of his department who have been assigned to take over the duty of reviewing citizens' complaints against the police.

The annual dinner dance in behalf of St. David's School, 12 East 89th Street, will be held on Dec. 5 at the Plaza. Mrs. J. Russell Duncan, Mrs. Gaspare Salvia and Mrs. W. Peter Slusser are in charge of plans for the evening.

The trustees of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine approved yesterday general plans to complete the unfinished Morningside Heights landmark with a large cylindrical dome of stained glass panels, set between concrete louvers.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 22 A leading state public health official called today for a campaign financed by the California government to convince the public that gasoline-powered motor vehicles must be banned in the state by 1980.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 Robert G. Baker's attorney asked a Federal Court today to order three separate trials on the Government's nine-count indictment of the former secretary to the Senate Democratic majority.

A 54-year-old German whose publishing empire began in the rubble of 1946 and is now the largest on the Continent will take out a double-page ad in an American newspaper to explain his philosophy, history and credo.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 22 (AP) Nearly $100-million in cash and securities was stacked in banks in two states today because of a strike by armored truck drivers against Brinks, Inc., and Armored Transport, Inc.
HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 22 A prominent independent film company announced plans today to turn "With Kennedy," Pierre Salinger's book about the late President, into a motion picture.

A group of 30 young property owners in downtown Brooklyn with five baby carriages lined up "bumper-to-bumper," yesterday in temporarily preventing the city from demolishing a 100-year-old house they considered worthy of preservation.
The Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church issued yesterday a special statement reaffirming his denomination's support of Federal participation in birth-control programs.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 20 They do not have much time in South Vietnam to watch developments in North Vietnam. But since both sides ...
The New York Central Railroad is getting deeper into the business of running hotels.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 22 Dr. Samuel D. Bell, a specialist in pediatrics and allergies, died yesterday after a brief illness. He was 74 years old and had homes at Wallack's Point, here, and at 125 East 74th Street in New York City.

Gen. William C. Westmoreland, United States commander in Vietnam, appealed yesterday to the American public to support the various volunteer agencies that contribute to the survival and development of the Vietnamese nation.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Nov. 22 (AP) Bermuda won the international team one-design world yacht championship by capturing the fourth and final race from Norway, 46 to 36, yesterday.

Dr. Huber William Hurt, who became professor of education and later director of admissions at Stetson University, De Land, Fla., after serving for nearly 30 years as an executive of the Boy Scouts of America, died today in De Land, according to the national headquarters of the Boy Scouts in New Brunswick, N. J. He was 83 years old.
MADRID, Nov. 22 The Spanish Falange, Europe's last surviving major Fascist movement, received a first-class funeral tonight from Generalissimo Francisco Franco, the Spanish chief of state.
MONTREAL, Nov. 22 (UPI) The Air Canada strike entered its ninth day today with no end in sight for the near future.
Buckpasser was named horse of the year yesterday in the 31st annual poll conducted by The Morning Telegraph and the Daily Racing Form.
STILLWATER, Okla., Nov. 22 (AP) James Edward Berry, former Lieutenant Governor of Oklahoma, died in a hospital last night. He was 85 years old.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 (AP) Two men in custody for another crime admitted today the theft of an $8,000 Picasso water-color study from the Philadelphia, Museum of Art last Tuesday, the police said.

NUTLEY, N. J., Nov. 22 Carl R. Johnson of 262 Grant Avenue, an electrical engineer with Louis Berger and Associates, consulting engineers of East Orange, died today of a heart attack in Bangkok, Thailand. He was working there on a special project. His age was 55.
Bohdan Swiryna, 21 years old, was shot in front of his home in Astoria, Queens, last night by a patrolman who had come to arrest him on charges that he had robbed a drugstore.

It is unfortunate, but not unexpected, that Britain and France should decline to serve on the fourteenmember United Nations ad hoc Committee on SouthWest Africa. Apart from this setback, Abdul Rahman Pazhwak of Afghanistan, President of the General Assembly, has named a committee that reflects fairly well the geographic and power distribution among U.N. members.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 22 Jagadguru Shankaracharya of Puri, one of the most revered of India's holy men, was flown to southern India today under armed guard as the Government moved with unusual firmness to squelch a revival of agitation over cow slaughter.

MADRID, Nov. 22 The Cortes (Parliament) approved by acclamation tonight a new Constitution introduced by Generalissimo Francisco Franco. It was an important step toward a careful liberalization of the national political system.

An award of $10,000 each for major achievements "leading toward prolonging human life" will be given by the Berk Foundation to Dr. Adrian Kantrowitz and Dr. Michael DeBakey, it was announced last night.
California sold $100-million of bonds yesterday in a sale that was extremely close and resulted in an interest cost moderately below the state's preceding bond sale.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Nov. 22 A few American engineers and Congolese technicians here are trying to meet a deadline a working television station in the Congo by Thursday, the first anniversary of the military regime of President Joseph Mobutu.
WITH a little ingenuity, economical cuts of beef can be turned into flavorful feasts. Simmering in wellseasoned broths and adding a tangy sauce or gravy can do the trick.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 22 Iraqi and Syrian officials began urgent talks in Damascus, Syria, today on a crisis that has arisen between the Syrian Government and the Iraqi Petroleum Company.

Officials of bus terminals, airports, railroad stations, tunnels and bridges prepared yesterday to handle five million travelers expected to pass in and out of the city during the four-day Thanksgiving holiday starting tonight.
The annual art festival aiding the North Shore Child Guidance Association will open with a pink champagne party on Dec. 9 at the Nassau Country Club in Glen Cove, L. I.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 The Republican National Committee announced today a new program aimed at the great and growing reservoir of politically uncommitted youth.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 22 A sharp difference of opinion between Federal agencies over the regulation of interest rates on savings accounts broke into the open here today at the closing session of the 73d annual convention of the Savings Banks Association of New York State.
ROME, Nov. 22 A group of young priests, about 70 in number, gather every afternoon at the Jesuit headquarters in Rome for classes with some of the best-known professors in the city.
DETROIT, Nov. 22 A number of the more than 500,000 motor vehicles that could have safety defects have already been recovered and, where necessary; repaired, it was indicated here today.

HONG KONG, Wednesday, Nov. 23--Communist China denounced today an Italian proposal for the establishment of a United Nations committee to try to find a solution to.. the question of Peking's representation.
GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 22 George Edward Stevens, a stockbroker in New York, died today at Greenwich Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived here at 18 Field Point Road.
Thoughts of turkey seemed more important than interest rates in the bond market yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 Treasury bill rates for ninemonth and one-year bills declined slightly at today's auction from last month's levels, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

In a move that Village preservationists regard as a victory for hostile real estate interests, the Landmarks Preservation Commission has decided to restrict the boundaries of a historic district designation it had proposed for Greenwich Village.

The vanguard of more than 250 of the country's most unusual custom cars began arriving at the New York Coliseum yesterday, preparatory to the opening today of the Fifth Annual National Road and Custom Car Show.
An accountant who was once president of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants has added his voice to the chorus of comment on his profession's performance.
The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company announced yesterday it was negotiating to acquire the stock of the Chun King Corporation, maker of oriental and Italian food.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 23 New regulations issued today for the Sao Paulo Biennial Exposition of art established a $10,000 grand prize and "denationalized" the jury.

A Committee representing about 200 residents of West 91st Street between Broadway and West End Avenue was formed last night to petition the city to close an all-night bottle club in a basement at 251 West 91st Street.
Miss Steffi Mokotoff and Robert Berne were married yesterday afternoon at the St. RegisSheraton by Rabbi Jacob P. Rudin.

WETUMPKA, Ala., Nov. 23 An Alabama county coroner held a day-long closed-door inquiry today into the death of a Negro man whose companions say he was beaten by three law enforcement officers during an arrest early Sunday morning.
A boy was born in the Port Authority Bus Terminal early yesterday. It was the first birth in the terminal since it opened Dec. 15, 1950.
A 200-foot barge tanker docked at the Marine Terminal at La Guardia Airport was rocked by an explosion in its engine room last night, but the ensuing fire was brought under Control Within an hour.
Abe Burrows has severed his connection with the incoming musical version of Truman Capote's story "Breakfast at Tiffany's."
GUATEMALA, Nov. 23 Five policemen were killed today in a series of clashes with unidentified armed men.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 23 The federal election campaign has entered its final days with increasing tension and turmoil. The balloting will be held Saturday, and the candidates have stepped up their efforts.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 23 Miss Heather Low, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Ernest Low of Natrona Heights, Pa., was married this afternoon to Capt. James MacDonald Ruth Jr., U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mack Ruth of Cameron, Mo.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) Representative Frank Thompson Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, called for Virginia to be accorded equal recognition with Massachusetts as the state in which Thanksgiving orginated.
At 10:30, at 10:45 and at 11 o'clock yesterday morning a clerk in State Supreme Court cried out: "Adam Clayton Powell."

Jack of All Trades sped to a convincing victory in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday, beating Mrs. Ethel Jacobs's Reflected Glory by a half-length in the seven-furlong sprint for 2-year-olds. Third in the field of seven came Herbert Allen's Native Guile, much to the disappointment of the favorite players in the crowd of 21,256 who sent him away at odds-on.

The State Liquor Authority yesterday postponed until Dec. 7 its license revocation hearing against the Left Bank, a discotheque in Lindenhurst, L.I., on charges that the ostensible owners of the establishment were acting as fronts for an ex-convict and two of his associates.
The Oglebay Norton Company, a mining and minerals transportation concern, has announced in Cleveland the election of Maurice H. Stans as a director.
VANCOUVER, Canada, Nov. 23 (Canadian Press) Half the longshoremen in Vancouver and several gangs at other British Columbia ports were discharged today for employing slowdown tactics.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 23--A resolution calling on all countries to obey international law prohibiting the use of poison gas and bacteriological warfare was approved 101 to 0 today.

LONDON, Nov. 23 A plan to centralize labor-management bargaining in Britain somewhat along the lines of industrywide bargaining in the United States was approved today by the Trades Union Congress. It would enhance the 8.5million-member organization's power and diminish that of the 350 affiliated unions.
The battle over the Storm King Mountain power project, now in its fourth year, has been costly for both sides.

Paperboard production rose 5.4 per cent with 463,800 tons in the week ended Nov. 19, from 440,200 tons in the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

John E. Morrison Jr., vice president of the Bankers Trust Company in charge of its Long Island City branch in Queens, died yesterday in New York Hospital at the age of 52. He lived at 510 Manatuck Boulevard, Brightwaters, L.I.
ASCHAFFENBURG, Germany, Nov. 23 (UPI) The rightist National Democratic party today expelled two members charged by the police with having tied a man to a lamppost for 45 minutes.
The Rangers refused to bow to the fates last night.
The 18th Junior League Debutante Ball honored 39 debutantes last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. The league's welfare trust fund benefited.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 The National Highway Safety Agency is exploring ways to give automobile owners a clear picture of potential safety hazards in their cars.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 23 Coach Tom Cahill of Army emphasized today that the cadets would not be satisfied to settle for a tie against Navy in their traditional football game on Saturday in Philadelphia. They will try to score whenever they have the ball.

Joseph Rosenthal, an accountant who was long active in civic and philanthropic affairs, died of a heart attack yesterday at Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park at the age of 66. He lived at 88-135 193d Street, Hollis Park Gardens, Queens.
The flow of earnings reports from the nation's retailers reached a peak yesterday as Sears, Roebuck Co., announced record profits for the first nine months of its fiscal year.

THERE are three living champions in the Landseer variety of the Newfoundland breed in this country and two of them will be entered as a brace at the Westminster Kennel Club show. The event will be in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 13 and 14.
LISBON The Portuguese expect a big decline in their wine production this year, and to a certain extent are glad of it.
LONDON, Nov. 23 The House of Commons defeated today an attempt to introduce a bill to restore capital punishment for the murder of police and prison officers only.

Three young women were presented last night at the Colony Club in a setting of topiary gardenia trees and vinecovered trellises. They are they Misses Janet Lathrop Stott, Kathleen Acheson Thompson and Anne Hampton de Peyster Todd.

The Grand Council of Columbia Associations filed a complaint yesterday with the State Human Rights Commission charging an unlawful discriminatory practice in the handling of an Italian-American couple's attempt to adopt a blond foster child.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 When Custis Curtis, public relations man for the Plymouth Colony, heard that Myles Standish and his colleagues were planning a day of Thanksgiving, he immediately dropped everything, threw a clean button-down doublet into his dispatch case and hopped the first horse to Plymouth Rock.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 President Johnson has ordered a $1.1-billion cutback, amounting to 25 per cent, in the federally aided highway program.
William F.R. Ballard, the retiring chairman of the City Planning Commission, yesterday answered charges that the board had had little effect on what happened in New York.

The Douglas Aircraft Company said yesterday it had "no comment" to make on reports circulating in Beirut, Lebanon, that Douglas had withdrawn an offer to sell three super jet aircraft to Middle East Airlines.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 23 (AP)--Seven months of undercover work by the Narcotics Squad ended yesterday with the arrest of six students and one former student at Tulane University on charges of possessing illicit drugs.
Tommy Agee, 24-year-old center fielder of the Chicago White Sox, was named American League rookie of the year yesterday by the Baseball Writers Association of America.

Criminal Court Judge Benjamin H. Schor, who is under indictment in an alleged attempt to shake down applicants for a Queens tavern license, won the right yesterday to inspect the grand jury minutes in the case.

Making room on their roster for possible selections in drafting sessions at the minor and major league winter meetings beginning Monday, the New York Mets asked waivers yesterday on Ralph Terry "for the purpose of unconditional release" and sent Larry Elliott and Shaun Fitzmaurice to minor league teams.
NEW JERSEY appears to be producing a better breed of Robin Hoods, for the Garden State archers took a record 1,328 deer in the fiveweek season that ended Nov. 3.
A new model of the McDonnell Phantom fighter plane recently ordered by the Air Force will incorporate some new features as a result of lessons learned in the air war over North Vietnam and Laos.

The American Broadcasting Company said yesterday that its television broadcast of the Army-Navy football game on Saturday would be transmitted live to Hawaii. The program will be relayed by Lani Bird, the new communications satellite over the Pacific. The game in Philadelphia will be televised here over Channel 7, beginning at 1:15 P.M.
DETROIT, Nov, 23 The automobile industry said today that unless motorists had been notified by certified mail, their vehicles were free of the defects disclosed yesterday.

Lassen Leon Walsh, a Republican lawyer who ran unsuccessfully for Representative Adam Clayton Powell's seat in the 18th Congressional District this year, died yesterday in Beekman Downtown Hospital. He was 65 years old.
A potential new bidder for the assets of Detroit's beleaguered Pioneer Finance Company has appeared on the scene.
The Monsanto Company, the chemicals producer, announced yesterday in St. Louis the election of Monte C. Throdahl as a director and member of the executive committee.

ROVIGO, Italy, Nov. 23 Forty square miles of dark green water broken by pockets of red tile roofs and reflecting a gray dripping sky that is how the Po River delta looked today from a helicopter after the worst flood from the sea in two decades.

CHRYSLER shot to the top of the list of active stocks traded on the Big Board yesterday after a large block of 222,990 shares went at a price of 30 3/8. With other trading during the day, Chrysler finished at 30 3/8, for a gain on 341,100 shares.

A Civil Court judge ruled yesterday that a woman public school teacher who elects to serve on a jury cannot claim from the Board of Education the difference between her jury pay and what she would have earned in school.

JASON RALPH NATHAN, the city's first Housing and Development Administrator, will find his belief in bureaucratic short cuts severely tested as he tries to incorporate four independent municipal fiefdoms into his domain.

The nation's electric power production rose 7.3% in the week ended Nov. 19 from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Nov. 23--Only one thing stood between C.W. Post College today and the best football season in its history: the walking wounded of Hofstra University.

City Controller Mario A. Procaccino said yesterday that he was investigating the possible "larceny" of city property by voluntary hospitals that administer city hospitals.
Mal Graham, the elusive 185pound star from White Plains, must live up to last season's form if New York University is to make a strong showing in basketball this season.

Mr. and Mrs. John Alfred Davenport of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Wheeler Davenport, to Piers Brooke of London and New York. He is the son of Lady Mabel Cheetham of Eyford Park in Gloucestershire, England, and Richard Brooke of Hamburg, Germany.

A FRIGHTENING thing happened to Sir Joseph Porter, K.C.B., aboard the H.M.S. Pinefore last night at City Center. During one of his fandangos, the Ruler of the Queens Navee bumped into the ship's wheel and the wheel, to his horror, started to move.
An intelligent-but-fat suburban high school girl has one-third less chance of getting into college than her intelligent-but-thin classmate, a study by the Harvard School of Public Health indicates.
The National Football League's Eastern Conference title may be settled today, for all practical purposes, when the Cleveland Browns meet the Cowboys at Dallas.
Enid LaMonte Meadowcroft, writer and editor of children's stories, died yesterday at the Sharon, Conn., Hospital. She was 88 years old and was a resident of Lakeville, Conn.
PARIS, Nov. 23 A Paris avenue was renamed after Sir Winston Churchill today. President de Gaulle said later at a Cabinet meeting that the action was "very satisfactory."
LONDON, Nov.24--A young, lively audience saw the first performance of a short season by the Merce Cunningham Dance Dance Company at the Saville Theater tonight and cheered Mr. Cunningham's "Place."

JOHNSON CITY, Tex. Nov. 23 President Johnson sounded a note of caution today against enthusiastic hopes that United States attempts to land men on the moon would proceed with the same relative smoothness as had recent American space efforts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) Two Federal Communications Commissioners asked the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for more information on its foreign operations that might influence news coverage by the American Broadcasting Company if their proposed merger is approved.

The Jones Laughlin Corporation's stainless and strip division yesterday joined other major steel companies in increasing prices on certain grades of stainless steel.

Prices advanced broadly on the London Stock xchange yesterday following a mildly optimistic forecast for the economy by the Chancellor of the Exchequer.

A Mineola, L.I. businessman was accused by the notice yesterday of trying to make money on the glamour of the Vladimir Horowitz piano recital this Sunday at Carnegie Hall.

Mayor Lindsay has made an ambitious start toward reorganizing the dispersed and often conflicting agencies in the housing field. By executive order he has grouped five agencies in a new Housing and Development Administration. A sixth the Housing Authority will be added if the Legislature approves.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 After years of stability, labor costs in manufacturing have risen significantly in the last two months, a Government report disclosed today.

The usual preholiday lethargy gripped the commodities markets yesterday, with one notable exception potato traders had an active day.
OTTAWA, Nov. 23 (UPI) Two and one-half tons of white spruce will be Canada's Christmas present to the United States this year.

The Sebring 12-hour sports car race will be run for the 16th time at Sebring, Fla., next April 1. A plan to transfer the international event to a West Palm Beach site has failed.

Britain's Labor Government has decided that it cannot permit much of a thaw in its policy of freezing wages. The freeze began last July for a six-month period. Now Labor plans to extend it almost intact until next July. And all with the generous land close about, a world of fields made fruitful by calloused hands. The thanks were for health and strength and independence.

The loss was the first for the Musketeers since Nov. 11, 1961. The victory was East Islip's eighth in an unbeaten season and also gave the team the Suffolk League Division three championship.

HONOLULU, Nov. 23 While Don Ho, a singing entertainer, is introducing New Yorkers to the new sound of Hawaiian music Friday night at the Royal Box of the Amercana Hotel, the man who wrote the songs that characterize the new musical Hawaii lies in a hospital in Tijuana, Mexico, fighting a long battle against cancer.

HONOLULU Henry J. Kaiser, a gentle Croesus who has 60 companies in 40 countries, is down to three television sets and three telephones in his cream and rust-colored bedroom. But life in his cement and marble palace has lost none of its grandeur.

Now that the election is over, the "very healthy movement toward price stability" the Administration discerned early this month seems to have gone into hiding again. Consumer prices for October went up almost half a per cent, bringing the total increase over the last year to 3.7 per cent. This is triple the rate of climb that has prevailed in most recent years, a period of exceptional stability in the purchasing power of the dollar.

QUANTICO, Va., Nov. 24 (AP) Tom Longsworth, a fullback, scored three touchdowns today to lead the Quantico Marines to a 30-26 victory over Lamar Tech, co-champion of the Southland Conference in Texas.

DETROIT, Nov. 24 (AP) John Brodie riddled the Detroit secondary with passes and Ken Willard ripped the line with runs as the San Francisco 49ers crushed the Lions, 41-14, in a National Football League game today.

Maj. Gen. Tom V. Stayton, commander of the country's first surface-to-air missile units, died yesterday of a heart attack at Walter Reed Medical Center in Washington. He was 58 years old. He had suffered an earlier attack on Oct. 25.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 24 William Osgood Morgan, a partner in the law firm of Morgan Nichols of Newark and New York, died on Tuesday at the Greenwich, Conn., home of his daughter, Mrs. Grant Oliver. He was 87 years old and lived for many years in Montclair.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Friday, Nov. 25 (AP) In a turnabout move, Aksel Larsen, Danish left-wing Socialist leader, early today agreed to try again to form as joint government with the Social Democrats. It would be Denmark's first government ever based on majority rule by Marxist parties.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 24 (Reuters) Syria's Government has broken off negotiations with the Iraqi Petroleum Company about oil royalties.

DALLAS, Nov. 24 Tom Landry, the coach, said it would be the most important game in the seven-year history of the Dallas Cowboys. His players responded to the challenge by soundly defeating the Cleveland Browns, 26-14, tonight before a record Cotton Bowl crowd of 80,259.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America strongly endorsed today the Administration's Vietnam policy, expressing confidence that President Johnson's position would ultimately result in "lasting peace."

LEN DAWSON was in Paul Brown's office when he learned that the Cleveland Browns had decided to release him as back-up quarterback. Dawson never hesitated. He reached for the phone, looked questioningly at Paul and received a nod of acquiescence. The call went to Hank Stram, the coach of the then Dallas Texans who were later to be the Kansas City Chiefs. The conversation was brief.

MIAMI, Nov. 24 (AP) Two outsiders Farbizon, at 9-1, and Happy Voter, at 28-1 scored victories today in the divisions of the $8,537 Alligator Stakes at Tropical Park.

PARIS The designer uses a monkey wrench to tighten the nuts and bolts that hold his sculptured aluminum dresses together. And when the models walk in the dresses, they must not move their arms or they will be cut by the edges.
AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 24 President Johnson spent a "quiet family day" at his ranch in the sparse central Texas hill country 60 miles west of here this Thanksgiving, White House officials announced.
Two touchdowns by Frank Muscolina led Cardinal Hayes to a 28-0 victory over Mt. St. Michael yesterday in a Catholic High School Football League game before 16,000 at Baker Field.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Friday, Nov. 25 Several thousand teenagers rioted in front of the Municipal Auditorium here last night when the police halted a concert by James Brown, a rock-'n'roll entertainer who bills himself as a "singer of soul music" and "a one-man riot." At least 20 persons were arrested.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 24 Communist spokesmen concentrated their fire today on a draft resolution supported by the United States that seeks to make Communist China's admission a question of importance requiring a two-thirds majority.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Nov. 24 C.W. Post College won its sixth straight football game today by defeating Hofstra, 25-21, in the annual Battle of Long Ilsand.
LONDON, Nov. 24 Unemployment in Britain rose sharply this month to the highest total since April, 1963.
Phil Ochs, the folk singer, gave a program of his own works last night at Carnegie Hall. As with his debut there last January, the auditorium was filled with teen-agers.
CAIRO, Nov. 24 United Arab Republic customs authorities have seized the assets of the Ford Motor Company assembly plant in Alexandria, officials told Egyptian newsmen tonight.
MIAMI, Nov. 24 The operating agent of the cruise ship Nill, which is heavily booked through April for cruises between Miami and the Bahamas.

Bushwick High of Brooklyn won the Public Schools Athletic League soccer championship for the fourth time in the last five years yesterday by defeating Charles E. Hughes of Manhattan, 1-0, at Randalls Island. The Tigers had won the title in 1962, '63, and '65.
The Lincoln Center Repertory Company has 31,400 subscribers this season. The figure for the previous season was 39,300.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) The Defense Department has started a crackdown on unscrupulous auto dealers and money lenders who prey on servicemen overseas.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) The Federal National Mortgage Association said today it would give investors a chance to earn about 6 per cent, a record rate, on a new offering of securities.
Lou Carnesecca has been St. John's University's basketball coach for only one season, but he has his own approach to the game.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) A committee of the National Research Council recommended today that the Federal Government support the use of computers to gain deeper understanding of the nature of language.
CEDARHURST, L.I., Nov. 24 Lawrence High marched 59 yards to a touchdown in the fourth quarter and defeated Brooklyn Tech, 18-13 today. Chris Kyprianides scored the deciding touchdown on a 4-yard run.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) Villanova scored the second time it had the ball today and stopped George Washington's running attack to post a 16-7 victory in the season finale for both teams.
THE HAGUE, Nov. 24 A conference on satellite communications here has taken a modest step toward the development of a European telecommunications satellite.

William J. Morgan of 302 West 12th Street, lecturer on psychology at Fairleigh Dickinson University for the last seven years, died of a heart attack Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. His age was 78.

TULSA, Okla., Nov. 24 (UPI) The University of Tulsa scored four touchdowns and intercepted five passes in fine second period today to trounce Wichita, 47-14, and gain a share of its 15th Missouri Valley champaionship.
MIAMI, Nov. 24 (AP) Airlifted "pilgrims" from Cuba knelt and prayed tearfully after arriving in a new land on Thanksgiving Day.

The city's narrow escape from air pollution disaster yesterday a holiday when there was little truck traffic, few operating incinerators and virtually no industry provided an unpleasantly dramatic reminder of the urgency for proper control of the air we breathe.

The cost of electricity supplied by the Consolidated Edison Company will go up today amid grumbling from consumers, charges of political "conspiracy," and demands for investigations of the Public Service Commission's approval of the rate increase.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Nov. 24 The Congo opened festivities celebrating the first anniversary of the military regime of President Joseph D. Mobutu with the inauguration of the former Belgian colony's first television station last night.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 25 (UPI) The Alabama Power Company, locked in the longest major utility strike in state history, said today that saboteurs used chains and rifles to disrupt service to 500 customers in the Montgomery area last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) Five lame duck members of the House are among scores of Representatives who are making inspection trips abroad.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 24 Progress in the Kennedy round was impeded today as Common Market ministers failed to agree on agricultural offers they must make in the worldwide round of tariff-cutting talks.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 24 The bells will soon be ringing again at Wesleyan University here, thanks to an anonymous gift of $16,500 and the skill of a Kentucky carillon and organ expert.
LONDON, Nov. 24 Pye of Cambridge, an electronics company that some of its competitors size up as ready for a takeover, angled for the best possible price today.
The Bank of Montreal reported yesterday record earnings of $19,905,599, or $3.28 a share, for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, up 6.3 per cent from the $18,730,353 or $3.08 a share earned in 1965.
MADRID, Nov. 24 The national referendum on Spain's new Constitution was set today for Dec. 14.
LONDON, Nov. 24 The House of Commons defeated by one vote tonight a proposal that its proceedings be televised.

FAIR LAWN, N.J., Nov. 24 Bruce Jankowski, the leading scorer in the Northern New Jersey Interscholastic League, scored three touchdowns today but it wasn't enough to prevent Ridgewood from recording a 40-33 upset victory over Fair Lawn. The loss was the first for the previously undefeated Cutters, who had not been beaten in 24 games over a threeyear yeriod.

ROME, Nov. 24 (AP) Heavy rain brought back serious floods to disaster-stricken Tuscany today and set off damaging landslides elsewhere. The generally stormy weather darkened Italy again three weeks after the worst floods in the nation's history.

AN animated musical fantasy on how Smokey the Bear might have grown up to become the valued fire prevention agent of the United States Forest Service was offered last night over the network of the National Broadcasting Company.
LONDON, Nov. 24 Leonard, Bernstein said here today he might live in London after relinquishing his post as music director of the New York Philharmonic in the spring of 1969.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 24 An ombudsman to protect Nassau County's 1.4 million residents against governmental maladministration was called feasible today by the chairman of a special study group.

MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Nov. 24 The blond, 4 -year-old foster child of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Liuni had Thanksgiving dinner, as she has had every year of her young life, with those she regards as "Grandma," "Aunt Angle," "Aunt Margaret," "Uncle Mike," and several "cousins."

New Yorkers with an interest in the visual arts have been chagrined to discover that the principal exhibition events of the new season are all taking place outside their own city. Almost weekly the...
GENEVA, Nov. 24 Suicide now ranks among the first 10 causes of adult deaths in industrialized countries, the World Health Organization said today.
CAP-HAITIEN, Haiti, Nov 23--The sleepy-eyed soldier at the guard post in the humid Haitian interior leaned on his Mauser rifle and looked at the visitors' jeep in mild surprise.
LONDON, Nov. 24 (AP) "The Silence of Lee Harvey Oswald," a play about President Kennedy's assassin, got lukewarm reviews today in London.

Helen Young, from 1921 to 1942 director of the Presbyterian Hospital's School of Nursing and its Nursing Service, died Wednesday in the Harkness Pavilion of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 92 years old and lived at 617 West 168th Street.

LONDON, Nov. 24 Air Commodore Patrick Huskinson, a World War I flying ace who designed the 12,000-pound blockbuster bombs used by the Royal Air Force against Germany in World War II, died at his home here today. He was 69 years old.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 24 (AP) Senator Milton R. Young, Republican of North Dakota; arrived in Saigon today to begin a three-day inspection of United States military operations and to check on the black market of American supplies. He was accompanied by staff members of the Senate Appropriations and Armed Services Committees.

PLEIME, South Vietnam, Nov. 24 The ritual sacrifice of a water buffalo and memories of a violent battle nearly blotted Thanksgiving from the minds of the 12 American soldiers who share this remote Central Highlands outpost with 400 mountain tribesmen.
Twenty-seven young women were informally presented to Francis Cardinal Spellman at the Gotham Ball, staged last night at the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.
An argument between two friends in the Bronx yesterday ended when one fired a rifle at the other and then shot at two patrolmen who tried to arrest him, according to the police.

Donald C. Dayton, chairman of the Dayton Company, Minneapolis, and Terence Ryan and Jerome Goldfarb, owners of the Splendiferous specialty store, New York, have been selected to receive the 1966 Tobe Awards in retailing.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Nov. 24 The marriage of Miss Marcia Gail Moonves, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Moonves, to Dr. Eugene M. Cooper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Cooper of Evanston, Ill., took place this afternoon. Rabbi Simon Resnikoff and Cantor David Mann officiated at the ceremony in the Temple Gates of Zion.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 24 The Navy football team completed its preparations for Army with a short drill in sweat suits this morning and then was given the rest of the day off to relax before leaving tomorrow for Philadelphia and Saturday's 67th service game.

SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 24 (UPI) A National Guard round-the-clock patrol was instituted today in a south Scranton section where poisonous fumes from an under ground mine fire have forced 18 families from their homes.

A year after the Northeast blackout of Nov. 9, 1965, certain segments of the business of producing electricity are busier than ever before. In general, these are the manufacturers of stand-by equipment and particularly those that make gas-turbine units as opposed to the larger standard generators.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 For a few days in late August and early September sober men in the money markets took seriously the possibility of a money crisis, or panic a freezing up in which money could not be borrowed at any rate of interest and bonds could not be sold at any price.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 24 (Reuters) The Salisbury High Court upheld today an injunction restraining the Government from deporting Sidney Brooks, an American, until he has appealed against an order declaring him a prohibited immigrant.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 24 (UPI) Pilots protesting "dangerous" proposed changes in regulations covering crew size and safety procedures struck Qantas Airlines today, paralyzing the carrier around the world. It was the third pilots' strike against Quantas in three years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 On the question of raising taxes, President Johnson is a little like one of his favorite Texas football players, Hardhead Jackson, who was a powerful runner, but just didn't like to carry the ball.
TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 25 (Reuters) Emperor Hirohito's 22-year-old niece, Princess Yasuko, will marry a Red Cross worker on Dec. 18, it was announced here today.

State Senator Jack E. Bronston declared yesterday he would seek legislation requiring that the President's Club, which has raised millions of dollars for the Democratic party, disclose the names of its contributors and the amounts they give.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) The nation's dairy farmers hope to persuade the 90th Congress to impose restrictions against the increasing importation of milk products.
AND I thought Hamlet had better taste.

DETROIT, Nov. 24 (AP) Mantom M. Cummins, a labor negotiator for the Ford Motor Company, died today of complications resulting from a recent fall at his home in suburban Bloomfield Hills. He was 60 years old.

VIENNA, Nov. 24--A Bulgarian passenger plane crashed tonight near Bratislava, Czechoslovakia, killing all aboard. Originally 84 persons were on the plane but some may have left when it made an unscheduled landing at Bratislava.

The marriage of Miss Cecilia Saladrigas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mario Saladrigas of New York, formerly of Havana, to Ronald H. Shiftan took place here yesterday. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Shiftan of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. James J. Gilhooley performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Hearts.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP) The Chicago Black Hawks scored three goals in the first 10 minutes of play tonight and coasted to a 5-0 victory over the Montreal Canadiens.

Raphael Feldhuhn, a retired hosiery manufacturer who aided Jewish refugees from the Baltic states during World War II, died Wednesday at his home of a heart attack. He was 77 years old and lived at 27 West 72d Street.

GREENWOOD, Miss. Nov. 24 (UPI) A Chicago Negro, Ottoway Barbee, has been sentenced to life imprisonment in the Mississippi state penitentiary after a biracial jury convicted him of killing a state highway patrolman.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 24 By the end of 1966 the ports of New Orleans, Lake Charles and Baton Rouge expect to have in operation the newly formed Mid-Gulf Seaports Marine Terminal Conference.
PARIS, Nov. 24 The United States proposed today that the Western industrial powers make a joint effort to expand economic ties with Eastern Europe.
For several months, Daniel Kiley, a young accountant at the Western Electric Company's downtown headquarters, left his desk at 5 P.M. every Tuesday as usual.

LONDON, Nov. 24 (Reuters) The Commonwealth Secretary, Herbert W. Bowden, left by air tonight for Rhodesia on a mission that may give Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's regime its last chance to avert the threat of United Nations economic sanctions.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 24 Several New York stars were among the leaders when the Blue Ribbon pairs event went into its second semifinal session here tonight at the American Contract Bridge League's fall national championships.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Only 204 out of 75,000 positions in community action agencies will be directly affected by a $15,000 limit on salaries that may be paid with Federal antipoverty funds, administration officials say. Further, the incumbents may not even suffer pecuniary losses.

Eleven men, including four who have been linked to the Mafia, were free yesterday after Criminal Court Judge J. Randall Creel dismissed charges that they had been consorting with criminals for an unlawful purpose.
The Rev. Canon Edward N. West has been named the first sub-dean of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24--The State Department announced today that Czechoslovakia had agreed to permit United State's officials to visit an American citizen of Czech birth who has been held incommunicado since his arrest on Oct. 31.

Miss Nicole Henry, daughter of Paul-Marc Henry of New York and Seguret, France, and Mrs. Blanchard Henry of Paris, was married yesterday to Pierre Berger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henri Berger of Lyon and Crest, France. The civil ceremony took place in the town hall of the 16th Arrondissement in Paris.
BOSTON, Nov. 25 New containerized shipping facilities, ready months ago, remain unused here today because of a jurisdictional dispute between two unions.
AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 25 President Johnson approved today the allocation of $1.05-billion to the states for aid to more than seven million school children in low-income areas.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 25 (UPI) An international labor boycott of Argentine shipping began to bite today when the Argentine state river fleet called off its service to Montevideo, in Uruguay across the River Platte.
LIMA, Peru, Nov. 25 (UPI) President Fernando Belaunde Terry replaced four Cabinet Ministers today, but made no essential change in the political make-up or policy of his Government.

An uninsured Utah savings and loan association, which last July experienced such heavy withdrawals that it was forced to operate on a "limited withdrawal" basis, has now stopped making any payments to depositors at all.

The Plaza's Grand Ballroom took a kaleidoscopic turn to white and gold last night for the first of the season's Junior Assemblies. It had been white and green Wednesday for the Junior League Debutante Ball, pink and red for Thursday's Gotham Ball. And this evening it will go bronze, yellow and white for the Grosvenor Debutante Ball.
The spot rate on the British dropped 14 points to $2.7904 in moderate trading on foreignexchange markets here yesterday.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 25 (AP) Kathy Whitworth of San Antonio, Texas, the defending champion, and Mary Mills of Ocean Springs, Miss., tied for the second-round lead today in the annual Titleholders golf tournament.
POTSDAM, N.Y., Nov. 25 Capt. Gary Milroy gave Michigan Tech a 4-3 victory over the Clarkson College hockey team tonight with his second goal of the game at 1:23 of a suddendeath overtime period.

WEST LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 Miss Susan Marie Lauer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter C. Lauer of Highland Park, N.J., was married here this evening to Edwin Creech Holt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin G. Holt of Summit, N.J. The Rev. Dr. L. David Cowie performed the ceremony in the Brentwood Presbyterian Church.
BRASILIA, Nov. 25 President Humberto Castelo Branco has told congressional leaders that he will refrain from using his power to oust deputies and senators while they vote on a new constitution.

Most of Broadway's troubles particularly the difficulty in raising funds for serious shows, are due to the "stubborn refusal of politicians to let the theater be free in a free-enterprise world." John F. Wharton, Broadway lawyer, declared yesterday.
John Morrell Co., the Chicago meat packer, reported yesterday a sharply improved level of operations in the fiscal year ended Oct. 29.

IN its sumptuous town house at 41 East 65th Street, the American Federation of Arts is playing host to a contemporary drawing show. Since there are never enough of such exhibitions in New York, the occasion is one for mild rejoicing.

Three major foreign airlines said yesterday they would match a new low fare for groups of 10 or more persons that Pan American World Airways plans to offer starting Jan. 1. The Pan American plan hinges on foreign government approval.
Mrs. Frances Herchberg Miller, wife of Rabbi Joseph Miller of Congregation Shaare Torah of Flatbush, died yesterday in her home at 120 East 19th Street in Brooklyn. She was 66 years old.

Two members of a committee to advise the Board of Supervisors of Nassau County on the question of making permanent the office of ombudsman there, the only one in the nation, have warmly endorsed the idea on their return from Scandinavia, home of the public protector. But the two did not agree on details.
TEL AVIV, Nov. 25 Communist candidates failed to gain control of the Nazareth city council in elections held yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 After five hours of heated debate, a resolution calling for the withdrawal of a major Jewish Orthodox congregational body from the Synagogue Council of America was defeated today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 Freight traffic volume generated by carloadings on U.S. railroads and intercity truck tonnage during the week ended Nov. 19 were both ahead of the corresponding period of last year.
WARWICK, R.I., Nov. 25 (AP) A Brooklyn truck driver leaped to safety today just before his 11-ton tractor-trailer truck plunged part of the way down a 30-foot embankment in Warwick.
RALEIGH, N.C. Nov. 25 Gov. Dan K. Moore said today he plans to recommend "a general and broad tax reduction" to the North Carolina General Assembly, which convenes in February.
Miss Irene Elizabeth McKenna, the only woman ever to serve as acting counsel to a New York State governor, died Thursday at her residence, 2 Tudor City Place. She was 80 years old.
Boys High will win its first Public Schools Athletic League Division II title today if it defeats a weak John Jay eleven.

The first stage of an air pollution emergency was declared yesterday in the New York metropolitan area, New Jersey and Connecticut as a stagnant air mass continued to envelop the Eastern Seaboard, trapping potentially, lethal gases and smoke.

MEMPHIS, Nov. 25 (AP)--Clarence Adams, the former Army corporal who defected to Communist China, said today he wanted the chance to tell the world how much better the Democratic system was than Communism.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI) Georgia told the Supreme Court today that unless the state Legislature was allowed to settle its governorship dispute, a series of indecisive runoff elections might wind up in a total stalemate.

API Instruments, Inc., said yesterday in Cleveland that it would make selective price increases on certain panel meters and meter-relays. The rises will range between 3 and 15 per cent and will take effect Dec. 15.

A flood of telephone calls and letters seeking souvenirs of the luxury liner Queen of Bermuda were received at Furness Line offices at 38 Whitehall Street yesterday, as the 41-year-old liner was berthed here for the last time.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI) Following is the text of the statement by J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, on re- cent challenges of the findings of the Warren Commission on the Kennedy assassination:
CLEVELAND, Nov. 25 (AP) --F. Lee Bailey said in a speech here today he had sent the names of the two persons he believes killed Samuel H. Sheppard's first wife to the Bay Village police chief.

Edward Fleischmann, a 43-year-old jobber, decided to do something yesterday about what he considered insufficient heat in his apartment. He set fire to a pile of newspapers and magazines in the lobby in the building in which he resides, at 220 Cabrini Boulevard.
GREAT NECK, L.I., Nov. 25 Samuel M. Abrams of 30 Stoner Avenue, a retired industrialist, died yesterday at Long Island Jewish Hospital, New Hyde Park, Queens. He was 72 years old.
The New York Stock Exchange had its busiest day of the year yesterday in people not securities.
Several commodity exchanges had one of their slowest trading sessions of the year yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 25 (AP) Frank Robinson tested his right knee in a stepped-up timetable today and reported satisfactory progress from his recent operation.

THE solution to a problem facing Mr. and Mrs. Rufus C. Stillman two years ago led to the current exhibition of hand-hooked rugs designed by artists at the Stephen Radich Gallery, 818 Madison Avenue (68th Street).
CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP) A Baptist minister was fined $25 today for violating an anti-littering ordinance by placing religious tracts under windshield wipers of parked cars.

In their search for new directorial talent, the major American film companies are showing an increasing interest in offbeat, usually quite young European directors whose reputations were made in so-called "art" films.

BONN, Nov. 25--Kurt Georg Kiesinger predicted tonight that West Germany's political crisis would be settled next week with the formation of a "grand coalition" between his Christian Democrats and the second largest party, the Social Democrats.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 25 The marriage of Miss Margaret Jeanne Hazen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dan F. Hazen Jr., to Harden Parke Ballantine took place in the First Presbyterian Church here today. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Ballantine of Lake Wales, Fla., formerly of Rumson. The Rev. Dr. Charles A. Platt performed the ceremony.

LAST night's documentary, "It's a Dog's World," was a show for every reasonable viewer who appreciates that a friendly bark is a form of expressive communication unmatched by either human voice or cat's purr. For all who confess to a helpless affinity for the most personable of four-legged companions, the David L. Wolper production was a winning review of canine society.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 25 (AP) Bert Bell Jr., the business manager of the Baltimore Colts, announced today he was quitting the Colts and "more importantly," the National Football League, saying he "cannot condone the crass commercialism that is striking at the very heart of the game."

The Russian Orthodox Cathedral of Our Lady of the Sign was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Adelaide Keene McKenzie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick O. McKenzie of 923 Fifth Avenue and New Canaan, Conn., to Jean Andre Sviatopolk-Mirsky. He is the son of Princess Stanislawa Sviatopolk-Mirsky of Grau-Du-Roi, France, and the late Prince Andre Vladimirovitch Sviatopolk-Mirsky of Kiev, Russia.
The Rangers were never a morose bunch of athletes, yet one would expect they would be a little more reserved, especially with today's game against the Chicago Black Hawks.
