SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Nov. 26 (AP) Premier Nguyen Cao Ky has recorated top officers of the United States First Infantry Division for leadership and courage in Tayninh Province in the largest American ground action of the war.
NEWARK, Nov. 25--The chairman of a state commission said today that it was planning to recommend the creation of a statewide public defender system in New Jersey.

CANTERBURY, England, Nov. 25 (AP) A Kent magistrate's court convicted a pirate radio station management today of broadcasting without a license on British territory. The station used an abandoned port in the Thames Estuary.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 25 King Hussein of Jordan has written to President Gamal Abdel Nesser of the United Arab Republic complaining about attacks on Jordan by the Palestine Liberation Organization, which is based in the U.A.R.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 25 (AP) Demonstrators here said today more than 40 persons were hit by bullets fired by Arab Legion troops and were taken to hospitals, where most were released after treatment.

The New York Giants, who had lost five players for the balance of the National Football League season, suffered a sixth blow yesterday. Their doctors said that Earl Morrall, the No. 1 quarterback who broke his right wrist three weeks ago, would be sidelined for the rest of the season because the wrist had failed to heal properly.
New Yorkers began paying more for electricity yesterday, but they have yet to get any adequate official assurance that the increase is justified.

SHERMAN, Conn., Nov. 25 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Louis Seligmann have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Elizabeth Seligmann, to Joel Alan Winter, son of Mrs. Albert Winter of Jackson Heights, Queens, New York, and the late Mr. Winter.

HARTFORD, Nov. 25 (AP) A prisoner of Connecticut must be regarded as a public figure, lacking the right of privacy accorded ordinary citizens, it was ruled today by United States District Judge M. Joseph Blumenfield.

The Asian Development Bank represents a significant new experiment in international finance. The bank has been established by nineteen Asian and thirteen other countries, which together have pledged $1.1 billion to support its operations. Headquartered in Manila and led by Takeshi Watanabe of Japan, it will provide financial help and development assistance throughout the vast continent except only in Communist China and North Vietnam.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 Mighty, battered Notre Dame meets not-so-mighty Southern California tomorrow in what looms as the Prestige Bowl.

Miss Jerry Darlene Bailey, daughter of Mrs. Charles Jennings of Foley, Ala., and Walter F. Bailey of Chattanooga, Tenn., was married yesterday afternoon to Photographer's Mate Airman Hugh Raymond Downs, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Malcolm Downs of New York.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Nov. 25 Miss Mary Worthey, daughter of the late Rev. Arthur Lester Middleton Worthey and the late Mrs. Catherine W. Worthey of Erie, Pa., and stepdaughter of Mrs. Worthey of Southport, was married here today to Samuel Cook Edsall 2d, a widower. He is the son of the Rev. and Mrs. Samuel Harmon Edsall of Geneva, N.Y.
ROME, Nov. 25 (UPI) Many political and religious difficulties stand in the way of reunion between the Eastern Orthodox and the Roman Catholic Churches, the Vatican press spokesman said today.

BRONXVILLE. N.Y., Nov. 25 James D. Maver Jr. and Ford White of Winged Foot combined for a gross best-ball card of 35, 33 68, 3 under par, at Siwanoy Country Club today to win a playoff for the British Victory Cup.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 25 (AP) The Bernz-O-Matic Corporation of Rochester said today a $20,435,000 damage suit by it against the Scovill Manufacturing Company has been transferred to Federal court jurisdiction.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 24 This republic is debating whether its new Constitution should get a 21-gun or a 101-gun salute when it is promulgated next week.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 25 (AP) Arthur Ashe led the advance of four more Americans today into the third round of the Victorian tennis championships.
A RECENTLY published, definitive book for the seafood devotee, ocean fisherman and cooking enthusiast is titled "The Savor of the Sea" by Dan Morris and Matilda Moore (Macmillan, $6.95).

Black smoke was pouring from the chimney of the apartment house at 549 West 163d Street yesterday morning as Benjamin Jacobs stepped out of a black automobile with a small sign in the windshield that read: "New York City Department of Air Pollution Control."

Earlier this month, only a few weeks after President Johnson announced a more liberal trade policy with the Communist bloc, a high government official predicted that United States trade with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe might reach record proportions this year.

Charles Silversmith of 167 Congress Street, Brooklyn, men's fashion editor of Footwear News, a Fairchild publication, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital, after an illness of two weeks. His age was 29.

LONDON, Nov. 25 An 82-year-old widow from Northamptonshire, who had come here hoping to vindicate her husband's love of paintings, walked out of a famous London art auction house today a saddened woman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) Representative John Bell Williams of Mississippi, who lost out on a committee chairmanship because his fellow Democrats deprived him of his seniority status in 1965, served notice today that he would fight next year for the chairmanship.

Arthur Hargate. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Henry de Greeff of Clearwater, Fla., formerly of Mount Kisco. The Pride of Judea Children's Services will hold its 51st annual dinner dance tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria, where Samuel Scheff will be honored for his service to the agency. Arthur Slavin is chairman of the event.
Foreigners will be permitted to visit Yugoslavia without visas in 1967, the International Tourist Year, a result of a law adopted yesterday by the Yugoslav Parliament.
TOKYO, Nov. 25 The Asian Development Bank elected the 10 members of its board of directors today.

HONG KONG, Nov. 25 The official press of Commu nist China rejected today a Canadian proposal that both the Peking regime and the Chinese Nationalist Government on Taiwan be allowed to sit in the United Nations.
Mayor Lindsay's three-day official visit to Puerto Rico, which was scheduled for next month, has been postponed until the spring.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange were generally steady yesterday in quiet trading.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 25 (Reuters) The lights dimmed in Buenos Aires nightclubs and patrolling policemen tossed down free drinks today as the city celebrated the ousting of its straitlaced morality enforcer.

What would normally be considered by Braulio Baeza as a routine accomplishment was really a noteworthy one for that highly competent jockey at Aqueduct yesterday. In the feature race on the program Baeza rode Jacques Wimpfheimer's Petite Rouge to a one-length victory over Reginald Webster's Nature, with the Hobeau Farm's Save Up next in the field of eight fillies and mares.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 25 (UPI) Despite the loss of Jerry Lucas on fouls, the Cincinnati Royals survived a late Knicks rally tonight and beat New York, 115-109, in a National Basketball Association game.
DRYDEN, N.Y., Nov. 25 (AP) Five persons including two cousins and their wives were killed today in a two-car, head-on crash on Route 38 near this village east of Ithaca.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 25 Miss Adrianne Carol Spevack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome S. Spevack, was married today to David M. Singer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Singer of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Jacob K. Shankman performed the ceremony in Temple Israel.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 25 (UPI) Lou Hudson, a rookie with the St. Louis Hawks, lost a sneaker during the National Basketball Association game between the Boston Celtics and the Hawks last night.

Two harness racing owners and a driver face grand jury action within two or three weeks in the continuing investigation of an alleged conspiracy to fix races, dope horses and defraud the state of $60-million in tax revenues, it was learned yesterday. If indictments are voted, these will be the jury's first indictments.

A 36-year-old patient apparently went berserk yesterday on the fourth floor of Fordham Hospital and injured a security guard in a wild battle with attendants before jumping to his death from a storage room window.
LAFAYETTE, La., Nov. 25 (AP) Bert Yancey took sole possession of the lead today after the second round of the $34,500 Cajun Classic golf tournament at the Oakbourne Country Club.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) The Pentagon officially announced today that the January draft call would be cut from 27,600 to 15,600.

IN a mixture and with a pace uniquely his own, H.V. Morton has contrived a charming excursion through the foun tains of Rome. He has blended history, folklore, technical matters, gossip, profiles of Popes and commoners into a relaxed and amiable travelogue. In a way Mr. Morton has pulled a neat trick.

Victor Herd, chairman of the Continental Insurance Company, will soon be invited to join the board of directors of the Diners' Club, Inc., following Continental's acquisition of about 20 per cent of Diners' Club common stock. Alfred S. Bloomingdale, chairman, president and chief executive officer of the Diners' Club, said late yesterday in Los Angeles.

Carnegie Recital Hall was nearly filled last night for a recital sponsored by a group of Latvian-Americans for the benefit of the performer. He was Arthur Ozolins, a 21-year-old pianist who arrived in this country alone a little more than two years ago and is now a student of Nadia Reisenberg at the Mannes College of Music.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 25 (Reuters) Yugoslav authorities announced tonight a new investigation of Mihajlo Mihajlov, now serving a one-year sentence for publishing false news abroad.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The National Right to Work Committee is undertaking campaigns to outlaw compulsory union membership in 11 more states. The recent election, it said in its November news letter, has provided "almost unprecedented" opportunities.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Nov. 25 Miss Susan Lingle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elmore Y. Lingle, was married here this afternoon to Dirk van Loon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bowditch van Loon of Manchester, Vt. Msgr. Leo Ruggle performed the ceremony in the St. Joseph Roman Catholic Pro-cathedral.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 J. Edgar Hoover said today that no evidence had been found to indicate that Lee Harvey Oswald had had an accomplice in the assassination of President Kennedy.
THE HUBSHMAN FUND, described as the first mutual fund offered to the public that will employ both hedging and leveraging principles, is scheduled to begin operating today.

The Soviet warning to neutral Austria not to take up associate membership in the Common Market undoubtedly was directed less at Austria than at its Eastern Communist neighbors. All are showing increased interest in trade with the West to speed their economic development.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 Dr. William Haddon Jr., the Federal Government's auto safety chief, was driving to work along the George Washington Memorial Parkway at 50 miles an hour in his shiny new Ford Fairlane sedan.
Two directors of the Wheeling Steel Corporation resigned yesterday as board members of the Crucible Steel Company of America.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 A United States diplomat was permitted today to visit for the first time the Czechoslovakborn American travel agent seized in Prague nearly a month ago on espionage charges. The travel agent was reported to be well and anxious to obtain a defense attorney.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 25 (AP) Murray Stable's Barletta rallied in the stretch today to win the Sweet 'n Lovely Purse from six other fillies at Laurel Race Course.
Tokyo Rokuro Ishiyama, 126 pounds, Japan, outpointed Suh Soo Kang, 125. South Korea, 10.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 25 (UPI) Alberto Carrero of Puerto Rico, the top-seeded player, defeated Jim Ward of Tuscaloosa, Ala., 9-7, 6-4, in a third-round match today of the National junior tennis tournament.
Thermal inversions that trap stagnant air have been held responsible for thousands of deaths and much illness in the last two decades.
MANCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 25 (AP) Mrs. Michael King, mother of Gov. John W. King of New Hampshire, died today at a hospital here. She was 80 years old.

VIENNA, Nov. 25 (UPI) A number of Latin-American delegates to the recent Communist party congress in Sofia were among 82 people killed in the crash of a Soviet-made Bulgarian airliner yesterday in Czechoslovakia, it was announced in Sofia today.
WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 25 Bob Farrington showed up at Roosevelt Raceway tonight and surprised everyone by announcing he would drive Easy Prom in tomorrow night's $25,000 Adios Butler Cup Pace.

WILLIAM STEINBERG took over the New York Philharmonic yesterday, afternoon to begin 12 weeks of conducting the orchestra at Philharmonic Hall. The orchestra did not play its regular Thursday night concert because of Thanksgiving.

SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 25 (UPI) More than 30 firemen trained in detection of carbon monoxide and remained with National Guardsmen on 24hour duty today in a 10-squareblock area plagued by deadly fumes from underground mine fires.
A 39-year-old patrolman who refused to sign a waiver of immunity before a grand jury investigating a bribery conspiracy was dismissed yesterday by Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 The 7-7 outcome of last year's game could prove to be the final reckoning of tomorrow's meeting here between Army and Navy football teams whose main reliance has been upon their defence in the absence of backs of breakaway speed and passers of surpassing excellence.
ATHENS, Nov. 25 The court-martial trying 28 army officers for high treason fined two defense lawyers today for obstructing the proceedings.

HONG KONG, Nov. 25 Chairman Mao Tse-tung reviewed a rally of Red Guards in Peking today at which Liu Shao-chi, head of state, and Teng Hsiao-ping, secretary general of the Chinese Communist party, were present.
PARIS, Nov. 25 The United States proposed today that the Western industrial powers establish an aid fund aimed specifically at the food problem of underdeveloped countries.
Tommy Helms, the 25-yearold infielder for the Cincinnati Reds, was elected rookie of the year in the National League yesterday.

At Lincoln Center today: "Turandot," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P.M.: "Aida," Metropolitan Opera. 8; New York Philharmonic. Philharmonic Hall, 8:30; Late, Late Concert, with chorus, soloists and orchestra conducted by Allan Miller. Philharmonic Hall, 11:30.

JERUSALEM (Jordan), Nov. 25 Palestinian Arabs demonstrating against King Hussein of Jordan shouted "Down with the monarchy!" and "Give us arms!" in the walled city of Jerusalem today. Sporadic fire by policemen and soldiers caused 11 casualties, it was reported.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 25 (Reuters) The British Commonwealth Secretary, Herbert W. Bowden, arrived in Salisbury by plane tonight and immediately began talks with the Royal Governor, Sir Humphrey Gibbs, on the deadlocked Rhodesian crisis.

Johann Strauss's "Fledermau," will return to the Metropolitan Opera after a three-year absence New Year's Eve. It almost seems like a conspiracy of natural phenomena: Longer nights than days, different atmospheric pressure patterns aloft than at sea level and the unusual stability of the weather this week have all combined to make the noxious pollutants of metropolitan New York behave as if they were filling a giant balloon with the city caught inside.

A change in policy of the Small Business Administration, to take tangible form here on Monday, will shut off new Federal loans to some poor people seeking to open shops in ghetto areas but will pave the way for more loans elsewhere.
Although it was the day between Thanksgiving and the start of the Investment Bankers Association convention, activity in the bond market yesterday was not dull.

The stock market yesterday continued its uptrend of Wednesday. The best gains in fairly active dealings were made by the airline, motor, aerospace and a sprinkling of the glamour issues.
BERLIN, Nov. 25 (AP) East Germany said today that it had proposed to the United States, Britain and France that the postal accounts office of the wartime allies in West Berlin be closed.
The New York Knickerbockers, who have scored convincing victories over the Bullets in their two meetings this season, face Baltimore tonight at Madison Square Garden.

EXETER, N.H., Nov. 25 Miss Elizabeth Jean Wormwood was married here this afternoon to Danforth Newcomb by the Rev. Robert C. Clarke at the Exeter Unitarian Church. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Paul Nelson Wormwood of Exeter and Mr. and Mrs. Russell Newcomb of Norwich, Vt.
NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 25 (AP) A 19-day fleet exercise in the mid-Atlantic and Caribbean will begin Monday, Atlantic Fleet Headquarters announced today.

The 100th annual statement of the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, released today, showed total assets on Oct. 31, of $6.6-billion. This is an increase of 6.2 per cent above last year's total of $6.2-billion.

The marriage of Miss Ellen Linda Greene, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Harold Greene of South Orange, N. J., to Alan Edward Adelman took place here last night. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Harry Adelman, also of South Orange. Rabbi Ely R. Pilchik performed the ceremony at the Plaza.
LONDON, Nov. 27--Britain's import surcharge ends Wednesday after two years on the books. It is coming off not so much because of its effectiveness as because of its ineffectiveness.

UTRECHT, the Netherlands, Nov. 27 (AP)--The Netherlands' Roman Catholic Church opened a Pastoral Council on the Renewal and Updating of the Church today in an action growing out of the Ecumenical Council. It is Catholicism's first such pastoral council.

THE aerial circus swooped into Shea Stadium yesterday and put on another entertaining show, one that held a gath- ering of 60,318 enthralled in the tight grip of mounting excitement. Bob Fitts, the National Collegiate Athletic Association, college division, cross-country champion, easily won a Road Runners Club of New York nine-mile race yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

After almost six years of uninterrupted prosperity that has enhanced the power and the prestige of economists, the economic myths that had once seemed so enduring have lost most of their hold.

After seventeen years of vigorous rivalry, the heads of West Germany's two major parties have recommended that they join forces in the long-discussed "grand coalition." It is still too early to be sure the plan will be ratified, but the odds seem strongly in its favor.

FREDERICKSBURG, Tex., Nov. 27--Sunday morning with the President of the United States begins at church in a small central Texas community and ends in a long procession of cars wending slowly down the highway while the Secret Service impedes traffic so that Mr. Johnson can drive in pri vacy back to his ranch.

Sidewalk interviews and scenes of Times Square at dusk were transmitted live to Japan yesterday on two television programs. The programs were relayed across the Pacific by Lani Bird, a communications satellite launched two months ago.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Nov. 27--The appointment of Dr. Nell Eurich as dean of the faculty and professor of English at Vassar College was announced today. It is to take effect next July 1.
