SEATTLE, Nov. 27 (AP)-- The Boeing Company, which has been hiring rapidly, announced over the weekend it would slow down its personnel build-up and cut costs.
LISBON, Nov. 27--Luis de Sttau Monteiro, considered Portugal's leading playwright, has been arrested and his latest work seized, it was learned here today.

MOSCOW, Nov. 27--Dean Reed, a young American singer, was cheered and applauded for 25 minutes this afternoon in Moscow's Variety Theater after a spirited performance in which the audience joined in to sing and clap to rock 'n' roll music.

DALLAS, Nov. 26 (AP)-- John Rosenfield Jr., drama and music critic for The Dallas Morning News for 41 years, died at his home today. Mr. Rosenfield, who retired from his post June 11, had been ill since suffering a heart attack last year. He was 66 years old.
WETUMPKA, Ala. Nov. 27 (UPI)--James Earl Motley, a 27-year-old Negro who died mysteriously in the county jail last weekend, was buried today.

ROME, Nov. 27--A recently reunified Socialist party faces its first test at the polls today and tomorrow as 1.5 million people cast their ballots in more than 300 local and provincial elections throughout the nation.

SHORT HILLS, N. J., Nov. 27--Herbert M. Perlmutter, a co-founder in 1948 and operator of Perlmutter Brothers, Inc., meat wholesalers, in Newark, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at 50 Farmstead Road. His age was 58.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 (AP)--A Swarthmore, Pa., minister who was asked to resign, primarily because of his civil rights activities, said today that pressure had been applied on him in terms of money-- pledges from church members.
"They want everything right now. They don't have any utopia. How do you communicate with students to whom nothing counts but the experience of the moment?
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 27--New York experts continued to dominate the Reisinger open team championship, which continued here this afternoon.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 27 (AP)--Herb Adderley's interception of a pass by Fran Tarkenton crushed Minnesota's bid for a victory in the final two minutes as the Green Bay Packers defeated the Vikings today, 28-16.

As he does on the morning of each fight, Gabriel (Flash) Elorde will serve at a special Roman Catholic mass today, about 13 hours before challenging Carlos Ortiz for the world lightweight boxing title at Madison Square Garden.

DENVER, Nov. 27 (AP)-- Alan Swallow, who doffed the robes of academe 16 years ago to become "one of the biggest little publishing houses in America," died today, apparently of a heart attack. His age was 51.
New orders for machine tools dropped by 2 per cent in October from the high level of the month before but continued to run well above the 1965 level.

In a professional football game packed with good passing, better pass catching, elusive running, spectacular kickoff returns, jarring tackling, fights, a pulsating last-quarter rally and a confusing last-minute play that killed the rally, the Kansas City Chiefs beat the New York Jets yesterday, 32-24, at Shea Stadium.
"QUIET back there. I see that I'll have to sepa rate you," said the instructor in hair coloring to a giggling boy and girl in the last row of her class at the Wilfred Academy one day recently.

A rate war among transAtlantic passenger airlines gained momentum yesterday when Air Canada announced it would offer "the lowest fares ever proposed by any airline for travel on trans-Atlantic routes during 1967."

GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Nov. 21--The euphoria of six months ago here has vanished with the flags and gay lights that brightened the dilapidated wooden buildings of this capital at the time British Guiana became independent Guyana.
John H. Conroy, a corporation lawyer and former Democratic member of the New York State Assembly, died yesterday in the Memorial Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 617 West End Avenue.
Unless $300,000 is raised by Dec. 10, the 33-year-old Pittsburgh Playhouse, which operates three theaters under one roof, will close.

ATHENS, Nov. 27--Greece's Communists made charges this weekend of "high treason" against a former conservative Premier, Constantine Caramanlis, and nine generals, saying they had plotted to rig elections in favor of the right wing.

CAIRO, Nov. 27--"I have never been an anti-Sem ite; I am a Semite myself," Ahmad Asaad Shukairy observed yesterday in a mellow bass voice that resounded through the marble-floored villa that houses his headquarters here.

MADISON TOWNSHIP, N. J., Nov. 27--Three masked men with guns held three priests in the rectory of St. Bernadette's Roman Catholic Church early today and got away with $1,000 from the rectory safe. One of the bandits pistolwhipped the pastor of the church, the Rev. Thomas O'Dea.
CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (AP)-- Gale Sayers streaked through the mud and the rain in guiding the Chicago Bears to a 23-6 victory over the Atlanta Falcons today in a National Football League game.
New York Photoengravers Union No. 1-P and the Photoengravers Board of Trade of New York have agreed on a new three-year contract providing for wage increases ranging from $19 to $20.91 a week.
As the last of the throngs of holiday travelers scurried into or out of the city yesterday, an obviously confused man in Pennsylvania Station asked aloud of nobody in particular:

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 27--Late returns in the Uruguayan election today indicated that the left-of-center Colorado party would return to power after eight years of rule by the conservative Blanco party.
CHICAGO, Nov. 27--Dr. Morris Teller, rabbi emeritus of the South Side Hebrew Congregation, died of a heart attack yesterday as he entered his home after attending services. He was 76 years old.

Annunzio Paolo Mantovani, the Italian-born, British-bred conductor who has parlayed lush harmonies and cascading strings into a million-dollar musical empire, held court last night at Philharmonic Hall.

With the 51-0 slaughter of Southern California's Rose Bowl-bound Trojans by Notre Dame, the marring of Nebraska's perfect record by Oklahoma 48 seconds before the end of the game, and the highly sentimental 20-7 triumph scored by the Army cadets over Navy for their new coach before 100,000 at Philadelphia, the curtain has come down on the intercollegiate football season.

There has been so much talk about tight money that many people undoubtedly feel they must keep tight reins on their Christmas spending on the grounds that they cannot get the money they need or that they will have to pay too much for the privilege of borrowing.

LONDON, Nov. 27--Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, said today that the recent growth of what he called neo-Nazis in Germany was "not too dangerous now" but represented a potential danger to the world in the future.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, minister emeritus of Christ Church, Methodist, returned to his former pulpit at Park Avenue and 60th Street yesterday and warned worshippers that Christianity was in as much danger today as it was in the first three years of its existence.
Shipments of bulk cargoes of iron ore, coal and grain on the Great Lakes continued at a high level last month, the Lake Carriers' Association reported yesterday.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 28-- Professional baseball got down to business today when 14 major league clubs drafted 23 players from 13 other clubs.

The Equity Theater is offering this season, besides its fully staged "showcase" productions at the Master Theater on Riverside Drive, a series of "informals" at the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts in Lincoln Center.
William C. Mattison, the City Commissioner of Public Works, died last night of a heart attack as he was attending a dinner of the Association of General Contractors of America at the Waldorf-Astoria.
Attorneys for the Metropolitan Opera and the members of its orchestra agreed yesterday on a schedule of meetings to put the tentative labor agreement between the two parties in final form.
FINALLY someone has got around to telling us what England's angry young men are so angry about. They are angry because they are impotent, or at least pathologically shy. I'd rather not have known.
Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts announced yesterday two measures for dealing with its postperformance traffic problems.
The Federal Reserve, in a move that caught Wall Street by surprise, pumped an estimated $500-million into the money market during a brief period around noon yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28--In New York it would be easy to overlook the Harper Dance Festival. Indeed, in Chicago it would be easy to overlook the Harper Dance Festival-- which is the more unfortunate as it actually takes place in Chicago.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 28-- As the minor leagues were announcing their 1967 schedules today, the Baltimore Orioles had new of monetary significance for their fans--ticket prices will be higher next season.

ALBANY, Nov. 28 (AP)--Dr. Paul Dudley White of Boston, the heart specialist who treated President Dwight D. Eisenhower, and Dr. Michael E. De Bakey of Houston will help the state set up its projected institute for heart research.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 28--Premier Jens Otto Brag dropped Foreign Minister Per Haekkerup from his Cabinet today and took the post himself.
BUJUMBURA, Burundi, Tuesday, Nov. 29--Premier Michel Micombero of Burundi has announced the overthrow of Mwame, or King, Ntare V by a military coup and has declared a republic here.

Garry Moore, whose television show will be dropped Jan. 8 by the Columbia Broadcasting System, said yesterday he would ask the network to release him from a personal contract that still has eight years to run. The contract guarantees him $100,000 annually even if he does not work.
PARIS, Nov. 19--"Nobody is surprised here because I am black," said Edward Barnett, when asked why he preferred to live here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28-- Following is the text of a letter, dated Dec. 21, 1964, from Gov. George Romney of Michigan to Barry Goldwater, who had been defeated six weeks before in his campaign for the Presidency:

PARSIPPANY, N.J., Nov. 28 (AP)--James J. Welsh, a former Army helicopter pilot who had survived 360 hours of combat missions in Vietnam, was killed today when his small foreign sports car smashed into a tree.

A court order was issued yesterday to the city's 53 deputy sheriffs; "without further process, take the body of Adam Clayton Powell, the defendant judgment debtor, and commit him to the Civil Jail...."
HILLSBOROUGH, Calif.-- "This is more than a home, this is a business," said Mrs. Harry Lillis Crosby, sitting in a Louis XV chair in the formal drawing room of her home here.
The charges on which District Court Judge Floyd Sarisohn of Suffolk County faces removal include "misconduct involving moral turpitude," it was disclosed yesterday.

Fiction prize contests continue to have troubles. For the second time since the Harper Prize Novel contest was established in 1923, the judges have voted to make no award. In June the Dell Publishing Company announced that judges Louis Auchincloss, Gore Vidal and Jean Stafford had voted against any award in its $10,000 Delta Prize Novel contest.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 28--Msgr. Joseph A. Smith, pastor of the Church of St. Thomas the Apostle and a Roman Catholic priest for 53 years, died in the rectory of the church here today. He was 77 years old.
RICHMOND, Nov. 28--The Virginia Supreme Court of Appeals ruled today that the state's poll tax, though no longer necessary as a condition for voting, could still be collected as a capitation tax.

The Kennedy Round of negotiations to liberalize world trade is continuing to lag seriously behind schedule. The participants were supposed to present their positions on major products by Nov. 30; but the six nations of the Common Market, which bargain collectively, have not yet been able to reach agreement on agricultural commodities. So the negotiations are stalled once again while the Six attempts to find common ground.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UPI)--Rosel H. Hyde, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, predicted today that the development of educational television would force the major networks to revise and perhaps improve evening programs.

AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 28--Premier Wasfi al-Tall said today that "considerable amounts" of money had been paid by "two outside Arab sources" to hire demonstrators for anti-Government disturbances in Jordan.

VENICE, Nov. 27--Three weeks after its worst inundation in more than a thousand years, the beautiful and exotic city of Venice has recovered so completely that a visitor must look hard to find evidence of the Nov. 4 flood.

A shareholder of the DWG Cigar Corporation has filed a complaint in United States District Court here seeking to enjoin the company, its principal shareholder and others from holding a special meeting tomorrow.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 28--This was the day of George Corley Wallace's return to the beautiful old Alabama State Capitol where Jefferson Davis took the oath of office as President of the Confederacy and above which the Stars and Bars still were rippling in brilliant sunshine and a stiff breeze.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28-- The Food and Drug Administration described as "intolerable" today the number of faulty drug products reaching the market because of poor manufacturing practices.

The Maritime Administration announced yesterday the allocation of 15 C-4 type of troop ships, now in reserve fleets, to eight unsubsidized American ship lines. The vessels are to be converted by the eight lines at their own expense to meet commercial and national defense requirements.
Heightened optimism for a settlement of the Rhodesian crisis caused a firming trend in all sectors on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
Four retail merchandisers rang up record sales in the three and nine months ended with October, with profits also well ahead of last year.

Ernie Cardone, the 22-yearold apprentice jockey from the Bronx, increases his lead among the riders at Aqueduct yesterday by steering home four winners. In recording his successes the popular rider thrilled the crowd of 21,629 by booting home three in a row.

TRUMAN CAPOTE, still stunned by the number of prominent people who begged him to invite them to what he insisted upon calling his "little masked ball for Kay Graham and all my friends," finally gave his much-discussed Black and White Dance at The Plaza last night, and it lived up to nearly all of its extravagant advance notices.

"The very existence of the U.S.O. epitomizes for our service personnel the widespread interest of the American people. For, without their financial assistance, the U.S.O. would long since have disappeared, and the serviceman's aloneness would have grown into an anguished awareness that no one is interested.
An insect-destroying chemical substance discovered last year in the newsprint used by various American newspapers has been identified by a team of scientists.
DJERBA, Tunisia, Nov. 28-- President Habib Bourguiba paid a visit today to the synagogue on the island of Djerba, one of the oldest in the world.
The spot rate on the British pound continued weak in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday, closing at $2.7903, off 1 point from Friday's close.
The Admiral Corporation has lowered its "fair-trade" prices on 18 color television models in the New York metropolitan area, a spokesman for the company said yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 28--Prime Minister Wilson paused today at the brink of a tough new policy toward the white minority regime in Rhodesia.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 28 --Louis E. Weed, former president and chairman of the board of the East Brooklyn Savings Bank, died Saturday in his home in Chatsworth Gardens. He was 75 years old.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 28 (UPI)--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that birth control information should be made easily accessible "so that every family may decide for itself, wisely and freely, the course it chooses to take."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP)--The members of the European Space Research Organization are about to set up a tracking station in Alaska.

President Johnson's decision to interrupt American grain shipments to India in mid-December, just as famine threatens and critical elections approach, is a serious error. But there is still time to limit the damage.

The National Football Foundation's eight-member awards committee is as undecided as most fans about which college team is the best in the nation this season. Therefore the committee decided yesterday to award the MacArthur Bowl, the Foundation's trophy that annually goes to its selection as the outstanding college football team in the country, to both Michigan State and Notre Dame.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28-- The United States and South Vietnamese Governments are expected to announce in a "day or so" their formal approval of brief halts in the fighting on the Christmas and New Year's holidays.
Leo Mulford Blancke, a partner in Hornblower WeeksHemphill, Noyes, stockbrokers, died Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Essex Falls, N.J.
GENEVA, Nov. 28--An Israeli mental health expert criticized the medical profession today as being "immune to the need for acceptance of psychiatric principles and understanding."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28--The United States raised its diplomatic relations with Hungary and Bulgaria to the ambassadorial level today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. T., Nov. 28--Italy believes that a report on Communist China's attitudes toward the United Nations and compliance with its charter can be made available to the General Asaembly by next July.
Three alleged Mafia leaders, two of them jailed for contempt, have agreed to testify before a Federal rackets grand jury under a grant of immunity.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 28 --To a bettor, a horse race is a personal thing, evoking strong visceral reaction. But bad weather, of the kind that Roosevelt Raceway had tonight, makes horse-players huddle together, seeking a type of common warmth.

The election of Richard L. Allen, Robert H. Cornwell and John C. Bierwirth as directors was announced here yesterday by the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation. The elections raise the number of directors to 18.
WAUKESHA, Wis., Nov. 28 (UPI)--Without a license, I don't have my car, job or social life. So I think that it is better to end it all right now."

The nation's second largest food chain, Safeway Stores, Inc., Oakland, Calif., which is credited with having triggered the rash of supermarket games with its bonus bingo, will be out of the game business by the first of February.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28--Albert J. Raby, Chicago Negro civil rights leader, was sentenced today to three months in jail and fined $500 on charges of resisting arrest and disorderly conduct in connection with a demonstration at City Hall last year.
WHEN new classrooms were not ready last year in time for the opening of school, Dr. Dumont Francis Kenny had a quick solution that involved an unusual method of "busing" students.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 28--A United States Air Force pilot described today how he safely crash-landed his flaming transport on a narrow runway lined with mines on Saturday.
IN 1963 the New York Giants had the second highest scoring team in the history of the National Football League. With Yelberton Abraham Tittle at the controls, it struck swiftly and well.
The Board of Examiners of the city school system accused the Board of Education yesterday of "scandalous" practices in creating and filling "hundreds of thousands of dollars" worth of new jobs.
LONDON, Nov. 28--An early 15th-century porcelain Ming flask, one of three known to bein existence, was sold here today for the equivalent of $70,560 at Christie's.

A City Council-approved bill became law last week without the signature of Mayor Lindsay, it became known yesterday. David Ross, Democratic majority leader of the City Council, said it was the first time in the Council's history that this had happened.

In a fight without pattern or purpose or very much action, Carlos Ortiz retained his world lightweight title at Madison Square Garden last night. He was credited with knocking out Gabriel (Flash) Elorde after 2 minutes and 1 second of the 14th round, but it was too many punches in too many rounds in too many cities of the world that drove the Filipino to the canvas.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 28 (AP)--Clift Richey of Dallas, a 19-year-old United States Davis Cup player, turned up with a suspected case of German measles today and may be forced to withdraw from the Victorian tennis championships.
ATLANTA, Nov. 28 (UPI)-- Two Atlanta lawyers filed suit today in Fulton Superior Court to force Secretary of State Ben W. Fortson to call a special election in the deadlocked gubernatorial race.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28--A jury of five women and seven men was selected in Criminal Court this afternoon to determine whether Richard F. Speck is mentally competent to be tried for murder in the mass slaying of eight student nurses last ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28-- Political analysts agree that Gov. George Romney would make a good Presidential candidate if he knew something about foreign affairs and something about domestic affairs. This is like saying that Rock Hudson would make a good surgeon if he knew something about surgery.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 28-- A plan to reapportion the Westchester Board of Supervisors was vetoed today by County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian as unworkable, unfair and probably illegal.
BUDAPEST, Nov. 28--Janos Kadar, the Hungarian leader, declared today that his party favored a large conference of like-minded Communist parties to discuss China's anti-Soviet policy.

NEWTON, Mass., Nov. 28-- The engagement of Miss Barbara Bonney Larsen to Richard Kimball Lincoln has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. George H. Larsen, parents of the prospective bride. Mr. Lincoln is the son of Mrs. Carl K. Lincoln of Nonquitt and the late Mr. Lincoln.
THE New York Giants have a new quarterback in mind for next year and Steve Spurrier, a likely candidate, has money on his mind.
BONN, Nov. 28--Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin defended today his decision, on behalf of the Social Democratic party, to enter a coalition headed by Kurt George Kiesinger.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28-- The Eisenhowers and the Roosevelts, the Clevelands, the Tafts, the Harrisons and the Grants, hobnobbed today in an extraordinary homecoming for former tenants of the White House.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) --The Air Transport Association has prepared a "priority listing" of more than 30 airports where it would like to see runways grooved for safer landings in wet weather.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28-- Yields on new Treasury bills declined to their lowest levels since late summer, the Treasury announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28--A top official of the American Bankers Association called today for the banking industry to get together with its competitors to work out ...
"Caddies won't be forgotten in Westchester County," said James D. Hoagg shortly after he was re-elected president of the Westchester County Golf Association last night.

Dry weather in the Southwest, where the winter wheat is getting a start, impelled higher futures prices yesterday. Wheat traders talked of parched fields in the area, and the weather bureau forecast little, if any, rain there for at least four or five days.
Labor leaders called yesterday for replacement of the state's Condon-Wadlin Act with a law that would insure collective-bargaining rights for govvernment employes without any prohibition on strikes.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 28 (AP)--A 230-pound middle guard, Elam (Lee) Hitchner of Moorestown, N. J., was elected captain today of next year's Princeton University football team.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 28 (UPI)--The Justice Department his completed its investigation of the heavyweight champion, Cassius Clay, and paved the way for the Kentucky Selective Service Appeals Board to act on his draft deferment requests this week, officials said today.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 28-- Sixty Kenyans who arrived on a lake Victoria steamer at Kisumu yesterday said they were victims of a purge of foreigners in Mwanza, Tanzanian port at the southern end of the lake.

A $68-million program to rebuild the Brooklyn-Cumberland Medical Center as a 1,675bed institution, twice its present size, was announced yesterday. Construction is expected to be completed by the end of 1972.

ACWORTH, N.H., Nov. 28-- Dr. George S. Amsden, who retired in 1935 as psychiatrist in chief of New York Hospital and professor of psychiatry at Cornell University Medical College, died yesterday in Rockingham Hospital, Bellows Falls, Vt. He was 96 years old and had practiced psychiatry here until two years ago.
The long-awaited Lindsay bill proposing an across-theboard reorganization of city government structure will be filed in the City Council Thursday.
MADISON, Wis., Nov. 28 (UPI)--The Wisconsin Athletic Board interviewed nine applicants tonight for the vacant post of head football coach.

TAKE five young designers; add a large dose of Persian lamb; throw in $2,500 in prize money for seasoning, and what emerges is young, snappy fur design. The ideas of recent graduates of the Parsons School of Design were translated into fact by Fred Gompertz of Fur and Sport.

PARIS, Nov. 28--Don Juan de Borbon y Battenberg, the pretender to Spain's throne and head of the Spanish Royal House, is represented as not planning under any circumstances to renounce his succession rights in favor of any candidate who may be selected by Generalissimo Francisco Franco or the Cortes (Parliament).
Vittorio Giannini, composer and music educator, was found dead in his Manhattan apartment at noon yesterday. He was 63 years old.
Local service air carriers-- the recipients of the bulk of Federal aid to airlines--should soon be able to get along with much less Federal subsidy, in the opinion of the Civil Aeronautics Board.

Judge Harry Serper of Criminal Court, a former first deputy commissioner of the Department of Sanitation, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at 3766 Surf Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 63 years old.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 28 --A strike of 400 pilots, which has grounded the worldwide fleet of 23 jets operated by Qantas Empire Airways, seemed deadlocked tighter than ever tonight. The walkout against Australia's Government-owned airline began Thursday.
The City Commissioner of Licenses warned yesterday that parking-lot and garage operators who left customers' cars parked at the curb faced fines and possible suspension of their licenses.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28-- The Government, in a move to bolster the depressed housing industry, pledged itself today to finance indirectly the mortgages of some 15,000 new houses of low and moderate prices.
Through almost 14 rounds, Carlos Ortiz slammed and swatted at Gabriel (Flash) Elorde last night. But the moments Ortiz will remember are the ones after Elorde had gone sprawling on his back.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28-- The National Traffic Safety Agency has been notified of potential steering assembly defects in two more late-model vehicles manufactured by the Ford Company and the International Harvester Company.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 28-- Samuel H. Sheppard was ordered today to appear before the Cuyahoga County grand jury next Friday in what may be the start of a new inquiry into the murder of his first wife.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 28 (AP) --The fourth of the Aranson quintuplets died today, and doctors expressed hope the survivor would live.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 28-- A group of Negro residents of New Cassel complained bitterly today that the community was being spoiled because it had too few policemen and too many welfare clients.

The Rev. Dr. Charles S. MacKenzie, who became pastor of the Broadway Presbyterian Church after its controversy with the Presbytery of New York, has resigned to accept a call from a congregation in San Mateo, Calif.

BOSTON, Nov. 28 (AP)-- Daniel A. Benson of Marblehead, former president of the Boston Maine Railroad, and Henry Mersey of New Haven, president of the International Railway Equipment Corporation surrendered to Federal marshals today to begin 18-month prison terms.
SYDNEY, Nov. 28--Australia's middle-of-the-road LiberalCountry party coalition continued to gain seats as votecounting after Saturday's parliamentary elections entered the final stages today.
BEN CASEY and his television colleagues notwithstanding, the day of the bache- lor interne seems to be on the wane.

TRENTON, Nov. 28--The State Senate reconvened today after a two-month recess and promptly pushed Gov. Richard J. Hughes' controversial proposal to reorganize public higher education in line for a vote next week.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 28--Uruguayan voters yesterday replaced their Swissstyle rotating presidential system with a one-man chief executive and elected a retired air force general, Oscar Daniel Gestido, to the new post.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 28--The highest-ranking enemy soldier to defect to allied forces said today that the Vietcong insurgency in South Vietnam would collapse if North Vietnamese support were withdrawn.

The Right Rev. James A. Pike, Retired Episcopal Bishop of California, called on his fellow churchmen yesterday to acknowledge that there are "lots of questions about religion where no absolute answers are possible."
Ogden Phipps's Buckpasser was acclaimed yesterday as the champion thoroughbred of the year by the Thoroughbred Racing Association.

Syracuse, which bounced back from resounding defeats in its first two games and finished with an eight-game winning streak, won the Lambert Trophy yesterday as the outstanding Eastern major-college football team. It marked the fourth time that Syracuse, under Coach Ben Schwartzwalder, had won the award.

Richard M. Nixon put politics aside yesterday to preside at ribbon-cutting ceremony marking the dedication of a memorial hall to the late President Herbert Hoover at the national headquarters of the Boys Clubs of America.

PARIS, Nov. 28--Gen Zinovi Pechkoff, who rose to high rank in the French military and diplomatic service and was a son of Maxim Gorky, the Russian novelist, died today at the American Hospital in suburban Neuilly. He was 82 years old.
The limited partners of Ira Haupt Co. opposed yesterday a proposed settlement between the bankrupt brokerage firm and the American Express Company as "inadequate."
It was a gray, wet day on Wall Street yesterday and the stock market went through a session that was about as soggy as the weather.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 28 --The sale of Juan Pizarro to the Pittsburgh Pirates by the Chicago White Sox was the principal transaction made public, today as the major-league player market remained surprisingly sluggish.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28-- Major labor contracts negotiated in the first nine months of 1966 provided for a median wage increase of 3.8 per cent a year, or about 11.5 cents an hour, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

The Uruguayan people have again lived up to their high reputation for political maturity and liberty. In a remarkable general election they turned out in great numbers; voted to change the executive branch of their Government from the cumbersome Swiss-type National Council to a President; picked an entirely new Senate and Chamber of Deputies and filled all local government posts. It was an election that made New York State's seem simple.
HONG KONG, Nov. 28--China called the readers of the Soviet Union today a "group of renegades" and predicted that they would eventually be overthrown.
FORT NORTH, Nov. 28 (AP) --Fred Taylor succeeded Abe Martin today as head football coach at Texas Christian University.
Not content with dotting the country with 1,063 orange roofs, the Howard Johnson Company has popped into the soft-drink business.
CHEMICAL stocks, the favorite of Wall Street for years, have fallen on hard times, even when compared with the rest of the stocks rolled and scraped in the bear market.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 28 (UPI)--Five young men, arrested yesterday for starting a fight by shouting "Heil Hitler" in a predominantly Jewish neighborhood, will be arraigned tomorrow in Municipal Court on charges of assault with a deadly weapon.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 28 --The head of the nation's investment bankers made a fighting plea here today for the Federal Government not to squeeze the profit margins of securities concerns.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 28 --The Social Democratic party of Premier Rafael Paasio ended a three-day congress today with a conciliatory gesture toward Moscow, but it made no sweep ing changes in its executive committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UPI)--Harold Howe 2d, United States Commissioner of Education, said today the Government was not seeking to require busing of school children to achieve racial balance in schools.

SEATTLE, Nov. 28--This growing metropolis of the Pacific Northwest, which sets the cultural tone for a vast region that includes Alaska, takes proper pride in the energy and diversity of its activities and is sensitive about being patronized.

MONTREAL, Nov. 28 (UPI) --Air Canada's 5,200 mechanics, ramp and station personnel returned to work today to prepare planes for full resumption of service after settlement of the Government-owned airline's first strike in its 29-year history.
BRASILIA, Nov. 28--Lucio Acauto Cardoso resigned today as president of the Chamber of Deputies in protest against the suspension of the political rights of six Deputies last month.

DETROIT, Nov. 28--Virgil E. Boyd, a fast-paced executive who played a major role in the revival of the Chrysler Corporation, will be named president of the company this week, informed sources said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28-- A Chamber of Commerce official said today that "irresponsible" labor union action was sweeping away the Negro job opportunities that grew out of civil rights demonstrations here in 1964.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP)--The Embassy of the United Arab Republic strongly objected today to news reports that alleged that the Egyptian Government had "seized" a Ford assembly plant in Alexandria.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Nov. 28 --College basketball coaches who may be mourning over the lack of experience, height and depth on their squads this season may derive a little cheer from the problems confronting Coach John Sipos at the United States Merchant Marine Academy.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 28--A fornier commander of the Indonesian air force, Vice Marshal Omar Dhani, will go on trial here Wednesday on charges of complicity in an attempt by Communists last year to seize power, Government spokesmen announced today.
PARIS, Nov. 28--Irene Monesi, a mother of three, won the Prix Femina today for her novel about tensions within a family, "Nature Morte a la Fenetre" ("Still Life from a Window").
LONDON, Nov. 28--Lord Moran, Sir Winston Churchill's personal physician and author of a controversial book on the statesman, sued the British Medical Association for libel today.

It was the season's seventh "Faust" at the Metropolitan Opera last night. Where a tired performance might have been expected, a radiant one turned up, thanks to a cast of gifted, personable young Americans with beautiful fresh voices.
VIENNA, Nov. 28--Albania has charged that the Soviet Union has stopped jamming broadcasts by the Voice of America and is jamming Albanian broadcasts instead.

Frank D. Gilroy, winner of the Pulitzer, Critics Circle and Tony prizes for his first Broadway play, "The Subject Was Roses," has written "That Summer--That Fall." The drama is due here Feb. 28 at a house not booked yet.
The election of J. Frank Belford, president of Seaboard Shipping Corporation, as president of the New York State Waterways Association has been announced.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28--A House Republican leader, Representative Melvin R. Laird of Wisconsin, said today his party would seek enactment next year of automatic cost of living increases in Social Security benefits.

ROME, Tuesday, Nov. 29-- The newly reunified Socialist party failed to make a significant showing in its first test at the polls in local elections Sunday and yesterday, incomplete returns indicated today.
The Board of Higher Education asked the city last night to make the Bellevue School of Nursing part of Hunter College.
LONDON, Nov. 28--A London magistrate ruled today that pictures by Jim Dine, the American pop artist, while "individually not indecent, became an indecent exhibition" by reason of their arrangement.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended with losses yesterday in active trading despite some late buying which pared earlier declines.
LONDON, Nov. 28--Many an Englishman wondered, as he pulled the cork from his bottle of dinner wine tonight, what was really inside.
Donald H. Elliott took the oath of office as chairman of the City Planning Commission yesterday and called for imaginative city redevelopment.
The Composers' Showcase began its 10th season with a pleasant and diversified concert last night at the Eisner and Lubin Auditorium of New York University.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 28--The final day of play in the Reisinger team event, concluding the American Contract Bridge League's fall national championships, began this afternoon with 24 New York stars in contention.

Wallace K. Harrison, one of the designers of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, agreed yesterday to fix a leaking pool at the Center and to erect handrails at the Metropolitan Opera House. The leak is in the reflecting pool in the North Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP)--The Internal Revenue Service announced today that commissioned officers serving in Vietnam could now exclude up to $500 of their monthly pay from income taxes. The previous limit was $200.

AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 18-- The Government is acting to persuade Bedouin tribesmen to forsake their romantic but uneconomic wanderings by providing them with homey hamlets and teaching them how to raise chickens, hay, vegetables and sunflowers.
Hospitals Commissioner Joseph V. Terenzio announced yesterday that last week's heavy air pollution almost certainly had no significant effect on the health of New Yorkers.
THEY rolled off the assembly line yesterday like dolls, newly painted and freshly coiffed, packaged in silk, satin and jewels and addressed to Truman Capote, the Plaza Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28-- After the Presidential election of 1964, Gov. George Romney wrote a 12-page letter to Barry Goldwater saying he had not supported the national Republican ticket because the Goldwater campaign had had, by design, a "Southern-rural-white orientation."

The Broad Street Investing Corporation announced yesterday it had acquired the assets of the Atlantic Securities Corporation, a Delaware mutual fund with assets of $40,134,000. Broad Street issued 2,768,986 of its shares free of sales charge in payment.
The Chase Manhattan Bank and the First National City Bank each announced yesterday the election of new senior vice presidents.

MARQUETTE, Mich., Nov. 28 (UPI)--The most paralyzing storm in 10 years buffeted the upper Great Lakes region today, stacking snow drifts seven feet high, stranding nearly 1,000 travelers and leaving thousands of homes without power.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28-- The index of primary market prices remained unchanged at 105.8 during the week ended Nov. 22, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and industrial commodities advanced in price, but processed foods declined.

Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism and East Asian Institute announced yesterday a joint program to develop foreign correspondents for China and Japan. They will be trained in journalism and the languages and cultures of the countries.

The value of residential building contracts throughout the country in October declined 35 per cent from October, 1965, making the total value of all contracts for future construction 6 per cent lower than it was a year ago. The total value was estimated at $4,106,093,000.
BONN, Nov. 28--The United States, Britain and West Germany opened the third round of their talks on defense and financial problems here today with little prospect of immediate agreement.
PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 28 (AP)--A robber armed with a dagger was thwarted in his attempt to rob a gasoline station here yesterday by a wooden crate bearing the sign: "Beware of the mongoose."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28-- The National Catholic Reporter has concluded that the statement of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops on the Government's role in family planning "has to be described as a disaster." The bishops' statement charged that welfare recipients were coerced to accept birth control or lose their benefits.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 28-- India's Foreign Minister said today that Reita Faria, Miss World, had shown "patriotism" by canceling plans to entertain American troops in Vietnam this Christmas.
GLASGOW, Scotland, Nov. 28 (AP)--Glasgow University announced today it was undertaking a three-year study on the possible hazards of carbon 14, a product of nuclear fission.

An auction of paintings and sculpture last night for the benefit of WNDT realized $76,775, according to officials of the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, where the auction was held. The auction was televised over Channel 13.

ALBANY, Nov. 28--Governor Rockefeller said today that he had ordered "a full investigation" into the case of a 4 year-old blond girl whose adoption by a brunette ItalianAmerican foster couple has been contested.

PARIS--The room in which Napoleon married Josephine while her former lovers looked on is preserved in authentic Louis XV style and is so steeped in tradition it is classified a historic monument. Paradoxically, it is also the source of some of the most creative and forward-looking thinking in French banking today.
The contractors' segment of New York's coat and suit industry is seeking to diversify production to include other items of apparel. To do this, it will be necessary for the ...
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 28 (AP)-- A member of the Jehovah's Witnesses church was sentenced to five years in prison today for refusing to report for civilian medical duty in lieu of military service.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 28 (AP)--The creation of volunteer medical groups to fight disease in slum districts and areas of racial violence was proposed today by the president of the American Medical Association.
SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 28 (AP) --The Rev. Joseph A. Sweeney, known in China and Korea as "the lepers' father," died yesterday of a gastric ulcer. He was 71 years old.
TORONTO, Nov. 28--The Canadian Government offered another high yield of 5.94 per cent on long-term bonds today but left some economists uncertain as to the significance for the market.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he had urged the state to allow the city Welfare Department to give birth-control information to welfare clients even if they did not ask for it.
Russell W. McFall, president and chief executive officer of the Western Union Telegraph Company, was elected yesterday to the additional post of chairman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28-- Sponsors of a Mississippi Head Start project that has been denied further antipoverty funds have replied to nine conditions laid down by the Office of Economic Opportunity, but the office considers the reply unsatisfactory.

The just-announced increase in penalties for drivers who tailgate and who fail to yield the right of way or signal a turn should strengthen the New York Department of Motor Vehicles' efforts to weed out incompetent drivers.

Sidney Alexander Mitchell, a banker, who served several Government agencies and many philanthropic organizations, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 36 East 72d Street and Locust Valley, L.I.

ALBANY, Nov. 28--Dr. William J. Ronan, secretary to Governor Rockefeller since 1959, is planning to resign soon, sources in Mr. Rockefeller's office said today. He will be succeeded by Alton G. Marshall, an excutive assistant to the Governor, the sources said.
RIO GRANDE CITY, Tex., Nov. 28 (AP)--Federal officials denied today that they were involved in any way in the investigation of the Rio Grande Valley farm workers' strike.
ATLANTA, Nov. 28 (UPI) --Herbert Caudill, a Baptist missionary jailed in Cuba last year after being accused of spying, has been freed from prison to get medical help for his failing eyesight.

Prices of United States Treasury bills rose sharply yesterday, spurred by heavy purchases by the Federal Reserve System. The gains, which reduced yields on the short-term securities by 10 to 15 basis points, were the largest for one day "in many a month," one trader said.
General Mills, Inc., whose breakfast food is consumed by many youngsters, is planning to bring them a broad line of educated toys, games and puzzles.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 28--A proposal to prohibit the use of nuclear weapons under a legally binding convention was shelved today.
FRAKES, Ky., Nov. 28 (AP) --Winter brings isolation for a small group of Kentuckians who live in Whitley County's southeast corner near Frakes.

"Social Register New York 1967" made its debut yesterday, a black-bound volume listing approximately 25,000 names of persons found acceptable by the Social Register Association. The 81st annual edition is slightly larger than last year's, with 1,051 pages as against 1,037.
"We attracted people to the health talks two ways--with free milk, and Walt Disney movies. Between Donald Duck and the milk we got a lot of Nicaraguans."

DETROIT, Nov. 28 (AP)-- Auto plants in the United States resumed production today after a Thanksgiving holiday interruption, with indications that November output would total about 835,000 cars, about 65,000 below originally planned schedules.

AURORA, Ill., Nov. 28--Mr. and Mrs. Mydrim Miles Evans have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gayle Frances Evans, to Samuel Lord Brookfield Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brookfield of Rye, N.Y. A winter wedding is planned.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (AP)-- Traffic deaths reached a new peak for holidays when 747 persons were killed during the long Thanksgiving weekend on the nation's streets and highways.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 23 (UPI)--Public school teachers went back to work here today, ending a week-long walkout. A similar strike by teachers in nearby Hubbard was settled tonight.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 --Mayor James H. J. Tate rejected today an offer by the city council to give him a $10,000 raise.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 28 (AP)--United States and North Vietnamese troops exchanged artillery and mortar fire in flurries of fighting in the Central Highlands near the Cambodian border today while allied forces reported 529 Vietcong slain in 19 days of a coastal operation.
In an apparently senseless shooting, an assailant in a car killed a woman and wounded her companion last night as the couple drove from Brooklyn to Staten Island over the Verrazano Bridge.

SAIGON, South Vietnam (UPI)--South Vietnamese gunboats have started escorting all foreign ships traveling the Mekong River to Cambodia to stop the smuggling of guns and ammunition to the Vietcong, it was learned today.
TOM CAHILL, the rookie head coach of Army, re ceived an endorsement yesterday from Joe Scanella, the Coach of C. W. Post College, as a candidate for college football coach of the year.

Manhattan Borough President Percy E. Sutton yesterday joined the critics of a new policy in the Small Business Administration that will deny Federal loans to some poor people who want to open shops in ghetto areas. The policy will pave the way for more loans in other areas.

DALLAS, Nov. 28 (AP)-- Curtis Cokes used superior height and reach to gain a unanimous decision over Jean Josselin, the rugged Frenchman, in 15 blistering rounds tonight and retained his world welterweight championship.
J.P. Stevens Co., the textile concern, announced yesterday record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended Oct. 29.

A new division alignment of the 16-team National Football League for next season was forecast here yesterday by Pete Rozelle, the newly designated commissioner of both profesisional football leagues, National and American.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP)--The New York Central Railroad challenged the Interstate Commerce Commission today, and told the agency it lacked legal power to impose a proposed capital-indemnity plan for railroad stockholders.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 28 (AP)--Nebraska voters abolished both the state property tax and the state income tax in the Nov. 8 election, the State Canvassing Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28-- The Soviet Embassy denied today as "absolutely groundless" recent reports that the Soviet Union had expressed concern to the United States about rising tensions along the Chinese-Soviet border.

ATHENS, Nov. 28--The Aspida trial took an unexpected turn today when the defense tried to prove that the prosecution's key witness, Lieut. Gen. George Grivas, the Cyprus Army commander, had direct contact with the Greek royal palace and the United States State Department.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28--The National Institutes of Health has decided against mounting a major program to build a complete artificial heart.
TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 28 (UPI)--The International Typographical Union struck the Tucson Daily Citizen and The Arizona Daily Star when negotiations for a new contract failed.

PARIS, Nov. 28--Portugal was cut off today from all UNESCO aid, barred from the organization's main bodies and rebuffed in a move to have the legality of these decisions examined by the International Court of Justice.

ROLLING FORK, Miss., Nov. 29 (AP)--The teen-age daughter of a Negro civil rights leader here lost the sight of one eye when she was struck by a shotgun blast fired at her home from a moving car last Thursday night, police officers said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 --Proposals aimed at attracting huge sums of private capital into slum rehabilitation received strong endorsement today as the Senate Government Operations subcommittee began a second round of hearings on what has been called the crisis in the cities.

Then union locals in the Catskill area, who represent plumbers, carpenters, electrical workers and other non-hotel employes, testified at a public hearing yesterday that they opposed higher wages for waiters, busboys, chambermaids and bellhops.

Defeat in the United Nations General Assembly of the Italian proposal to set up a committee to study the problem of admission of Communist China was disappointing. The United Nations cannot go on forever ignoring the existence of a nation that contains one-fourth of the world's population; but for twelve months more, at least, it will have to make believe that mainland China is not on the world map.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 29 --The Government of President Carlos Lieras Restrepo, deliberating at a Cabinet meeting until almost dawn today, suspended foreign exchange operations in the free market until further notice.
Two strikes threatened for tomorrow could pose citywide problems in the disposal of commercial garbage and in getting laundry done.

HONG KONG, Nov. 29--The Peking Press printed today many messages from Chinese Communist leaders on the 22d anniversary of Albania's liberation in World War II, but not any from China's Chief of State, Liu Shao-chi.

A giant crane swung a preassembled kitchen and bathroom unit through a hole in the roof of a five-story oldlaw tenement on the Lower East Side yesterday. Within an hour workmen had bolted it into place and would have had it ready for use except for the plumbers' strike.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 30--The South Vietnamese Government announced this morning that its troops and those of its allies would observe brief cease-fires at Christmas and during the Western and Asian New Year's holidays.
BOSTON, Nov. 29--"A major new Federal aid program" is needed to rescue airports from strangulation, an airline executive told the nation's largest aerospace meeting today.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Nov. 29--The engagement of Miss Virginia Arlene Van Ess to Richard Gerard McDermott Jr. has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Jerome R. Van Ess, parents of the prospective bride. Mr. McDermott is the son of Mr. and Mrs. McDermott of New York and Hampton Bays, L.I.
HASTINGS--ON--HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 29--Howard T. Brinton, former chairman of the Phelps Dodge Copper Products Corporation, died yesterday in his home here. He was 69 years old.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 29 (AP)--The Richey brother and sister act from Texas was eliminated from the Victorian tennis championships today, Cliff by an attack of German measles and Nancy by the tenacious play of Judy Tegart of Australia.
TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 29 (UPI) --A printers' strike failed to stop publication of The Arizona Daily Star and The Tucson Daily Citizen today.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla,, Nov. 29 --Change is coming to Wall Street. The securities industry has been served notice that it must alter its present ways of merchandising stocks and bonds to American investors and raising funds for American industry if it is to continue to hold its key role in the nation's economy.
When City College opens its basketball season against Columbia in the Lions' den on Morningside Heights tomorrow night, it will have an added incentive.

A whole library contained in a shoebox and a month's reading in a wallet were part of the picture painted yesterday by R. Stanley Laing, president of the National Cash Register Company, as he announced the company's entry into the Microform information retrieval market.

Robert G. Rankin, former controller of Texaco, Inc., died here Monday, apparently of a heart attack. He collapsed beside Grand Central station shortly after 8:30 P.M. and was taken to Bellevue Hospital, where he was pronounced dead.

There is no sign of saturation among television audiences that have seen more pro football this season than ever before. Ratings of the size of the audiences show no declines and several gains on a national level, while the Jets have almost pulled even with the Giants in the New York market.
Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello called yesterday for Federal aid to achieve a scientific breakthrough in getting rid of the ever-mounting waste of cities without polluting the air.

TRENTON, Nov. 29--Federal District Judge Arthur Lane signed today an order directing military authorities to show cause why a soldier who describes himself as a conscientious objector on religious grounds, and who is now confined...
Notre Dame was named the national champion of the 1966 college football season yesterday by the United Press International board of coaches.

KENILWORTH, Ill., Nov. 29 --Miss Sharon Lee Percy, the 21-year-old daughter of Charles Harting Percy, Republican Senator-elect from Illinois, plans to be married in March to 29-yearold John D. (Jay) Rockefeller 4th, Mr. Rockefeller, who has been elected to the West Virginia House of Delegates on the Democratic ticket, is a nephew of Governor Rockefeller of New York and Governor-elect Winthrop Rockefeller of Arkansas, both Republicans.

Raymond J. Cothran, executive director of the New York State Conference of Mayors, recommended yesterday that serious consideration be given to maintaining the present Condon-Wadlin law, which prohibits strikes by public employes.
SELMA, Ala., Nov. 29 (UPI) --Stokely Carmichael was convicted today of inciting a riot, and was fined $100 and sentenced to 60 days in jail at hard labor.
Test flows of natural gas amounting to 45.5 million cubic feet a day from the North Sea were announced yesterday by the Atlantic Richfield Company, operator for six oil companies.
BONN, Nov. 29--A new investigation of the Reichstag fire of 1933 will be opened by a West Berlin court in the near future.
GENEVA, Nov. 29--The aging of a man can often be measured better by the degree of his solitude than by the state of his arteries, a Swiss mental health specialist said today.

TOKYO, Nov. 29--Premier Eisaku Sato accepted the resignation of nine executive officers of the governing Liberal-Demoeratic party today to pave the way for a wholesale reshuffle of his Cabinet and party.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29-- President Johnson has established a special study group to search for new ways to cope with strikes that are judged threaten the national interest.

The saga of the baby bulls came to an end for the New York Giants yesterday when Allie Sherman, the coach, indicated the last bull, Chuck Mercein, had lost the fullback position to Allen Jacabs, the unheralded newcomer who came to the Giants from the Green Bay Packers just before the season began.
When he was directing two major companies in the production of material for the armed forces during World War II. Mr. Peo had a sign posted in his office that read: "Get it done!"
A postponement of the annual stockholder meeting of the Columbia Pictures Corporation from Dec. 21 until sometime in January was disclosed yesterday by Abe Schneider, president.
A Hebrew version of "Man of La Mancha," which celebrated its first New York anniversary Nov. 22, is to open Jan. 23 at Tel Aviv's Alhambra Theater.
PARIS, Nov. 29--The Place de la Concorde and the Place Vendome, two of Europe's most beautiful squares, are to be rescued from their blighting function as parking lots.
State Senator Seymour R. Thaler yesterday discovered two unused, fully equipped endocrinology laboratories at Lincoln Hospital, where physicians have complained of shortages of other equipment.

The ladies auxiliary of Boys Towns of Italy will hold its annual benefit luncheon and fashion show on Saturday in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom. The guest of honor will be Msgr. J.P. Carroll-Abbing, founder and president of the beneficiary.

PARIS, Nov. 29--The French national library has acquired more than 2,500 unpublished pages written by Heinrich Heine and another 2,500 pages of letters to the poet and documents about him, it was learned today.

Waterfront employment rose slightly during October when pier hirings totaled 388,856, compared with 383,271 job calls during September, the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor reported yesterday.
Free negative and footage processing will be made available to 100 contestants accredited to the coming International Experimental Film Competition in Belgium.

Janita and James Byars, making their professional debut, put together an interesting rogram of familiar and new works for clarinet and oboe last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The Byarses are married, 24 years old, and 25, respectively, and are well-trained musicians.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy shocked members of a state legislative committee yesterday by calling the Surrogates' Court system a political toll booth exacting tribute from widows and orphans.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 29-- The New York Mets traded Ron Hunt and Jim Hickman to the Los Angeles Dodgers today for Tommy Davis and Derrell Griffith.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 29-- The New York Yankees traded Clete Boyer to the Atlanta Braves late tonight for a rookie outfielder, Bill Robinson, and a relief pitcher named Chi Chi Olivo. The deal added new urgency to the Yankees' attempts to get Maury Wills, the shortstop, from the Los Angeles Dodgers.
FAIR LAWN, N.J., Nov. 29--The lion, tiglon, ocelots and tiger cubs in a private zoo here were drowsy but recovering today after having been accidentally fed poisoned meat.
Ernest S. Marsh was elected yesterday as chairman and chief executive officer of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway System, effective Jan. 1, 1967.
The British pound fell yesterday below the 2.7900-level in relatively modest trading on foreign exchange markets here and in London.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI)--Home mortgages interest rates rope again in October, making one of their sharpest increases of the year, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

PARIS--Allied statesmen keep rummaging about in the attic among old ideas and documents, but all they find is that there is no Western policy for any major part or issue of the world, nor anything approaching a Western policy.

IN his new book, Richard Poirier, chairman of the department of English at Rutgers, author of "The Comic Sense of Henry James." an editor and critic, investigates two aspects of American literature, mostly of the last century.

LIGONIER, Pa., Nov. 29-- Donald R. MeLennan of Ligonier and Mrs. Hulbert Johnston of Lake Forest, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alexandra Purves McLennan, to John Linzee Whittaker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Whittaker of Brookville, L.I.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 29 --Native troops in Australian New Guinea were portrayed in the territory's legislature today as eager to fight Communists in Vietnam.

Mr. and Mrs. Chester S. Friedman of New York and Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rita Ann Friedman, to Jeffrey Bruce Aron, Son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Aron of New York and Norwalk, Conn.
Floyd Little of Syracuse, Townsend Clarke of Army and Ray Ilg of Colgate were named yesterday to The Associated Press All-East football team for the second time.
The election of Eleuthere I. du Pont as president was announced yesterday by the Blue Ridge Mutual Fund, a growth-income fund founded in 1951.

Eight singers have been selected from 150 candidates to participate in the finals of the Maria de Varady Vocal Competition. The finals will be held on the stage of the New York State Theater at 2:30 P.M. on Dec. 12.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 29--The General Assembly decisively defeated today a resolution that would have substituted Communist China for the Nationalist Government in the United Nations. The vote was 57 against Peking to 46 for. Seventeen members abstained.

DORADO, P.R., Nov. 29 (AP)--Gov. George Romney of Michigan cabled his regrets to Barry Goldwater in Arizona today over the publication of a letter he wrote Mr. Goldwater two years ago explaining why he withheld his support in the Presidential campaign of 1964.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI)--The Defense Department announced today a further lowering of mental standards for draftees and said plans were being made to rescreen 2.4 million men who had been rejected for service previously.
Washington's agreement with Hungary and Bulgaria to raise diplomatic missions to the ambassadorial level changes the atmosphere rather than the substance of relations.
JERUSALEM (Israel), Nov. 29--Two MIG-19's of the Egyptian Air Force were shot down today by an Israeli Mirage in a brief encounter over the Sinai border.
MOSCOW (UPI)--The Soviet Union, which once sniffed disapprovingly at high fashion, has announced plans for the biggest and most glamorous style show in Russian history.
