CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (AP)-- A Circuit Court jury awarded $100,00 in damages today to Jim Brewer, a Los Angeles pitcher, in a suit filed against Billy Martin, a coach for the Minnesota Twins.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Nov. 29 (AP) --Scientists have launched a 150-ton rocket through an 80foot tube, blowgun style. They say the system saves energy and offers great promise for large solid-fuel rockets.

Three persons who complained to two patrolmen last Oct. 22 that there was a "Stop Civilian Review Boards" sticker on their police car were found guilty yesterday of disorderly conduct by Criminal Court Judge Julius Archibald.
LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 30 (AP)--The Earl of Snowdon, the 36-year-old husband of Princess Margaret, was reported today to be "not well" after an operation for an undisclosed ailment.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 (UPI)--Wilt Chamberlain became the first player in National Basketball Association history to reach the 22,000 point mark while leading the Philadelphia 76ers to a 137-116 victory over the St. Louis Hawks tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP)--A Federal judge upheld today the Army's refusal to permit a decorated war hero to be buried in Arlington National Cemetery because he had been convicted of conspiring to overthrow the Government.
"Romeo and Juliet" (Royal Ballet) at the Lincoln Art Theater.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov, 29 (AP)--Nebraska legislators rejected today a proposal that they meet in special session to enact sales and income tax legislation to replace the 99year-old state property tax that was thrown out in the Nov. 8 election.
Channel 13 confirmed yesterday that it had canceled next Monday night's performance of "The Golden Screw." Tom Sankey's folk-rock musical about the corruption of a popular singer.

The New York State Banking Board approved yesterday the formation of a holding company made up of four banks in upstate New York headed by the Lincoln Rochester Trust Company. Together, the banks have assets of $1.1-billion.
ALBANY, Nov. 29--Governor Rockefeller promised today to do "everything" to avoid a tax increase next year but refused to pledge that new taxes will not be needed.

The following items and their cost were selected by the regional office of the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics for a typical Sunday dinner to show the rising cost o f living. The items and portions are based on nutritional values and the "liberal family food plan" of the Agriculture Department. For some of the items the portions are slightly larger because most families tend to have their biggest dinner on Sunday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29--United States District Judge Abraham L. Marovitz today ordered a hearing on Dec. 9 on a suit for an injunction prohibiting city officials from limiting admission to showings of the controversial movie "Georgy Girl," which had its premiere in New York last month and is being exhibited here. He told opposing attorneys to submit briefs of Supreme Court decisions on censorship.

There were nearly 10,000 unwanted children born to mothers on welfare rolls in New York City last year; but the state will not allow welfare workers to give birth-control information, unless they are specifically asked for it.
The American Stock Exchange made a mixed showing yesterday in active trading
LONG-AWAITED rules governing the way pension costs are reflected in company statements are out, and they promise to affect earnings of some prominent companies after the first of the year.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 29 (UPI)-The first teacher strike in Ohio history ended quietly today as classes resumed in the four schools at nearby Hubbard.
The widows of five of the 12 firemen killed in a blaze that destroyed three buildings opposite Madison Square Park on Oct. 17 will sue the building owners for a total of $5-million.

LONDON, Nov. 29--If the National Coal Board had built a cableway to dispose of coal waste, the lives of 116 children and 28 adults in the Welsh village of Aberfan might have been saved, the Attorney General said today.
NEW MILFORD, N.J., Nov. 29--The Board of Education has voted to expel a 15-yearold high school student for refusing to have his long hair cut.
Pacific Industries, Inc., a California electronic-components producer controlled by the Equity Corporation, disclosed yesterday that it had "removed" Harry T. Whitley as president.
Buster Crabbe, the Tarzan of another time, is back in animal skins--this time for Johnson Johnson's First Aid Cream.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 29 (AP)--The high cost of living has finalty put the pinch on the Elizabeth Police Department.
IF fashion were sensible, husbands wouldn't com- plain about its cost, parties would lose much of their savor, and designers would learn to program computers.
The city is expected to renew today the permit for helicopter operations from the Pan Am Building for another year, a top Marine and Aviation Department official indicated yesterday.

A new method of explaining the rising cost of living that can be easily understood by any housewife who has ever cooked Sunday dinner was unveiled yesterday by the regional office of the Labor Department.

ALPENA, Mich., Nov. 29 (AP)--Taking advantage of a brief break in a gale-force snow squall, a Coast Guard helicopter rescued eight seamen from the stricken German freighter Nordmeer today in upper Lake Huron. The ship broke in half moments later.
Mayor Lindsay discussed national politics and international affairs at length yesterday at a regular news conference for the first time since his election.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. Nov. 29 (AP)--Max Conrad, 63 years old, known for his longdistance hops in light aircraft, took off today in a two-engine Piper Apache for the Antarctic.
Workmen bolted a scaffolding of pipes and planks around a towering white spruce in Rockefeller Plaza yesterday while the eyes of many of the onlookers wrapped the huge tree in a mantle of nostalgia.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29-- After the elections Nov. 8, the Democrats pointed with pride to one of their few winners in the Farm Belt, Governor-elect Robert Docking of Kansas.

The Kansas City Chiefs wrapped up the Western division title of the American Football League last Sunday by downing thE New York Jets, 32- 24, and just about put a stranglehold on league offensive sta- tistics, which were issued yesterday.

Half a dozen sizable tax-exempt bond issues were sold yesterday to underwriters, who reoffered them to investors at yields ranging from "a touch higher" to 10 basis points higher than those for recent offerings of similar quality. The market gave them a mixed reception.
ROME, Nov, 29--A year has passed since the Roman Catholic bishops held the last working sessions of Ecumenical Council Vatican II. Almost everywhere since then, Catholicism has been in a ferment.
As a result of the Liuni case, all New York state laws pertaining to adoption are being reviewed to see whether remedial legislation is needed, it was dislosed yesterday.

Twentieth Century-Fox has signed Harry Joe Brown Jr. to produce a series of low-budget films, all to be based on original screenplays and most expected to be made in New York, where Mr. Brown makes his headquarters.

LINCOLNWOOD, Ill., Nov. 29--The engagement of Miss Alice Barbara Barnow to Dr. Jesse M. Weinger, son of Dr. and Mrs. Irving I. Weinger of Valley Stream, L. I., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Chester K. Barnow.
ALBANY, Nov. 29--Governor Rockefeller's campaign organization has reported spending about $5-million to win his third-term election, ranking it as probably the most costly state campaign in history.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 29 (AP)--A high ranking Western source said today that the consortium of 17 oil companies that runs the Iranian oil industry had agreed to a demand by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, to increase the country's oil production.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Nov. 29--Capt. Victor Eyre Tyson Jr., assistant superintendent of the United States Merchant Marine Academy, and Mrs. Tyson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Vivea Tyson, to Lieut. Lawrence Ford Dickie, U. S. A., son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Ford Dickie of Riverside, Conn.
As if to camouflage the lateness of the season, Aqueduct highlighted the New Look Purse yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (UPI)-- A psychiatrist testified today that Richard F. Speck had told him he "went blank" while under the influence of liquor and narcotics on July 13, the eve of the day he is accused of murdering eight young nurses in this city.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--A 4.5 per cent pay increase that would breach the Administration's 3.2 per cent wage guideposts has been proposed for a key group of Government workers.

Paramount Pictures has acquired rights to Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard's autobiographical book, "Endure and Conquer," for filming next year. The World Publishing Company book went on sale last Wednesday in Cleveland, where the osteopath was re-tried and recently acquitted of the killing of his wife, Marilyn.
A champion challenged two other champions yesterday and the brother of a former champion talked about getting a title of his own following fights Monday night at opposite ends of the country.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 29 (AP)--Some 1,500 students, singing "We shall overcome," staged a brief and orderly sitin today at the University of Michigan.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29-- The Administration is expected to ask Congress next year to clear the way for the use of highway funds to help cities finance off-street parking.

Directors of the New Yorker Magazine, Inc., declared yesterday an extra year-end dividend of $1.50 a share, in addition to the $1 quarterly dividend, both payable Dec. 15 to stockholders of record Dec. 8.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29-- A Mrs.Lyndon B.Johnson Scholarship, to enable a Jewish woman college student to study the problem of poverty, was established today by the women's branch of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations.
Prices on the London stock exchange failed yesterday to hold the firm levels of the day before as buyers withdrew during the morning and profit taking caused prices to slip.

BUDAPEST, Nov. 29--Leonid I. Brezhnev said today that the meeting of pro-Soviet Communist parties that he is sponsoring would be a "comradely discussion" to "elaborate a common line for the future" without any idea of expelling the Chinese party.

We meet here tonight at a time of continuing national tragedy. As the President emphasized Sept. 9 in signing the Highway and Traffic Safety Acts, every day 9,000 of our fellow countrymen are injured or killed in highway accidents.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP)--In the summer of last year 28 law students spread through 11 Southern states to test a theory.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 29-- The search for a successor to Lee MacPhail as right-hand man to Baseball Commissioner William D. Eckert is just beginning. Among those being mentioned are George Sisler Jr., the president of the International League; Dewey Soriano, president of the Pacific Coast League, and John McHale of the Atlanta Braves.
AUSTIN, Tex., NOV. 29-- President Johnson faced the public for the first time today in his ten-room, teakpaneled office suite in the new Federal Office Building here.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 29--President Johnson told his news conference today that Federal programs totaling $5.3 billion were, being canceled or delayed in the current fiscal year, with savings of $3billion in expenditures in the fiscal year. [Opening statement, Page 18.]

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP)--The American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations said today it swelled the ranks of organized labor by about 1 million members in the last three years, reversing seven lean years of dwindling membership.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Nov. 29--Three Westchester soloists will perform with the Philharmonic Symphony of Westchester at its second concert of the season Saturday night in Wood Auditorium.

A program of documentary and news films will have its premiere tonight at the Village Theater, Second Avenue and sixth Street, for the benefit of the Newark Community Union Project. Thereafter the program will be shown daily on a continuous basis at the FilmMakers' Cinematheque, 125 West 41st Street.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 28 (UPI)--South Vietnamese gunboats have started escorting all foreign ships traveling the Mekong River to Cambodia to stop the smuggling of guns and ammunition to the Vietcong.
BONN, Noy. 29--The Munich police disclosed today that a Jewish memorial at the site of the foimer Dachau concentration camp was desecrated by vandals some time this week.

Cazzie Russell is still waiting for his first starting assignment as a professional basketball player. The Knicks' rookie sat on the bench as his team went against the Los Angeles Lakers last night at Madison Square Garden.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 29 (AP)--The first of three hydrographic survey ships was christened today for a mission that Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor called one of the most vital facing the world.
The Campbell Soup Company achieved record sales in the first fiscal quarter, ended Oct. 30, but earnings dipped because of increased costs, the report disclosed yesterday.

WESTBURY, L. I. Nov. 29-- Outside the thermometer read 38 degrees, and an icy wind added to the discomfort today. Nor were matters helped by the off-track, left soft by last night's rain, as Career Boy and Bridget's Lassie joined six other pacers in a one-mile qualifying event at Roosevelt Raceway.
Two secondary offerings of listed stocks were made yesterday and both were oversubscribed.

WASHINGTON, Nove. 29(AP) --The Agriculture Department announced today that it was asking the nation's animal feed industry to cooperate in a campaign to eliminate dangerous Salmonella contamination in their products.

PARIS, Nov. 29--The French Government's major prizes for achievement in the fields of letters and arts went today to Julien Green, a French-language novelist of American parentage, and Vieira da Silva, a Portuguese-born abstract painter.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, the largest stock brokerage concern in the country, has leased three full floors, the 19th through the 21st, in the new 44-story Home Insurance Building at 59 Maiden Lane, at William Street.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 29--The United States came under strong attack in Parliament today for having delayed grain shipments while many Indians faced the threat of starvation.
A top spokesman for the city's retail trade warned the City Council yesterday that some department stores here were actually becoming burdens on their more prosperous suburban branches.

CAMILLA, Ga., Nov. 29-- The details seemed simple enough when Arnold Palmer scheduled a couple of days off from winning golf tournaments and managing his considerable business enterprises to shoot Georgia quail with friends.
A Queens grand jury will begin hearing evidence Friday in the unsolved 16-month-old mystery deaths of the two young children of Edmund and Alice Crimmins.
POTSDAM, N. Y., Nov. 29-- Cornell defeated the defending Eastern collegiate hockey champions, Clarkson, tonight, 3-2, in overtime.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 29-- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Alexander Parrott of Washington and Fishers Island, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Holmes Parrott, to Andrew Pierce MacNair, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierce MacNair of Washington.

IT was only a few weeks ago that Lorin Maazel was pre- siding over the New York Philharmonic. Last night he turned up again, as conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra's concert in Philharmonic Hall. It was the orchestra's first New York appearance of the season, because of the labor-management hassle that ended with the players on strike.
CHICAGO, Nov. 29--Dr. Alice G. Masaryk, a daughter of Thomas G. Masaryk, first President of Czechoslovakia, died today in the Bohemian Home for the Aged. She was 87 years old.
Dawdling copper futures took off yesterday--downhill. During the trading session, prices dropped as much as the 2 cents a pound limit, and volume was heavier than usual.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 29 --The Securities and Exchange Commission is still impatient with the pace of change in the securities business, and is not at all likely to pay much attention to the industry's plea to leave its profits alone.
At Lincoln Center today: Instrumentae Anciens, LibraryMuseum, 6 P.M.; "Tristan und Isolde," Metropolitan Opera, 7:45; Chamber Symphony of Philadelphia, 8:30.

The diplomatic and political worlds now seem to be following the fashion world. Policies, like ladies' pants, are being redesigned to stretch. Nothing much has really changed, but everything is being cut for change, flexibility and ease of movement.
The Aluminum Company of America has been cleared of price-fixing charges brought by a customer in 1963, it was announced yesterday.

SALTIMORE, Nov. 29--Norval Baptie, whose early racing and figure-Skating blades were forerunners of today's elaborate ice shows, died Saturday at the Bolton Nursing Home after a long illness. He was 87 years old and had a home here.
State Democrats are about to begin a heavy schedule of meetings to plan for next year's legislative session and Constitutional Convention, and to explore ways to revitalize the party.
Price cutting on liquor has accelerated in the last two weeks to the point where it is estimated that half the stores in the city have joined in to meet competition.

BOSTON, Nov. 29--The man who spearheaded the development of America's ballistic missile arsenal warned here today that the nation cannot ignore the threat of manned military aggression in outer space.

TEL AVIV, Nov. 29--The wife of an American businessman and three Israelis were charged today with "conspiracy to commit crime" in connection with an alleged plot to blow up a railway bridge in Zambia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29-- Senator Gale W. McGee, Democrat of Wyoming and one of the Senate's stanchest supporters or President Johnson's Vietnam policy, could lose his place on the Foreign Relations Committee as a result of Republican gains in this month's elections.

A strike deadline of noon Friday was set yesterday against Pan American World Airways by the Transport Workers Union.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 29--The Security Council made a new appeal tonight to persuade Secretary General Thant to stay on in office instead of retiring as he has said he would do. There was an indication that he was still considering the appeal.
PHOENIX, Ariz. (AP)--Bill Smith, athletic director of the San Francisco Olympic Club, has been named United States wrestling coach for the 1968 Olympics.
WASHINGTON, Nov, 29-- The home of Mrs. Alice Roosevelt Longworth on Embassy Row here was burglarized last night while Mrs. Longworth was attending Truman Capote's masked ball in New York.
LONDON, Nov. 29 (AP)-- Sixty-four seafaring nations approved today sweeping measure intended to safeguard passenger and pleasure ships from fire at sea.
Lois Whiteman, a pianist who made her local debut at Town Hall on Feb. 17, 1965, returned there last night for her second major New York recital.
Twenty-seven Adelphi University faculty members, aided by the New York Civil Liberties Union, filed suit yesterday to have New York's teacher loyalty oath declared unconstitutional.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 29-- Edgar Kaplan of New York and Norman Kay of Philadelphia followed their recent success in qualifying for the 1967 North American international team by winning the Reisinger team championship here last night.
LONDON, Nov. 29--Farreaching legal reforms to help combat crime were proposed today by the Government.
Nine of the nation's largest insurance companies were sued yesterday under provisions of the Sherman Antitrust Act by a relatively small Georgia insurance company.
The National, American and Western Hockey Leagues met yesterday to discuss the expansion of the N.H.L. and a possible merger of the other two, but reached no decisions.
Stock prices drifted downward in moderately active trading yesterday, closing near the lowest levels of the day.

BIRMINGHAM, England, Nov. 29 (Reuters)--Reita Faria of India, who won the Miss World contest, said today she was ready to entertain American soldiers in Vietnam and appealed to the Indian Government to keep her title out of politics.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29-- Broadcast Music, Inc., and the Justice Department agreed today to a settlement of the department's two-year-old antitrust suit against the music licensing company.
Bold Bidder was voted the champion older horse of 1966 yesterday by the Thoroughbred Racing Association, beating Bold Lad, another son of Bold Ruler, for the honor.

A children's fashion show and a tea on Friday at 3 P.M. will benefit the day school of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest. Pupils will act as models for the show, to be held in the church auditorium at 2 East 90th Street.
SEATTLE, Nov. 29 (AP)-- Maury Wills, the Los Angeles Dodger shortstop, said tonight he might retire if traded to a team not to his liking.

The director of the New York University study group that called for the abolition of the city school system's Board of Examiners denied yesterday that the proposal would open school jobs to "ward heelers" and other unqualified persons.

A New York dress manufacturer paid $32,000 in damages yesterday to the New York Joint Board of Dress and Waistmakers Union in a dispute over a contract provision prohibiting the importation of garments that can be made here.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 29 --The Rev. and Mrs. John Groenfeldt have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Groenfeldt, to David Andrews, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Benjamin Andrews of New Britain, Conn.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 29 (AP)--New Federal support of family planning, including birth control, was pledged today by an official of the Health, Education and Welfare Department.

THERE will be a boxing show at Sunnyside Garden tonight, an event of little intrinsic importance. What lifts it out of the ordinary, though, is that 100 ringside seats have been set aside at $100 apiece as this low-brow and cold-blooded sport yields to a rare gush of sentiment to lend a helping hand to one of its more admirable characters.

LONDON, Nov. 29 (UPI)-- Plans for a merger of three major British steel companies, already capable of producing one fourth of the nation's steel needs, were announced today.

Students and faculty members on more than 80 college campuses have sent contributions and offered to form local chapters supporting a KennedyFulbright ticket in 1968, according to the Citizens for KennedyFulbright.
AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 29-- President Johnson announced today that he would join President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz of Mexico Saturday to inspect the partly completed Amistad Dam on the Rio Grande.

Two tenement fires, one in East Harlem and the other in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant section, took the lives of three young children and critically injured a fourth yesterday. Both fires broke out in the absence of the youngsters' parents.
DETROIT, Nov. 29--The nation's new traffic safety chief disclosed tonight that the Government was proposing 23 automobile safety standards for all cars sold in the United States.
An investment broker, who disappeared last March, and three other men were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to evade $7-million in interest-equalization taxes.

Normally blase New Yorkers who happened to be passing by the Union Carbide Building at 270 Park Avenue yesterday around 11 A.M. were startled to see a man in a crash helmet and parka driving a motorbike in circles on the sidewalk.

A joint campaign among maritime unions to organize several thousand unorganized seamen and officers sailing on American-flag tankers was proposed yesterday by Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union.
A record price for a Rembrandt etching was paid yesterday in London. "The Three Crosses," with the artist's signature and the date of 1653, was sold at auction at Sotheby Co. for $84,000.

President Woodrow Wilson suffered from severe personality problems that thwarted his efforts to win a lasting peace after world War I, according to a "psychological study" by Sigmund Freud and William C. Bullitt.
A group of smaller retailers added their interim earnings reports yesterday to those submitted earlier this month by many of the nation's largest merchandising concerns.
The Plaza's Baroque Suite will be the setting on Monday for a Christmas boutique and luncheon benefiting Just One Break (J.O.B.), a job placement agency for the disabled.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 29 (AP)--Ray L. Heffner, president of Brown University, issued today a statement to the student body decrying violence at any open meetings held on campus.
UP to last night, this reviewer had not been swept off his feet by what he had seen and heard of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company's current season in New York. But then he tried their "Patience."

REVOLUTIONS in art inevitably provoke counter- revolutions, if only in the form of parody, and modern art has been no exception. The illusion persists that the past--or some fantasy of what the past was--can be restored. The hope lingers that the disturbing art of the present is but a temporary aberration that a benevolent providence will consign to oblivion--and the sooner the better.
BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Wednesday, Nov. 30--This placid Caribbean island became the newest and smallest nation in the Western Hemisphere at one minute past midnight today.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Nov. 29 (AP)--Frank E. (Pappy) Noel, Pulitzer Prize-winning Associated Press photographer, died in a hospital here tonight following brain surgery. He was 61 years old.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 30--A Hindu holy man who had been fasting for 10 days to oppose cow slaughter died here today. His body promptly became the object of a dispute between his followers and the police.

MIAMI, Nov. 30--The Federal District Court here today ordered the cruise ship Nili sold at auction to satisfy a bankruptcy claim.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 30-- The husband of a 21-year-old Clifton housewife slain early this year was arrested tonight and charged with her murder.
A method of handling oceangoing container cargoes at 10story, high-speed, computerized waterfront depots is being studied by the city in an effort to make the Port of New York more efficient.

United Utilities, Inc., a holding company that owns 17 telephone operating companies, is planning to enter the Florida area through the proposed acquisition of the Inter-County Telephone Telegraph Company. The deal would involve $70-million in stock.

The National Football League next season will be divided into four groups of four teams each and will follow a new scheduling formula with semi-final games among the division winners before the league championship contest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--A California Democrat said today that he would try to deny Representative Adam Clayton Powell a seat in the 90th Congress when it convenes in January if Mr. Powell has not purged himself of contempt of court in New York.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 30-- President Johnson received to day a generally gloomy report on the first year's effort to reach poor children through Federal education funds.

HOUSTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) --Harold (Bo) Hagan, an assistant, has been selected to succeed Jess Neely as head football coach of Rice University.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Nov. 30 --The use of helicopters to pluck disabled autos from commuter traffic jams was proposed here today before a state legislative committee hearing on suburban problems.

The Film-Makers' Distribution Center, formed here seven months ago to release experimental, or "underground," films to commercial theaters, has apparently found its "Sound of Music" in Andy Warhol's new production, "The Chelsea Girls."

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (UPI)-- Teachers union members began a strike today at all nine campuses of Chicago's 33,600-student city junior college system. Late in the day Circuit Judge Daniel A. Covelli issued a temporary restraining order to force an end to the walkout.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30-- The Federal Power Commission was told today that it would cost at least five times as much to bury the transmission lines that would zigzag across Putnam County from Consolidated Edison's proposed Storm King plant as to run them overhead.
Pan American World Airways reported yesterday a 23.7 per cent gain in operating revenues in October, but an even sharper jump of 25.6 per cent in operating expenses.
Sebastian Caratelli, flutist, offered three first performances in his program of 20th-century works last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

GENEVA, Nov. 30--The Kennedy round of negotiations to expand world trade reached today its next-to-last stage, with the United States and other major industrial nations flexing their economic muscles in a diplomatic but determined show of bargaining strength.

Queers residents renewed their battle against public housing yesterday as City Hall moved ahead with its plan to scatter low-rent apartment houses in white, middle-class areas outside the city's densely populated core.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30-- Water resource conditions in the drought-plagued Northeast have improved, but "it is still too early to say that water supplies are back to normal," the Geological Survey said today.

The New York Telephone Company will invade Staten Island today with 91,000 new telephone directories.

A State Supreme Court Justice yesterday awarded support payments of $2400 monthly-- after taxes--and record counsel fees in a bitterly fought estrangement case that has achieved "national, if not international, importance."

Demand for most fixed-income securities was strong again yesterday as dealers and investors bid up prices of Government issues and purchased large quantities of municipal bonds. The day's new corporate offering was a sellout.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 --Roy Wilkins asserted before a Senate subcommittee today that it would be "criminal" for either Congress or the Administration to cut back budget expenditures on social and urban programs.

JERUSALEM (Israel), Nov. 30--Israel abolished military government in her Arab communities today and brought to a close a long and uncomfortable chapter in the nation's relations with its Arab minority, which now numbers 300,000.

A few big price advances were the standout developments on the American Stock Exchange yesterday was the market ended mixed for the second consecutive session in active trading.

THE Chamber Symphony of Philadelphia returned to Philharmonic Hall last night for its second concert in its debut season. On the program was the New York premiere of Benjamin Lees's Concerto for Chamber (1966).
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 30--Three Roman Catholic priests said today that Joseph Cardinal Ritter had transferred them because of their liberalism. A spokesman for the Cardinal said he had no comment.

A New Yorker who raises funds for the Vietcong has started a legal fight with the United States Customs Service, which recently intercepted a shipment of North Vietnamese literature addressed to his organization.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30--Secretary General Thant is prepared to remain in office for another five year term, sources from four member states on the Security Council reported today.

"We're small, inexperienced, can't play defense and can't handle the ball." With that summation by Coach Fred Wieboldt, it appears that Upsala College's basketball prospects for the coming season are dreary, of not hopeless.
Eastern Airlines said yesterday it had added a golf professional to its staff. Juan (Chi chi) Rodriguez, the Puerto Rican star, will serve as consultant to the line's Flying Golfer Club.
Federal Judge Harold R. Tyler Jr. reserved decision yesterday on a motion for a change of venue filed on behalf of industrialist Leuis E. Wolfson and Elkin E. Gerbert, one of his associates.
The city administration announced emergency procedures yesterday for the removal of garbage and trade waste in the event of a strike against private carting companies.

ATHENS, Nov. 30--Hopes of locating ancient Helice, a city that vanished after a violent earthquake in 373 B.C., grew today when a GreekAmerican team was reported to have discovered an "unusual" configuration in the sea bed off the south shore of the Gulf of Corinth.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 30--Federal and civil rights attorneys began trying to ersuade a Federal court today that Alabama should be placed under a statewide school desegregation order.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30-- The Justice Department dropped today its outright opposition to the proposed merger of the Pennsylvania and the New York Central railroads.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30-- "Should be a much-programmed item, with top sales to follow" --Billboard.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI)--The United States gold loss totaled $45-million in October after a gain of $37-million in September, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30-- The Job Corps said today it was discontinuing its series of articles on sex education because the subject was "too complex" for the written word.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30-- Dean Burch, former chairman of the Republican National Committee, has dismissed as "baloney" a charge that the Republican Presidential campaign of 1964 was designed to appeal of segregationist Southerners.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30-- The budget cutbacks announced yesterday by President Johnson represent, for the most part, delays in spending, not cancellation of Federally aided projects.
This is the time of the year when shoppers fill the department and specialty stores throughout the nation in their quest for holiday gifts.

LONDON, Nov. 30--Prime Minister Wilson said tonight that Britain wanted to join in building Europe as a "pillar of equal strength" with the United States and in preventing American economic domination.

A leading French Communist official said yesterday that increased dialogue between Christians and Marxists was not only possible in the wake of the Ecumenical Council Vatican II, but "absolutely necessary for world peace" in the atomic age.
Two New York doctors report good results with a new drug that stimulates fertility in some previously infertile women without causing the serious problem of multiple births.

BONN, Nov. 30--The third round of the talks on military costs and strategy among the United States, Britain and West Germany ended today with the question of Bonn's payments to Washington and London to offset their troop costs in Germany still unresolved.

William S. Paley, chairman of the Columbia Broadcasting System, defended television and radio networks yesterday against "Monday morning quarterbacks [who keep] telling us what broadcast journalism did wrong" on election night.

The threat of a possible strike tomorrow against Pan American World Airways remained yesterday despite efforts of Federal mediators to resolve issues between the airline and the Transport Workers Union.
Twelve-hundred persons attended the annual luncheon of the Friends of the Philharnionic yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 30--Like millions of other Americans impressed with the high cost of living, major league baseball players made a pitch today for higher pay and better working conditions.

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Nov. 30--The Government of this newly independent island nation was formally installed today and immediately pledged close relations with "the democratic countries of the Western Hemisphere."

LAS VEGAS, Nov, 29--Ask the average visitor to this vastly publicized "Sin City" whether it contains anything beyond a phantasmagoria of gaudy hotels, night spots and casinos for gambling and an infinitude of slot machines geared to all coins, and he will stare at you in bewilderment.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 30 --A sit-in around a Navy recruiting table in the Student Union brought 10 arrests tonight and returned disorderly protest to the Berkeley campus of the University of California.

BOSTON, Nov. 30--It remained for the Boston Opera Company to give the American premiere of Arnold Schoenberg's "Moses and Aaron."

Rockefeller Center, Inc., has chosen J. Richardson Dilworth, senior financial adviser to the Rockefeller family, to be chairman of the board of the center. He succeeds Laurance S. Rockefeller in the post.

Maurice F. White, a big man with a quick smile, has left they public relations department of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to join a much smaller group-- Negroes with their own publicrelations agencies.

Bernard Newman, the readyto-wear designer since 1947 for Bergdorf Goodman, women's apparel shop at 754 Fifth Avenue, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 17 West 54th Street.

Columbia College has undertaken a soft-sell campaign to warn its students against the indiscriminate use of marijuana, LSD, barbiturates, tranquilizers and other potentially dangerous nonnarcotic drug.
TRENTON, Nov. 30--State Attorney General Arthur J. Sills came out today in favor of a legislative effort to compensate the innocent victims of crime.

A shopping center that will have 140,000 square feet of selling area is being built in Patchogue, L.I., by Frank Properties, a concern that specializes in the construction and operation of shopping centers.
THE ski season is getting off to a happy start if only because Award House, a division of Ski Magazine, has just published "Ski Down the Years." It's a graphic presentation that the sport has needed.

George Kern, media supervisor for the Fletcher Richards, Calkins and Holden advertising agency at his retirement two and a half years ago, died yesterday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in the Bronx. He was 62 years old and lived at 4810 Boston Post Road, Pelham Manor, N.Y.

The much-advertised detente between the Soviet Union and the West does not seem to operate in the Middle East. Moscow is not responsible for the tensions and ferment agitating Israel and the Arab nations; but it is surely fanning the flames.
A new three-year contract agreement was reached here yesterday between a union representing 15,000 laundry workers and representatives of 400 commercial laundries.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30-- President Johnson announced today a reorganization of the Federal Bureau of Prisons to streamline the administration of new programs for prisoner rehabilitation.

CAIRO, Nov. 30--The Government of the United Arab Republic ended today its legal seizure of vehicles and machinery belonging to the Ford Motor Company's Egyptian subsidiary, a Ford executive said today.

DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 30 (AP)--The stockholders of the DWG Cigar Corporation met here today and approved a diversification program, including a move to acquire the Wilson Brothers Company, an Illinois concern with principal offices in New York City. DWG's headquarters are in Lima, Ohio.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 30-- The supreme commander of Nigeria unveiled his blueprint for the nation's political future tonight, pledging himself to preserve "one Nigerian army and one country."
ALBANY, Nov. 30--The Democrats spent about oneeighth as much as the Republicans in the recent gubernatorial election campaign, records filed with the Secretary of State indicated today.

NEW YORKERS who think of De Pinna's as elegant but somewhat staid had better take another look. The Fifth Avenue store, like many of its competitors, has had a face-lifting, the first in a series of projected operations.

ALTHOUGH collies and Shetland sheepdogs are related and look alike (but with the collie almost twice the size of the Sheltie), they are distinct breeds with different characteristics and standards, said Margaret Osborne, an English authority on both breeds, last weekend.
Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons agreed yesterday to sever its 150-year association with Bellevue Hospital.

The National Aeronautics and Space Administration released yesterday a spectacular close-up photograph of the interior of the moon's fabled Crater of Copernicus showing ranges of steep, jagged, irregular mountains rising from the crater's floor.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30-- The Justice Department disclosed tonight that it was reviewing all past and pending cases in which evidence may have been obtained by means of electronic eavesdropping.

Oberlin College's Conservatory of Music is celebrating this season the centenary of its becoming a division of the college. As part of the celebration it scheduled eight concerts in local halls under the title "Oberlin in New York." The series opened last night with a recital in Town Hall by George Neikrug, a cellist now teaching at Oberlin.
THE AFFLUENT investor who is looking for that hard-to-find commodity--a high-yield investment with little risk--might find it in a curious kind of hybrid bond called a "pre-fund."

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 30 --The Senator who will be most concerned in the 90th Congress with the workings of the economy raised today the possibility of direct wartime controls on wages, prices, credit, rents and materials because of the Vietnam conflict.
There are 3.308-billion people on this planet, but a poet writes almost exclusively for himself.
Miss Audrey C. Schipper and Col. Bernt Halchen, U.S.A.F., retired, the aviator and explorer, were married yesterday evening.
TANGIER, Morocco, Nov. 30 (Reuters)--Hooker Austin Doolittle, a retired minister in the United States Foreign Service who was a specialist on Arab problems, died here today. He was 77 years old.
AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 30--The Johnson Administration began laying the groundwork today for public acceptance for a budget close to $140-billion next year.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (UPI)-- The dying remnants of a wintry storm system dumped deep snows today on New England mountains and a bitter cold wave rode high winds deep into, the nation's midlands.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30-- Government financial officials representing 20 rich and poor countries from the non-communist world concluded a threeday meeting here today on an unqualified note of optimism. They saw progress being made toward the creation of additional international financial resources.

BOSTON, Nov. 30--Nine persons in 10 would not be concerned about the pace of the United States lunar program if the Soviet Union landed a man on the moon first, a Trendex survey indicated today. Trendex is a private polling service.

CAMILLA, Ga., Nov. 30-- Arnold Palmer shoots quail the way he plays golf --very well. He demonstrated this the other day while gunning with friends at Riverview Plantation, a commercial quail preserve here.
Speculative demand for copper shares enlivened a mixed market on the London stock exchange yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)--Prices of farm products declined 3 per cent between midOctober and mid-November.
RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 30-- The State Supreme Court assured some North Carolinians of a less convivial Christmas season today by ruling that "brown bagging" is illegal.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30-- Jordan will start receiving supersonic jet fighters from the United States in the middle of next year, but, contrary to her expectations, they, will not be new.

President Johnson's designation of a special study group to seek more reliable strike preventives offers hope that the Administration will not default again next year on its pledge to recommend legislation that would deal effectively with "strikes which threaten irreparable damage to the national interest."

JOE Namath leads the American Football League in pass completions (188) and yardage (2,599). He needs only 10 completions and 150 yards at Oakland Saturday to break Al Dorow's New York Jet records for one season's work.

Harte Co., manufacturer of extruded vinyls, has developed a new knitted vinyl fabric, it was made known yesterday by Fred S. Straus, president. It will greatly broaden the application of vinyls, he said, in such products as luggage, auto seat covers, furniture, handbags, shoes, and wearing apparel.
Four major organizations brought suits in state and Federal courts yesterday challenging the use of Federal funds to aid parochial education.

City Council President Frank D. O'Connor said yesterday that he was working on legislation that would protect the rights of people who buy defective homes.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed yesterday with the Federal Communications Commission a request to make two changes in its interstate Wide Area Telephone Service.

SINCE Stuart Gilbert edited "Letters of James Joyce" (1957), a great many new letters have been found. Sanitation Commissioner Samuel J. Kearing Jr. announced yesterday the appointment of Capt. Edgar D. Croswell, an investigating officer of the New York State Police, as head of the new office of inspector general in the city's Department of Sanitation.
Two show-business hoofers were feeling their oats yesterday as they shuttled between bits at two hit musicals, one at Radio City Music Hall, the other at the Metropolitan Opera.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) --The principal spokesman for the nation's Mayors appealed to President Johnson today to reconsider planned cuts in antipoverty spending and to reduce space expenditures instead.
SIGOURNEY, Iowa, Dec. 1 (AP)--Dale Kramer, a former newspaperman who wrote nine books, died at his home here yesterday. He was 55 years old.
PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 1-- A fourth person was arrested today on indictments handed up by the grand jury that investigated the slaying of Mrs. Judy Kavanaugh of Clifton last February.
At the flick of a switch yesterday, 1,600 sticks of dynamite blasted 10 feee of rock under New York Harbor to open a 25,032-foot tunnel that will deliver more water to Staten Island.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1--The murder trial of Richard Speck, accused slayer of eight student nurses, was ordered today to be held outside Chicago and Cook County.
The McDonnell Company, which disclosed last June that it had sold all of the Douglas Aircraft Corporation stock in its portfolio, has apparently taken a new position in the shares of that concern.

The General Telephone Electronics Corporation and Hawaiian Telephone Company announced yesterday plans for a $266-million merger, one of the largest in recent years in the telephone industry. Under the agreement, Hawaiian Telephone would be merged into a new wholly-owned subsidiary of General Telephone.

Snow Weapon won the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday and many in the crowd of 20,053 were surprised. This reaction was natural, as Snow Weapon, a 3-year-old filly owned by the King Ranch, was next to the outsider in the betting in the field of seven.

Thirty-two civic leaders and officials, called by the New York Civil Liberties Union to a closed meeting, have agreed that the city needs an ombudsman to deal with the public's complaints against city officials and agencies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--In an effort to find some noncontroversial means of broadening contacts with Communist China, the United States has offered to exchange seed samples with the Peking regime, officials disclosed today.

Joseph W. Messina, who turned the old Shoreham Hotel in Sayville, L.I., into a bonanza by installing rock 'n' roll bands and go-go girls who dance in cages, denied yesterday that he was running the place, renamed the Shore Club, as a front for Julius F. (Julie) Klein, an exconvict, or for anyone else.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 1--The design for a $10,750,000 library center to contain President Johnson's papers and audio-visual collections and perhaps to provide a place for him to lecture on public administration was shown today by the University of Texas.

GIBRALTAR, Friday, Dec. 2--Prime Minister Wilson and Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia met here early today aboard the British cruiser Tiger for secret talks on the year-old Rhodesian independence crisis.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--A policy-making unit of the Committee for Economic Development, a nonpartisan organization composed mainly of businessmen, called today for as large a tax increase as necessary next year to achieve a $3-billion budget surplus.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1-- The Commerce Department has proposed safety standards for all 1968-model automobiles that differ in several major respects from the standards already established for cars bought by the Federal Government.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 1 --Two Thais described as captured Communist agents told today of their training in North Vietnam and their efforts to stir up the peasants in Thailand's restless northeast.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--Richard W. Reuter has resigned as special assistant to the Secretary of State in the Food for Peace program, effective Jan. 1.

Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson and Cardinal Spellman were among five persons who received awards last night from the National Institute of Social Sciences for "Distinguished service to humanity," at a dinner in the Plaza Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1-- That household nuisance-- broken eggs from the market --may be on the way out.

An aggressive 6-foot-3-inch sophomore, Roger Walaszek, took the place of Dave Newmark and led the Columbia basketball team to its first victory of the season last night.

Isadore J. Caplan, a certified public accountant with offices at 2 Park Avenue, and a former president of the Accountants Association of New York, died here on Sunday. He was 73 years old and lived in the Beacon Hotel, Broadway and 75th Street.

Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower has written a foreword and Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen an introduction for a book, "Charlie Halleck," by Henry Z. Scheele. It was issued last week by Exposition Press of New York. Dr. Scheele is assistant professor of speech ...
THE North American international team gained its revenge in a practice match here Sunday for a defeat on the previous day.

Mrs. Munn Baker and George F. Baker Jr. of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pauline Munn Baker, to D. Dixon Boardman, son of Mrs. Vivien Dixon Wanamaker of London and T. Dennie Boardman of New York.

Robert E. Kintner needed only 6 minutes and 30 seconds yesterday to endorse the foreign and domestic policies of President Johnson and urge the television industry to expand newcasts so that controversial issues could be discussed at greater length.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) --The Defense Department identified today 26 men killed in the Vietnam war.

An old friend of the Neediest Cases Fund mailed in her contribution last Friday before the stories of individual cases that form the basis for the annual Christmastime appeal appeared in Sunday's issue of The New York Times.

The London Stock Exchange closed with widespread losses of fractions yesterday as traders acted cautiously following the failure of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia to meet the deadline for a decision on terms for a settlement of the constitutional dispute.

FOR the purposes of "I Do! I Do!" at the 46th Street Theater, a Santa Claus who shall here be known as David Merrick has hitched a very high-powered Donner and a very high-powered Blitzen to a very low-powered One Horse Shay.

GENEVA, Dec. 5--The retirement last Thursday of the Rev. Dr. W.A. Visser 't Hooft as General Secretary of the World Council of Churches marked the end of an epoch in the ecumenical movement. His successor wrote recently.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5-- The Treasury bill rate declined slightly at today's auction to a level not seen for three months, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
Bob Wolff, a former broadcaster and now director of public relations for Madison Square Garden, was given another post yesterday.
The New York County Medical Society, seeking liberalized abortion laws, held the first public meeting in its history last night on the controversial subject.
CAIRO, Dec. 5--An American company has made the first major oil strike in Egypt's Western Desert, Egyptian officials said today.
All city commissioners and agency heads were ordered yesterday by Mayor Lindsay to report to him whether their departments authorized overtime pay for high-salaried officials.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 5--A group of local investors bought the Cincinnati Reds today at a price reported to be about $7million.
Louis Harris, in a survey published yesterday in the New York Post, declared that public approval of President Johnson sank this month to a low of 43 per cent.
The trend toward larger and faster ships will make automatic radar data analysis a necessity, according to the Maritime Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5-- Walter P. Reuther said today that the United Automobile Workers union would assert its independence of some positions of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations. He left open the possibility of a withdrawal from the federation.
DETROIT, Dec. 5--Changes in the law governing airline labor disputes--the Railway Labor Act--were proposed today by the president of Eastern Air Lines, Floyd E. Hall.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (UPI)-- A storm lashed the West today with snows, rains and winds. Freezing rain also plagued travelers in the Middle West and was spreading over the Appalachians and across the Atlantic seaboard.
At Lincoln Center tonight: "Turandot," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Little Orchestra Society, Philharmonic Hall, 8.
PARIS, Dec. 5--A man won an important literary prize here today. This year, that is news.

Ivan Dixon, who plays Kinchloe in "Hogan's Heroes," a Columbia Broadcasting System comedy series about G.I. prisoners of war in World War II, will star in the first production of "C.B.S. Playhouse," a series of original dramas.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
The Caterpillar Tractor Company announced yesterday it was cutting back on production schedules and eliminating overtime at most domestic plants.
It was hard to find a mutualfund sales executive yesterday who did not have his fingers crossed.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, Dec. 6--Charging that United States aircraft had attacked and sunk five Chinese fishing boats in the Gulf of Tonkin, Communist China said today it was prepared for war and "now standing in battle array." Fourteen fishermen were killed and 20 were wounded in the bombing Peking said.

THE problems of the world were discussed over champagne and supreme of pheasant last night at a party given by Arthur J. Goldberg, United States delegate to the United Nations, aboard the liner Constitution, docked at the foot of West 44th Street.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 5 (AP)--Australia's two top Davis Cup players, Roy Emerson and Fred Stolle, defeated younger teammates today to gain the men's singles final in the Victorian tennis championships.

A three-step fluoride treatment involving a half-hour visit to the dentist each year and daily use of a fluoridated toothpaste can reduce tooth decay in adults by more than 70 per cent, naval dentists reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) --The Supreme Court refused today to review a lower Federal court ruling that the Chrysler Corporation had violated its dealer agreement by discontinuing production of DeSoto automobiles.
WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 5-- A 53-year-old Bellmore widow was found murdered in her automobile today in a municipal parking lot behind the store in which she was employed as a meat packager.
